question: A 62-year-old Caucasian female is being evaluated after she had an episode of syncope. She complains of having progressive exertional dyspnea aver the last twa manths with an occasional dry cough. Cardiac auscultation findings over the apex are given below. Which of the following best explains the physical findings in this patient?
explanation:
The combination of this patient's exertional dyspnea, dry cough, and halosystalic murmur an auscultation are mast suggestive af mitral regurgitation (MR). Although the clinical manifestations of MR vary significantly with the degree of regurgitation, exertional dyspnea and fatigue are the most common symptoms, which occur secondary to a combination of decreased cardiac output and increased left atrial pressure. This patient's dry cough may relate to pulmonary congestion and edema, which is an indicator of more severe disease that has resulted in left ventricular dysfunction. The murmur of MR is classically a halosystolic murmur heard best aver the apex with radiation to the axilla.
Mitral regurgitation can occur as a result of primary mitral valve disease (e.g. rheumatic heart disease, infective endocarditis, or trauma) or may be associated with other cardiac conditions (e.g. ischemic heart disease or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy).
(Choice A) An ascending aortic aneurysm can be associated with aartic regurgitation, which wauld result in a diastalic murmur.
(Choice B) Although patients with constrictive pericarditis often present with exertional dyspnea, physical findings such as elevated jugular venous pressure, pulsatile hepatomegaly, and signs of fluid overload are often present as well.
(Choice D) Tricuspid stenosis would cause a diastalic murmur, nat systolic. Rheumatic heart disease is the most comman cause of tricuspid stenosis.
Educational objective:
Mitral regurgitation classically results in a halosystolic murmur heard best at the apex with radiation to the axilla. Common clinical features of MR include exertional dyspnea, fatigue, atrial fibrillation, and signs of heart failure.

question: A 74-year-old man presents to your office for a routine check-up. He has no present complaints. His medical histary is significant for right knee osteoarthritis. He takes naproxene occasionally, to relieve knee pain. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. His BP is 165/75 mm Hg and PR is 70/min. The physical examination showed a mild systolic ejection-type murmur at the base of the heart, to the right. An EKG revealed left ventricular hypertrophy and secondary ST segment and T wave changes. Moderate left ventricular hypertrophy, without any flow abnormalities, was demonstrated on echocardiography. The ejection fraction was 60%. What is the most probable cause of hypertension in this patient?
options: A. Rigidity of the arterial wall
explanation:
Isolated systolic hypertension (ISH) is an important cause of hypertension in elderly patients. The pathophysiologic mechanism leading to ISH is believed to be decreased elasticity of the arterial wall, which leads to an increased systolic blood pressure, without concurrent increase (and even decrease) in diastalic blood pressure. Normally during systole, the heart ejects the blood under a certain pressure that is dumped by elastic properties of the aorta and major arteries. Then, this elastic recoil of the arterial wall contributes the diastalic flow of the blood and diastolic pressure. When elastic properties of the arterial wall diminish and arteries become more rigid, this 'dumping’ of pressure changes during the cardiac cycle also decreases. As a result of increased arterial rigidity, patients with ISH have a widened pulse pressure (the difference between systolic and diastolic pressure). Widened pulse pressure was recently recognized as an important cardiovascular risk factor. Therefore, ISH should be treated appropriately, in spite of the fact that diastolic pressure is not elevated. Hydrochlorothiazide is considered to be the drug of chaice far this condition.
An increased plasma renin activity (Choice B) causes systolic and diastalic hypertension as seen in renal artery stenasis. Renin activity is low to normal during ISH.
Aartic insufficiency (Choice C) leads to elevated pulse pressure and can cause isolated systalic hypertension, but this was ruled out by echocardiography.
An increased cardiac output (Choice D) can be a cause of systolic hypertension in hyperdynamic states, such as in hyperthyroidism. There is no sign of hyperdynamic circulation in this case.
Increased intravascular volume (Choice E) causes systolic and diastalic hypertension in various renal disorders, with a decrease in the ability of the kidney to excrete solutes and/or water.
Educational Objective:
Isolated systolic hypertension is an important cause of hypertension in elderly patients. It is created by decreased elastic properties of the arterial wall. Always treat isolated systalic hypertensian, in spite of the fact that diastolic blood pressure is not elevated. The drug of chaice would be hydrochlorothiazide.

question: A 32-year-old Caucasian female comes to the physician because of a one-week history of fatigue, progressive warsening of shortness of breath, and swelling of feet. She denies any chest pain. She has no ather medical problems except a recent cold two weeks ago. She is not taking any medications. Her temperature is 36.7 C (38 F), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 20/min. Bilateral basal crackles, elevated jugular venous pressure, and 2+ bilateral pitting edema of the ankles are noted. Complete blood count is unremarkable. Transthoracic echocardiogram of her heart will most likely show?
options: A. Concentric hypertrophy of the heart
B. Eccentric hypertrophy of the heart
D. Hypokinesia of the inferior wall
G. Dilated ventricles with diffuse hypokinesia
explanation:
The clinical presentation of this patient is suggestive of cangestive heart failure (CHF). A history of recent upper respiratory tract infection followed by sudden onset of cardiac failure in an otherwise healthy patient is suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy, mast likely secondary ta acute viral myocarditis.
Dilated cardiomyopathy is the end result of myocardial damage produced by a variety of toxic, metabalic, or infectious agents. Viral or idiopathic myocarditis is most commonly seen following Coxsackie B infectian. Viral myocarditis is seen in about 3.5-5 % of patients infected with Coxsackie B virus. Other viruses implicated are adenovirus, cytomegalovirus, echovirus, hepatitis C, influenza virus, parvovirus B-19, and Epstein-Barr virus. The diagnosis is made by echocardiogram, which typically shows dilated ventricles with diffuse hypokinesia resulting in low ejection fraction (systolic dysfunction). Viral myocarditis can cause dilated cardiomyopathy by direct viral damage, as well as sequel of humaral or cellular immune responses ta persistent viral infection.
(Choice A) Concentric hypertrophy of the heart is seen following chronic pressure overload, as in valvular aortic stenosis or untreated hypertension; however, these are chronic conditions and would not have acute onset of heart failure.
(Choice B) Eccentric hypertraphy of the heart is seen following chronic volume overload, as seen in valvular regurgitation; however, this is a chronic condition and would nat have acute onset of heart failure.
(Choice C) Mitral stenosis is characterized by middiastolic murmur and opening snap. EKG shows left atrial hypertrophy. Chronic mitral stenosis would cause right ventricular hypertrophy and, thus, right ventricular heave secondary ta pulmonary hypertension.
(Choice D) Hypokinesia of the inferior wall would be seen in case of inferior wall myocardial infarction, but clinical presentation of this patient is nat suggestive of myocardial infarction.
(Choice E) Aortic valve vegetation can cause aortic regurgitation, which, if acute, would not have dilated heart, and, if chronic, would have eccentric hypertrophy of the heart. Also, patients with infective endocarditis appear sick, and they will have low to high-grade fevers, chills, or night sweats.
(Choice F) Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a disease of the young, and is less likely to present with acute cardiac failure, rather than sudden cardiac death which is commanly seen.
Educational Objective:
Dilated cardiomyopathy may be seen following viral myocarditis (postpartum), particularly following Coxsackie B infection. Diagnosis is made by echocardiogram, which typically shows dilated ventricles and diffuse hypokinesia resulting in systolic dysfunction (low ejection fraction).

question: A 47-year-old woman loses consciousness for 2 minutes while shopping in a supermarket. In the emergency roam, she recounts feeling nausea and warmth spreading over her body immediately before passing out. She has never had a similar episode before. She has not seen a doctor for several years and does not take any medications, nor does she use tobacco, alcohol or drugs. Her family history is unremarkable. Which of the following most likely caused this episode?
explanation:
Meuracardiogenic syncope, alsa known as vasovagal syncope, is a cammon cause of fainting. It occurs due to excessive vagal tone and is characterized by nausea, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and pallor immediately prior to the syncopal episode. It frequently occurs in response to stress, pain, and certain bodily actions (e.g. urination). tis particularly common in young women. Vasavagal syncope can be diagnosed with the tilt table test.
(Choice A) Conduction disorders (e.g. AV block], tachyarrhythmias (e.g. ventricular ar supraventricular tachycardia), and disorders of automaticity (e.g. sick sinus syndrome) can all cause fainting. Generally there are na preceding signs ar symptoms, except for palpitations in same. Patients usually have underlying cardiac disease.
(Choice B) Seizures and syncapal episodes are sometimes difficult to distinguish. This patient does not have clear signs of seizure (e.g. tongue biting), a history of seizures, ar a post-ictal state, making syncope mare likely.
(Choice D) Syncope due to aortic stenosis most often accurs with activity. Dyspnea, chest pain, and fatigue an exertion are symptoms of aortic stenosis that generally occur earlier in the disease course.
(Choice E) Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a drop in systolic blood pressure greater than 20 mm Hg after the patient rises to a standing position. It is most common in the elderly, diabetics, those with autonomic neuropathy (e.g. Parkinson's disease], those with hypovolemia, and peaple taking diuretics, vasodilators, or adrenergic-blocking agents. Prolonged recumbence increases the risk. Patients commanly experience pre-syncopal lightheadedness.
(Choice F) Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) can produce syncope, but are a rare cause because the TIA must affect the posterior circulation and brain stem in order for syncope to occur. This patient has no risk factors for stroke.
Educational Objective:
Meurocardiogenic, or vasovagal, syncope occurs due to excessive vagal tone. Episodes are preceded by nausea, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and pallor. Fain, stress, and situations like medical needles and urination can all precipitate vasovagal syncope.

question: A 25-year-old woman experiences sudden-onset palpitations and generalized weakness. During this episode, her blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and her heart rate is 160/min and regular. She has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. She reports having a few similar episodes in the past, which she has self-treated by immersing her face in cold water. Generally, she says, cold water immersian relieves her symptoms within several minutes. This cold water therapy warks by affecting which of the following?
options: F. Venous return to the heart
explanation:
Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) is the mast comman paroxysmal tachycardia in people without structural heart disease. Attacks begin abruptly and are characterized by heart rates between 160-220 beats per minute. The most common mechanism underlying PSVT is re-entry into the AY node. Mechanical and medical therapies far PSVT decrease AV node conductivity. Vagal maneuvers, such as Valsalva, caratid sinus massage, and immersion in cald water increase vagal tone and decrease conduction through the AV nade. This slows the heart rate and can often break the rhythm. Adenosine is a very short acting Av-nodal blocker that is often used as well.
(Choice A) Cold water immersion increases the vascular tone in the face but this is not the mechanism by which PSVT resolves.
(Choice B) Vagal maneuvers do decrease SA node automatism, but SA node automatism is not the underlying problem in PSYT. In most cases, re-entrant pathways through the AV node are respansible. Thus, AV nade suppression, not SA node suppression, will treat PST.
(Choice D) Alterations in Purkinje fiber conduction would not significantly affect FSWT because the re-entrant pathways in PSVT da nat involve the Purkinje system.
(Choice E) Ventricular myocardial contractility decreases with increased vagal tone. Changes in myocardial contractility will not affect PSVT.
Educational objective:
Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSYT) most commanly results from accessory conduction pathways through the AY node. “Vagal maneuvers and medications that decrease conduction through the AY node often resalve the PST.

question: A 67-year-old man is evaluated far hypertension. He complains of occasional morning headaches. His past medical histary is also significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and a stroke with residual left-sided weakness. He underwent caranary artery bypass surgery seven years ago and carotid endarterectomy five years ago. His current medication list includes lisinopril, hydrochlorathiazide, amlodipine, metoprolol, aspirin, metformin and glyburide. His blood pressure is 190/120 mmHg on the right arm and 170/110 mmHg an the left arm. His heart rate is 85/min. Physical examination reveals a periumbilical systolic-diastolic bruit. The latter finding is best explained by which of the following?
explanation:
This patient has atherosclerotic vascular disease, hypertension, and an abdominal bruit concerning for renal artery stenosis. Renal artery stenosis is a leading cause of secondary and refractory hypertension and chranic kidney disease.
Bruits are caused by turbulent blood flow within a vessel and often reflect luminal irregularities. Abdominal bruits are quite comman in young people, affecting up to 30% of patients without hypertension. They are found in up to 85% of patients with renal artery stenosis, compared to 25% of patients with hypertension. The character of the bruit is also suggestive of renal artery stenosis. Systolic-diastolic bruits are seen in approximately 40% of patients with renal artery stenosis but less than 1% of patients without renal artery stenasis.
(Choice A) Abdominal aortic aneurysms are seen most commonly in older men with atherosclerosis and a smaking history. They classically present with a pulsatile abdominal mass. A systolic bruit may be heard, but a systolic-diastolic bruit would be rare.
(Choice B) Aortic dissection presents with tearing pain of acute onset.
(Choice C) Aortic coarctations are congenital strictures along the aorta. They can cause hypertension and differences in blood pressures between the upper and lower extremities. Patients are most often diagnosed in infancy or childhood.
(Choice E) Aorto-enteric fistulas are rare causes of massive gastrointestinal hemarrhage. They may be primary or secondary (i.e. due to surgery). This patient does nat have any histary of surgery or Gl bleeding. Moreover, an aorto-enteric fistula would cause hypotension, nat hypertension.
Educational objective:
The presence of a systolic-diastolic abdominal bruit in a patient with hypertension and atherosclerosis is strongly suggestive of renal artery stenosis.

question: A 67-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode. He lost consciousness while shopping in the mall. He denies any nausea, diapharesis, chest pain, or shortness of breath. He has had two episodes of lightheadedness aver the last month, but has not seen a doctor. His past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertensian, which is being treated with enalapril. His blood pressure is 135/390 mmHg while supine, and 130/85 mmHg while standing. His heart rate is 64/min. ECG shows a sinus rhythm with high voltage, prolonged PR interval, prolonged QRS interval, normal QT interval and occasional premature ventricular contractions (PVC). Echocardiography reveals left ventricular hypertrophy and an ejection fraction (EF) of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's syncope?
explanation:
Syncope is characterized by the sudden, transient loss of consciousness with or without warning symptoms. Warning symptoms include lightheadedness, visual blurring, diaphoresis and nausea. Patients usually do not have any confusion ar neurological deficits following recovery from the syncaopal episode.
Maormal patients can maintain the cerebral blood supply with a heart rate ranging from 30 to 180 bpm. When the heart rate is lower than 30 bmp, cerebral perfusion is impaired, even if there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. A patient with a disease of the sinus node (sick sinus syndrome) ar conduction system can have intermittent bradycardia and typically manifest with recurrent syncopal episodes. The presence of a conduction disturbance on electrocardiography (e.g. prolonged PR or QRS interval) is often assaciated with bradyarrhythmias.
(Choice B) Patients with cardiomyopathy and a low ejection fraction can present with exercise-induced syncopal episodes. An ejection fraction of 55% goes against the diagnosis of decreased myocardial contractility.
(Choice C) A prolonged QT interval is associated with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia called "torsades de pointes," in which the QRS complexes undulate over a point. The most important cause of tarsades de pointes is hypomagnesemia.
(Choice D) Postural hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction can cause presyncope and syncape; however, this patient did not have any postural hypotension (i e., his blood pressure readings did not significantly decrease from a recumbent to an upright position).
(Choice E) Ventricular beats, by themselves, are not associated with syncope.
(Choice F) The most important differential diagnosis of syncope is generalized seizures. Distinguishing features of a seizure include the presence of sustained clonic-tonic mavement, tongue biting, and paost-ictal confusian.
Educational objective:
A prolonged QRS interval (i.e. typically bundle branch block) suggests a bradyarrhythmia, whereas a prolonged QT interval suggests a tachyarrhythmia.

question: A 60-year-old male is 2 days status past, primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement. He had previously suffered fram an antero-lateral myocardial infarction. His cardiac enzymes have been trending down since admission. He has recovered well and is ready for discharge. He is currently asymptomatic. His temperature is 37.5 C (39.5 F), blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, pulse is 66/min, and respirations are 14/min. He is discharged with instructions ta take the following medications: aspirin, simvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and sublingual nitroglycerine. In addition to the medications listed above, which of the following medications should this patient also be taking after discharge?
explanation:
All patients wha have had a myocardial infarction should receive secandary prevention. The following medications have been shown to have a mortality benefit when given as secandary prevention:
1. Aspirin (75-325 mg/day)
2 Beta-blockers
3. ACE-inhibitars
4 Lipid-lowering statin drugs
In addition, clopidogrel should be prescribed to all patients with unstable angina/non-ST elevation MI (UANSTEMI), as well as patients who are past PCI {percutaneous coronary intervention). Clopidagrel belongs ta the class of drugs called Thienopyridines, which also include ticlopidine. These drugs have an anti-platelet effect and act by antagonizing ADP. Clopidogrel is preferred over ticlopidine because it has less toxicity associated with it.
Studies have shown the following regarding the effectivity of clopidogrel:
1. For patients who need to be on aspirin but cannot tolerate it, clopidogrel is an appropriate alternative because it is as effective.
2. Far patients who are post UA/NSTEMI, clopidogrel + aspirin has been shown to be more effective, in terms of mortality, than aspirin alone. Data suggest that clopidogrel should be continued for at least 12 months following UA/NSTEMI. Aspirin should be continued indefinitely.
3. Clopidogrel + aspirin is more effective than aspirin alone for the first 30 days following percutaneous coronary interventions (FCI), as it helps prevent subacute stent thrombosis. Patients who receive drug-eluting stents need a longer duration because epithelialization occurs slowly.
In patients with STEMI (ST elevation MI}, the role of clopidogrel depends on the form of reperfusion therapy (primary PCI, thrombolysis, or no reperfusion). Clopidogrel is recommended for at least one month in patients wha have undergone primary PCI with stenting (as stated above). Itis less clear whether clopidogrel should be used with thrombolytic therapy ar no reperfusion therapy, although some experts choose to do so.
(Choice A) Isosorbide manonitrate is appropriate if the patient continues to experience angina; however, its benefits are symptomatic, and it has no effect on mortality.
(Choice B) Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is usually given post-MI far the first 48 hours or until angiography is performed, but it is not necessary after the patient has been discharged from the hospital.
(Choice C) Warfarin is indicated if the patient has evidence of ventricular thrombus, which is usually seen in individuals with apical infarcts and dyskinetic wall motion abnormalities.
(Choice E) Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is typically not indicated in acute coronary syndrome, as calcium channel blockers have been associated with increased mortality in this patient population. These are typically used as anti-anginal therapy, along with long-acting nitrates in patients with diffuse coronary artery disease who are not candidates for either PCI or caranary artery bypass graft (typically referred as medical management).
Educational Objective:
Clopidogrel should be included as secondary prevention following UA/NSTEMI for at least 12 manths. It should also be prescribed for thirty days (bare metal stents) to one year (drug eluting stents) following PCI, as it has been shown to help prevent subacute stent thrombosis.

question: A 47-year-old male presents to your office with a two month histary of lethargy and decreased libido. His medical records reveal that he has been treated for joint pain and swelling over the last six months and was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus one year ago. Fhysical examination reveals hepatomegaly and testicular atrophy. Which of the following cardiac abnormalities is most likely to also be present in this patient?
explanation:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a multi-organ system disease process, including hypogonadism (testicular atrophy, decreased sexual drive), arthropathy, pancreatic endocrine dysfunction (diabetes) and hepatomegaly. Hemochromatosis is a candition that can cause the above findings, in addition to cardiac abnormalities. Cardiac invalvement may include dilated or restricitve cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure or various conduction abnormalities. Hemosiderin depasition in the pituitary can lead to hypagonadotropic hypogonadism and deposition in the joints can cause arthropathy.
(Choice A) Atrial septal defects are usually isolated, sporadic congenital anomalies. Only rarely do they accur as part of an inherited disorder involving ather argan systems (e.g. Holt-Cram syndrome, which also causes upper limb deformities).
(Choice B) Aortic stenosis generally results from localized senile calcific changes to the valve, which may be accelerated by the presence of a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve.
(Choice C) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy results from mutations in genes that encode cardiac sarcomere proteins. It is not known to be associated with hepatomegaly, testicular atrophy, pancreatic endocrine insufficiency ar arthropathy.
(Choice E) Endocardial fibroelastosis is a rare, idiopathic, diffuse fibroelastic thickening of the left ventricular endocardium. It usually occurs in the first two years of life and is generally nat associated with hepatomegaly, testicular atrophy, pancreatic endacrine insufficiency ar arthropathy.
Educational objective:
Hereditary hemochromatosis can cause cirrhosis, pancreatic fibrosis (diabetes) and increased skin pigmentation due to melanin and hemaosiderin deposition (bronze diabetes), as well as abnormalities of cardiac conduction.

question: A 35-year-old Caucasian male is being evaluated for poor exercise talerance and muscle weakness. He has no past medical history. His blood pressure ranges from 175-185 mmHg systolic and 105-115 mmHg diastolic on repeat measurements. His heart rate is 78-85/min. His serum chemistry is significant for blood glucose of 95 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 0.7mg/dL, serum Na of 146 mEq/L, and serum K of 24 mEq/L. CT scan of the abdomen reveals a 3 cm mass in the left adrenal gland. Which of the following additional findings would you expect in this patient?
options: A. Plasma renin activity High, Serum aldosterone High, Serum bicarbonate Low
B. Plasma renin activity High, Serum aldosterone High, Serum bicarbonate High
C. Plasma renin activity Low, Serum aldosterone High, Serum bicarbonate High
D. Plasma renin activity Low, Serum aldosterone High, Serum bicarbonate Low
E. Plasma renin activity High, Serum aldosterone Low, Serum bicarbonate High
explanation:
This patient has primary hyperaldosteranism (Conn's syndrome). The presentation of a young non-obese and nan-black patient with hypertension should raise suspicion far secondary hypertension. Furthermare, this patient's symptoms, lab values and adrenal mass suggest Conn's syndrome. Conn's syndrome presents with hypertension, mild hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. This combination of abnormalities is the result of excess aldosterone, which promotes distal tubular reabsorption of sodium, volume expansion, and secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions. The mass seen on the patient's CT scan is likely an adrenal adenoma secreting excess aldosterone. To definitely diagnose Conn's syndrome, renin and aldosterone levels should be checked. Aldosterone release is regulated by renin. Therefore, while aldosterone levels are elevated in Conn's syndrome, renin levels are decreased due to feedback inhibition. Symptoms of muscle weakness and exercise intolerance are the result of hypokalemia.
Educational objective:
Primary hyperaldosteronism (aka Conn's Syndrome) causes hypertension, mild hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabalic alkalosis. The diagnosis of Conn's syndrome can be confirmed by findings of a low renin level and an elevated aldosterone level.

question: A 67-year-old homeless male presents 24 hours after the onset of substernal chest pain and is diagnosed with an anterior wall myocardial infarction. There is no history of previous chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations, syncope ar leg swelling. He has no hypertension or diabetes mellitus. He does acknowledge a 40 pack-year smaking history. Upon discharge, echocardiography shows normal left ventricular size, left ventricular anterior wall hypokinesis and an ejection fraction of 50%. Two years later, the patient is found dead in the street. Autopsy reveals a dilated left ventricle with a globular shape and thinned walls along with a scar on the anterior wall. Which of the following would have mast likely prevented this patient's pathalogic findings?
explanation:
Following a myocardial infarction, ventricular remodeling occurs and gradually causes dilatation of the left ventricle with thinning of the ventricular walls. This can result in CHF. Ventricular remodeling occurs in the weeks to months following a myocardial infarction, therefore it was nat seen an the patient's discharge echocardiogram. ACE inhibitors have been shawn ta limit ventricular remodeling. An ACE inhibitor should be initiated within 24 hours of myocardial infarction in all patients without a contraindication.
(Choice A) Aspirin is typically given to patients after myocardial infarction to inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent recurrence of coranary artery blockage. However, aspirin has na effect on ventricular remadeling.
(Choice C) Calcium channel blockers such as amlodipine are not routinely prescribed for patients following myocardial infarction. They could be added if a patient has hypertension not completely controlled with ACE inhibitors and B-blockers.
(Choice D) Isosorbide dinitrate is a long-acting nitrate used to prevent anginal chest pain. It may be needed by some patients with chronic symptoms of stable angina, but it does not prevent ventricular remodeling.
(Choice E) Digoxin is shawn to provide symptomatic relief patients with systolic heart failure. However, it does not provide a mortality benefit, and it does not help to prevent the remodeling process.
(Choice F) Antiplatelet agents such as aspirin are favored aver warfarin in past Ml patients, but neither will reduce ventricular remodeling.
Educational objective:
Ventricular remodeling in the weeks to months following myocardial infarction can lead ta dilatation of the ventricle. This process is lessened by ACE inhibitors.

question:
A 50-year-old woman presents to your office complaining af lower extremity edema that started several weeks ago, and slowly progressed thereafter. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension, treated with metoprolal far 2 years. Amlodipine was added recently because of inadequate control of BF with metoprolol alone. She does not smoke or consume alcohal. She has nao known drug allergies. Her blood pressure is 130/80mm Hg and her heart rate is 84/min. The physical examination reveal bilateral symmetric 3+ pitting edema of both lower extremities, without any skin changes ar varicosities. Her neck vein pulsation is normal. Other physical findings are within normal limits. Her laboratory studies reveal the following:
Serum albumin              4.5 g/dL
Total serum bilirubin         0.8 mg/dL
Serum sadium               140 mEq/L
Serum potassium            4.0 mEq/L
Serum creatinine             0.8 mg/dL
Urinalysis is within normal limits. What is the most likely cause of the edema in this patient?
options: E. Side effect of her medications
explanation:
It is important to remember that peripheral edema is a common side effect of the treatment with dihydropyridine Ca-channel antagonists like amlodipine. These medications can cause significant edema, as in this patient, due to the property to dilate peripheral blood vessels; it is NOT an allergic reaction! If the edema is significant, the drug should be discontinued. The clues to the correct diagnosis in this case are the therapy with a dihydropyridine Ca-channel antagonist, amlodipine initiated recently, and narmal physical examination with normal laboratory findings. Of course, it is necessary to exclude other mare serious causes of edema.
Congestive heart failure (Choice A) is an important cause of lower extremity edema, but the absence of other symptoms of heart failure (e.g. dyspnea, orthopnea) and physical findings, especially elevated neck vein pulsation and liver enlargement, makes this diagnosis unlikely.
Liver diseases (Choice B) can cause lower extremity edema, but usually ascites dominates over peripheral edema, and abnormal labaratary findings characteristic of liver dysfunction are present (e.q., hypoalbuminemia, hyperbilirubinemia).
Renal diseases (Choice C) can cause peripheral edema due to massive proteinuria (as with nephrotic syndrome) ar fluid retention (such as during acute nephritic syndrome). The absence of proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and normal creatinine level are inconsistent with renal causes of the edema.
Venous insufficiency (Choice D) is a possibility in this case. Symmetric edema without skin changes and varicasities, however, argues against venous insufficiency.
Educational objective:
Dihydropyridine Ca-channel antagonists can cause peripheral edema and should always be considered in the differential diagnosis of this condition, along with other causes, such as heart failure, renal disease and venous insufficiency.

question: A 64-year-old male who has not seen a doctor far the past 20 years presents to the emergency raam with excruciating chest pain that started suddenly about three hours ago. He describes the pain as tearing in quality and says that it radiates to his back. On physical examination, you hear an early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the sternal border. Chest x-ray shows widening of the superior mediastinum. EKG is normal. Which af the following medical conditions mast likely accounts far this patient's presentation?
explanation:
The diagnosis here is acute aortic dissection. Patients classically present with sudden, tearing pain that radiates to the back. The decrescenda diastolic murmur heard here suggests aortic regurgitation, which can be a consequence of aortic dissection invalving the aartic root. The classic chest x-ray finding of a widened mediastinum is seen in about 60% of patients. There are a variety of risk factors for the development of aortic dissection, but the mast comman is hypertension (seen in abaut 75% of cases).
(Choice B) Marfan's syndrome is caused by a mutation of the fibrillin gene, which results in "weakened" connective tissue. Patients with Marfan's syndrome are at increased risk for aortic dissection. However, Marfan's syndrome is nat the strongest risk factor, and would tend to cause aortic dissection in younger patients.
(Choice C) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a connective tissue disease involving collagen that can predispose to aortic dissection. Like Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is not the most comman cause af aortic dissection and would tend to present in younger patients.
(Choice D) There is an association between having a bicuspid aortic valve and developing aortic dissection, but it is not the most common risk factor.
(Choice E) Giant cell arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis that often affects the aorta. While it can cause aortic aneurysms and dissections, it is a relatively uncommon cause.
(Choice F) Diabetes mellitus is a risk factor for atherosclerosis, but is not directly associated with aortic dissection.
(Choice G) Atherosclerosis is a risk factor for aortic aneurysms, which can in turn lead to dissection. However, hypertension is a stronger and more common risk factor for dissection.
Educational Objective:
The most common predisposing factor for aortic dissection is hypertension.

question: A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency room with palpitations and lightheadedness of acute anset. Also, she has experienced insomnia, fatigability, and weight loss lately. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She is not taking any medications. Her blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg and heart rate is 120/min, irregular. Physical examination reveals lid lag and fine tremor of the outstretched hands. ECG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of Grave's disease - insomnia, fatigability, weight loss, lid lag, and tremor. Atrial fibrillation is a common complication of hyperthyroidism. As in other cardiovascular complications, atrial fibrillation in patients with hyperthyroidism is believed to be caused by increased sensitivity of beta-adrenaoreceptors to sympathetic stimuli. The best initial choice for these stable patients is a beta-blocker like propranolol. It nat only helps to control the rhythm in tachysystalic atrial fibrillation, but also diminishes other symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
Digoxin (Choice A) is not a good chaice, because rapid ventricular respanse in hyperthyraidism-related atrial fibrillation is resistant to cardiac glycosides.
Cluinidine (Choice D), when used without pretreatment with rhythm-cantrolling drugs, may even worsen tachysystoly. It is not commonly used today for chemical cardiaversian.
Electrical cardioversion (Choice E) is effective in restoring the sinus rhythm; but, if the underlying condition (hyperthyroidism) is not addressed, atrial fibrillation will mast probably recur. Emergent cardioversion is indicated if the arrhythmia precipitates dangerous complications (like hypotension, angina, or heart failure), or if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.
Lidocaine (Choice C) is useless in this situation, because it is not effective in atrial arrhvthmias.
Educational Objective:
In patients with hyperthyraidism-related tachysystolic atrial fibrillation, a beta-blocker is the drug of choice.

question: A 43-year-old Caucasian man with a two-year history of diabetes mellitus presents to your office for a routine check-up. He has no complaints. His medications are metformin and aspirin. He works as a computer programmer and has a sedentary lifestyle. He drinks one to two cans of beer on weekends and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 153/94 mm Hg and his heart rate is 82/min. His BMI is 32.5 kg/m? The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal an HbA of 7.6%. At his check-up one manth ago, his blood pressure was 149/32 mm Hg. Which af the following interventions would be most effective for cantralling his blood pressure?
explanation:
Systemic hypertension is a major source of morbidity and martality worldwide. While the vast majarity of affected patients will ultimately require pharmacotherapy to meet their blood pressure goals, lifestyle modification can help. Weight loss is the most beneficial lifestyle intervention for obese individuals. Every 10 kg reduction in weight can decrease the systalic blood pressure by 5-20 mm Hg. For all patients, the goal BMI is 18.5-24.9 kg/m”.
(Choice A) Regular aerobic exercise, at least 30 minutes per day an most days of the week, can decrease systolic blood pressure by 4-9 mm Hg.
(Choice C) Smoking cessation will markedly decrease this patient's overall cardiovascular risk but will not significantly decrease his blood pressure.
(Choice D) Improved glycemic cantral will decrease this patient's risk of developing microvascular disease (neuropathy, nephropathy, and retinopathy). It will not imprave his blood pressure control, however.
(Choice E) Limiting alcohol cansumption to na mare than 2 drinks per day for a man ar 1 drink per day far a woman will decrease the systalic blood pressure by 2-4 mm Hg.
(Choice F) Restricting the daily sodium intake to no mare than 2.4 g daily will decrease the systolic blood pressure by 2-8 mm Hg.
Educational objective:
Most patients will require pharmacotherapy for blood pressure control, but lifestyle changes can make a difference. Weight contral is the most important intervention, followed by physical activity, salt restriction, and moderation of alcohol consumption.

question: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency room complaining of chest pain for the past several hours. She describes it as sharp, centrally located, and non-radiating. The pain worsens somewhat with inspiration and movement. The patient denies having fevers, chills, dyspnea, swelling, or difficulty breathing at night. She says she first noticed the pain while exercising three weeks ago, but has experienced it at rest as well. She says that she has been exercising heavily in an attempt to lose weight. Her BMI is currently 34kg/m”. Her father had a myocardial infarction at age 60. Her medical history is significant far twa narmal vaginal deliveries. She smokes a half-pack af cigarettes daily. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 112/69 mm Hg and her heart rate is 72/min. Cardiac exam reveals a regular S1 and S2 without extra sounds or murmurs. There is tenderness to palpation over the sternum. What is the mast likely cause of her chest pain?
explanation:
This woman's chest pain suggests costochandritis, a pain syndrome characterized by tenderness of the costochondral or costosternal junctions. The fact that her pain is sharp, focal, lasts for hours, and warsens with inspiration and movement all suggest a musculoskeletal etiology. That the tenderness is reproducible with palpation on physical examination also supports this diagnosis. The ather diagnoses listed dao not cause reproducible chest pain.
Educational objective:
Chest pain that is reproducible with palpation suggests a musculoskeletal etiology.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to the ER with substernal chest pain and diaphaoresis. The pain started one hour ago and did not remit with antacids. He has a past medical history of asthma for which he uses inhaled fluticasone and peptic ulcer disease for which he takes omeprazole. His family history is significant for prostate cancer in his father and breast cancer in his mother. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure af 180/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 30/min. A bruit is heard over the right carotid artery and a mild systolic murmur is present at the cardiac apex. Sublingual nitroglycerin and aspirin are administered in the ER. Within minutes, the patient reports decreased pain. Which of the following most likely accounts far this improvement in his symptoms?
explanation:
Mitrates like nitroglycerin decrease chest pain in angina pectoris primarily by reducing cardiac wark and increasing oxygen delivery to the myocardium. Their venodilatory effects account for the decrease in cardiac work. “enodilation causes blood to pool in the systemic venous circulation, which decreases preload. A reduced preload reduces ventricular volume and wall stress (stretch), thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand. Nitrates also cause some arterial vasodilation resulting in a modest decrease in afterload and myacardial oxygen consumption, but these are not the most impartant mechanisms of nitrate action.
(Choices A & C) Nitrates do not directly alter myocardial compliance ar contractility. Such changes may accur as downstream effects of nitrate therapy, but this is not the way in which nitrates decrease chest pain.
(Choices D & E) An increased preload or afterload would increase cardiac work, thus increasing cardiac oxygen demand and warsening angina.
(Choice F) Significant arterial and venous dilation might result in rebound tachycardia in patients given high doses of nitrates. This would increase myocardial oxygen demand and warsen chest pain. Beta-blockers are used in acute myocardial infarction to prevent tachycardia.
Educational objective:
Mitrates cause venodilation, which improves cardiac chest pain by reducing cardiac preload and thus decreasing myocardial oxygen demand.

question: A 38-year-old female comes to your office complaining of occasional palpitations. She describes feeling a fast and irregular heartbeat. Over the past twa months, she has had three such episodes, each lasting about twa hours. She denies any associated chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, or ankle swelling. She drinks alcohol on social occasions and does not smoke cigarettes. She has no ather medical problems and is nat taking any medications. On physical examination, her temperature is 37.1°C {98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. On auscultation of her heart, the apical impulse is displaced and there is an 53. You also hear a pansystalic murmur, which is loudest at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Which of the following is the mast likely cause of her symptoms?
explanation:
This patient most likely has mitral valve prolapse that has progressed to mitral regurgitation and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Mitral valve prolapse is fairly common, affecting about 2-4% of the general population. There does not appear to be a strong predilection for gender ar age. The underlying pathology involves myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. Mitral valve prolapse is the most common cause af mitral regurgitation, which typically causes a pansystolic murmur that radiates to the axilla. In some with mitral valve prolapse, a midsystalic click can also be appreciated. Mitral regurgitation can lead to increased left atrial size, which can in turn lead to atrial fibrillation, which is probably the cause of this patient's intermittent palpitations.
(Choice B) Myocardial ischemia can cause mitral regurgitation, but is unlikely in this patient without chest pain or strong caronary artery disease risk factors.
(Choice C) Rheumatic heart disease is uncommon in developed countries. It may lead to mitral regurgitation, but mitral stenasis is a more comman complication.
(Choice D) Mitral annular calcification is not a common cause of mitral regurgitation.
(Choice E) Infective endocarditis can cause mitral regurgitation, but there are usually accompanying signs of systemic infection such as fever.
Educational objective:
Mitral regurgitation can cause a holosystalic murmur that radiates to the axilla. Mitral valve prolapse is the most comman cause of mitral regurgitation. Mitral regurgitation can lead to left atrial dilation and atrial fibrillation.

question:
A 42-year-old woman is evaluated far depression, mood swings and poor sleep. She also complains of mild headaches and muscle weakness. She has had two ER visits for kidney stones over the past year. She denies any illicit drug use. Her blood pressure is 160/105 mmHg and her heart rate is 85/min. Her laboratory findings are shown below:
Sodium              140 mEg/L
Potassium           3.6 mEgiL
Chloride          111 mEgL
Bicarbonate         24 mEq/L
BUN                 13 mg/dL
Creatinine           0.9 mg/dL
Glucose             98 mg/dL
Calcium             11.7 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypertension?
explanation:
This woman has hypertension, psychiatric symptoms (depression, mood swings, and poor sleep), recurrent kidney stones, and hypercalcemia. This presentation is concerning for hyperparathyroidism. The parathyroid gland produces parathyroid hormone (PTH) which acts to increase serum calcium levels and decrease serum phosphate. The mnemanic "stones, banes, groans, and psychiatric overtones" describes the comman symptoms which result from hypercalcemia. Specifically, hypercalcemia may lead to kidney stones, constipation/indigestion, and depression/fatigue/psychaosis. Patients with hyperparathyroidism also have an increased incidence of hypertension, although it is an uncommoaon cause of secondary hypertension.
(Choice A) Renal parenchymal disease causes hypertension. However, parenchymal disease severe enough to cause hypertension should also cause a decrease in glomerular filtration rate. This patient's creatinine concentration is normal.
(Choice B) Renal artery stenasis is an important cause of secondary hypertension. Usually due to atherosclerosis, renal artery stenosis generally presents with few systemic complaints and may be entirely asymptomatic. It would not explain this woman's hypercalcemia, kidney stones, and psychiatric symptoms. A bruit may often be heard upon auscultation of the affected renal artery.
(Choice C) Aortic dissections present with tearing chest pain that radiates ta the back. They most commonly occur in patients with hypertension but are nat, themselves, causes of hypertension.
(Choice D) Hypothyroidism causes weight gain, fatigue, bradycardia, depression, and skin and hair changes. This patient's hypercalcemia, kidney stones, and hypertension suggest hyperparathyroidism, not hypothyroidism.
(Choice F) Corticosteroids, mineralocorticoids, and adrenal androgens are made in the adrenal cortex. This patient's systemic symptoms do not suggest Cushing's syndrome, primary hyperaldosteronism, ar virilization.
(Choice G) Increased activity within the medulla (pheochromocytoma) would cause hyperadrenergic symptoms such as weight loss, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and amdety.
Educational objective:
Hyperparathyraidism is an uncommon cause of secondary hypertension. Asymptomatic hypercalcemia in a hypertensive patient ar the presence of "stones, bones, groans and psychiatric overtones" should raise suspicion for this condition.

question: A 14-year-old African American male is referred to your office after his alder brather experienced sudden cardiac arrest during hiking trip. He has no current complaints. He denies any illicit drug use. His blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg and his heart rate is 78/min. Neck is supple, no jugular venous distentian is appreciated. Carotid pulse seems to have dual upstroke. Lungs are clear. There is strong apical impulse and a systolic ejection-type murmur along the left sternal border. Which of the following is mast likely to increase the murmur intensity in this patient?
explanation:
This patient mast likely has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The condition is mare common in African-Americans. It shows an autosomal dominant inheritance, so the sudden death of the patient's brother is likely a clue to the diagnosis. The patient's physical exam is also suggestive. A carotid pulse with dual upstroke accurs fram midsystalic abstructian that develops as the heart contracts. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy typically causes a systolic gjection-type murmur along the left sternal border, and often has a strong apical impulse. Contrary to most murmurs, the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy increases as preload decreases since this lessens the size of the ventricular cavity and causes increased outflow abstruction. Most murmurs will decrease with decreased preload since there will be less flow. The Valsalva maneuver is the anly maneuver listed that will decrease venous return, and therefore preload.
(Answer A) Squatting decreases the vertical height of the blood column, and therefare will increase venous return to the heart. This increase venous return will result in a larger size of the ventricle and hence less autflow obstruction.
(Answer C) Sustained handgrip leads ta an increase in systemic vascular resistance and increased afterload. Increased afterload leads to a larger ventricular volume and thus a decrease in outflow obstruction and a quieter murmur. Handgrip is typically used ta differentiate between the murmurs of aortic stenosis and mitral regurgitation where it causes a decrease and increase, respectively, in the severity of the murmur.
(Choice D) Recumbency increases venous return. As described above, this will decrease outflow obstruction and the murmur will therefore be less severe.
(Choice E) Leg raising will also increase venous return and will decrease the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
Educational objective:
The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is located at the [eft lower sternal barder and is worsened by maneuvers that decrease preload (e.g. Valsalva, standing)

question: A 60-year-old male is brought to ER by his son because he had an episode of syncope. He was watching TV in an arm-chair when suddenly lost his consciousness without any warning sign. He had several clonic jerks while unconscious. He never had such an episode before. His past medical history is significant for acute myacardial infarction six months ago and well-controlled hypertension. His current medications include captopril, metoprolol, hydrochlorathiazide, clopidogrel and aspirin. His blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg and heart rate is 80fmin with frequent ectopic beats. Physical examination revealed mild holosystolic apical murmur radiating to the axilla. Which of the following is the most probable pathophysiologic mechanism far his syncopal episode?
explanation:
The most probable explanation of the episode is arrhythmia. The clues for the correct diagnosis include sudden onset of syncope without warning signs, presence of structural heart disease (post-infarction scar and probable mitral regurgitation because of the characteristic murmur), and frequent ectopic beats. Anather important clue is the presence af the thiazide diuretic in the medication list that can cause electrolyte disturbances predisposing ta ventricular arrhythmia.
Vasovagal syncope (Choice A), a comman fainting spell, is usually precipitated by emotional reaction and is preceded by presyncopal dizziness, weakness and nausea.
Autonomic dysfunction (Choice C) or drug-induced postural hypotension (Choice E) may cause syncope, but this syncope is orthostatic in nature. That means it occurs on standing when blood is redistributed ta the dependent parts of the bady. When syncope occurs without preceding change in body position (e.g. standing), it is unlikely to be orthostatic.
Clanic jerks may occur during any syncape if it is prolonged and are due to brain hypoxia. Absence of a previous history of seizure and the description of syncope make the diagnosis of seizure (Choice D) less likely in this patient.
Educational objective:
Know the basic pathophysiologic mechanisms of syncape. Be able ta differentiate various types of syncope based an the clinical scenario.

question: A 45-year-old recently immigrated Mexican farmer comes to your office complaining of dyspnea, fatigue and abdominal distention for the past two months. On physical exam, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.0°F), blood pressure is 126/80 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are16/min. You note pedal edema, elevated jugular venous pressure with pasitive Kussmaul's sign, and increased abdominal girth with free fluid. Chest auscultation reveals decreased heart sound intensity at the apex and an early heart sound following 52. The jugular venous pressure tracing shows prominent 'x' and 'y' descents. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
explanation:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is constrictive pericarditis, a condition marked by pericardial fibrosis and obliteration of the pericardial space. Constrictive pericarditis impairs ventricular filling during diastole, causing patients to experience symptoms of decreased cardiac output (fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, muscle wasting) and signs of venous overload (elevated JVF, ascites, positive Kussmaul's sign, pedal edema). Sharp 'x' and 'y' descents on central venous tracing are characteristic of constrictive pericarditis as is the presence of a pericardial knock (early heart sound after 52).
In developing countries, tuberculosis is a commaon cause of constrictive pericarditis (Choice B). In the United States, causes of constrictive pericarditis include idiopathic or viral (=40%), radiotherapy (~30%), cardiac surgery (~10%), and connective tissue disorders.
(Choice A) COPD and pulmonary emboli are the most common causes of cor pulmanale. Cor pulmanale results from pulmonary hypertension. Signs of pulmonary hypertension on physical examination include a narraw split S2 and/or increased intensity of the pulmonic component of 52.
(Choice C) Trypanosoma cruziis the cause of Chagas disease. tis endemic to South America and may cause megacolon, megaesophagus and cardiac disease. Whereas constrictive pericarditis anly impairs diastalic function, Chagas disease causes both systolic and diastolic heart failure. Chagas may alsa cause arrhythmias and mitralftricuspid regurgitation.
(Choice C) Psittacosis is a disease transmitted to humans by birds. Patients present with fever, dry cough and headache. On physical exam, pulmonary findings are mast prominent. Cardiac involvement is rare.
(Choice D) The pneumocanioses are occupational lung diseases caused by inhalation of inorganic dust. Examples include asbestosis and silicosis. Patients may gradually develop dyspnea on exertian, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale years after exposure.
Educational objective:
Constrictive pericarditis results in pericardial fibrosis and diastolic dysfunction. Patients present with signs of decreased cardiac output and venous overload. Inthe United States, comman etiologies include viruses, radiation, and idiopathic. In third world countries, tuberculosis is the most common cause.

question: A 25-year-old G2, P1 at 28 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend, who found her lying on her bed in a pool of blood. She is very drowsy, but denies any pain ar uterine contractions. Her temperature is 38 C (100.4 F) and respirations are 18/min. Fhysical examination is suggestive of a transverse lie. Inspection of the perineum reveals gross blood and active bleeding per vagina. Which of the following set of parameters would mast likely be seen in this patient?
options: A. CO Decreased, PCWP Increased, SVR Increased, BP Decreased, HR Increased
B. CO Decreased, PCWP Decreased, SVR Increased, BP Decreased, HR Decreased
C. CO Decreased, PCWP Decreased, SVR Increased, BP Decreased, HR Increased
D. CO Decreased, PCWP Decreased, SVR Decreased, BP Decreased, HR Increased
E. CO Increased, PCWP Decreased, SVR Increased, BP Decreased, HR Increased
explanation:
This patient is suffering from hypovolemic ar hemarrhagic shack secondary to antepartum hemarrhage, probably placenta previa. Blood lass represents intravascular valume loss, which consequently decreases the cardiac output, as well as pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (an indirect measure of left atrial pressure). The decreased cardiac output stimulates the sympathetic system, thereby leading to generalized vasoconstriction (increased systemic vascular resistance), and an increase in heart rate. Although the goal af sympathetic stimulation is to increase the blood pressure back to normal, almost all cases of shock have blood pressures that fail to return to baseline.
Educational objective:
Hypovalemic shock is characterized by hypotension, tachycardia, decreased central venous pressure (or pulmonary capillary wedge pressure), decreased cardiac output, and increased peripheral vascular resistance.

question:
A 54-year-old male comes to the physician because of abdominal distention. He thinks his big belly is making it hard for him to breathe. He received radiation therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma several years ago and was told that he is cured. He drinks alcohol an a regular basis. His temperature is 36.7C (98F), blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min and respirations are 20/min. Examination shows a jugular venous pressure 8 cm above the sternal angle. Dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds are noted in the right lung base. The abdomen is quite distended with an obvious fluid wave. Mild hepatomegaly is present. Extremities have 2+ lower extremity edema. Initial laboratory studies are shown below:
Serum creatinine 0.5 mgfdL
Albumin              4.0 mofdL
Total bilirubin         1.0 magidL
Prothrombin time 11 sec
Urinalysis is within narmal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
explanation:
Canstrictive pericarditis is a condition where the pericardium is thickened or scarred resulting in restriction of diastalic filling. Because the heart is unable to fill properly during diastole, cardiac output is compromised and venous pressures become chronically elevated resulting in increased jugular venous pressures (JVF), severe ascites and hepatic congestion, dyspnea and weakness. On examination, Kussmaul's sign, failure of JVP to decrease on inspiration, is often present though not specific. The mast common causes of constrictive pericarditis are cardiac surgery, viral pericarditis and radiation therapy. Many cases are idiopathic. The diagnosis is established by identifying a calcified pericardium on chest x-ray, identifying a thickened pericardium on CT or MRI scanning ar by measuring pressures during cardiac catheterization. Treatment is with diuretics or pericardiectomy.
(Choice A) Urinary protein loss causes generalized edema, including pulmanary edema in some cases, due to decreased oncatic pressure in capillary beds. However, his urinalysis shows no pratein.
(Choices B and C) Fartal vein thrombosis or compression would cause ascites and peripheral edema but would nat cause increased VP ar hepatomegaly.
(Choice E) Thoracic duct obstruction would cause lymphedema, a firm, nonpitting edema that does not cause the skin changes associated with venous stasis such as ulceration and dermatitis.
(Choice F) Venous valve incompetence in the lower extremities causes dependent edema, but ascites and increased VF are not normally observed in the absence of concomitant disease.
Educational objective:
Constrictive pericarditis causes hepatomegaly, ascites and increased JWF due to decreased diastolic filling and impairment of cardiac output. Comman causes include radiation therapy, viral pericarditis and cardiac surgery.

question: A 32-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion ane month after returning from a vacation in Texas. She says that her symptoms have progressed to the point that she now wakes during the night with a choking sensation that improves only with sitting up. Recently her shortness of breath has required her ta significantly limit her physical activity. She denies having associated chest pain, skin rash ar joint pain. She has no significant past medical history. Family history is significant for thyroid cancer in her aunt and lung cancer in her father, a heavy smoker. On physical examination, her temperature is 37 2°C (99° F), pulse is 86/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. Bilateral pitting ankle edema is present. Her liver is enlarged 2 cm below the right costal margin. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds at the bilateral bases. Cardiac exam reveals the presence of a third heart sound. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and small bilateral pleural effusions. EKG is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
explanation:
This patient has signs and symptoms of CHF including paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, dyspnea on exertion, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, cardiomegaly, bilateral pleural effusions, and a third heart sound. Myocarditis is the most likely precipitant given her young age and lack of risk factors for caronary artery disease. Viral myocarditis, often due to Coxsackie B virus, is most likely respansible. Patients often, though not always, have preceding viral-type symptoms.
(Choice A) Atherosclerosis-related ischemic heart disease is the most common cause of CHF butitis unlikely in this young patient with no risk factors.
(Choice C) Lyme disease can cause myocarditis, but is more comman in the Northeast states than Texas. Accompanying rash ar joint pain may be seen in Lyme disease.
(Choice D) While endemic to Texas, Coccidioides does not typically cause myocarditis.
(Choice E) Autoimmune mechanisms can lead to a hypersensitivity myocarditis, often accompanied by rash.
(Choice F) Hypothyroidism rarely leads to CHF.
Educational objective:
In otherwise young healthy patients who develop CHF, myocarditis should be considered high an the differential. Viral infection, especially with Coxsackie B virus, is the most common cause.

question: A 45-year-old mildly overweight male recovering from an anterior wall myocardial infarction develops sudden anset of sharp pain in the [eft side of his chest. He presented five days earlier with substernal chest pain and diaphoresis. He has had no dyspnea, extremity swelling ar palpitations since admission. His past medical history is significant far diabetes mellitus type 2. He seems mildly restless, especially in the supine position. The pain improves when sitting up and leaning forward. His breathing is fast and shallow due to the pain. His lungs are clear on auscultation. His blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg and his heart rate is G0/min. There is no change in blood pressure upon deep inspiration. ECG shows sinus rhythm with new diffuse ST segment elevation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Acute pericarditis is a complication of myocardial infarction that typically occurs within the first several days after the event. It is characterized by sharp, pleuritic pain that is warse in the supine position and improved by sitting up and leaning forward. A pericardial friction rub may be heard on examination. Diffuse ST elevations, especially with PR depressions, are typical ECG manifestations of acute pericarditis.
(Choices A & F) Interventricular free wall rupture and papillary muscle rupture typically occur 3-7 days after myocardial infarction and present with new onset systalic murmur.
(Choice B) Ventricular free wall rupture typically occurs 3-7 days after anterior wall MI. It presents with rapid deterioration secondary to pericardial tamponade. Pulseless electrical activity Is comman.
(Choice C) Fulmonary infarction secondary to pulmanary embolism can cause chest pain, but it should not cause diffuse ST elevations on ECG. In addition, while the pain of FE is pleuritic, it should not imprave with leaning forward.
(Choice D) Recurrent ischemia would most likely present with ST elevations focused in a few contiguous leads, rather than diffuse ST elevation. The positional nature of the pain is also more characteristic of acute pericarditis.
(Choice E) Right ventricular infarction is most common with inferior wall MI. It presents with hypotension, but is unlikely to lead to such a rapid deterioration as is seen in this patient.
(Choice G) Aortic dissection can cause acute onset of chest pain but it is not a typical complication of myacardial infarction and the pain is not pleuritic ar positional.
(Choice I) Ventricular aneurysm is a complication of anterior wall MI that can occur days to months after the initial infarction. It presents with akinesis of the invalved partion of the left ventricular wall, ventricular arrhythmias, and systemic embolization.
Educational objective:
Acute pericarditis typically occurs in the first several days after myocardial infarction. It is characterized by sharp, pleuritic pain that is worse in the supine position and improved by sitting up and leaning forward. Diffuse ST elevations, especially with PR depressions, are typical ECG findings.

question:
An 88-year-old female nursing home resident is brought to the hospital with a one week history of moaning, decreased oral intake and decreased ambulation. Physical examination reveals a very thin female who is moaning and appears to be in pain. She opens her eyes spontaneously but does not respond to questions. Her blood pressure is 75/43 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, temperature is 35 5°C (96°F), and respirations are 22/min. Oxygen saturation (pulse oximetry) is 97% on room air. Her skin and oral mucosa are dry and her neck veins are flat. There is no lymphadenopathy. On chest auscultation, there are crackles in the right upper lung lobe. Abdomen is saft and nan-distended. There is 2+ pitting presacral and lower extremity edema, and a deep pressure ulcer in the sacral area. Laboratory analysis reveals the following:
Sodium                155 mEg/L
Potassium            5.3 mEglL
Glucose               88 mao/dL
Bicarbonate           14 mEg/L
BUN              151 mg/dL
Creatinine          3.1 mg/dL
Which of the following is the mast likely cause of her lower extremity edema?
options: C. Renal water and sodium retention
explanation:
When a patient presents with multiple, non-specific symptoms and signs, it is helpful ta arganize the relevant clinical data. Here we have an elderly, nursing home resident, with issues including decreased oral intake, pain, and poor communication, as well as physical examination findings of hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, decubitus ulcer, right upper lobe crackles, flat neck veins, and 2+ pitting edema in both lower extremities. Matable laboratory findings include hypernatremia, hyperkalemia, elevated BUN and creatinine, BUMN/Cr ratio of 48.7 (ratio > 20 indicates prerenal azotemia), and low bicarbonate.
Generally speaking, lower extremity edema can result fram increased venous or lymphatic pressure, decreased plasma oncotic pressure, increased capillary leak, ar recent trauma aor infection. This patient has hypotension, flat neck veins and laboratory studies consistent with hypovolemia, so venous hypertension is unlikely. Lymphatic obstruction is a rare cause of edema, and the patient has no histary of lymphadenectomy, lymphadenopathy ar lymphangitis. There is no mention of hemasiderin pigment deposition on physical examination, so capillary leak is less likely, and there is no history of trauma or infection of the legs. Thus, the most likely cause of her lower extremity edema is decreased oncotic pressure resulting from malnutrition and a low serum albumin.
Educational objective:
Bilateral lower extremity pitting edema may be a sign of hypoalbuminemia secondary to malnutrition. Decreased oncotic pressure causes the edema.

question: A 84-year-old man complains of palpitations and progressive shartness of breath aver the past several hours. He says that he also develops a choking sensation every time he tries to lie down. His medical histary is significant for hypertension for the past 20 years and medication non-compliance. He also has a 35 year smaking history. He reports that his father died of a heart attack at age 70 and his mother suffered from asthma. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 130/min and irregularly irregular. Lung exam reveals bibasilar crackles. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Bedside echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is mast likely responsible far his symptoms?
explanation:
This man has heart failure due to diastolic dysfunction, alsa called heart failure with preserved left wentricular ejection fraction. Diastolic dysfunction refers to impaired filling of the left or right ventricle, either because of impaired myocardial relaxation or a stiff, non-compliant ventricle. Contractility (i.e. ejection fraction) may remain normal but diastolic pressures are elevated, consequently reducing cardiac output. This leads to typical findings of congestive heart failure.
Systemic hypertension is the classic cause of diastolic dysfunction. Chronically elevated left ventricular diastolic pressures cause left atrial dilatation, which in turn can lead ta atrial fibrillation, as in this patient. Treatment is with diuretics and blood pressure contral.
(Choice A) Cardiogenic shock usually results from compromised left ventricular function due to an acute myacardial infarction or chronic heart failure. Affected patients show signs of heart failure but would not have the left ventricular function to produce a blood pressure of 170/100. An ejection fraction of 55% wauld be very unusual far a patient with cardiogenic shock.
(Choice C) High-output heart failure refers to supranormal ventricular function that still cannat meet the body’ s metabolic demands. Causes include anemia, hyperthyroidism, beriberi, Faget's disease, and arteriovenous fistulas. The patient abave has a normal ejection fraction.
(Choice D) Asthma is due to small airway bronchocanstriction and will not cause the signs and symptoms of heart failure described here.
(Choice E) Lung compliance increases in chronic obstructive lung disease. COPD would not cause this patient's pulmonary edema or signs of right heart failure. Lung compliance is decreased in pulmonary edema.
Educational objective:
Diastolic dysfunction refers to impaired ventricular filling due to poor myocardial relaxation or diminished ventricular compliance. Itis usually due to hypertension and is treated with diuretics and antihypertensives. In severe cases, diastolic dysfunction can cause decompensated heart failure.

question: A 22-year-old Caucasian male is evaluated for an episode of syncope that occurred while playing soccer. It lasted only 2 minutes without any post-syncopal confusion, sleepiness ar weakness. He had prior episodes af dizziness while playing active sparts as well as vague chest discomfort. His uncle died suddenly at a young age. Auscultation of his precardium reveals a [IV/VI] systolic murmur along the left sternal border. The patient is mast likely to benefit fram which of the following medications?
explanation:
This patient most likely has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 15-25% of patients report syncope as a symptom. Many athers will have presyncope and chest pain with exertion, as this patient has had previously. The disease has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and can often lead to sudden death, s0 the sudden death of his uncle is a strong clue as to the diagnosis. The finding of a systolic murmur at the left sternal border points towards hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, as opposed to aortic stenosis which typically produces a murmur at the right upper sternal border. The murmur classically worsens with maneuvers that decrease preload since the smaller ventricular valume then leads to a higher degree of obstruction. The hypertrophied myocardium leads to primarily diastolic heart failure. Therefore, B-Blockers are one af the treatments af choice since they slow the heart and prolong diastole, leading to mare time for the heart ta fill and therefore less outflow obstruction. B-Blockers have an anti-anginal effect as well. A calcium channel blocker such as diltiazem is also a good option if patients are unable to tolerate B-Blockers.
(Choice A) Nitrates would be a poar choice for this patient and should be avoided. They primarily act as venodilators, and therefare reduce preload. Decreased preload will lead to decreased ventricular volume and therefore mare outflow obstruction in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
(Choice C) Disopyramide is an antiarrhythmic drug with negative inotrapic properties as well, and is an aptian for treating patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It is very effective in reducing the pressure gradient across the obstructing hypertrophied myocardium. However, it is not considered first line therapy in part ta its potential to be pro-arrhythmagenic.
(Choice D) Amlodipine is a peripherally acting calcium channel blocker, so it does not have the diastale-pralong effects of a drug such as diltiazem. It acts primarily as a arterial vasodilator.
(Choice E) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes diastolic heart failure due to an inability of the myocardium to relax properly. Digoxin is therefore contraindicated because its positive inotropic effect may further warsen diastalic relaxation.
Educational objective:
The first line of medical therapy for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is either B-blockers or a cardiac acting calcium channel blocker such as diltiazem since they promate diastalic relaxation.

question: A 55-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with muscle pain of recent onset. His past medical history is significant far hypertension and an acute myocardial infarction experienced 2 months ago. His current medications include metoprolol, captopril, aspirin and simvastatin. His blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg and heart rate is 60/min. Liver function tests are slightly abnormal. Serum creatine kinase level is elevated. You suspect a drug-induced reaction. Which of the following is the mast possible mechanism of drug-induced reaction in this patient?
explanation:
Elevated liver enzymes and myopathy are well-known side effects of statins, the popular lipid-lowering drugs. They inhibit HWG-CoA reductase, a rate-limiting enzyme in the synthesis of cholesterol that converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate. It is important to know that mevalonate is used nat anly for the synthesis of cholesteral, but alsa far the production of several other products including dolichol and CoQ10. Reduced CoQ10 production has been implicated in the pathogenesis of statin-induced myopathy; therefore the decrease in the synthesis of such products may be responsible for some adverse effects of statin therapy.
(Choices B and C) Cell surface receptar blackage and extracellular enzyme blockage are the effects produced by beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors respectively; these are their main mechanisms of action, which may also cause some adverse effects.
(Choice A) Immune-mediated reactions are responsible for a variety of drug-induced conditions, e.g. membranous glomerulonephritis induced by captopril.
(Choice E) Damage of membrane-bound lipids is usually by peroxidation due to free radicals.
Educational Objective:
Decrease in the synthesis of non-cholesteral products may be respansible for some adverse effects of statin therapy; for example reduced CoQ10 production is implicated in the pathogenesis of statin-induced myopathy.

question: A 40-year-old male presents with six months of warsening dyspnea. His symptoms have progressed to the point that walking even one block causes him to become short of breath. He has a histary of cigarette smoking, but quit 10 years aga. He drinks approximately one alcoholic drink daily. His medical history is significant for peptic ulcer disease far which he takes antacids. On physical examination, he is afebrile. His pulse is 86/min, blood pressure is 140/56 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. While examining his heart you note a high-pitched, blowing, early diastolic, decrescendo murmur, which is heard best in the left third intercostal space and is intensified by handgrip. There is prominent cardiomegaly on chest x-ray. Which of the following medications would improve both this patient's symptoms and cardiomegaly?
explanation:
This patient likely has aortic regurgitation (AR) based on his symptoms and physical exam findings. A diastolic decrescenda murmur at the left third intercostal space is classic for AR. Handgrip increases peripheral vascular resistance and afterload, which in turn increase regurgitation and cause a louder murmur. Patients with AR also have a widened pulse pressure (systolic — diastolic blood pressure), here 84 mmHg, due to an increased stroke volume. The regurgitant blood flow causes dilation af the left ventricle, seen as cardiomegaly an CXR.
The primary medical therapy for AR is afterload reduction with vasodilators like nifedipine or ACE inhibitors. For AR sa severe as ta cause symptoms, valve replacement is generally recommended.
(Choice A) Quinidine is an antiarrhythmic medication.
(Choice B) CHF secondary to AR should be treated according to standard CHF management guidelines, except that beta-blockers should not be used. By slowing the heart rate and therefore extending the time during diastole when regurgitation can take place, beta-blockers can actually worsen AR.
(Choice D) Ephedrine has alpha- and beta-agonist activity and is sometimes used to treat orthostatic hypotension.
(Choice E) Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication.
Educational objective:
The murmur of aartic regurgitation is typically described as a diastolic decrescendo murmur at the [eft third intercostal space. Medical therapy consists of afterload reduction with calcium channel blockers or ACE inhibitors.
