The pathophysiology of this patient's condition is mast similar to that of which of the following?
explanation:
This patient has variant angina, also known as Prinzmetal's angina. It is caused by temparary spasm of the coronary arteries, as opposed to atherosclerotic narrowing which is seen in myocardial infarction. Young women are classically affected, and the greatest risk factar far variant angina is smoking. Aside fram smoking, there is often an absence of cardiovascular risk factors. Variant angina is associated with other vasospastic disorders, such as Raynaud's phenomenon and migraine headaches. The episodes often occur in the middle of the night (midnight to 8 am) and are precipitated by exercise, hyperventilation, ematianal stress, cold exposure ar cocaine use. The angina episodes are accompanied by transient ST elevations with return of ST segments to baseline upon resolution of symptoms. This is in contrast to the ST depressions seen in unstable angina, and the longer duration of ST elevations seen in myocardial infarction. Medical therapy for variant angina typically involves calcium channel blockers ar nitrates.
(Choice A) Lacunar strokes occur in the setting of hypertension, and affect small, penetrating arteries which supply the basal ganglia, subcortical white matter, and pons. Occlusion of these small arteries by microatheroma and lipohyalinasis is the mechanism of lacunar stroke—not vasospasm.
(Choices B & C) Intermittent claudication is leq pain that occurs with exercise and is due to atherosclerotic narrowing of the arteries feeding the leg. The mechanism is similar to that of typical angina--nat variant angina. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are alsa the result of atherosclerotic disease.
(Choice E) The most comman cause of pulmanary embalism is embolization of blood clots from the deep veins of the lower extremities. Variant angina does nat involve embolic phenomena.
Educational objective:
Yariant Angina (or Frinzmetal's angina) is a vasospastic disorder that typically occurs in young female smakers. Chest pain usually occurs in the middle of the night, and episodes are associated with transient ST elevations an ECG.

question: An 84-year-old Caucasian male is brought to the ER with severe chest pain, dyspnea and diaphoresis. His past medical history is significant for a long history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, type 2. He experienced a severe myocardial infarction 6 months ago. His current medications are enalapril, metapralal, aspirin, furosemide, potassium, glyburide and pravastatin, but he says that he has not been taking some of his medications recently. Physical examination reveals acrocyanosis and symmetric 3+ lower extremity edema. Point of maximal apical impulse is displaced to the left, and a holosystolic [IV/VI] apical murmur is heard at the apex. Non-specific ST segment and T wave changes are present on ECG. The initial set of cardiac enzymes are positive. The patient continues to deteriorate, despite aggressive diuretic and vasodilator therapy. You perform an echocardiographic evaluation of left ventricular function and decide to proceed with pulmonary artery catheterization. Cardiac index (CI), total peripheral resistance (TPR) and left ventricular end-diastalic volume (LVEDV) are determined. Which af the following is most likely to present in this patient?
options: A. Cl decreased, TPR decreased, LVEDY decreased
B. Cl decreased, TPR increased, LVEDY decreased
C. Cl decreased, TPR increased, LVEDV increased
D. Cl decreased, TPR increased, LVEDVY normal
E. CI normal, TPR decreased, LVEDY increased
explanation:
The clinical scenario described is consistent with systolic heart failure. Non-compliance with the treatment regimen and acute myocardial damage are the precipitating factors for the acute distress observed in this patient.
It is important to know the basic pathophysiologic changes assaciated with heart failure. First, look at Cl, a measure of cardiac output - it is always decreased in systolic heart failure. Next, look at LVEDY - it should be elevated in systolic heart failure, although it may be normal in pure diastolic heart failure (choice D). TPR is elevated in systolic heart failure due to neurohumoral activation that includes sympathetic hyperactivity and activation of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.
Suboptimal left ventricular filling that may relatively reduce LVEDY can be due ta blood redistribution with low TFR (e.g., anaphylaxis) (choice A) or hypovolemia with elevated TPR (e.g., hemarrhage) (choice B).
Marmal CI, elevated LVEDY and LVEDP, and decreased TPR can be caused sometimes by high-output heart failure (choice E).
Educational Objective:
Systolic heart failure is characterized by depressed cardiac index (Cl) accompanied by increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) and left ventricular end-diastalic volume (LVEDV).

question:
A 42-year-old male with a past medical history of bladder cancer and recurrent hematuria presents ta the emergency room after "passing out" when he got out of bed this morning. The patient says that he was standing up to urinate shortly after waking when he began feeling dizzy. Fortunately he was able to return to his bed before losing consciousness for 7-10 minutes. His EKG at the time of admission is shown below:
Which of the following most likely accounts for the observed EKG changes?
explanation:
The above EKG demonstrates an irregular rhythm, with P waves preceding every QRS but with certain P waves not conducted. Closer examination reveals PR intervals that grow progressively longer between beats, leading up to a dropped beat. This pattern is consistent with second degree, Mabitz type I AV block (Wenckebach). Mobitz type I black is due to dysfunction at the AY node. Patients are generally asymptomatic, but in some cases the dropped beats cause hypoperfusion leading to syncope and/or angina.
(Choice A) Ventricular preexcitation usually results in premature ventricular complexes (PVCs).
(Choice B) Impaired SA node automaticity (sick sinus syndrome) mast often results from fibrosis of the sinus node ar disease of the SA nodal artery. Patients may present with bradycardia, lightheadedness, or syncope. On EKG, this often appears as tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome (bursts of atrial tachyarrhythmia followed by bradycardia).
(Choice D) Atrial reentry leads ta atrial tachycardia of abrupt onset and terminatian.
(Choice E) Bundle branch block occurs below the AY node and impedes ventricular depolarization. The result is a prolonged QRS complex.
Educational objective:
Second degree heart block is identified by prolongation of the PR interval with occasional dropped beats. In Mohitz type I, the PR interval gradually lengthens until a beat is dropped. In type II, the PR intervals are of constant length before the dropped beat. The prognosis is better for Mohitz type I, which is the result of AY node dysfunction.

question: A 65-year-old man comes to your office for a follow-up after his previous visits revealed inadequately controlled hypertension. He has no present complaints except difficulty walking uphill or climbing stairs, because of the pain in the right thigh, which makes him stop and rest. His past medical history includes stable angina, requiring caronary angioplasty and stenting 2 years ago; hypercholesteralemia; a 20-year history of hypertension; and a 10-year history of diabetes mellitus, type 2. His current medications are aspirin, metoprolol, hydrochlarothiazide, enalapril, amlodipine, pravastatin and glyburide. He smokes 1.5 packs of cigarettes per day and does not consume alcohal. His blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg in his right arm and 180/110 mmHg in his left arm. Which of the following findings will point ta the potential cause of the resistant hypertension in this patient?
options: A. Increased pulsation of intercostal arteries
B. Continuous murmur in the paraumbilical area to the right
C. Increased urinal excretion of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)
E. Increased 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion
explanation:
This clinical scenario demonstrates a patient with advanced atherosclerosis, having atherosclerotic lesions of multiple sites: Coronary atherosclerosis, intermittent claudication, a difference between right arm and left arm BP readings. He also has multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis, such as hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, smoking, and hypertension. Resistant hypertension in such a patient should make you suspect atherosclerotic narrowing of renal arteries. Continuous (systolic and diastalic) murmur in the periumbilical area, ar in the flanks, is characteristic of renal artery stenosis; the diastolic component makes this murmur more specific, compared to the systolic component alone. If you carefully auscultate the periumbilical area of such a patient with advanced atherosclerosis and resistant hypertension, you have a good chance ta arrive at a carrect diagnosis.
The increased pulsation of intercostal arteries (Choice A) is typical for coarctation of the aorta.
Urinary excretion of vanillylmandelic acid (Choice C) is increased in pheochromocytoma.
A high aldosterone/renin ratio (Choice D) is characteristic for primary hyperaldosteraonism.
An increased 24-hour urinal free cortisol excretion (Choice E) is observed in Cushing's syndrome.
Educational objective:
Renal artery stenosis is a common cause of resistant hypertension in a patient with advanced atherosclerosis. Carefully auscultate the periumbilical area of such a patient to reveal continuous (ar systalic with diastolic component) murmur characteristic of renal artery stenosis.

question:
A 65-year-old Hispanic male is brought to the emergency room with severe substernal chest pain and diaphoresis that began suddenly 1 hour ago. He reports that his pain started while he was at rest and radiates to his left shoulder. The patient notes having vomited twice when the pain first began. Despite administration of 2 baby aspirins and 3 tablets of sublingual nitroglycerin, the pain persists. His initial EKG is shown below.
On physical examination, the patient's temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 18/min. S1 and S2 are normal, and an S4 is heard. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no jugular venous distension or pedal edema. Interventions to achieve which of the following goals would most improve this patient's long-term prognosis?
explanation:
This patient is having an ST-elevation Ml in the inferiar distribution (leads II, ll, and aVF), likely secondary to an acclusive thrombus. His long-term prognosis is most influenced by the duration of time that lapses befare coranary blood flow is restored. The twa primary options for restaring coronary blood flow are percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (FTCA) and fibrinolysis. FTCA has been shown tao have superiar autcomes compared to fibrinalysis, and should therefore be the chosen reperfusion modality when available. Ideally, FTCA should be done with a "door-to-balloon” time of less than 90 minutes. When fibrinolytics are used, a "door-to-needle” time of 30 minutes is the goal.
(Choice A) Myocardial oxygen demand is determined by heart rate, preload, contractility, and afterload. Medications such as nitrates and beta-blockers affect these parameters and can be used to reduce myocardial oxygen demand. However, these treatments are more effective in angina as opposed to STEMI, as this patient cannot meet much myocardial oxygen demand since there is no coronary blood flow.
(Choice B) Decreasing blood coagulability with medications such as aspirin, clopidogrel, and/or heparin is part of the management of STEMI. However, these medications only stop the thrombus from progressing. In contrast, FTCA and fibrinolysis disrupt the thrombus that is occluding coranary blood flaw.
(Choice D) At ane time, lidocaine was recommended as prophylaxis against ischemia-related arrhythmias, but this is no longer the case. Arrhythmias should be treated only as they arise.
(Choice E) Reperfusion injury can occur after PTCA or fibrinolysis, potentially causing continued myocyte death. However, there are no medications currently available to inhibit this process, and the benefits of reperfusion far autweigh the consequences of reperfusion injury.
Educational objective:
The strongest influence on long-term pragnosis following an ST-elevation myocardial infarction is the duration af time that passes befare coronary blood flow is restored (via FTCA ar fibrinolysis).

question: A 43-year-old man is hospitalized with chest pain, lightheadedness and nausea. He describes the pain as dull and non-radiating. He has never had chest pain before, but does report occasional episodes of dyspnea and coughing. His medical history is significant for eczema. He is not presently taking any medications. His family history is significant for prostate cancer in his father and rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. He does not smoke or consume alcohal. The patient is admitted to the hospital and is given aspirin, low-maolecular weight heparin, metoprolol and captopril. On day 2 of his hospitalization he complains of shortness of breath. Physical examination reveals prolonged expirations and bilateral wheezes. There are no crackles. You estimate the jugular venous pressure to be 7 cm with the patient's head elevated at 45 degrees. Which af the following is most likely responsible for this patient's current respiratory symptoms?
explanation:
This patient was admitted to the hospital with chest pain concerning for acute caranary syndrome. Shortly after being started an several medications, he developed shortness of breath and prolonged expirations. While the differential diagnosis for dyspnea is broad, we can take several clues fram the vignette to point us toward the carrect diagnosis. First, the patient has a history of intermittent dyspnea and coughing. Given his histary of eczema, these symptoms may represent mild undiagnosed intermittent asthma.
Metoprolol is a competitive, beta1-selective adrenergic antaganist, but it can also block beta2 receptars in the bronchial tree. (This beta2 effect is mare prominent at higher doses.) In patients with reactive airway disease, beta2 blockade causes bronchaoconstriction with symptoms like wheezing, cough and prolonged expiration. Thus, while beta1-selective adrenergic blockers are preferred over nonselective agents in patients with asthma and COPD, even these agents should be used with caution as the above vignette demonstrates.
(Choice A) Post-infarction pericarditis is typically seen 2 to 5 days after a myocardial infarction. Autoimmune pericarditis is seen one to several weeks after an acute myocardial infarction or open-heart surgery.
(Choice B) Bronchitis is characterized by shortness of breath, productive cough and fever. This patient does not have fever or productive cough, making this diagnosis less likely.
(Choice C) Recurrent myocardial ischemia would likely manifest with pain, but symptoms like nausea and diaphoresis are sometimes the most prominent. Breathlessness due to acute heart failure can occur secondary to myocardial infarction. While wheezing may be present ("cardiac asthma"), crackles and elevated jugular venous pressure would also be expected.
(Choice D) Inferior wall infarctions may damage the right ventricle and present with hypotension and elevated venous pressure, but wheezing would not be expected.
(Choice E) Pleural effusions present with dullness on tharacic percussion, decreased breath sounds, and decreased movement of the ipsilateral chest wall.
(Choice F) Dyspnea, tachypnea and chest pain, but not wheezing, may be signs of a pulmonary embolism.
Educational objective:
Metoprolol is a selective beta1-adrenergic antagonist that, when administered in high doses, can block bronchodilatary beta2 adrenergic receptors causing bronchocanstriction in susceptible individuals.

question:
A 64-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with general malaise and a funny’ heart rhythm far the past 2 weeks. He had an echocardiogram done last year, which revealed mild left atrial dilatation and left ventricular hypertrophy. He has been taking hydrachlorothiazide for hypertension. His blood pressure at today's visit is 180/98 mm Hg. An EKG is obtained and is shown below.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment far this patient?
explanation:
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a cardiac arrhythmia characterized by lack of organized atrial activity. Hypertension is the mast comman cause. Other causes include valvular heart disease, myocardial infarction, heart failure, hyperthyroidism, and alcohol. AF is identified on EKG by absent P waves, an irregularly irregular rate, and a narrow CRS complex. This patient has AF with rapid ventricular response, as his heart rate is approximately 140 beats/minute. The treatment of AF depends on a number of factors, including whether the patient is hemodynamically stable and the length of time spent in AF. In patients wha are hemodynamically unstable (low BF, altered mental status), immediate cardioversion is indicated. If the patient is hemodynamically stable—as is the case in this vignette—then the duration of AF must be considered. If AF has been present for <=48 haurs, then electrical ar pharmacologic cardioversion is appropriate. If AF has been present >48 hours, there is a high risk of thromboembalism with cardioversion; such patients should be treated with rate control and 3-4 weeks of anticoagulation before cardioversion is attempted. Rate control is most often achieved with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers. Diltiazem, a calcium channel blocker, is the only rate-controlling agent listed above, and is the correct answer (Choice E).
(Choice A) Atrial fibrillation has been present for >48 hours in this stable patient, making immediate cardioversion inappropriate.
(Choice B) Lidocaine is a class Ib antiarrhythmic. It is used to treat ventricular tachycardia but not atrial arrhythmias.
(Choice C & D) Carotid massage and adenosine may be used to manage patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Carotid massage is a vagal maneuver that slows the heart rate and may terminate SVT. Adenosine works in SVT by causing transient AY nade blockade, which allows identification of the rhythm and terminates certain farms of SVT.
Educational objective:
Atrial fibrillation is identified an EKG by an irregularly irregular R-R interval with absent FP waves and narrow CRS complexes. In unstable patients, immediate cardioversion should be performed. In stable patients who have been in atrial fibrillation (AF) <48 hours, cardioversion is appropriate. In stable patients in AF >=48 haurs, 3-4 weeks of rate control and anticoagulation should precede cardioversion.

question: A 53-year-old Caucasian male is admitted to the hospital with a 2-week history of fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. He says he can hardly climb two flights of stairs without getting dyspneic. He denies palpitations or chest pain. His past medical history is insignificant, and a routine check-up 6 months ago was normal. He admits two episodes of binge drinking during the last month, but says that he 'got it under control". He is currently not taking any medications. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and heart rate is 130/min, irregular. Lungs are clear on auscultation. ECG does not reveal P waves. Echocardiography shows significant left ventricular dilation with an ejection fraction of 35% and mitral regurgitation (1+). Which of the following intervention will most likely improve the left ventricular function in this patient?
explanation:
Prolonged, tachysystalic atrial fibrillation causes significant left ventricular (LV) dilation and a depressed ejection fraction. LV dysfunction results from tachycardia, neurohumoral activation, absence of an atrial ‘kick’ (that accounts for up to 25% of LY end-diastolic valume]), and atrial-ventricular desynchronization. Controlling the rhythm in such patients usually improves the LV function significantly {sometimes even dramatically!}.
(Choice F) Although an underlying disorder like alcoholic cardiomyopathy ar coronary artery disease may account for LY dysfunction in this patient, rhythm control seems ta be the most effective tool in impraving this patient's condition.
(Choice A, B and D) Freload optimization, decreasing afterload, and inotropic support are less urgent in this case and would be less beneficial without first controlling the rhythm or rate.
(Choice E) Slight mitral regurgitation is a secondary event explained by LV dilation.
Educational Objective:
Controlling the rhythm ar rate in patients with prolonged tachysystolic atrial fibrillation usually improves the LV function significantly, sometimes even dramatically.

question: A 64-year-old male is admitted in ICU for acute myocardial infarction. He is on metoprolol, lisinopril, aspirin, furosemide, and potassium supplements. All of a sudden, the nurse mentions that the patient has a change in his tele monitoring. His blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg. His potassium level is 4.2. He is alert, awake and oriented time, place and person. Examination shows scattered bilateral crackles, peripheral pedal edema and elevated JVD. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
The abave patient has developed ventricular tachycardia (regular, wide complex tachycardia) but there is no hemodynamic compromise. The patient is alert, awake and oriented ta time, place and person and his potassium level is within normal limits; his BP is stable. The cause of the ventricular tachycardia is due to coranary artery disease. The best treatment for a patient with ventricular tachycardia who has no hemodynamic compromise Is loading with either lidocaine or amiodarone. Either of these 2 agents will aid in the conversion to narmal sinus rhythm. However, amiodarone has become the drug of choice (Choice A).
(Choice B) In the presence of a ventricular tachycardia, digitalis should never be administered as the arrhythmia can worsen. Digoxin is anly used to treat atrial arrhythmias.
(Choice C) Cardioversian is an excellent aption for sustained ventricular tachycardia with hemadynamic compromise. The above patient has a stable blood pressure and cardioversion is not indicated. However, the electrode pads should be placed an the anterior and posterior chest walls in case the tachycardia does not revert back to normal sinus rhythm.
(Choice D) IV Cardizem should not be used for ventricular arrhythmia. It is indicated only for atrial arrhythmias.
(Choice E) Carotid massage is useful for supraventricular tachycardia (narrow complex) nat for ventricular tachycardia. It has na rale in the management of ventricular tachycardia.
Educational objective:
“entricular tachycardia in the presence of a stable blood pressure does nat warrant cardioversion. The best treatment is loading with lidocaine ar amiodarone (drug of choice).

question: A 48-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office complaining of progressive exertional dyspnea. It has become especially bothersome over the past two months. Presently, he becomes short of breath after climbing one flight of stairs. He denies any significant problems in the past. He is not taking any medications and he denies smoking or drinking alcohol. His temperature is 37.2C (98.9F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 130/75 mm of Hg and respirations are 14/min. Chest examination reveals a harsh systalic murmur that is best heard at the right second intercostal space with radiation along the carotid arteries. An S4 is heard at the apex. Based on these findings, what is the mast likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
explanation:
This patient appears to be suffering from congestive heart failure as a consequence of aortic stenosis. A harsh systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border with radiation to the caratid arteries is a classic description of the murmur caused by aortic stenasis. The S4 occurs as the result of left atrial kick against a stiff left ventricle. In aortic stenosis, the high resistance generated by the stenosed aartic valve causes concentric hypertrophy and stiffening of the left ventricle, resulting in the S4. The three most common causes or aortic stenosis in the general population are senile calcific aortic stenosis, bicuspid aartic valve, and rheumatic heart disease. The most impartant hint to the underlying etiology of this patient's aortic stenosis is his relatively young age. A bicuspid aortic valve is the cause of aortic stenosis in the majority of patients under 70 years old, so this is the most likely cause of this patient's aortic stenosis.
(Choice A) The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can be easily confused with that of aortic stenosis. Both entities can cause a systalic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and an S4. However, the murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is usually best appreciated in the lower left sternal border and it does not typically radiate ta the carotids.
(Choice B) Myxomatous valve degeneration is the typical pathologic entity that causes mitral valve prolapse.
(Choice C) As mentioned above, rheumatic heart disease can be a cause of aortic stenosis. However itis a much less common cause than either senile calcific aortic stenasis or a bicuspid aortic valve.
(Choice E) Senile calcific aortic stenosis is the most common cause of aortic stenosis in patients who are alder than 70 years old. As people age, the aortic valve can accumulate calcium, causing stenosis.
Educational objective:
The three most common causes of aortic stenosis in the general population are senile calcific aortic stenosis, bicuspid aortic valve, and rheumatic heart disease. A bicuspid aortic valve is the cause of aortic stenosis in the majority of patients under 70 years old.

question: A 47-year-old Caucasian female presents with occasional episodes of nocturnal substernal chest pain that wakes her up during sleep. The pain episodes last 15-20 minutes and resolve spontaneously. She denies any illicit drug use. She leads a sedentary lifestyle but states that she can climb twa flights of stairs without any discomfort. She has no history of hypertension or diabetes. Her pulse is 75/min and regular, blood pressure is 134/70 mmHg and respirations are 14/min. Extended ambulatory ECG monitoring reveals transient ST segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V4-V6 during the episodes. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
explanation:
This patient has variant angina (ar Prinzmetal’s angina), which causes chest pain by coronary vasospasm. It typically occurs in young females, and the greatest risk factor for variant angina is smoking. Aside from smoking, affected patients often lack cardiovascular risk factors. The episodes characteristically occur at night (fram midnight to 8 am) and can be associated with transient ST elevations an ECG. The treatment of this condition invalves elimination of risk factors such as smoking, as well as pharmacologic therapy with calcium channel blockers ar nitrates. These medications work in variant angina by promoting vasodilation and preventing vasocanstriction.
(Choice B) Monselective B-Blockers such as propranolol should be avoided in variant angina because B2 receptor inhibition can lead to worsened coronary vasospasm.
(Choice C) Aspirin should also be avoided in variant angina because it causes prostacyclin inhibition, which may promote coronary vasospasm.
(Choices D & F) Patients with variant angina often lack cardiovascular risk factors such as hyperchalesteralemia. Inthe absence of lipid abnormalities, variant angina management does not entail cholesterol lowering medications. If this patient's lipids were found to be abnormal on a screening test, then lipid-lowering medications could be considered.
(Choice E) Digoxin is typically used to increase contractility in patients with congestive heart failure or as a rate control agent in patients with atrial fibrillation or flutter, none of which are a problem for this patient.
(Choice G) Heparin is an anticoagulant. Vasospasm—and not the coagulation cascade—is the cause of variant angina. Heparin plays no role in the management of uncomplicated variant angina.
(Choice H) Streptokinase is used for thrombolysis in the treatment of a STEMI if percutaneous caranary intervention is nat rapidly available. However, this patient's presentation is more consistent with variant angina than myocardial infarction.
Educational objective:
Pharmacologic management of variant angina invalves calcium channel blockers and/or nitrates to prevent coranary vasoconstriction. Monselective B-Blackers and aspirin should be avoided because they can promote vasocanstriction.

question: A 36-year-old male patient, who has a history of Marfan's syndrome, presents with sudden onset of severe central tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is 9/10 in severity and is unrelated to exertion. He denies any history of alcohol or tobacco use. Measurement of his BP shows a difference of 35 mm Hg between his two arms. Chest auscultation reveals clear lung sounds and a mid-systolic click. What is the mast appropriate next diagnostic step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
This patient is most likely suffering fram acute aortic dissection, for which transesophageal echocardiography ar computed tomagraphy of the chest are the diagnostic studies of choice. The collagen abnormalities of Marfan's syndrome predispose patients to both aortic dissection and mitral valve prolapse (as evidenced by the mid-systaolic click on the patient's cardiac exam). Tearing pain with radiation to the back and a difference in BF of greater than 30 mm Hg between the twa arms are important clinical clues to the presence af aartic dissection.
(Choice B) TEE, CT and MRI are much mare sensitive than TTE for the diagnosis of aortic dissection. The distal ascending, transverse and descending aorta cannot be adequately visualized with TTE.
(Choice C) Cardiac enzymes are crucial to the diagnosis of myocardial infarction, and it is reasonable to draw them on almost any patient with chest pain. However, this patient's age, symptoms and history of Marfan's make aortic dissection mare likely than myocardial infarction (MI). Therefore, TEE is the most appropriate next step.
(Choice D) Coronary angiography is typically performed as quickly as possible in patients with an ST elevation MI and within the first 48 hours in patients with unstable Angina/NSTEMI. As discussed above, Ml is not the most likely diagnosis in this patient. Even if there were a high suspicion far MI, ECG and cardiac enzymes should precede caronary angiography.
(Choice E) A ventilation/perfusion scan is indicated when pulmanary embolism is suspected. Pulmonary embolism (PE) belongs in the differential for life threatening causes of chest pain. However, the chest pain of PE is typically pleuritic in nature; tearing pain with radiation to the back and a BF differential between the arms is far mare suggestive of aortic dissection.
Educational objective:
Tearing pain with radiation to the back and a difference in BF of greater than 30 mm Hg between the arms are impartant clinical clues for aortic dissection. Transesophageal echocardiography or CT with contrast are the two diagnostic studies of choice for suspected aortic dissection.

question: A 55-year-old male presents to your office with a 6-month history of periodic substernal pressure. He experiences this pressure while walking uphill or climbing twa flights of stairs. His past medical history is insignificant. He smokes 1 pack a day and consumes alcohol occasionally. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg and heart rate is 75/min. Resting ECG is normal. You suspect stable angina and order an ECG stress test that reveals horizontal ST segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF at submaximal heart rate. What is the best medication to treat this patient's condition?
explanation:
This patient presents with typical exertional angina canfirmed with ECG stress testing. Another impartant finding in this patient is hypertension. A beta-blocker is probably the best initial treatment for this patient, because it would increase the threshold far the development of an anginal episode and control the hypertension. Besides that, it is believed that beta-blockers are cardioprotective; they can potentially reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events and arrhythmic episodes by decreasing the sympathetic output to the heart.
Calcium antagonists (Choices B and C) are considered if beta-blockers are contraindicated or poorly tolerated.
Nitrates (Choice A) can cantrol anginal episodes, but they are nat good antihypertensive agents. If the effect af a beta-blocker is not satisfactory, a nitrate can be added ta the regimen.
Enalapril (Choice E) is an antihypertensive agent without anti-anginal activity. There is some evidence that ACE inhibitors may decrease the risk of major cardiovascular events in patients with ischemic heart disease not anly by lowering blood pressure, but also affecting the development of atherosclerotic plague, but this evidence is controversial.
Educational Objective:
In patients who present with stable angina and hypertension, a beta-blocker is the drug of choice.

question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of dyspnea, fatigue, poor appetite and weight gain aver the past several weeks. He says that about four weeks ago he began to develop worsening shortness of breath with exertion and mare recently has been waking at night with breathlessness. He also notes that it is sometimes difficult for him to open his eyes in the morning due to facial edema. He has no significant past medical history and he takes no medications. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 200/120 mmHg and his heart rate is 100/min. You note generalized bodily edema and distention of his jugular veins while he is sitting upright. On lung auscultation you hear bibasilar rales. Urinalysis shows trace protein, no nitrites, trace leukocyte esterase, 50+ red blood cells and occasional neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
explanation:
Peripheral edema can result fram a number of etiologies including argan failure (cardiac, hepatic, ar renal}, hypoalbuminemia (secondary to nephrotic syndrome, malnutrition, ar liver disease), and venous insufficiency. The patient described above has anasarca, or generalized edema, characterized by pulmanary edema and ascites in addition to swollen extremities. Organ failure and/or hypoalbuminemia are potential causes of anasarca. Based on the information presented in the vignette, acute glomerulonephritis appears to be the unifying diagnosis here. In glomerulonephritis, edema results from glomerular damage and a decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
In glamerulonephritis, the urine sediment will reveal red blood cells, red blood cell casts, and might contain white blood cells and protein as well. Patients may have significant proteinuria, which contributes to their edema. (This patient has anly trace protein on his urinalysis meaning that the majarity of his edema is secondary to a decreased GFR) Decreased GFR is the cause of edema in patients with end-stage renal disease as well.
(Choice A) Renal hypoperfusion can occur in heart failure (decreased cardiac output), which in turn promotes increased renal sodium reabsorption and edema. Urinalysis would not show significant red blood cells ar casts.
(Choice B) Hypoalbuminemia can result from excessive albumin loss (as in nephratic syndrome) or decreased albumin synthesis (as in cirrhosis ar severe malnutrition). While this patient clearly has renal disease, he does not have significant proteinuria to explain his presentation.
(Choice D) Cirrhosis can cause portal hypertension as the scarred liver limits blood flow through the sinusoidal network. Patients with cirrhosis typically have ascites out of propartion to edema in other tissues, plus other signs of chranic liver disease like spider angiomata, palmar erythema, and caput medusa.
(Choice E) While hypothyroidism can cause pretibial edema, it is not a commaon cause of anasarca.
(Choice F) Right ventricular failure {often a consequence of left ventricular failure) is a frequent cause of peripheral edema. It manifests with an elevated jugular venous pressure, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, and peripheral edema. Of nate, isolated right ventricular failure will not cause pulmonary edema because it does not cause blood to pool in the pulmanary capillary beds.
Educational objective:
Anasarca typically results from organ failure ar hypoalbuminemia. In patients with glomerulonephritis, edema results from the decreased glomerular filtration rate as well as proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia in some Cases.

question: A 45-year-old white male presents to the ER after an episode of syncope. His medical history is unremarkable except far an upper respiratory infection ane week ago. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and respirations are 13/min. His neck veins are distended and his heart sounds are distant. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Chest x-ray reveals small bilateral pleural effusions and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Which of the following EKG findings is fairly specific for his condition?
options: E. Mew-onset right bundle branch black
explanation:
This patient has a pericardial effusion, which often causes electrical alternans on EKG. His recent upper respiratory infection is a clue towards the diagnosis, as pericardial effusions are often secondary to viral pericarditis. Accompanying pleural effusions may be found as well.
Electrical alternans describes QRS complexes whose amplitudes vary from beat to beat on EKG. tis thought to result fram the heart's swinging back and forth within an increased quantity of pericardial fluid. Jugular venous distention, muffled heart sounds and borderline blood pressure indicate developing cardiac tamponade. Echocardiography can confirm the presence of pericardial effusion.
(Choice A) The PR’ interval is prolonged in first degree heart block, a condition that is usually asymptomatic and requires na treatment.
(Choice B) The presence of 'F' waves, ar flutter waves, is diagnastic of atrial flutter. Jugular venous distention and hypotension can develop if the heart rate is rapid enough, but this patient's rate is only 90.
(Choice D) A ‘delta’ wave is an upsloping just before the QRS complex that occurs in patients with an accessory conduction pathway, like in Walf-Parkinsan-VWhite syndrome. It is not associated with pericardial effusion.
(Choice E) Mew-onset right bundle branch block can sometimes be seen in pulmonary embolism. Pulmanary embali usually cause tachypnea and/or tachycardia.
Explanation:
Electrical alternans is when the amplitudes of the QRS complexes vary from beat to beat. It is fairly specific far pericardial effusion. Enlargement of the cardiac silhouette can be seen an chest x-ray as well. Echocardiogram can more definitely demanstrate a pericardial effusion.

question: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. He describes waking up during the night with difficulty breathing and chest pain that kept him from falling back to sleep. He has never had these symptoms befare. His past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and non-compliance with his antihypertensive therapy. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 120/min and regular. Lung auscultation reveals bibasilar rales and scattered wheezes. Which of the following is most likely ta relieve this patient's dyspnea?
explanation:
This patient presents with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea in the setting of long-standing hypertension and a pulmanary exam cancerning for cardiogenic pulmonary edema. He has likely developed diastolic dysfunction (impaired ventricular relaxation) fram his long-standing hypertensian and is now in left ventricular failure. Mitroglycerin (MTG), either IV, sublingual, or topical, relieves the dyspnea and tachycardia associated with cardiogenic pulmanary edema by rapidly reducing preload. Several studies have suggested that it warks quicker than marphine ar loop diuretics. NTG is not part of the long-term management for patients with heart failure but can be beneficial in acutely alleviating symptoms. It should be used cautiously in patients with hypotension. Beyond NTG, loop diuretics are the mainstay of therapy for decompensated heart failure and principally wark by reducing total body volume.
(Choice A) Beta-blockers are tremendously efficacious in treating chronic heart failure, and have been shown to significantly improve long-term morbidity and mortality in affected patients. However, beta-blockers are negative inotropes and may acutely worsen heart failure symptoms.
(Choice B) Hydralazine given in combination with an aral nitrate has proven efficacy for treating African American men with heart failure. However, hydralazine given alone will not alleviate symptoms as quickly as NTG.
(Choice C) Salmeterol is a long-acting B2-adrenergic agonist used in the chronic treatment of asthma and bronchodilator-responsive COPD. Because it has a slow onset, salmeterol is not beneficial in the treatment af asthma or COPD exacerbations. Regardless, this patient's wheezing is due to pulmonary edema, not asthma, sa salmeteral is not the appropriate therapy here.
(Choice D) At moderate doses (3-10 mcg/kg/min), dopamine stimulates myocardial B-receptors and increases myocardial contractility. However, at these doses, dopamine is also arrhythmogenic and may worsen heart failure.
(Choice E) Amiodarone can be used to treat atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia in patients with heart failure but it is not a treatment for pulmonary edema.
(Choice F) Verapamil can be used far rate contral in atrial fibrillation and to improve diastolic relaxation in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. However, it is also a negative inotrape and may acutely worsen heart failure symptoms.
(Choice G) Aminophylline is a bronchodilator used ta treat asthma and COPD. It is not typically recommended in heart failure.
Educational objective:
Cardiogenic pulmanary edema results from left heart failure and is characterized by crackles on pulmonary exam. Mitroglycerin is the most rapidly acting medication ta relieve the symptoms of pulmonary edema.

question:
A 34-year-old female presents to the ER with difficulty breathing and dizziness. Blood pressure tracing fram an arterial line placed in the ER is depicted below.
Inspiration
Which of the following best accounts for these findings?
explanation:
In an arterial pressure diagram, the peaks correspond to systolic pressures and the valleys to diastolic pressures. We can see that in this patient, the diastolic pressure remains relatively constant throughout the tracing, but systolic pressures drop substantially with each inspiration. Some drop in systalic pressure (<=10 mm Hg) during inspiration is normal. This physiologic drop is the result of increased venous return ta the right heart during inspiration, which impedes left ventricular filling and thus causes a drap in systalic pressure. Pulsus paradoxus is the term far an abnormally large drop in systolic blood pressure (>=12 mm Hg) with inspiration. Itis seen in some forms of cardiac disease (tamponade, pericardial effusion) and pulmanary disease (tension pneumatharax, severe asthma). In asthma, significantly elevated intrathoracic pressures during inhalation are thought to exacerbate compression of the left ventricle, causing pulsus paradoxus.
(Choice B to E) None of these conditions typically cause pulsus paradoxus.
Educational objective:
Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a difference in systolic blood pressure of >=12 mm Hg during inspiration. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumotharax, and severe asthma.

question:
A 43-year-old man complains of progressive weakness and shortness af breath over the last two weeks. He denies any chest or muscle pain, nausea, vomiting or weight loss. He had a recent upper respiratory tract infection. His heart rate is 90/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Jugular venous pressure is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. His chest x-ray is shown below.
Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
options: B. Non-palpable point of maximal impulse
E. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound
explanation:
This patient has a pericardial effusion without evidence of cardiac tamponade. On chest x-ray, a large pericardial effusion may appear as an enlarged, globular-appearing cardiac shadow (the characteristic "water bottle" heart shape), as seen an this patient's chest x-ray. Due to the increased fluid in the pericardial space, physical exam will reveal distant heart sounds and a non-palpable pulse at the cardiac apex or paint of maximal impulse.
It is important to recognize that this patient does nat have cardiac tamponade. Tamponade presents as hypotension, right heart failure (distended jugular veins), and tachycardia. Fulsus paradoxus may be present. The therapy for cardiac tamponade is vigorous volume resuscitation and pericardiocentesis.
(Choice A) &n audible fourth heart sound is heard in normal, young patients and in people with left ventricular hypertrophy. This patient's chest x-ray is more cansistent with a pericardial effusion than left ventricular hypertrophy, which often appears as a "boot-shaped" cardiac shadow on x-ray.
(Choice C) Pulsus bisferiens, ar biphasic pulse, refers to two strong systolic impulses with a midsystalic dip. It can be seen in aortic regurgitation with or without aortic stenosis and in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.
(Choice D) An opening snap is heard with mitral stenosis. Significant mitral stenosis will cause left atrial enlargement. This will be seen on chest x-ray as a straightening of the left part of the cardiac silhouette {as apposed to the normal mild concavity visible below the pulmanary artery shadow). Enlargement of the entire cardiac silhouette would not be seen.
(Choice E) Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is associated with atrial septal defects.
(Choice F) Intermittent ptosis wauld be seen if this patient had myasthenia gravis in assaciation with thymoma. These tumars present as anterior mediastinal masses on chest x-ray with preserved cardiac size. This chest x-ray is not consistent with a thymoma.
Educational Objective:
Pericardial effusions will appear as an enlarged, "water bottle" shaped cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray. Physical exam findings of pericardial effusions without cardiac tamponade include diminished heart sounds on auscultation and a difficult to palpate point of maximal impulse.

question: A 66-year-ald white male presents to his primary care physician for follow-up evaluation of high blood pressure noted on each of three prior visits over a period of 6 months (systolic blood pressure ranging 140-145, diastolic blood pressure ranging 90-96 mm Hg). He has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years and takes 5-8 drinks of alcohol daily. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications. There is no family history of diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia ar hypertension. On physical examination today, his blood pressure is 146/97 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. Which of the following nonpharmacaologic interventions would be expected to have the greatest impact on his high blood pressure?
options: B. Increased consumption of complex carbohydrates
E. Decreased consumption of animal protein
explanation:
This patient has had multiple blood pressure readings greater than 140/90 aver a period of manths, and therefore meets the criteria for stage I hypertension. In such patients, it is reasonable ta enact a trial of lifestyle madifications to reduce blood pressure before resorting to medications. The most effective lifestyle intervention for reducing blood pressure is decreased consumption of alcohol. It is recommended that males consume less than 2 drinks daily, and women less than 1.
(Choice A) There is no question that smoking cessation reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease in patients with hypertension. However, in terms of improving hypertension itself, abstinence from alcohal has a greater effect.
(Choice B) Diets rich in fruits, vegetables, and whale grains have been shown to aid weight loss and may therefare indirectly help lower blood pressure. Decreasing alcohal consumption would be expected to have a mare dramatic effect, however.
(Choice C) Patients with a low dietary intake of calcium do have a higher risk of developing hypertension, but qiving these patients calcium supplements has not been shawn to substantially impact blood pressure.
(Choice E) Vegetarians tend to have less hypertension than meat-eaters, but there is not strong data to suggest that eliminating animal protein from the diet is an effective means of controlling hypertension.
Educational objective:
Lifestyle modification should be the first-line intervention for newly diagnosed stage 1 hypertension. Reduction of alcohol and sodium intake, weight loss, and aerobic exercise can all decrease blood pressure. Quitting smoking will decrease a patient's risk of cardiovascular disease, but does nat improve blood pressure itself.

question:
A 55-year-old male is admitted to the ICU after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. He requires exploratory laparotomy for suspected bowel perforation. Two days after the surgery he remains hypotensive and requires bath aggressive intravenous fluids and vasopressors to maintain his blood pressure. On physical examination, you note the fingertip changes pictured below:
All four extremities feel cold to touch. Which of the following is most likely responsible?
explanation:
This patient's coal, dusky fingertips are the result of norepinephrine-induced vasospasm. Morepinephrine has alpha-1 agonist properties which cause vasoconstriction; this property is useful when trying to increase the blood pressure of hypotensive patients. However, in some patients with decreased blood flaw, vasocanstriction can result in ischemia and necrasis of the distal fingers and toes. A similar phenomenan can occur in the intestines (resulting in mesenteric ischemia) or kidney (causing renal failure).
(Choice A) Endocarditis can spread septic embali throughout the body, but would not be expected to affect all fingers.
(Choice B) Raynaud's phenomenon is a cause of finger ischemia that typically progresses from pallor to cyanosis to erythema. It can be accompanied by pain and is usually due to cold exposure ar stress. The duskiness of the fingers pictured above, hawever is more suggestive of ischemia.
(Choice D) Cholesterol embali can occur in patients with atherosclerosis and can affect the distal portions of the digits, thus its occasional name "blue toe syndrome " However, symmetrical involvement of all digits would be unusual.
(Choice E) Superior vena cava syndrome occurs in patients with lung cancer, thrombi, ar fibrosing mediastinitis and can cause upper extremity edema. However, arterial flow is preserved and so ischemia does not occur.
Educational objective:
Fressaors such as norepinephrine can cause ischemia of the distal fingers and toes secondary to vasospasm. The diagnosis is suggested by symmetric duskiness and coolness af all fingertips.

question: A 14-year-old African American male collapses and dies while playing basketball at a school tournament. He has no known past medical histary. Which of the following is the mast likely underlying disease in this patient?
explanation:
Sudden cardiac death in a young individual, especially during exertion, is most common with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is mare camman in African-Americans than whites. Mast of the patients who die suddenly from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy have had no prior symptoms. Ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation can occur in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The generation of these arrhythmias is multifactorial, but all derive from the underlying abnormality of abnormal myocytes and myocardial scarring. Death can also occur in these patients fram heart failure and stroke as well, but these would be unlikely to cause such a sudden death.
(Answer B) Coronary atherosclerosis can lead to myocardial infarction, which can produce the sudden anset af ventricular arrhythmias resulting in death. However, the extremely young age and lack of any significant past medical history make this unlikely for this patient.
(Answer C) Aartic aneurysms in a patient of this age are rare. In the general population, they are usually due to atherosclerosis, which this patient would be unlikely to have.
(Answer D) Ventricular septal defects are often a congenital disorder and would be possible in this patient. However, they are not a cause of sudden death. If the patient were ta die from complications of a ventricular septal defect, he would likely have some symptoms beforehand.
(Answer E) A bicuspid aorta is a congenital condition that can lead to aortic stenosis. However, patients typically have symptoms of the condition and they usually develop at a later age. Bicuspid aortic valve would therefore be an unlikely cause of sudden death in this patient.
Educational objective:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can lead to ventricular arrhythmias, and should be suspected in a sudden death af an atherwise healthy young individual.

question: A 63-year-old female presents to your office for a routine check-up. She has no present complaints. Her past medical history includes DM, type 2, and hypertension. Her current medications include glyburide and atenolol. She does not smake. She drinks 2-3 glasses of wine 1-2 times a week. Three consecutive BP measurements were in the range of 138-142/87-90 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits. Her recent fasting glucose level was 250 mg/dL. ECG recorded 1 month ago showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Which statement about the BP control in this patient is the most accurate?
options: A. BP is within acceptable range
B. BP is within optimal range
C. It is better to keep systolic pressure less than 130 mmHg to slow end-organ damage
D. Diastolic BF is within acceptable range, but systolic is not
E. Systolic BP is within acceptable range, but diastolic is not
explanation:
Traditionally a goal, blood pressure is considered to be below 140/90 mmHg. But it is recently recognized that BP needs more tight contral in diabetics and patients with chranic renal failure. These two groups of patients are especially sensitive to high BP, that's why the values of systolic BF for these patients should be kept lower than 130 mmHg and diastolic BF lower than 80 mmHg to prevent end argan damage.
Blood pressure could be considered in acceptable range (Choice A) if the patient was not diabetic. According to JNC-7 report (JNC stands far Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure) BF is considered optimal when it is below 120/80 mmHg (Choice B) In this patient both systolic (Choice E) and diastolic (Choice D) BFP are above the goal values.
Educational objective:
It is better to keep systolic pressure <= 130 mmHg to slow end-organ damage in patients with diabetes and chronic renal failure.

question: A 70-year-old patient presents ta the ER with a 3-hour history of intensive retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the interscapular area. He states that he has never experienced this pain before. His past medical history is significant for a 20-year history of hypertension and a 10-year histary of diabetes mellitus, type 2. His current medications include enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He does not smoke ar consume alcohol. His vital signs are: BP 180/110 mm Hg in the right arm and 178/110 mm Hg in the left arm, PR 85/min and RR 18/min. The physical examination revealed an early decrescendo-type diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. The EKG is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
options: D. CK. MB and troponin T levels
explanation:
The patient described in this scenario mast probably has aartic dissection. Intensive retrosternal pain that radiates to the back of the chest, along with a normal EKG strongly suggests aartic dissection. Another important clue is the presence of the early diastolic murmur, characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Dissection af the ascending aorta may lead to acute aortic regurgitation. Hypertension is an impartant risk factor and blood pressure should be measured in both arms (there may be a difference in inter-arm blood pressure readings due to dissection). Although an aortogram was recommended as the most reliable diagnostic toal in diagnosing aortic dissection a decade ago (Choice C) non-invasive methods have gained popularity more recently. The sensitivity and specificity of the MRI, CT and transesophageal echocardiography in diagnosing aartic dissection exceeds 90%. Transesophageal echocardiography is usually preferred to an MRI (Choice A) because the latter is time-consuming.
Cardiac troponins (Choice D) are the markers of myocardial injury. They are used in patients with acute coronary syndromes. This patient has no EKG changes, and the pain is not typical of acute coronary syndrome.
Yentilation/perfusion scanning (Choice E) is used in patients with suspected thromboembolism of the pulmonary artery. In that case, the patient would also be tachypneic, tachycardic and hypotensive.
Educational Objective:
Suspect aortic dissection in a patient with acute retrosternal pain and a narmal EKG. Check blood pressure in both arms and auscultate for diastolic murmur of aortic regurgitation. Transesophageal echocardiography is the preferred diagnostic tool. Before performing the TEE, HTN should be controlled.

question: A 46-year-old man complains of exertional dyspnea and dry cough. He also describes occasional episodes af a suffocating nighttime cough that is relieved only when he stands up. His medical histary is significant for a myocardial infarction six months ago. His current medications are metoprolol, aspirin and simvastatin. He does not use tobacco but drinks alcohol on social occasions. His father died of a stroke and his mother suffers fram diabetes mellitus. His blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 60/min. Chest examination reveals bibasilar rales. His cardiac apex is palpated in the sixth intercostal space. The liver span is 12 cm. Bilateral pitting leg edema is also present. Which of the following most likely contributes to his edema?
options: A. Constriction of the renal arterioles
B. High sodium delivery to the distal tubule
explanation:
This patient has ischemic heart disease, cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, elevated venous pressure, and peripheral edema, all findings cansistent with a diagnosis of congestive heart failure (CHF). In heart failure, there is a decrease in the effective circulating blood volume, leading to renal hypoperfusion. Due to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, the kidney's arterioles constrict (both afferent and efferent) and sodium reabsarption is enhanced. These changes increase water retention and elevate the total body volume, further exacerbating the CHF.
(Choice B) In CHF, there is a decrease in sodium delivery to the distal tubule due to both decreased renal perfusion and increased sodium retention mare proximally in the kidney.
(Choice C) In CHF, renal perfusion is decreased, nat increased.
(Choice D) Sodium is the principle electralyte responsible far edema. Potassium does not play a significant rale in the development of edema.
(Choice E) Fartal hypertension is the hallmark of cirrhosis. This patient does not have significant risk factors far cirrhosis (e.g. alcoholism, hepatitis C) and does not have other stigmata of chronic liver disease like spider angiomata, palmar erythema, or caput medusa.
(Choice F) Hypoalbuminemia is the leading cause of decreased plasma calloid pressure. Low serum albumin concentrations typically result from nephratic range proteinuria ar poar albumin synthesis. This patient's presentation is mare cansistent with congestive heart failure than hypoalbuminemia.
Educational objective:
Edema in congestive heart failure is due to both mechanical impedance to fluid remaval and increased renal sodium retention.

question: A 22-year-old white female is brought to your office by her mather because of the recurrent syncopal episodes. The first episode occurred about one year ago when her roommate committed suicide and then several similar episodes occurred usually provaked by a strong emation. The episodes are preceded by lightheadedness, weakness, and blurred vision and last about three minutes with rapid recovery of consciousness. Past medical history is insignificant. She is not taking any medications and denies drug abuse. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg while supine and 108/70 mmHg while standing. Physical findings are within normal limits. EKG performed ane month ago was narmal. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
The most probable cause of this patient's episodes is vasovagal syncope (common faint). This is also known as neurally mediated or neurocardiogenic syncope. The clinical scenario described is very typical far this condition including prodrome (lightheadedness, weakness, and blurred vision), provacation by an emational situation, and rapid recovery of consciousness. Vasovagal syncope is frequently recurrent. In this case, upright tilt table testing with or without pharmacologic provocation (isoproterenal) may be indicated to confirm the diagnosis.
24-hour manitaring (Choice B) or invasive electraphysialogic testing (Choice D) are indicated when arrhythmia is suspected as a cause of syncope. This is usually the case in patients with caranary artery disease and underlying cardiac disease.
Echocardiography (Choice A) can confirm the diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyapathy or acquired valvular defects. Generally, if history and physical examination are not indicative of a cardiac disease, the probability af cardiogenic syncope is low.
EEG (Choice C) is used when seizure is suspected as a cause of syncope. The scenario described is not characteristic for seizure, e.g, presyncopal prodrome and rapid recovery of consciousness.
Educational Objective:
“Yasavangal syncope is the mast common cause of syncope. It is frequently recurrent. Upright tilt table testing may be indicated to confirm the diagnasis if the syncope is recurrent.

question: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a three day history of fever, cough and weakness. His blood pressure is 120/80mmHg and his heart rate is 110/min. Physical examination reveals multiple needle tracks an his arms. ECG shows sinus tachycardia but is otherwise normal. Chest X-ray shows scattered round lesions in the peripheral lung fields bilaterally. Urinalysis is positive for 2+ protein. Which of the following accompanying findings is most likely in this patient?
options: A. S4 when patient is in the left lateral decubitus pasition
B. Systolic murmur that increases on inspiration
C. Diastolic murmur heard best with the patient sitting up
D. Systolic murmur that increases when the patient stands up
explanation:
This patient has bacterial endocarditis affecting the tricuspid valve based an the following evidence: He has fever, weakness, and cough; there is physical exam evidence of intravenous drug abuse; and his chest X-ray is concerning for septic embali from the tricuspid valve. Septic pulmanary embali typically cause cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis and produce numerous round alvealar infiltrates on chest X-ray. This patient's proteinuria is likely the result of septic emboli to the kidneys or immune-complex deposition. IV drug users are at increased risk for bacterial endocarditis invalving the right-sided heart valves. Tricuspid regurgitation is comman in individuals with endocarditis of the tricuspid valve, and causes a systalic murmur that increases an inspiration.
(Choice A) A fourth heart sound (S4) audible with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position is suggestive af hypertensive cardiomyopathy. An audible S4 can be a normal finding in children and young adults.
(Choice C) Aortic regurgitation produces a diastolic murmur that is best heard when the patient sits up. While the aortic valve is a comman site of infective endocarditis in both IV drug users and nan-drug users, it would not explain the septic pulmanary emboli seen here an chest x-ray.
(Choice D) Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyapathy (HOCM) produces a systolic murmur that increases an standing. HOCM is not associated with endocarditis.
(Choice E) Paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2) occurs in patients with left bundle branch block (LBBB) due to delayed closure of the aortic valve. LBBB is not strongly associated with endocarditis.
Educational Objective:
Patients who abuse IV drugs are at increased risk for subacute bacterial endocarditis (SBE) of both the right and left heart. If the tricuspid ar pulmanic valve is affected, SBE can present with embalic phenomena ta the lung. SBE must be in the differential for all IV drug abusers presenting with fever and malaise.

question: A 34-year-old woman presents to your office complaining of several months of chest pain. She says that the pain is left-sided, does nat change with deep inspiration, and typically lasts several hours. The pain has no relation to physical activity, but worsens with emational stress. The patient has no significant family history, and does nat use tobacco, alcohol or drugs. She takes no medications and has na drug allergies. On exam, her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and her heart rate is 78/min. ECG is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in her management?
options: A. Stress thallium myocardial perfusion testing
explanation:
There are several methods for determining a patient's risk of coronary artery disease, ranging fram epidemiological models like the Framingham 10-year risk score to stress testing. These methods are most helpful for individuals at intermediate risk for coronary artery disease. This is because a negative nan-invasive evaluation for coronary artery disease in a high risk patient is likely to be a false negative, whereas a positive test in a low risk patient is likely ta be a false positive. Test results are mast likely to change the management of intermediate risk patients. The patient described is at low risk far coronary artery disease. She does not have risk factors like male gender, family history, or smoking. Mareover, her chest pain would be unusual for angina, especially given that it is unrelated to activity and lasts for hours. The etiology of her chest pain most likely has a psychosocial cause, and she should be reassured with regards to her cardiac health.
(Choices A and B) This patient is at low risk for coronary disease and does not need a stress test.
(Choice C) A transthoracic echocardiogram can assess cardiac ischemia by detecting wall motion abnormalities during stress. As described above, this patient is at low risk for cardiac disease.
(Choice D) Given her normal heart rate, nan-pleuritic pain, and lack of dyspnea, this patient is unlikely to have a pulmonary embolism. Moreover, a helical chest CT would be a better study to detect a PE than ultrasonography.
(Choice E) A chest x-ray is indicated if the patient's story raises concerns for infection, a primary lung process, broken ribs, or pneumaperitoneum. As described above, this patient's chest pain is most likely psychosacial in origin.
Educational Objective:
The differential diagnosis for chest pain is broad and varies significantly depending upon a patient's age and risk factors. In young women, anxiety and other psychosocial factors are a common cause af chest pain.

question: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency room with the chief complaint of progressive exertional dyspnea and fatigue. He denies any chest pain, syncope, cough, or edema. He suffered an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction one month ago. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles in his lower chest. Cardiac auscultation reveals a pansystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the axilla. ECG shows previously present unchanged Q waves and a persistent ST segment elevation in the anterior leads. Based an these findings, what is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?
explanation:
“Ventricular aneurysm is a complication that may occur days to months after myocardial infarction. Camman consequences of ventricular aneurysms include symptoms of CHF | ventricular arrhythmias, mitral regurgitation, and/or thrombus formation. This patient's physical exam finding of a pansystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the axilla is suggestive of mitral regurgitation, the result of aneurysmal alterations of the ventricular geometry. Persistent ST elevations are often seen on ECG in ventricular aneurysm. Echocardiography demonstrating dyskinetic wall motion of a portion of the left ventricle may be used to confirm the diagnosis.
(Choice A) Interventricular wall rupture typically occurs around & days after infarction and causes an acute left-to-right shunt with right sided heart failure and new-onset systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border.
(Choice B) Ventricular free wall rupture typically occurs around 5 days after myocardial infarction and causes acute pericardial tamponade and rapid decompensation with pulseless electrical activity.
(Choice C) Pulmonary infarction secondary to pulmonary embolism can cause dyspnea, but it should not cause new anset mitral regurgitation or ST elevations on ECG.
(Choice D) Recurrent ischemia is a consideration, given the ST elevations on ECG. However, it appears that the ST elevations and Q waves are unchanged since the initial infarction. These findings are more consistent with ventricular aneurysm.
(Choice E) Right ventricular infarction can occur with inferior wall MI, but usually not with anterior wall MI. Since LV function is relatively preserved in RY infarction, crackles would not be expected on lung exam.
(Choice F) Papillary muscle rupture typically accurs 3-7 days after an infarct and can cause severe acute mitral regurgitation and pulmonary edema. It does not typically cause persistent ST elevations an ECG.
(Choice H) Acute pericarditis can occur in the first several days after infarction, while Dressler's syndrome is an immune-mediated pericarditis that can occur weeks to manths after infarction. Diffuse ST elevations are typically present on ECG, and positional chest pain is usually the primary complaint.
Educational objective:
Ventricular aneurysm is a late complication of myocardial infarction characterized by persistent ST elevations an ECG. Patients may have CHF, ventricular arrhythmias, and/or thrombus farmation along with mitral regurgitation.

question: A 65-year-old male presents to your office with a six-month history of periodic substernal pain. The pain episodes are experienced during strong emotion, last for 10-15 minutes, and resolve spontaneously. He has a long history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, type 2. His right foot was amputated two years ago due to diabetes-related complications. You suspect angina pectoris and decide to perform myacardial perfusion scanning. It reveals uniform distribution of isotope at rest, but inhomogenesity of the distribution after dipyridamale injection. You conclude that the patient has ischemic heart disease. Which of the following effects of dipyridamole helped you in making the diagnosis?
explanation:
The histary is suggestive of angina pectoris in this patient (episodes of substernal pain provoked by emation). Exercise testing is not possible, because this patient's activity is limited by amputation. Myocardial perfusion scanning can be employed instead using dipyridamole ta reveal the areas of restricted myocardial perfusion.
Dipyridamole and adenosine are coronary vasodilators. Infusion of these substances in patients without coranary artery disease, increases caranary blood flow three to five times above the baseline levels. However, in patients with caranary artery disease, the diseased vessels distal to the obstruction are already maximally dilated (Choice C), and their ability to increase myocardial perfusion is limited; therefore, redistribution of caranary blood flow to 'non-diseased’ areas occurs, and the perfusion of 'diseased' segments diminishes. This phenomenon demanstrated by dipyridamale is called coronary steal and is used to diagnose ischemic heart disease.
Dipyridamaole is a patent antiplatelet aggregate (Choice D), but this property is not employed to assist in diagnosis. Increased cardiac contractility (Choice A) can occur as the result of vasodilatation, butitis a secondary phenomenan. Placebo effect (Choice E) is irrelevant in this case.
Educational Objective:
Dipyridamaole can be used during myocardial perfusion scanning to reveal the areas of restricted myocardial perfusion. The redistribution of the coronary blood flow to 'non-diseased' segments induced by this drug is called coronary steal phenomenon.

question: A 37-year-old healthy Caucasian male is seen in your office for a routine physical examination. He denies any symptoms or illness. He says he smokes a pack a day and drinks one to two beers every weekend. He has no allergies. Examination is unremarkable. The EKG reveals normal sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 72; there are frequent premature atrial beats present. The blood pressure is 120/65mm Hg. The next step in his management is:
explanation:
The diagnosis of atrial premature beats depends upan the recagnition of 'P' waves that are premature relative to sinus cycle length and which differ in morphology fram sinus 'P' waves. Atrial premature beats frequently reset the sinus node, producing pauses, which are only partially compensatory. The QRS width is normal.
Premature atrial beats may be completely normal ar due to anxiety, CHF, hypoxia, caffeine or electrolyte abnormalities. Premature atrial beats never require any treatment and are completely benign (Option E).
(Option A): Digoxin is a classic inotrope, which is frequently used in the treatment of atrial arrhythmias, especially fibrillation. It increases the AY nodal refractoriness and thereby slows the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation and flutter. Digoxin is particularly used in patients with heart failure {systolic dysfunction) and atrial fibrillation/flutter. Digoxin has na role in the management of premature atrial beats.
(Option B): Lidocaine is a class 1 anti arrhythmic agent used in the treatment of ventricular arrhythmias. It has na role in the treatment of atrial arrhythmias. The drug is usually given intravenously.
(Option C): Rarely premature atrial beats may be due to electrolyte abnormalities. In such cases, levels of potassium, magnesium and calcium may need to be evaluated. Removing the causative agent or replacing the deficient electrolyte can treat premature atrial beats. Electrolyte abnormalities are unlikely in a healthy patient without comorbid illnesses.
(Option D): Electrophysiological study can establish whether an anomalous pathway is present or absent and allow its localization. Premature atrial beats do not have an anatomical disturbance and EF studies are not helpful at all.
Educational objective:
Premature atrial beats are benign and neither require any fallow up nor treatment.

question: A 56-year-old white male presents with dyspnea for the last 3 manths. His dyspnea was initially exertional but it has worsened progressively and now he is breathless even at rest. He denies any chest pain ar ankle swelling. He has been smoking one-pack/day cigarettes for the last 30 years and has been drinking alcohal heavily for the last 10 years. He is not taking any medication. His mather died of breast cancer at 57. His vitals are, PR: 86/min, BP: 113/76mm of Hg; Temperature: 37.1C(98 9F); RR: 13/min. On auscultation of his precardium an S3 is heard, but there are no murmurs. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral basal crepitations. Chest x-ray shows marked cardiac silhouette enlargement and pulmonary venous congestion. EKG shows non-specific ST-T wave changes. Echocardiography shows a dilated left ventricle and systolic dysfunction (EF of 25-30%). CBC shows hematocrit of 32%, WBC count of 8,000/microL, and platelet count of 60,000/microL. Peripheral blood smear shaws MCV of 101 fL. LFTs show AST of 180U/L and ALT of 66 U/L. The findings of cardiac catheterization and coronary angiography are not compatible with the diagnosis of ischemic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following measures is mast likely to reverse his heart failure?
explanation:
This patient is mast likely suffering from dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to alcoholism. Findings of thrombocytopenia, macrocytosis, and elevated transaminases are all suggestive af alcohalism in this patient. His cardiomyopathy could be due to ischemia but coranary angiography excluded this diagnosis in this patient. Total abstinence from alcohol is the mainstay of alcoholic cardiomyopathy management and it may reverse this condition if it is employed earlier in the course of the disease.
Reduced salt intake only improves symptoms of heart failure and does not reverse the disease process itself.
Digitalis is most useful in those heart failure patients who have systolic dysfunction and have rapid ventricular rates due to atrial flutter or atrial fibrillation. It proves to be useful in these cases by its positive inotropic effect and negative dromatropic (slowing AY conduction). Use of digitalis has not been shown to provide any survival advantage in patients with congestive heart failure and has not been shown ta reverse the disease process.
ACE inhibitors have been shown to slow the progression af heart failure but they don't reverse the disease process of alcoholic cardiomyopathy. ACE inhibitors should be given to all patients with heart failure who have systolic dysfunction unless they are contraindicated or the patients can't tolerate them.
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for coronary heart disease and its cessation should be encouraged in all patients with heart failure. Cessation of cigarette smoking does not reverse the disease process of alcohalic cardiomyopathy.
Educational Objective:
Know how to diagnose and manage a patient with congestive heart failure due to alcoholic dilated cardiomyopathy.

question: A 55-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office for a routine check-up. His past medical history is significant for gout, hypertension, and hyperchaolesteralemia. His current medications include enalapril and pravastatin. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. His blood pressure is 156/94 mmHg and heart rate is 80/min. Physical examination reveals that the patient is moderately overweight (BMI = 27 kg/m2) with increased waist-to-hip ratio.
