There is some evidence that ACE inhibitors may decrease the risk of major cardiovascular events in patients with ischemic heart disease not anly by lowering blood pressure, but also affecting the development of atherosclerotic plague, but this evidence is controversial.
Educational Objective:
In patients who present with stable angina and hypertension, a beta-blocker is the drug of choice.

question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of dyspnea, fatigue, poor appetite and weight gain aver the past several weeks. He says that about four weeks ago he began to develop worsening shortness of breath with exertion and mare recently has been waking at night with breathlessness. He also notes that it is sometimes difficult for him to open his eyes in the morning due to facial edema. He has no significant past medical history and he takes no medications. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 200/120 mmHg and his heart rate is 100/min. You note generalized bodily edema and distention of his jugular veins while he is sitting upright. On lung auscultation you hear bibasilar rales. Urinalysis shows trace protein, no nitrites, trace leukocyte esterase, 50+ red blood cells and occasional neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's edema?
explanation:
Peripheral edema can result fram a number of etiologies including argan failure (cardiac, hepatic, ar renal}, hypoalbuminemia (secondary to nephrotic syndrome, malnutrition, ar liver disease), and venous insufficiency. The patient described above has anasarca, or generalized edema, characterized by pulmanary edema and ascites in addition to swollen extremities. Organ failure and/or hypoalbuminemia are potential causes of anasarca. Based on the information presented in the vignette, acute glomerulonephritis appears to be the unifying diagnosis here. In glomerulonephritis, edema results from glomerular damage and a decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
In glamerulonephritis, the urine sediment will reveal red blood cells, red blood cell casts, and might contain white blood cells and protein as well. Patients may have significant proteinuria, which contributes to their edema. (This patient has anly trace protein on his urinalysis meaning that the majarity of his edema is secondary to a decreased GFR) Decreased GFR is the cause of edema in patients with end-stage renal disease as well.
(Choice A) Renal hypoperfusion can occur in heart failure (decreased cardiac output), which in turn promotes increased renal sodium reabsorption and edema. Urinalysis would not show significant red blood cells ar casts.
(Choice B) Hypoalbuminemia can result from excessive albumin loss (as in nephratic syndrome) or decreased albumin synthesis (as in cirrhosis ar severe malnutrition). While this patient clearly has renal disease, he does not have significant proteinuria to explain his presentation.
(Choice D) Cirrhosis can cause portal hypertension as the scarred liver limits blood flow through the sinusoidal network. Patients with cirrhosis typically have ascites out of propartion to edema in other tissues, plus other signs of chranic liver disease like spider angiomata, palmar erythema, and caput medusa.
(Choice E) While hypothyroidism can cause pretibial edema, it is not a commaon cause of anasarca.
(Choice F) Right ventricular failure {often a consequence of left ventricular failure) is a frequent cause of peripheral edema. It manifests with an elevated jugular venous pressure, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, and peripheral edema. Of nate, isolated right ventricular failure will not cause pulmonary edema because it does not cause blood to pool in the pulmanary capillary beds.
Educational objective:
Anasarca typically results from organ failure ar hypoalbuminemia. In patients with glomerulonephritis, edema results from the decreased glomerular filtration rate as well as proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia in some Cases.

question: A 45-year-old white male presents to the ER after an episode of syncope. His medical history is unremarkable except far an upper respiratory infection ane week ago. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and respirations are 13/min. His neck veins are distended and his heart sounds are distant. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Chest x-ray reveals small bilateral pleural effusions and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Which of the following EKG findings is fairly specific for his condition?
options: E. Mew-onset right bundle branch black
explanation:
This patient has a pericardial effusion, which often causes electrical alternans on EKG. His recent upper respiratory infection is a clue towards the diagnosis, as pericardial effusions are often secondary to viral pericarditis. Accompanying pleural effusions may be found as well.
Electrical alternans describes QRS complexes whose amplitudes vary from beat to beat on EKG. tis thought to result fram the heart's swinging back and forth within an increased quantity of pericardial fluid. Jugular venous distention, muffled heart sounds and borderline blood pressure indicate developing cardiac tamponade. Echocardiography can confirm the presence of pericardial effusion.
(Choice A) The PR’ interval is prolonged in first degree heart block, a condition that is usually asymptomatic and requires na treatment.
(Choice B) The presence of 'F' waves, ar flutter waves, is diagnastic of atrial flutter. Jugular venous distention and hypotension can develop if the heart rate is rapid enough, but this patient's rate is only 90.
(Choice D) A ‘delta’ wave is an upsloping just before the QRS complex that occurs in patients with an accessory conduction pathway, like in Walf-Parkinsan-VWhite syndrome. It is not associated with pericardial effusion.
(Choice E) Mew-onset right bundle branch block can sometimes be seen in pulmonary embolism. Pulmanary embali usually cause tachypnea and/or tachycardia.
Explanation:
Electrical alternans is when the amplitudes of the QRS complexes vary from beat to beat. It is fairly specific far pericardial effusion. Enlargement of the cardiac silhouette can be seen an chest x-ray as well. Echocardiogram can more definitely demanstrate a pericardial effusion.

question: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dyspnea. He describes waking up during the night with difficulty breathing and chest pain that kept him from falling back to sleep. He has never had these symptoms befare. His past medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and non-compliance with his antihypertensive therapy. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 120/min and regular. Lung auscultation reveals bibasilar rales and scattered wheezes. Which of the following is most likely ta relieve this patient's dyspnea?
explanation:
This patient presents with paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea in the setting of long-standing hypertension and a pulmanary exam cancerning for cardiogenic pulmonary edema. He has likely developed diastolic dysfunction (impaired ventricular relaxation) fram his long-standing hypertensian and is now in left ventricular failure. Mitroglycerin (MTG), either IV, sublingual, or topical, relieves the dyspnea and tachycardia associated with cardiogenic pulmanary edema by rapidly reducing preload. Several studies have suggested that it warks quicker than marphine ar loop diuretics. NTG is not part of the long-term management for patients with heart failure but can be beneficial in acutely alleviating symptoms. It should be used cautiously in patients with hypotension. Beyond NTG, loop diuretics are the mainstay of therapy for decompensated heart failure and principally wark by reducing total body volume.
(Choice A) Beta-blockers are tremendously efficacious in treating chronic heart failure, and have been shown to significantly improve long-term morbidity and mortality in affected patients. However, beta-blockers are negative inotropes and may acutely worsen heart failure symptoms.
(Choice B) Hydralazine given in combination with an aral nitrate has proven efficacy for treating African American men with heart failure. However, hydralazine given alone will not alleviate symptoms as quickly as NTG.
(Choice C) Salmeterol is a long-acting B2-adrenergic agonist used in the chronic treatment of asthma and bronchodilator-responsive COPD. Because it has a slow onset, salmeterol is not beneficial in the treatment af asthma or COPD exacerbations. Regardless, this patient's wheezing is due to pulmonary edema, not asthma, sa salmeteral is not the appropriate therapy here.
(Choice D) At moderate doses (3-10 mcg/kg/min), dopamine stimulates myocardial B-receptors and increases myocardial contractility. However, at these doses, dopamine is also arrhythmogenic and may worsen heart failure.
(Choice E) Amiodarone can be used to treat atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia in patients with heart failure but it is not a treatment for pulmonary edema.
(Choice F) Verapamil can be used far rate contral in atrial fibrillation and to improve diastolic relaxation in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. However, it is also a negative inotrape and may acutely worsen heart failure symptoms.
(Choice G) Aminophylline is a bronchodilator used ta treat asthma and COPD. It is not typically recommended in heart failure.
Educational objective:
Cardiogenic pulmanary edema results from left heart failure and is characterized by crackles on pulmonary exam. Mitroglycerin is the most rapidly acting medication ta relieve the symptoms of pulmonary edema.

question:
A 34-year-old female presents to the ER with difficulty breathing and dizziness. Blood pressure tracing fram an arterial line placed in the ER is depicted below.
Inspiration
Which of the following best accounts for these findings?
explanation:
In an arterial pressure diagram, the peaks correspond to systolic pressures and the valleys to diastolic pressures. We can see that in this patient, the diastolic pressure remains relatively constant throughout the tracing, but systolic pressures drop substantially with each inspiration. Some drop in systalic pressure (<=10 mm Hg) during inspiration is normal. This physiologic drop is the result of increased venous return ta the right heart during inspiration, which impedes left ventricular filling and thus causes a drap in systalic pressure. Pulsus paradoxus is the term far an abnormally large drop in systolic blood pressure (>=12 mm Hg) with inspiration. Itis seen in some forms of cardiac disease (tamponade, pericardial effusion) and pulmanary disease (tension pneumatharax, severe asthma). In asthma, significantly elevated intrathoracic pressures during inhalation are thought to exacerbate compression of the left ventricle, causing pulsus paradoxus.
(Choice B to E) None of these conditions typically cause pulsus paradoxus.
Educational objective:
Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a difference in systolic blood pressure of >=12 mm Hg during inspiration. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumotharax, and severe asthma.

question:
A 43-year-old man complains of progressive weakness and shortness af breath over the last two weeks. He denies any chest or muscle pain, nausea, vomiting or weight loss. He had a recent upper respiratory tract infection. His heart rate is 90/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Jugular venous pressure is normal. Lungs are clear to auscultation. His chest x-ray is shown below.
Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
options: B. Non-palpable point of maximal impulse
E. Fixed splitting of the second heart sound
explanation:
This patient has a pericardial effusion without evidence of cardiac tamponade. On chest x-ray, a large pericardial effusion may appear as an enlarged, globular-appearing cardiac shadow (the characteristic "water bottle" heart shape), as seen an this patient's chest x-ray. Due to the increased fluid in the pericardial space, physical exam will reveal distant heart sounds and a non-palpable pulse at the cardiac apex or paint of maximal impulse.
It is important to recognize that this patient does nat have cardiac tamponade. Tamponade presents as hypotension, right heart failure (distended jugular veins), and tachycardia. Fulsus paradoxus may be present. The therapy for cardiac tamponade is vigorous volume resuscitation and pericardiocentesis.
(Choice A) &n audible fourth heart sound is heard in normal, young patients and in people with left ventricular hypertrophy. This patient's chest x-ray is more cansistent with a pericardial effusion than left ventricular hypertrophy, which often appears as a "boot-shaped" cardiac shadow on x-ray.
(Choice C) Pulsus bisferiens, ar biphasic pulse, refers to two strong systolic impulses with a midsystalic dip. It can be seen in aortic regurgitation with or without aortic stenosis and in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.
(Choice D) An opening snap is heard with mitral stenosis. Significant mitral stenosis will cause left atrial enlargement. This will be seen on chest x-ray as a straightening of the left part of the cardiac silhouette {as apposed to the normal mild concavity visible below the pulmanary artery shadow). Enlargement of the entire cardiac silhouette would not be seen.
(Choice E) Fixed splitting of the second heart sound is associated with atrial septal defects.
(Choice F) Intermittent ptosis wauld be seen if this patient had myasthenia gravis in assaciation with thymoma. These tumars present as anterior mediastinal masses on chest x-ray with preserved cardiac size. This chest x-ray is not consistent with a thymoma.
Educational Objective:
Pericardial effusions will appear as an enlarged, "water bottle" shaped cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray. Physical exam findings of pericardial effusions without cardiac tamponade include diminished heart sounds on auscultation and a difficult to palpate point of maximal impulse.

question: A 66-year-ald white male presents to his primary care physician for follow-up evaluation of high blood pressure noted on each of three prior visits over a period of 6 months (systolic blood pressure ranging 140-145, diastolic blood pressure ranging 90-96 mm Hg). He has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years and takes 5-8 drinks of alcohol daily. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications. There is no family history of diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia ar hypertension. On physical examination today, his blood pressure is 146/97 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. Which of the following nonpharmacaologic interventions would be expected to have the greatest impact on his high blood pressure?
options: B. Increased consumption of complex carbohydrates
E. Decreased consumption of animal protein
explanation:
This patient has had multiple blood pressure readings greater than 140/90 aver a period of manths, and therefore meets the criteria for stage I hypertension. In such patients, it is reasonable ta enact a trial of lifestyle madifications to reduce blood pressure before resorting to medications. The most effective lifestyle intervention for reducing blood pressure is decreased consumption of alcohol. It is recommended that males consume less than 2 drinks daily, and women less than 1.
(Choice A) There is no question that smoking cessation reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease in patients with hypertension. However, in terms of improving hypertension itself, abstinence from alcohal has a greater effect.
(Choice B) Diets rich in fruits, vegetables, and whale grains have been shown to aid weight loss and may therefare indirectly help lower blood pressure. Decreasing alcohal consumption would be expected to have a mare dramatic effect, however.
(Choice C) Patients with a low dietary intake of calcium do have a higher risk of developing hypertension, but qiving these patients calcium supplements has not been shawn to substantially impact blood pressure.
(Choice E) Vegetarians tend to have less hypertension than meat-eaters, but there is not strong data to suggest that eliminating animal protein from the diet is an effective means of controlling hypertension.
Educational objective:
Lifestyle modification should be the first-line intervention for newly diagnosed stage 1 hypertension. Reduction of alcohol and sodium intake, weight loss, and aerobic exercise can all decrease blood pressure. Quitting smoking will decrease a patient's risk of cardiovascular disease, but does nat improve blood pressure itself.

question:
A 55-year-old male is admitted to the ICU after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. He requires exploratory laparotomy for suspected bowel perforation. Two days after the surgery he remains hypotensive and requires bath aggressive intravenous fluids and vasopressors to maintain his blood pressure. On physical examination, you note the fingertip changes pictured below:
All four extremities feel cold to touch. Which of the following is most likely responsible?
explanation:
This patient's coal, dusky fingertips are the result of norepinephrine-induced vasospasm. Morepinephrine has alpha-1 agonist properties which cause vasoconstriction; this property is useful when trying to increase the blood pressure of hypotensive patients. However, in some patients with decreased blood flaw, vasocanstriction can result in ischemia and necrasis of the distal fingers and toes. A similar phenomenan can occur in the intestines (resulting in mesenteric ischemia) or kidney (causing renal failure).
(Choice A) Endocarditis can spread septic embali throughout the body, but would not be expected to affect all fingers.
(Choice B) Raynaud's phenomenon is a cause of finger ischemia that typically progresses from pallor to cyanosis to erythema. It can be accompanied by pain and is usually due to cold exposure ar stress. The duskiness of the fingers pictured above, hawever is more suggestive of ischemia.
(Choice D) Cholesterol embali can occur in patients with atherosclerosis and can affect the distal portions of the digits, thus its occasional name "blue toe syndrome " However, symmetrical involvement of all digits would be unusual.
(Choice E) Superior vena cava syndrome occurs in patients with lung cancer, thrombi, ar fibrosing mediastinitis and can cause upper extremity edema. However, arterial flow is preserved and so ischemia does not occur.
Educational objective:
Fressaors such as norepinephrine can cause ischemia of the distal fingers and toes secondary to vasospasm. The diagnosis is suggested by symmetric duskiness and coolness af all fingertips.

question: A 14-year-old African American male collapses and dies while playing basketball at a school tournament. He has no known past medical histary. Which of the following is the mast likely underlying disease in this patient?
explanation:
Sudden cardiac death in a young individual, especially during exertion, is most common with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is mare camman in African-Americans than whites. Mast of the patients who die suddenly from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy have had no prior symptoms. Ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation can occur in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The generation of these arrhythmias is multifactorial, but all derive from the underlying abnormality of abnormal myocytes and myocardial scarring. Death can also occur in these patients fram heart failure and stroke as well, but these would be unlikely to cause such a sudden death.
(Answer B) Coronary atherosclerosis can lead to myocardial infarction, which can produce the sudden anset af ventricular arrhythmias resulting in death. However, the extremely young age and lack of any significant past medical history make this unlikely for this patient.
(Answer C) Aartic aneurysms in a patient of this age are rare. In the general population, they are usually due to atherosclerosis, which this patient would be unlikely to have.
(Answer D) Ventricular septal defects are often a congenital disorder and would be possible in this patient. However, they are not a cause of sudden death. If the patient were ta die from complications of a ventricular septal defect, he would likely have some symptoms beforehand.
(Answer E) A bicuspid aorta is a congenital condition that can lead to aortic stenosis. However, patients typically have symptoms of the condition and they usually develop at a later age. Bicuspid aortic valve would therefore be an unlikely cause of sudden death in this patient.
Educational objective:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can lead to ventricular arrhythmias, and should be suspected in a sudden death af an atherwise healthy young individual.

question: A 63-year-old female presents to your office for a routine check-up. She has no present complaints. Her past medical history includes DM, type 2, and hypertension. Her current medications include glyburide and atenolol. She does not smake. She drinks 2-3 glasses of wine 1-2 times a week. Three consecutive BP measurements were in the range of 138-142/87-90 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits. Her recent fasting glucose level was 250 mg/dL. ECG recorded 1 month ago showed left ventricular hypertrophy. Which statement about the BP control in this patient is the most accurate?
options: A. BP is within acceptable range
B. BP is within optimal range
C. It is better to keep systolic pressure less than 130 mmHg to slow end-organ damage
D. Diastolic BF is within acceptable range, but systolic is not
E. Systolic BP is within acceptable range, but diastolic is not
explanation:
Traditionally a goal, blood pressure is considered to be below 140/90 mmHg. But it is recently recognized that BP needs more tight contral in diabetics and patients with chranic renal failure. These two groups of patients are especially sensitive to high BP, that's why the values of systolic BF for these patients should be kept lower than 130 mmHg and diastolic BF lower than 80 mmHg to prevent end argan damage.
Blood pressure could be considered in acceptable range (Choice A) if the patient was not diabetic. According to JNC-7 report (JNC stands far Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure) BF is considered optimal when it is below 120/80 mmHg (Choice B) In this patient both systolic (Choice E) and diastolic (Choice D) BFP are above the goal values.
Educational objective:
It is better to keep systolic pressure <= 130 mmHg to slow end-organ damage in patients with diabetes and chronic renal failure.

question: A 34-year-old male presents to his physician's office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has a five year history of bronchial asthma for which he uses an albuterol inhaler. He says that he uses the inhaler an average of two times per week during the day. In addition, he states that his asthma symptoms wake him from sleep approximately 3-4 times per month. He does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. His family histary is significant for asthma in his grandfather. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
options: A. Add long-acting beta-2 aganist inhaler
explanation:
The proper pharmacologic treatment of asthma varies depending on the severity of symptoms. Asthma is classified into four categaries: intermittent, mild persistent, moderate persistent, and severe persistent. The category is determined by assessing the frequency of a patient's daytime symptoms, nighttime awakenings, use of short-term beta agonists, and pulmanary function testing. The criteria for each category are as follows:
Intermittent: daytime symptoms <= 2x/week, nighttime awakenings <= 2x/maonth, beta agonists <= 2x/week, normal baseline FEV1 and FEV1/FVC, and no limitations an daily activities.
Mild persistent: symptoms >2 days/week but not daily, nighttime awakenings 3-4x/month, minor limitation an activities, and normal PF Ts.
Moderate persistent: symptoms daily, weekly nighttime awakenings, moderate limitation on activities, and FEV1 60-80% of predicted.
Severe persistent: symptoms throughout the day, frequent nighttime awakenings, extremely limited activity, and FEV1 <=60% predicted.
The patient in the above vignette is prescribed anly a short-acting beta-2 agonist (albuteral), which would be AanmmrArriatre tharame Far infarritHtant acta Havsonsasr he hace 3-4 nighttime awakenings per manth, cansistent with mild persistent asthma. Therefore, continuing the current medical regimen (Choice E) would be insufficient. Proper treatment for mild persistent asthma includes a PRN albuteral inhaler plus inhaled corticosteroids. Therefore, Choice B is correct.
In addition to a FRM albuterol inhaler and low-dase inhaled corticosteroids, patients with moderate persistent asthma should receive a long-acting inhaled beta-2 agonist inhaler (Choice A).
Patients with severe persistent asthma should receive a PRM albuteral inhaler, long-acting beta-2 agonist inhaler, and high-dose inhaled corticosteroids. Oral prednisone (Choice D) can also be used in cases of severe persistent asthma.
Educational objective:
Proper treatment of mild persistent asthma includes a PRM albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroids.

question:
A 34-year-old male is recovering from head trauma sustained in a motor vehicle accident. He is currently in the intensive care unit on mechanical ventilation. His most recent arterial blood gas analysis shows:
pH                    7.54
PaO2                 124 mmHg
PaCO2               20 mmHg
Bicarbonate          17 mEq/L
Which of the following additional findings do you most expect in this patient?
explanation:
While being mechanically ventilated this patient is vulnerable to farced hyper- or hypoventilation. Ventilation is defined as the tidal volume multiplied by the respiratory rate. Hyperventilation {caused by increased tidal volume and/or respiratory rate) results in excessive CO2 losses and respiratory alkalosis, while hypoventilation (caused by decreased tidal volume and/or respiratory rate) results in CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis. The patient described is experiencing respiratory alkalosis as evidenced by his increased arterial blood pH (normal = 7.4) and his decreased PaCO2 (normal = 40 mmHg). His serum bicarbonate level is decreased due to attempted renal compensation for the metabolic alkalosis. Specifically, the kidneys retain increased amounts of H+ (protons) and excrete increased amounts of bicarbonate (HCO3-) in an attempt to normalize the serum pH. The increased amount of HCO3- in the urine alkalinizes the urine.
(Choice A) Renal compensation for respiratory or metabolic acidosis involves low urine bicarbonate excretion.
(Choice C) Increased serum aldosterone would result in increased H+ and K+ losses in the urine and serum alkalosis. "Contraction alkalosis" occurs in states of intracellular volume contraction, where increased levels af aldosterone function to restore intravascular valume but also cause increased urinary proton loss.
(Choice D) A high serum anion gap occurs in metabolic acidoses resulting from diabetic ketoacidosis, renal failure, lactic acidosis, and methanol, ethylene glycal or salicylate poisoning.
(Choice E) A high serum albumin level may indicate hemaocancentration, as occurs in dehydration.
Educational objective:
The kidney compensates for respiratory alkalosis by preferentially excreting bicarbonate in the urine. The result is an alkalinized urine (increased urine pH).

question:
A 35-year-old man wha recently emigrated from Mexico complains of persistent cough. He says that he coughs up yellowish sputum that is occasionally streaked with blood. He alsa notes occasional fevers and frequent nighttime awakenings with cough and choking. He has a 20 pack-year smoking histary but does nat use alcohal ar drugs. CT of his chest is shown below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient has pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) based on his classic clinical presentation (chronic cough, hemoptysis, intermittent fevers), his recent travel fram a country where TB is endemic, and his chest CT with twa right upper lobe cavitary lesions with surrounding alveolar infiltration. Reactivation of pulmonary TB typically causes upper lobe cavitations. This patient should be treated with four drug therapy for active TB.
(Choice A) Bronchiectasis is progressive branchial dilation, cyst formation, poor mucus clearance, and secretion pooling that results from severe repeated airway inflammation. CT scans show bronchial thickening, nat upper lobe cavitation.
(Choice C) Lung cancer can cause a chronic cough but typically appears as a salitary, dense nodule an chest CT. This patient, on the other hand, has two cavitary lesions. Moreover, he is relatively young to develop a primary lung cancer.
(Choice D) Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABFA) is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus colonization of the bronchi. It occurs most commonly in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis and presents with fever, malaise, productive cough, eosinophilia, and hemoptysis.
(Choice E) Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most cammanly affects the lungs. Perihilar lymphadenopathy is the typical finding but patients may also develop interstitial lung disease and pulmanary fibrosis. Cavitary lesions are uncommon.
Educational objective:
Pulmonary tuberculosis presents with productive cough, hemoptysis, and recurrent fevers. Weight loss may also be present. Imaging most commonly reveals upper lobe cavitary lesions. TB must be suspected in patients fram endemic regions with subacute or chronic pulmonary complaints.

question: A 33-year-old male was invalved in a motor vehicle accident with numerous rib fractures. His course in the hospital was complicated by difficulty with deep breathing and later developed pneumonia. The chest x-ray later confirmed that the patient had developed a parapneumaonic effusion. Which ane of the following laboratory tests an the pleural fluid is currently thought to be mast helpful in determining the need for chest tube placement in parapneumanic effusion?
options: E. Color of the pleural fluid
explanation:
Farapneumanic effusions usually occur from pneumania. The fluid may be sterile in the initial stages and resalve with antibiotic therapy; however, in a few cases, the patient will continue to have elevated temperatures, pleuritic chest pain, and dyspnea. CT scan will identify the fluid collection. The fluid may be aspirated to determine if empyema has set in. The aspirated fluid should always be analyzed for the protein content (exudates have more than transudates), gram stain, cell count, cytology (rule out malignancy), and glucose levels (low in rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis, empyema, malignancy, and esophageal rupture). The pH of the fluid should always be assessed. Low pH (<= 7.2) is almost always indicative of an empyema and indicates removal of the fluid by thoracostomy (Choice C). Glucose of less than 60mg/dL is also an indication far tube thoracostamy.
(Choice A) Lactate dehydrogenase is generally higher in exudates than in transudates, but does nat indicate if an empyema has accurred. LOH levels are elevated in a number of conditions, including myocardial infarction, cirrhosis, and generalized ischemia.
(Choice B) WBC count is essential to determine the presence of neutrophils ar lymphocytes. Elevated levels af lymphocytes are seen in tuberculosis effusions and lymphomas. These findings da nat always indicate an infected pleural space. Elevated levels of neutrophils almost always signify an infected fluid.
(Choice D) Total protein may be elevated in almost all exudative effusions. The level of protein in transudates is much lower than in exudates. Protein is elevated in neoplasms, tuberculosis, and other infectious effusions. However, the protein content does not determine the need for a chest tube.
(Choice E) The colar of the pleural effusion does not determine the need for drainage. The effusions in nan-infectious causes are generally clear, and, in infectious, may be cloudy. Hemarrhagic effusions are bloody in nature, and a ruptured thoracic duct will reveal a milky white effusion.
Educational Objective:
When the pH of the pleural fluid is less than 7.2, the probability is very high that this fluid needs to be drained. Glucose of less than 60mg/dL in pleural fluid is alsa an indication for tube thoracostomy. Infected pleural space is usually initially drained with a chest tube.

question: A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of daytime sleepiness. He says that he often falls asleep during meetings, watching TV, and even while driving his car. He does not feel refreshed after his daytime naps, and has not experienced vivid hallucinations when falling asleep or upon awakening. He has occasional morning headaches and his wife complains that he sometimes keeps her up at night. Physical exam reveals a body mass index (BMI) of 31.3 kg/m2. An arterial blood gas is normal. What is this patient's most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient has several classic signs and symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a phenomenon of nocturnal hypoventilation. There are two types of abnormal ventilation during sleep: 1) apnea (cessation of breathing for >= 10 seconds) or 2) hypopnea (reduced airflow causing Sa02 to decrease by >= 4%). The most comman cause for bath of these in the United States is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a transient upper airway obstruction due to poor pharyngeal muscle tone. In OSA, the patient continues to contract the diaphragm in an attempt to breathe, but airflow is impeded by upper airway obstruction. OSA is the most common medical cause of excessive daytime sleepiness in this country, affecting over seven million people. Risk factors for OSA include obesity, tonsillar hypertrophy, and hypothyroidism. Men are more frequently affected than women. Typical symptoms include excessive daytime sleepiness, morning headaches, impotence, poor judgment, and depression. Bed partners may be kept awake by snoring, as in this vignette. Physical exam often reveals obesity and increased soft tissue in the oropharynx. Lab studies may reveal erythrocytasis. Chronic OSA can lead to pulmanary hypertension and right ventricular failure.
(Choice A) Narcolepsy Is a sleep disorder characterized by poorly regulated rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. It, like OSA, is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, but patients also suffer from cataplexy, sleep attacks, hypnagagic/hypnopompic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis.
(Choice B) Obesity hypoventilation syndrame (OHS), alsa called the Pickwickian Syndrome, occurs when obesity impedes the expansion of the chest and abdominal wall during breathing. This leads to increased respiratory work and decreased respiratory drive. OHS is characterized by underventilation of the lungs during all hours, leading to a chronically elevated FaCO2 and reduced PaQ2. Therefore, this patient's normal arterial blood gas is not consistent with OHS. Eventually, as in OSA, polycythemia, pulmonary hypertension, and right ventricular failure can result. Notably, patients with OHS often have concomitant obstructive sleep apnea.
(Choice D) In contrast to obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea occurs when the patient's central drive to initiate breaths is absent. Thus, it is caused by a neurologic rather than mechanical problem. This patient's presentation is not consistent with central sleep apnea.
Educational Objective:
Obstructive sleep apnea is the most common medical cause of excessive daytime sleepiness inthe US. It occurs due to poor oropharyngeal tone and results in daytime sleepiness, marning headaches, and depression.

question: A 24-year-old Caucasian man is brought to the emergency room with acute asthma exacerbation. His current medications include inhaled fluticasone and salmeteral. The attack started 10 hours ago and did nat respond to numerous albuterol inhalations and systemic steroids. His blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg and heart rate is 110/min. The patient is tachypneic and speaks with difficulty. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds, prolonged expiration, and bilateral wheezing. Pulse oximetry showed 86% at room air. ABG at room air are: pH- 7.43, Po2 - 68 mmHg, Pco2 - 40mmHg. The chest x-ray demonstrates hyperinflated lungs. Which of the following findings indicates that the patient is getting worse?
explanation:
In determining the severity of an asthma attack, it is very impartant in choosing an appropriate management tactic. Marmal Pco2 is ane of the indicators of a severe attack. During asthma exacerbation, hyperventilation (tachypnea) is usually present, and the wark of breathing is increased. Po2 is usually depressed (but 68 is not bad) because of the V/Q mismatch (Choice D), and tachypnea is usually present (Choice B). At the same time, Pco2 is decreased due to hyperventilation. Normal to increased Pco2 values indicates CO2 retention because of severe airway obstruction (air trapping) and/or respiratory muscle fatigue. Other indicatars of severe attack include speech difficulty, diaphoresis, altered sensorium, cyanosis, and ‘silent’ lungs. Lung hyperinflation (Choice A) and tachycardia (Choice C) are typical findings during an asthma attack and are not indicators of severity.
Educational Objective:
Indicators of a severe asthma attack include normal to increased Pco2 values, speech difficulty, diapharesis, altered sensorium, cyanosis, and silent’ lungs.

question: A 19-year woman presents to her physician's office far a routine health maintenance examination. She notes experiencing occasional wheezing and breathlessness following aerobic exercise, but has no symptoms at other times of the day or night. Her medical history is otherwise significant for allergic rhinitis and acne, for which she uses topical benzoyl peroxide and erythromycin cream. She does not use tobacco, alcohal or illicit drugs. Cn physical examination, her vital signs are within normal limits and chest auscultation is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her management?
explanation:
Exercise-induced asthma is the mast likely diagnosis here. Asthma is an intermittent obstructive airway disease characterized by dyspnea, cough and wheezing following exposure to various triggers. Atopic dermatitis and allergic rhinitis are commanly associated conditions. In exercise-induced asthma, the trigger is high minute ventilation of dry, cold air, which stimulates mast cell degranulation and airway canstriction. Beta agonists and mast cell stabilizers are both important in the management of exercise-induced asthma. Shart-acting beta-adrenergic agonists used 20 minutes prior to exercise are typically sufficient to prevent symptoms and are considered first-line therapy. Long-acting beta-adrenergic agonists may be used in children or athletes wha engage in athletic activities throughout the day.
(Choice B) Daily oral steroids are indicated only for severe persistent asthma, which is characterized by cantinuous daytime symptoms, frequent nighttime symptoms, and an FEV less than 60% of predicted.
(Choice C) Daily steroid inhalers are the preferred treatment far mild persistent asthma, which is characterized by mare than two episodes per week and mare than two nighttime episodes per manth.
(Choice D) Daily oral theophylline may be used as an alternative or adjunctive treatment for any form of asthma other than mild intermittent.
(Choice E) Ipratropium inhalers are often combined with beta-adrenergic agonists for an additive bronchodilator effect. Ipratropium is mare effective in patients with COPD than in those with asthma.
Educational objective:
Short-acting beta-adrenergic agonists administered 20 minutes befare exercise are the first-line treatment for isolated exercise-induced asthma. The inciting trigger in exercise-induced asthma is rapid ventilation of cold, dry air.

question: A 34-year-old male is rushed to the emergency room with severe respiratory distress. He is agitated and gasping far breath. He has been seen in the ER several times before for difficulty breathing, food intolerances and skin allergies. Physical examination is notable for excessive accessory respiratory muscle use, retraction of the subclavicular fossae during inspiration, and scattered urticaria over the upper body. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This is a patient with acute-onset dyspnea and clinical features suggestive of upper respiratory abstruction. Given his history of food allergies and urticaria, laryngeal edema is likely the cause of his respiratory symptoms. Patients with laryngeal edema typically present with acute-onset dyspnea. There is usually an identifiable precipitating event, e.g. peanut ingestion in a patient with a history of peanut allergies. Physical examination will reveal stridor and harsh respiratory sounds from the trachea. Wheezing is generally absent on lung auscultation.
(Choice B) Asthma exacerbations generally do not come on with the sort of catastrophic acuity described here. On exam, there will be scattered wheezes over the lung fields rather than stridor, differentiating asthma fram upper respiratory obstruction.
(Choice C) Like in patients with laryngeal edema, patients with pneumothorax present with acute-onset dyspnea. However, stridor and wheezing are absent. In fact, breath sounds are absent altogether an the side of the pneumothorax. Chest percussion an the side of the pneumothorax will reveal a tympanitic note.
(Choice D) In eosinophilic pneumonia, symptom onset is gradual. Patients generally present with asthma-like symptoms angaing far several days. On physical examination, there are diffuse wheezes and fine inspiratory crackles suggestive of bronchial and interstitial involvement. Peripheral eosinophilia is also present.
(Choice E) Leukocytoclastic vasculitis is characterized by prominent cutaneous manifestations. Pulmonary infiltrates and pleural effusions can accur but symptoms are slow to evalve compared to those described in the above vignette.
Educational objective:
In a patient presenting with sudden anset of severe shortness of breath with stridor and coarse upper respiratory sounds, laryngeal edema is the mast likely diagnosis and the patient should be managed as such.

question: A 57-year-old male was invalved in a motor vehicle accident and was immediately brought to the Emergency Room. He suffered minar head and neck injury, but was found to have a broken tibia. He underwent repair of the tibial fracture the following day. Five days later, he suddenly develops tachycardia and is tachypneic. He complains of increasing chest discomfort and has a syncopal episode. His blood pressure is 80/55 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 24/min. Pulse oximetry showed 82% on room air. Stat echocardiogram reveals obstruction in the main pulmonary artery. Which of the following choices is the most appropriate course of action?
explanation:
Pulmonary embolism can present acutely with a sudden onset of dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypotension. If there is hemodynamic compromise and the clot is situated in the main pulmonary artery, the best treatment aptian is to perform a pulmonary embaolectomy. A pulmonary embaolectomy can be perfarmed either surgically ar percutaneausly. The clot is pulled out and most patients da well. Making the diagnosis is the mast important thing. Even after an embolectomy, the patient may require warfarin (coumadin) far a few months (Choice C).
(Choice A) Heparin is a good choice, but does not dissolve the clot. In addition, it does not improve the hemodynamics immediately. In the past, the majority of these patients died from shock. Heparin can be started, and the patient taken to the operating room.
(Choice B) Fibrinalytic therapy is an excellent chaice, but nat in a fresh postoperative patient, especially after trauma. It may cause diffuse bleeding, which can result in death.
(Choice D) A vena cava filter is generally placed when a patient has recurrent DVT occurrence or when there is a contraindication to heparin. These devices can be placed percutaneously either via the jugular ar femaral vein and are always placed below the renal vein.
Educational Objective:
When an acute pulmonary embolus occurs with hemodynamic compromise, the best treatment is fibrinalytic therapy. But, if the patient has contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic therapy, an embolectomy is the treatment of choice.

question: A 60-year-old man comes to the office with worsening shortness of breath over the last 5 months. He has had two episodes of bronchitis over the last 12 months. He now has a mild nonproductive cough. He denies any fever, chills, hemoptysis, chest pain, or difficulty breathing while lying on his back. His medications include an ipratropium inhaler, aspirin, and amlodipine. He was hospitalized twice in the last 3 years due to an exacerbation of his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day far the last 40 years. His temperature is 99 F (37.2 C), blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 18/min. Examination shows a thin man in mild respiratory distress with increased anteroposterior chest diameter, diffuse expiratory wheeze and loud S2. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation of bilateral lung fields with diaphragm flattening and small heart size. Which of the following is the most effective measure to decrease mortality in this patient?
options: A. Adding a short acting beta-agonist inhaler
C. Adding a long-acting beta agonist
explanation:
This patient mast likely has emphysema, which is a permanent destruction of the airways without obvious fibrasis. Both chronic bronchitis and emphysema are very common in individuals wha have an extensive smoking history. While 10-15% of smokers develop COPD, about 80-90 % of patients with COFD are smokers. Smaking cessation and home oxygen therapy are the only two treatments currently available that have been shown to decrease mortality in patients with COPD.
(Choice A) Short acting beta-agonists like albuteral have a quick onset of action and imprave lung function and symptoms in the shart term, but have not been shown to decrease mortality. They should be used as second-line drugs in combination with inhaled anticholinergic agents.
(Choice B) Although inhaled corticosteroids have been shown to decrease the number of COPD exacerbations and imprave quality of life they have no mortality benefit.
(Choice C) Long acting beta-agonists are used in patients with more advanced disease. They do provide improved quality of life and better symptom contral, but do not alter mortality.
(Choice D) Systemic corticosteroids are useful on a short term basis during acute exacerbations of COFD, but should not be used long term due ta their significant adverse effects.
(Choice F) Antibiotics are useful in patients with acute COPD exacerbations, but chronic antibiotics are not indicated. Antibiotics do nat effect martality.
Educational objective:
In all patients with COPD, the two modalities that have been shown to decrease mortality are home oxygen therapy and smoking cessation.

question: A 68-year-old female comes to the Emergency Room with increased shortness of breath and cough for 12 hours. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease for the past 14 years and has been oxygen dependent far two years. Twelve hours ago, she felt unable to get her breath. She took two extra nebulizer treatments and used her as-needed inhaler with no relief of symptoms. She denies any fever, chills, sweating, nausea ar vomiting, and hemoptysis. She rarely uses alcohal, but had smoked two packs/day for 45 years. She quit smoking about six years aga. Her medications include ipratropium, albuteral, multivitamins, and oxygen 2 liters/min by nasal cannula. She is a thin, frail female in moderate distress. Her temperature is 36.7C (98F), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 28/min. Pulse oximetry shows 84% on 2 liters oxygen by nasal cannula. The patient is given oxygen, methyl prednisolone, aerosolized ipratropium, and albuteral; however, the patient remains dyspneic and bedridden. ABGs are ordered and the results show: pH 7.32, PCO2 60 mmHg, and PO2 52 mmHg on 4-liters O2. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Increase oxygen by nasal cannula
C. Intubate and mechanically ventilate the patient
explanation:
This patient is having an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which at this stage is refractary to the standard initial management of corticosteroids and aerosolized bronchodilators. However, the patient is not crashing. In such patients there is a consensus to use non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) ahead of intubation. NIPPV is associated with decrease complications that are a hallmark af intubation, which includes infections. NIPFV is recommended in a patient of respiratory distress with a pH<=7.35 or PaCO2 >45 mmHg or respiratory rate >25 per min. There is better alveolar ventilation and less fatigue of respiratory muscles by using NIPFY. However, in septic, hypotensive, or dysrhythmic patients, NIPPV is contraindicated (Choice D).
The patient is already on oxygen therapy, but she is hypercapnic as well as acidotic. In such cases, increasing oxygen alone will reduce the respiratory drive. In COPD patients, PCO2 is elevated at baseline and it does not stimulate the respiratory center, unlike in narmal individuals. Their only drive ta increase the respiratory rate is hypoxia. If you just provide oxygen, it, in fact, worsens the situation. You should provide NIPPY to provide mare oxygen and to wash out the CO2 (Choice A).
Decreasing oxygen (Choice B) is certainly going ta cause mare harm. You should provide the oxygen in a mare appropriate way, such as NIFFY, rather than nasal cannula.
It is always better to avoid intubation, if possible, because of various complications associated with it. Intubation results in increased incidence of nosocomial infections, which increases long-term mortality in these patients (Choice C). However, if the patient does not respond to MIFFY, then intubation should be considered.
Aminaphylline is proven to be inferiar to a combination of bronchodilator and corticosteroids for the treatment af acute exacerbation of COPD (Choice E).
Educational Objective:
MIPPY is an excellent aption far patients with COPD exacerbation. It should be tried befare intubation and mechanical ventilation in COPD patients with CO2 retention.

question:
A 67-year-old white male with a long histary of bronchial asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency roam complaining of acute anset of shortness of breath far the last 30 minutes. He says that for the past 2 or 3 days he has been having some difficulty breathing and a productive cough with thick phlegm, but nothing as bad as the current episode. He also has a history of congestive heart failure after suffering a myocardial infarction for which he is taking furosemide and lisinopril. While talking to you in halting sentences, you note that he appears cyanotic, confused and is sweating profusely. He normally takes albuterol, ipratropium and budesonide inhalers for his breathing difficulties, but they have not relieved his current symptoms. On examination, he is found to be markedly dyspneic and his PaO2 is 55 mm Hg. A chest x-ray done in the ER is shown below.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: E. Increase furosemide and start digoxin
explanation:
This patient has a complete left lung collapse, seen as a complete opacification of the left lung on the x-ray. The leftward shift of the mediastinum indicated that the lung has collapsed due to volume loss (atelectasis), which has caused the mediastinum to be pulled toward the affected side. This most commanly results from bronchial obstruction, which can be caused by mucus plugging, tumar, foreign body or external compression. Obstruction of a mainstem bronchus can cause respiratory distress resulting in dyspnea, tachypnea and diaphoresis. The resulting hypoxia causes confusion and cyanosis. This patient requires urgent bronchoscopy for diagnosis and possibly treatment of his underlying obstructing lesion. Removal of secretions ar mucus plugs is associated with rapid improvement in PaO2 and quick symptomatic relief.
(Choice A) Theophylline is a xanthine derivative uncommanly used to treat acute bronchoconstriction in asthma; it is not indicated far complete collapse of the lung.
(Choice B) The patient does not have a tension pneumothorax or pleural effusion; therefore, a thoracocentesis is not required.
(Choice D) A central venous line is indicated for patients requiring volume replacement ar intravenous medications. This patient has no signs of hemorrhage.
(Choice E) The chest x-ray does not show pulmanary edema, despite this patient's histary of heart failure, so there is no need to add diuretics.
Educational objective:
Opacification of a single lung with shifting of the mediastinum toward the affected lung indicates a collapsed lung due to atelectatic volume loss. Urgent bronchoscopy is required to identify and possibly treat the abstructing bronchial lesion.

question: A healthy 36-year-old Caucasian woman comes ta the physician because of dyspnea on exertion. She has na other medical problems. She does not use tobacco, alcohal, or drugs. Her father has prostate cancer and her mother had a stroke. She takes no medication and has no known drug allergies. Her temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 22/min. Examination shows clear lung fields. Her chest x-ray shows prominent pulmonary arteries and an enlarged right heart border. EKG shows right axis deviation. Which of the following is the mast likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The physical findings in this patient are suggestive of pulmanary hypertension. Pulmanary hypertension is defined as a mean pulmonary arterial pressure greater than 25 mmHg at rest ar 30 mmHg with exercise. It is seen following the narrowing of the precapillary vessels, the loss of the pulmanary capillary bed, or passive backpressure from the post capillary vessels from any cause. It can be classified as follows:
1. Pulmonary hypertension associated with disorders of the respiratory system, hypoxemia, or both.
2. Pulmonary hypertension due ta pulmonary venous hypertension (left ventricular heart disease, mitral valve disease, or pulmonary veno-occlusive disease).
3. Pulmonary hypertension following chronic thromboembolic disease.
4. Pulmonary arterial hypertension (primary pulmanary hypertension, pulmonary hypertension associated with vasculopathy).
5. Pulmonary hypertension due to disorders directly affecting the pulmonary vasculature (pulmonary capillary hemangiomatosis).
The clinical features of pulmonary hypertension remain the same regardless of the underlying cause. Dyspnea, weakness, and fatigue are early complaints, which may be followed by chest pain, hemaptysis, syncape, or hoarseness (due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve). Right ventricular failure develops late in the disease and manifests with right ventricular heave, jugular venous distension, tender hepatomegaly, ascites, edema, etc. Chest x-ray would shaw enlargement of the pulmanary arteries with rapid tapering of the distal vessels (pruning) and enlargement of the right ventricle. An EKG may show right axis deviation, which is secondary to right ventricular strain and hypertrophy due to pulmonary hypertension. Untreated pulmonary hypertension would eventually lead to Cor pulmonale.
This patient mast likely has primary (idiopathic) pulmonary hypertension.
(Choices A, B, and C) All these options can cause secondary pulmanary hypertension: however, you will see signs and symptoms of pulmonary venous congestion.
(Choices D and E) Emphysema and bronchitis are unlikely since she is young and a nonsmaoker. A chest ®-ray will be different.
(Choice G) Scleroderma would cause pulmanary fibrosis, which eventually leads to secondary pulmonary hypertension.
Educational Objective:
Primary pulmonary hypertension can be seen in middle-aged patients, and it presents with exertional breathlessness. Lungs will be clear to auscultation. Chest x-ray would show enlargement of the pulmonary arteries with rapid tapering of the distal vessels (pruning) and enlargement of the right ventricle.

question: A 65-year-old male comes to the physician because of fever, chills, and productive cough. The symptoms started four days ago. He also complains of chest pain, which increases with inspiration. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. He drinks 3-4 ounces of alcohol daily. His chest x-ray showed an infiltrate in the right upper lobe. The sputum examination of the patient reveals capsulated gram-negative bacilli. Sputum culture is growing mucoid colonies. Which of the following is the mast likely causative arganism in this patient?
explanation:
This patient is most likely having Klebsiella pneumonia, also known as Friedlander's pneumonia. Gram-negative bacilli accounts far = 2% of cammunity-acquired pneumania, but account far most of the nosocomial infection and have high mortality rates. Some of the comman gram-negative bacteria (GMB) causing pneumonia are E.coli, Klebsiella Pneumoniae, Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, Proteus, Serratia marcescens and Acinetobacter. GMB pneumanias are rare in healthy individuals and usually occur in infants, the elderly, alcohalics, and an immunacompromised host, especially with neutropenia. The usual pathophysiclogical mechanism is colonization of the oropharynx, followed by micro aspiration of upper airway secretions.
Friedlander's pneumonia aor Klebsiella pneumaonia most frequently affect the upper lobe and produce currant jelly-like sputum with tissue necrosis and early abscess formation and a fulminant course. Klebsiella is ane af the most common organisms responsible for pneumania in alcoholics (Choice C). It is an encapsulated GMB and grows as mucoid colonies.
(Choice A) E. coliis a non-capsulated gram-negative bacillus. It generally causes nosocomial pneumonia. However, in alcoholics, Klebsiella is much mare common.
(Choice B) 5. Pneumaniae is the mast comman organism for cammunity-acquired pneumania; however it appears as gram-positive cocci in pairs.
(Choice D) Legionella is also a gram-negative bacillus and is generally seen following contamination of a water supply with aerosolized arganisms. Alcoholics can develop Legionella pneumania; however, it is not an encapsulated organism and does not produce mucoid colonies.
(Choice E) Mycoplasma is a common cause of atypical community-acquired pneumonia. Gram stain of expectorated sputum would show sparse bacteria, a mixture of polymorphonuclear leukocytes and mononuclear cells, and clumps of desquamated respiratory epithelial cells.
(Choice F) Pseudomonas is also a gram-negative bacillus and a very common cause of nosocomial infection. It is generally seen in patients with cystic fibrosis, neutropenia, advanced AIDS, bronchiectasis, and pneumonias acquired in intensive care. tis also an encapsulated organism.
Educational Objective:
Klebsiella is an encapsulated gram-negative bacillus and can cause pneumonia in subjects with debilitating conditions, especially alcoholics. Friedlander's pneumonia generally affects the upper lobe and is characterized by currant jelly-like sputum.

question: A 26-year-old Caucasian male comes to the physician because of severe productive cough for the past two manths. He alsa complains of occasional blood in sputum, and dyspnea for the last three weeks. His past medical histary is significant far otitis media, twa episodes of pneumonia, and sinusitis. He and his wife were recently worked up far infertility. Physical examination shows crackles in the left upper lobe. Chest x-ray shows dilated and thickened airways and irregular peripheral opacities in the left upper lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to make the diagnosis of his condition?
explanation:
The respiratory findings in this patient are suggestive of bronchiectasis. Bronchiectasis along with infertility in a young adult with history of recurrent respiratary infection is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. Bronchiectasis is a comman finding in cystic fibrosis patients and may be the only finding in adults. Bronchiectasis secondary to cystic fibrosis is often limited to the upper lobe and sputum generally grows pseudomaonas. The chest x-ray findings of dilated and thickened airway (Tram Track pattern) and irregular peripheral opacities (due to mucopurulent plugs) supparts the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.
Cystic fibrosis is the most common fatal autosomal recessive disease among Caucasians caused by mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein found in all exocrine tissues, leading to abnormal chlaride transportation and thick exocrine secretions. The diagnosis of cystic fibrosis is made an the basis of compatible clinical findings with laboratory confirmation. Sweat chloride test is the gold standard test for diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Sweat chloride concentration >= 60 mEq/L is almost diagnostic of cystic fibrosis.
(Choice B) Malecular diagnosis based an direct mutation analysis may be used for canfirmation af cystic fibrosis; however, there are several number of mutations (mare than 1,250) leading to cystic fibrosis, and the sensitivity is less than 90% even when tested for 20-30 of the mast commaon mutations. Thus, sweat chloride test is still preferred over molecular diagnosis.
(Choice C) Fulmonary function tests may show the obstructive pattern, but they are not useful in diagnosing the cystic fibrosis.
Educational Objective:
The diagnosis of cystic fibrosis is made on the basis of compatible clinical findings with laboratory confirmation. Sweat chloride test (>=60 mEg/L) is the gold standard test far diagnosis of cystic fibrosis and preferred over direct mutation analysis as more than 1,250 mutations in CFTR can lead to cystic fibrosis.

question: A 68-year-old male is hospitalized following an intracerebral hemorrhage. On hospital day 3, he develops redness, swelling, and tenderness of the left calf. There is no fever. Compression ultrasonography reveals a thrombus in the popliteal vein. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: C. Placement of an inferior vena cava filter
D. Mo treatment for his deep vein thrombosis
explanation:
Proximal deep vein thromboses (DVTs) require treatment ta prevent acute pulmonary embolism (FE). Most patients are treated acutely with heparin and then managed with warfarin aver the long-term. However, there are absolute contraindications to anticoagulation including recent surgery, hemorrhagic stroke, bleeding diathesis, and active bleeding. In patients with contraindications to anticoagulation, a history of complications from anticoagulation (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia), and in patients who develop a DVT or PE despite receiving anticoagulation, the use of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter is appropriate. VC filters may be placed via a transvenous approach, and inhibit progression af lower extremity clots through the VC towards the lungs. IVC filters may be permanent or removable. While there is some debate surrounding their long-term effectiveness, IVC filters have been proven ta prevent PE in patients with DVT in the acute setting.
(Choice B) The clinical benefit af thrambalytic therapy aver anticoagulation in the treatment of DVT is uncertain, but there is a definite increased risk of bleeding with thrambalytic therapy Absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy in DWT or PE include history of hemorrhagic stroke, active intracranial neoplasm, and active or recent internal bleeding.
(Choice E) Compression stockings decrease venous stasis in the lower extremities and are effective in reducing postoperative venous thrombosis in low risk surgical patients. While they may be useful in preventing OW Ts, compression stockings offer no benefit in the treatment of existing DV Ts.
Educational objective:
Patients with OT in whom anticoagulation is contraindicated (those with recent surgery, hemarrhagic stroke, bleeding diathesis, ar active bleeding) require placement of an inferior vena cava filter ta prevent PE.

question:
A 69-year-old Caucasian man presents with a two-day history of increasing shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. He is currently short of breath at rest and has an occasional cough. There is no past history of hypertension or ischemic heart disease. He reports drinking half a bottle of vodka daily and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 45 years. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. JVP is elevated and auscultation of his heart reveals faint heart sounds. The liver span is 18 cm and ascites is also present. Mo rales are heard in the lungs. There is 3+ lower extremity pitting edema up to the knees. The chest radiograph is shown below.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: D. Metastatic carcinoma of the liver
explanation:
This patient's signs and symptoms are highly suggestive of right-sided heart failure (jugular venous distension, hepatomegaly, ascites, peripheral edema). This patient is a chronic smoker and alcoholic, but there are no rales on examination and the CXR does not reveal significant pulmonary congestion. His chest radiograph shows a normal sized heart with some prominent pulmonary vessels and flattened diaphragms. The mast common cause of isolated right-sided heart failure is pulmonary disease, and when it accurs is known as cor pulmonale. Car pulmonale is most commonly caused by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Less frequent causes include pneumocaniosis, pulmonary fibrosis, kyphoscaoliosis, primary pulmonary hypertension, and repeated episodes of pulmonary embolism. The predominant symptoms of compensated cor pulmanale are related to the pulmonary disorder and include chronic cough, exertional dyspnea, wheezing, and fatigability. When the pulmonary disease is severe enough to cause RY dysfunction, signs of right-sided heart failure develop (i.e. jugular venous distension, right sided S3, right ventricular heave, hepatomegaly, ascites, and dependent edema). A chest radiograph may reveal a prominent right ventricle and pulmonary artery, in addition to any lung disease that can be visualized.
This patient mast likely has cor pulmonale secondary to COPD. He has a heavy smoking history and the diminished heart sounds may be due to the hyperinflated lungs.
(Choice A) Alcoholic cirrhosis usually results in a small and firm, fibrosed liver rather than hepatomegaly. Ascites may be present, but cirrhosis would not account for the other symptoms af right heart failure.
(Choice B) Coronary artery disease more commonly results in left-sided ar biventricular cardiac failure. If this were the case, there would be evidence of pulmonary congestion. Rarely, coronary artery disease (especially inferior wall myocardial infarction) may cause isolated right-sided heart failure. However, chronic pulmonary disease is a much more comman cause.
(Choice C) Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition in which a pericardial effusion develops so rapidly or becomes so large that it compresses the heart. The classical features include: jugular venous distension, hypotension, distant heart sounds, and pulsus paradoxus. This patient is not hypotensive.
(Choice D) Metastatic carcinoma of the liver can cause hepatomegaly (usually irregular hepatomegaly) and ascites; however, it would not account far the elevated JVP in this patient.
Educational Objective:
Cor pulmonale is a term for right-sided heart failure most commonly due to pulmonary disease. Signs of right-sided heart failure include: jugular venous distension, right-sided $3, right ventricular heave, hepatomegaly, ascites, and dependent edema.

question:
A 53-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with severe dyspnea and left-sided chest discomfort. He says that he was driving to work when he began to feel suddenly weak and short of breath. He has a long history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, esophageal reflux and chronic pyelonephritis. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. His current medications include ranitidine and inhaled ipratropium and albuterol as needed. Physical examination reveals trace ankle edema, decreased breath sounds aver the left chest and scattered wheezes over the right chest. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Arterial blood gas analysis is given below:
pH              7.42
PaO2            59 mmHg
PaCO2       41 mmHg
Which of the following most likely underlies this patient's current condition?
explanation:
COPD is a very cammon cause of secondary pneumothorax. Destruction of alveolar sacs and formation of large airspaces (generally in the upper lobes) are predisposing factors. Patients with pneumaotharax typically present with acute chest pain and shartness of breath. On the affected side, breath sounds are reduced and the chest is hyperresanant to percussion. In a patient with COPD presenting with catastrophic worsening of their respiratory symptoms, spantaneous secondary pneumatharax should always be suspected.
In cantrast, the evolution of clinical symptoms is much slower in an acute exacerbation of COPD secondary to infection ar anather inflammatory cause. Such patients generally give a history of increased production of purulent sputum, and lung examination will reveal diffuse rhonchi and wheezing. In COPD with predominant emphysema, breath sounds are reduced over bath lung fields.
Measurement of the arterial blood gases is a very useful tool for assessing the degree of respiratory failure. The partial pressure af oxygen (pO2) is not generally reduced until the FEV decreases below 50% af normal, and the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is generally nat increased until the FEV decreases by 25%. The arterial pH does nat decrease significantly unless the pCO2 is aver 45 mmHg. Hypercarbia generally accompanies ventilatory failure in patients with acute COPD exacerbations.
(Choice B) Patients with COFD are at increased risk for pneumania. Patients with pneumonia present with chest pain, breathlessness, cough with sputum and fever. Examination reveals dullness to percussion aver the infiltrated lung, crackles and branchial breath sounds. The symptoms are slower to evalve compared to those described in the vignette above.
(Choice C) It can be very difficult to differentiate a COFD exacerbation from acute CHF in patients presenting with acute shortness of breath. The presence of fine crackles bilaterally on physical examination is cansistent with CHF.
(Choice E) Transudation of pleural fluid often occurs in patients with CHF. The presence of fluid in the pleural space is characterized by dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds aver the effusion (usually in the lower lung fields). It takes a very large and/or bilateral pleural effusion to cause shortness of breath.
Educational objective:
Suspect secondary pneumothorax in COPD patients presenting with catastrophic worsening af their respiratory symptoms.

question: A 31-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath. She denies associated chest pain or palpitations. She tells you that she recently returned from a trip to Thailand. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and drinks alcohol occasionally. She is married and uses aral contraceptives. She has no significant past medical history. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and her heart rate is 120/min. A negative result on which of the following tests would best exclude pulmonary venous thromboembolism in this patient?
explanation:
Pulmonary embolism (FE) is a serious and potentially fatal complication of clots within the deep venous circulation. Thus, making a prompt and accurate diagnasis is critically important. Ruling aut PE is similarly important in patients with suggestive presentations. D-dimer is a fibrin degredation product elevated in the presence of blood clots and a number of other inflammatory conditions. It is 95-97% sensitive for venous thromboembalism with a specificity of 45%. Thus, a negative D-dimer result has a negative predictive value af greater than 95%, though a positive test has poor positive predictive value. In other words, a negative result is useful in ruling out PE, but a positive test provides less definitive information.
(Choice A) In the presence of large pulmanary embali, echocardiography may reveal pulmonary hypertension and/or evidence of right heart strain. However, small PE are unlikely to produce such changes, meaning that a normal echocardiogram is of limited value in excluding the diagnosis.
(Choice B) Classic chest x-ray findings in patients with PE include pleural-based densities representing lung infarction (Hampton's hump) and a prominent central pulmonary artery with lacal oligemia (Westermark's sign). However, it is not uncommon for affected patients to have perfectly normal chest x-rays, making this study minimally useful in attempting to exclude a diagnosis of PE.
(Choice C) Venous utrasonography is both sensitive and specific for diagnosing proximal deep vein thromboses. Unfortunately, only 70% of patients with PE have detectable deep vein thrombases, meaning that normal venous ultrasound of the legs cannot exclude the diagnosis of PE.
(Choice E) 70% of patients with FE have ECG abnormalities. However, most of the changes are nonspecific. Only a very small fraction of patients with PE have the classic S-wave in lead I, G-wave in lead ll, and T-wave inversion in lead III.
Educational objective:
A negative D-dimer is very helpful in excluding the diagnosis of pulmonary venous thromboembalism. A positive D-dimer, however is far from diagnostic and must be followed by mare specific studies.

question:
A 32-year-old man with a known history of recreational drug abuse is found by a friend on the floor of his apartment. There is a pool of urine around him. He is confused, not oriented to time or place, and does nat recall recent events. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and his heart rate is 120/min. He talks and moves all his extremities. His laboratory findings are the following:
Hemaglobin                      15.2 mg/dL
WBC                             12,500/mm3
Platelets                       160,000/mm3
Sodium                          136 mEg/L
Potassium                  5.1 mEg/lL
Creatinine                  1.1 mg/dL
AST                              35 units/L
ALT                              40 units/L
Alkaline phosphatase            70 unitsiL
CPK                             26,000 units/L
His urine toxicology screen is positive for cocaine and cannabinoids. The patient is at the greatest risk of which of the following?
explanation:
The greatest risk for this patient is acute renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis. There is ample evidence that this patient has rhabdomyolysis. First, he has twa strong risk factors for rhabdomyolysis: immabilization and cocaine abuse. Prolonged immobilization, as suggested by his presence an the floor, causes direct muscle damage and the release of creatine phosphokinase (CPK). Similarly, cocaine is a potent vasoconstrictor that causes diffuse ischemia, seizures, agitation, incidental trauma, hyperpyrexia and a direct toxic effect on myocytes. All of these may contribute to increased muscle breakdown. Second, the elevated potassium and CPK concentrations are strongly suggestive of rhabdomyolysis. As muscle cells break down, potassium, CPE, and myoglobin are released into the blood stream. In fact, 20% of cocaine overdoses are complicated by these laboratory abnormalities.
Renal failure in rhabdomyolysis is caused by acute tubular necrosis from excessive filtered myoglobin. The risk of myoglobin-induced renal failure is significant when the CPK concentration is greater than 20,000 units/L. Aside fram an elevated creatinine, potassium, and CPK, rhabdomyalysis is suggested when a urine dipstick tests positive for blood, but no red blood cells are seen on microscopy. This finding is caused by myoglobin in the urine. The risk of rhabdomyaolysis-induced renal failure may be decreased with aggressive hydration. Mannitol and urine alkalinization may also be beneficial
(Choice A) Aseptic meningitis is meningeal infection and/or inflammation in which no causative organisms are found on routine CSF stains and cultures. It is most commanly caused by Coxsackie virus or Echovirus. Intravenous drug abuse can predispose to bacterial meningitis.
(Choice C) Reye syndrome is an often fatal childhood hepatoencephalopathy associated with a viral infection and treatment with salicylates. It is not assaciated with rhabdomyolysis.
(Choice D) Dermatomyositis in an inflammatory auto-immune myopathy that causes direct destruction of skeletal myocytes. Itis, therefore, associated with elevated CPK levels, but it does nat fit the context of this atherwise healthy patient who recently used cocaine.
(Choice E) Splenic rupture generally results from blunt abdominal trauma. Neither cocaine nar marijuana use are risk factors If trauma is not involved. Infectious mononucleosis and post transplant Epstein-Barr virus-mediated pseudolymphaoma can also predispose to splenic rupture.
Educational objective:
Nearly 20% of cocaine overdoses are complicated by rhabdomyolysis, as indicated by marked elevations in serum creatine phosphokinase (CPK). The main danger associated with CPK levels greater than 20,000 U/L is acute renal tubular necrosis due to myoglobinuria.

question: A 66-year-old man complains of exertional dyspnea that has progressed over the last two years. As a result he has had to limit his physical activities to avoid becoming short of breath. He denies any significant chest pain, but does note having a recurrent cough productive of whitish sputum. His past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorathiazide. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history. His family history is significant for a strake in his mother. His blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg and his heart rate is 80/min. Physical examination reveals a mildly overweight patient in no acute distress. His anteroposterior chest diameter is markedly increased. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally with scattered expiratory wheezes. Which of the following agents is most likely to reduce this patient's symptoms?
explanation:
This patient's history and presentation are classic for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COFD). Typically due to cigarette smoking, COFD causes gradually decreasing expiratary flow rates, increased lung compliance, and increased lung volumes. The only therapies proven to pralong survival in patients with COPD are smoking cessation, supplemental oxygen, and lung reduction surgery in certain patients.
