The remainder of therapies are aimed at decreasing respiratory symptoms, improving quality of life, and decreasing hospitalizations. The mainstays of treatment are inhaled bronchodilators, especially anti-chalinergic medications like ipratropium and tiatrapium. Anti-muscarinic agents may be cambined with shart-acting beta agonists like albuteral. Inhaled steroids and long-acting beta agonists may be used for patients with more severe COPD.
(Choice A) Alpha-adrenergic blockers are used to treat benign prostatic hypertrophy and hypertension. They do not play a role in the treatment of COPD.
(Choice B) Beta-adrenergic blockers may exacerbate pulmanary symptoms in patients with severe reactive airway disease. They are safe in mast patients with mild to maderate COPD and asthma, however.
(Choice D) Dopamine agonists are used to treat Parkinson's disease, prolactinomas, and restless leg syndrome. They are not used to treat COPD.
(Choice E) Alpha 2-adrenergic agonists include clonidine, methyldopa, and dexmedetomidine. Clonidine and methyldopa are used to treat hypertension. Dexmedetomidine is used for sedation in the intensive care unit. These medications are not used to treat COPD.
Educational objective:
Inhaled anti-muscarinic agents such as ipratropium are the mainstay of symptom management in COPD. These anti-cholinergic medications may be combined with short-acting beta-adrenergic agonists for greater symptam relief.

question: A 52-year-old nursing home warker presents with a four week history of non-praductive cough and nighttime sweating. She also reports having unintentionally lost five pounds over the last month. Her medical history is significant for a mastectomy for left-sided breast cancer five years ago and hepatitis C for which she does not take treatment. She says she was last tested for HIV 6 manths ago and the test was negative. She takes no medications currently. She emigrated from Mexico two years ago. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and consumes two bottles of beer every weekend. Chest x-ray shows a right upper lobe cavity with surrounding infiltration. Which of the following is the mast impartant epidemiologic clue ta the etiology of this patient's disease?
explanation:
This patient most likely has reactivated tuberculosis. Reactivation of latent tuberculosis typically causes an apical cavitary lesion on chest x-ray. Clinically, patients complain of chronic low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss and a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum. In the United States, most cases of tuberculosis accur in patients who have immigrated from developing countries with a high incidence of the disease.
(Choice A) Nursing home warkers, health care workers, and prison workers come into contact with peaple who have tuberculosis mare frequently than the general public, but this patient's recent immigration from an endemic geagraphic regian is a mare significant risk factar.
(Choice C) Smoking is a risk factor far occlusive arterial disease and various forms of cancer including squamous and small cell lung cancer as well as pancreatic cancer and cancers of the upper aerodigestive tract.
(Choice D) This patient's history of breast cancer puts her at increased risk for malignancy recurrence.
(Choice E) Hepatitis C is a risk factor for many illnesses including hepatocellular cancer, cirrhasis, lichen planus, parphyria cutanea tarda, cryoglobulinemia and glomerulonephritis.
Educational objective:
Most cases of active tuberculosis in the United States occur in people who have immigrated to this country from endemic geographic regions.

question: A 44-year-old obese Asian immigrant presents to the ER complaining of a persistent cough for about 3 manths. He denies any fever, chills, runny nose or sputum production. He does complain of dyspnea on exertion, which also has been of a short duration. He says that aver the last year, he has become progressively short of breath and is unable to sleep lying down. He denies any chest pain or diaphoresis, but has had palpitations in the past. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. On examination, he is alert and in mild distress. He has a BP of 110/70 mmHg, pulse 100/min and is afebrile. Auscultation is difficult. The chest-x ray reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. It appears that the left main stem bronchus is elevated. There is no other lung pathology visible. The ECG shows irregularly irregular rhythm. The pathophysiology of this condition is related to which of the following?
explanation:
Mitral stenosis usually presents with symptoms in the third to fifth decade of life. The mast commaon cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic fever. The principal symptoms are those of dyspnea, pulmanary edema and precipitated by exercise, fever, anemia, sexual intercourse, tachycardia and pregnancy. In mitral stenosis, the left atrium gets very large and tends to push up on the left main stem bronchus. In the occasional patient, the irritation on the left main stem (and phrenic nerve) by the enlarged left atrium can produce a persistent cough.
Other findings will include a loud S1, opening snap and a diastolic murmur. ECG will reveal atrial fibrillation and/ar left atrial enlargement when narmal sinus rhythm is present. ECHO will confirm the diagnosis. All patients should receive endacarditis prophylaxis. Mitral valve surgery is the treatment (Choice B).
(Choice A) Acute pericarditis can present with chest pain which is sharp and pleuritic. There may be a law-grade fever and palpitations. The ECG shows diffuse ST segment elevations. Chest-x ray will reveal an enlarged cardiac silhouette. ECHO will reveal the presence of effusion.
(Choice C) In interstitial lung disease, patients may have fatigue, malaise, dyspnea and cough. Crackles may be heard and hypoxemia is common. Chest-x ray may be normal or may show a diffuse process. Generally, a lung biopsy is required for the diagnosis.
(Choice D) Malignancy will present with weight loss, anarexia and more specific signs of a mass. Ina 44 year old, mediastinal masses can be present. CT scan of the chest is usually diagnostic.
(Choice E) Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that may be asymptomatic or may present with cough, fever, weight loss, anorexia and fatigue Chest-x ray may show an enlarged mediastinum (bilateral hilar adnopathy) and CT scan will show adenopathy. Blood wark may reveal elevated calcium and angiotensin-converting enzyme levels. Bronchoscopy and/or mediastinoscopy are required for diagnosis.
Educational Objective:
An enlarged left atrium in mitral stenosis can cause a persistent cough and elevation of the left main stem bronchus.

question: A 72-year-old white male with a past medical histary of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and coronary artery disease presented to the physician's office because of fever, malaise, nonproductive cough, and shortness of breath. His temperature was 38.3C(101F). His chest x-ray showed a patchy right lower lobe infiltrate. He was sent home on aral amaxicillin. Four days later, the patient was brought to the emergency room because he was having continuous fevers, headache, pleuritic chest pain, and abdominal pain. He appears confused. His blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse rate is 100 per minute, respiratory rate is 24 per minute, and temperature is 38.9 C (102 F). His chest x-ray showed consolidation of the right lower lobe. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pneumania?
explanation:
In any elderly patient, confusion and tachypnea might be the anly manifestations of pneumania. Legionella pneumania should be suspected in those who have not responded to beta-lactam antibiotics. This disease accounts for 5% of community-acquired pneumania and up to 30% of nosocomial pneumania. Patients usually present with an acute onset of fever, malaise and headache followed by a nonproductive cough and dyspnea. Confusion, often with severe headache, abdominal pain and diarrhea are other characteristic features of Legionellosis. More characteristic features suggestive of Legionella pneumonia are the presence af hyponatremia (sodium of less than 130 mmal/mL) and a Gram stain smear of respiratory secretions showing many polymorphs but very few visible organisms. Chest x-ray usually shows patchy interstitial inflammation and unilateral lower lobe invalverment, which may progress to areas of consolidation over a few days.
The definitive diagnosis of Legionella pneumania is generally made by urinary Legionella antigen testing using an ELISA test. The treatment of choice is high dose erythromycin ar azithromycin.
Legionella species reside in water and are transmitted to humans via aerosol Identification of the enviranmental source and reduction of Legionella colonization should be undertaken to prevent Legionellosis. The most commonly used method of decontamination is periodic superheating and flushing of water supplies. This method is particularly useful for urgent disinfection during an outbreak. Hyperchlorination is no langer recommended because Legionella species are relatively chloride-resistant. Biocides are also relatively ineffective.
(Choice B) Mycoplasma pneumonia also does not usually respond ta penicillins or cephalosparins; however, it rarely gives severe illness. Chest x-ray usually shows peribronchial pneumania pattern. Confusian with severe headache and abdominal pain are also not typical of Mycoplasma pneumania.
Strepiococcus, Haemophilus and Moraxella usually respond to beta-lactam antibiotics. Again, these infections usually do not cause abdominal pain and confusion with severe headache.
Educational Objective:
Any elderly patient who presents with pneumonia, abdominal pain, confusion and hyponatremia should be suspected for Legionella pneumonia. This should also be suspected in patients who fail to respond to beta-lactam antibiatics and Gram stain showing many polymorphs with few visible organisms. The treatment of choice for Legionella pneumonia is high dose erythromycin or azithromycin.

question:
A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressive exertional dyspnea that worsened after he contracted an upper respiratory infection. He also complains of bilateral ankle swelling. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking. Physical examination reveals a mildly overweight patient in mild respiratory distress. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral wheezes and a prolonged expiratory phase. His white blood cell count is 14,500/mm3 and his hemaoglobin level is 16 mg/dl. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following:
pH = 7.37
pO2 = 65 mmHg
pCO2 = 60 mmHg
Absence of marked acidosis in this patient is best explained by which of the following?
explanation:
This patient has chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure due to chronic obstructive pulmanary disease (COPD). However, he has maintained a normal pH because his kidneys have increased bicarbonate retention to compensate for the increased pCO2. Patients with chronic hypoventilation due to COPD, obesity hypoventilation syndrome, or neuromuscular causes have gradual increases in the pCO2 that results in respiratory acidosis. To compensate, the kidneys increase bicarbonate retention approximately 0.1 mEg/L for every 1 mmHg increase in pCO2 above baseline. Importantly, patients never completely normalize or over avercarrect their pH.
(Choice A) Minute ventilation is the product of tidal volume and respiratory rate. Patients increase minute ventilation in order to compensate for metabolic acidosis, not to carrect underlying obstructive pulmonary disease.
(Choice B) There is increased dead space ventilation in COPD, which warsens the respiratory acidosis.
(Choice C) Pulmonary vasoconstriction results from alveolar hypoxia. It may help normalize shunting and ventilation-perfusion mismatching within the lung but will not compensate for respiratory acidosis.
(Choice E) The shift bicarbonate out of and chloride into erythrocytes is integral to carbon dioxide transpart throughout the body. However, this process does not markedly affect the acid/base status.
Educational objective:
The body compensates for chranic hypercapnia by increasing renal bicarbonate retention. Typically 0.1 mEq/L of bicarbonate is retained for every 1 mmHg increase in pCO2.

question: A 43-year-old woman with congestive heart failure, rheumatoid arthritis and chronic hepatitis C complains of abdominal discomfort and difficulty breathing. Physical examination shows dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Chest x-ray reveals a large right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis yields pleural fluid with a glucose content of 30 mg/dL and an LDH of 192 units/L. Which of the following explains the pleural fluid glucose concentration?
options: C. Increased permeability of the right hemidiaphragm
D. High white blood cell content of the pleural fluid
E. High amylase content of the pleural fluid
explanation:
This patient has a pleural effusion with a low glucose concentration, consistent with an exudative pleural effusion. Concentrations less than 30 mg/dL suggest an empyema ar rheumatic effusion. A glucose cancentration between 30-50 mg/dL indicates an effusion due to malignancy, lupus, esophageal rupture, or tuberculosis. Glucose concentration is thought to be deceased in exudative pleural effusions due ta the high metabolic activity of leukocytes (and/or bacteria) in the fluid.
(Choice A) Inflammatory conditions cause pleural effusions by increasing the pleural membrane and capillary permeability. While this mechanism establishes the effusion it does not cause a decreased pleural glucose concentration, specifically.
(Choice B) Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure is the mechanism responsible for transudative pleural effusions. It does not cause the low glucose concentration.
(Choice C) Increased permeability of the right hemidiaphragm is thought ta contribute to the development of right-sided pleural effusions in cirrhosis, also known as a hepatic hydrothorax, Effusions due to cirrhosis are typically transudates.
(Choice E) Elevated pleural amylase concentrations are found in pleural effusions due to esophageal rupture ar pancreatitis. High amylase concentrations are not respansible far the low glucose concentration found in these effusions.
Educational objective:
The low glucose concentration in exudative effusions is due to the high metabolic activity of leukocytes within the pleural fluid.

question:
A 64-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and confusion. Upon arrival his blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg and pulse is 120/min. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender, distended, and rigid with positive rebound tenderness. His past medical history is significant far rheumatic fever as a child, hypertension, coronary artery disease and atrial fibrillation. He receives a total of 6 liters of normal saline and undergoes emergent laparotomy. Postoperatively he complains of shortness of breath. His respiratory rate is 34/min. He is emergently intubated because of poor oxygenation. His chest x-ray is shown below:
This film is compared to a chest x-ray performed one week earlier, which was within normal limits. Currently, the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 8 mmHg. Which of the following is the mast likely cause of his current condition?
explanation:
This patient was initially admitted ta the hospital with symptoms of an acute abdomen, hypotension, and tachycardia, which together suggest severe internal bleeding. After laparotomy, he developed hypoxia, shortness af breath, and tachypnea, at which time chest x-ray showed diffuse alveolar infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema.
Pulmonary edema can be cardiogenic ar non-cardiogenic. Non-cardiogenic pulmanary edema, or ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), may develop in the setting of sepsis, severe bleeding, pneumania, toxic ingestion, or burns, when release of inflammatory mediators causes increased alveolar capillary permeability and resultant pulmonary edema. Measurement of the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) can help distinguish these two processes. A PCWP <=18 mmHg suggests ARDS (Choice C), while a value >=18 mmHg suggests cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
(Choice A) Idiopathic pulmanary fibrosis (IPF) presents with gradual onset of cough, dyspnea, crackles, and clubbing. Chest x-ray findings include decreased lung volumes and interstitial prominence, particularly at the bases. The acuity of this patient's symptoms and his diffuse alveolar (rather than interstitial) findings rule out IPF.
(Choice B) Mitral stenosis may cause dyspnea and pulmonary edema. This patient's history of rheumatic fever puts him at risk. However, in mitral stenosis a mid-diastolic rumble is expected on cardiac auscultation and the PCWP should be elevated.
(Choice D) Left ventricular systalic dysfunction can lead ta pulmanary edema. Given this patient's risk factors (coronary artery disease, HTM, age 64), an intra-operative myocardial infarction is plausible. However, the PCWP would certainly be elevated if this were the cause of his pulmanary edema.
(Choice E) Iatrogenic fluid overload can induce signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure including pulmonary edema and dyspnea. However, pulmonary edema accumulates as a result of congestion and elevated hydrostatic pressure, rather than from increased alveolar capillary permeability, so the PCWP would be elevated.
Educational objective:
ARDS is a form of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema caused by inflammatory damage to alveoli. Sepsis, severe bleeding, trauma, and toxic injury may result in ARDS Criteria for diagnasing ARDS include: acute dyspnea, an inciting condition, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray, PCWP <18, and Pa02/F,0,, ratio <200.

question:
A 45-year-old black female presents to you because of a dry cough and has not been feeling well for the past manth. She did have some pain in her shins a few weeks ago. She denies any allergies, smoking, or other medical problems. Her ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. The chest x-ray is shown below.
What is the most likely pathophysiology in this patient?
explanation:
Sarcaid is a granulomatous disease seen typically in young black females. tis a systemic disarder, which primarily affects the lungs. The condition may be asymptomatic or the patients may present with dyspnea, fewer, night sweats, or weight loss. The classic finding on a chest x-ray is bilateral mediastinal adenapathy, as seen above. Some times patients may present just with erythema nodosum (painful skin lesions over the shins). Some individuals may have skin, eyes, liver, kidney, and central nervous system involvement. Elevated calcium and angiotensin converting enzyme levels are also seen. Once mediastinal adenopathy is seen on a chest x-ray, the next step is to perform a mediastinal bronchascapy and obtain tissue for biopsy. Symptomatic patients require steroids (Choice C).
(Choice A) The above clinical presentation and findings are not representative of congestive heart failure In a young female, congestive heart failure would be a rare finding without any history. On chest x-ray, the lung fields will be engarged and Kerley B lines will be seen.
(Choice B) Lupus can present with numerous systemic organ findings, but adenopathy is nat typical. Patients may have a rash, arthralgia, pneumaonitis, brain syndromes, nephritis, and a vasculitis. Diagnosis is by findings of antibodies to dsDNA.
(Choice D) Lung cancer can present with adenopathy. Small cell cancer can present in such a way; however, the majority of patients with such significant adenapathy from lung cancer will be symptomatic. Weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis may be the other symptoms. Small cell cancer is rare in patients under the age of 40-50, especially if they are nansmakers.
(Choice E) Most interstitial lung disease present with lung fibrosis and not adenopathy. Patients may have progressive dyspnea, weight loss, and fever. Lung parenchymal changes are seen in the majority, but a normal x-ray does not rule out interstitial lung disease. A CT scan is required, followed by a lung biopsy.
Educational Objective:
Sarcoid can present in a black female with bilateral hilar adenopathy. Recognize the association with erythema nodosum. Biopsy typically shows non-caseating granulomas. Serum Ca and ACE levels are elevated. Steroids are the treatment of choice in symptomatic patients.

question: A 42-year-old morbidly obese man is being evaluated for poor sleep. He complains of frequent awakenings due to a choking sensation and says that the resulting tiredness severely limits his physical activity. He also complains of chronic leg swelling. He denies cigarette, alcohol, or drug use. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and his heart rate is 110/min. Which of the following additional findings is mast likely to be present in this patient?
options: A. Anemia due to low erythropoietin
B. Decreased chloride due to bicarbonate retention
C. Decreased sodium due to increased ADH secretion
D. Decreased CO2 due to persistent hypoxia
E. Increased BUN due to volume constriction
explanation:
This marbidly obese man presents with classic obstructive sleep apnea and obesity hypaventilatian syndrome. Patients with sleep apnea alone hypoventilate at night, which causes transient hypoxia and hypercarbia that resolves during wakefulness. Patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome, however, do not have respiratory mechanics that allow them ta resume normal ventilation during wakefulness and hence develop chronic respiratory failure. Consequences of abesity hypoventilation syndrome include pulmanary hypertension with cor pulmonale, secondary erythrocytosis, hypoxia, chronic hypercapnia (due to persistent hypoventilation) and respiratory acidosis. In a compensatory effort to maintain a normal pH, the kidney increases bicarbonate retention and decreases chloride reabsarption.
(Choice A) Patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome are chronically hypoxic and develop a compensatory erythrocytosis.
(Choice C) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome may lead to cor pulmonale, volume overload, and hypervalemic hyponatremia. However, the low serum sadium in this situation is not due to increased ADH secretion.
(Choice D) Patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome have bath hypoxia and increased pCO2 due to chranic hypoventilation.
(Choice E) This patient has total body hypervalemia and does not give a history concerning far intravascular volume depletion.
Educational objective:
Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is a long-term consequence of severe obesity and untreated obstructive sleep apnea. It causes chronic hypercapnic/hypoxic respiratory failure, secondary erythrocytosis, pulmanary hypertension, and cor pulmonale.

question: A 32-year-old Caucasian female presents to your office with persistent cough and shortness of breath. She has had three episodes of pneumonia over the last year. She had severe sinusitis one year ago, and an episode of bloody diarrhea that required hospitalization and IV antibiotic therapy six manths ago. She does not smoke or consume alcohal. She denies any illicit drug use. She is currently not taking any medications. All her immunizations are up-to-date. Her blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg and heart rate is 90/min. Physical examination reveals fine crackles over the right lower lung lobe. Ma lower extremity edema is present. Meck palpation does not reveal any lymph node enlargement. The chest x-ray shows right lower lobe infiltrates and left upper lobe fibrosis. The ECG reveals non-specific ST segment and T wave changes. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Measurement of serum alpha-1-antitrypsin level
C. Quantitative measurement of serum Ig levels
explanation:
This patient has a history of recurrent bacterial infections that is highly suggestive of immunodeficiency with involvement of humaral immunity. Selective immunoglobulin deficiency that includes [gA and/or 1gG subfractions is a possible diagnosis. Far example, selective deficiency of IgG3 alone is mare camman in adult females and is associated with recurrent sinopulmonary as well as gastrointestinal infections. Food allergies and autoimmune diseases may also be present. IgA deficiency and common variakle immunodeficiency are also possible. The latter may be associated with suppressed cell immunity and increased risk of malignancy. Quantitative measurement af serum immunoglobulin levels helps to establish the diagnosis.
(Choice D) Cystic fibrosis is also a possibility, but it usually manifests earlier in life and does not cause gastroenteritis.
(Choice A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is an inherited disorder that leads to emphysema and liver damage, but does nat increase the risk of recurrent infections.
(Choices B and E) Methacholine challenge is used to diagnose asthma, and V/Q testing is employed in patients suspected to have pulmonary thromboembolism; both these diagnoses are unlikely in this case.
Educational objective:
Recurrent bacterial infections in an adult patient may indicate a humoral immunity defect. Quantitative measurement of serum immunoglobulin levels helps to establish the diagnosis.

question:
A 32-year-old man presented to the emergency department five hours aga with an acute asthma exacerbation. He has been receiving continuous albuteral nebulizer treatments since that time. He has a 20 year history of asthma but notes that recently the frequency of his attacks has increased. Presently, his blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and heart rate is 120 and regular. On physical exam, the patient appears drowsy. Breath sounds are diminished bilaterally but there are no wheezes. The most recent ABG reveals:
pH =7.32
pO2 = 65 mmHg
pCO2 = 50 mmHg
Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation:
The mainstay of treatment for an asthma exacerbation is an inhaled short-acting Bo-agonist like albuterol. Other bronchodilators, such as ipratropium, may be beneficial early in the course. Corticosteroids are also indicated in all patients with exacerbations but they take several hours to significantly decrease inflammation. This patient has developed hypercarbia, hypoxia, and somnolence, and is nat moving air an exam despite continuous inhaled bronchodilators. He therefore needs mechanical support to breathe. Due to asthma's obstructive nature, CO2 retention is a worrisome marker of respiratory failure.
(Choice A) In patients with asthma that is mild persistent or warse, maintenance therapy with inhaled corticosteroids is important. However, steroids play no role in the management of acute exacerbations.
(Choice B) Ipratropium is an anticholinergic agent that reverses vagally mediated, but not allergen-induced, branchaspasm. It has same benefit as an adjunctive medication in moderate to severe exacerbations when given early in the course.
(Choice C) Theophylline is a bronchodilator occasionally used to treat severe asthma or COPD. It is nat considered first-line because it has a number of acute and chronic side effects and is not as powerful a bronchodilator as mast B-agonists.
(Choice D) Intravenous corticosteroids are used in patients with moderate to severe asthma exacerbations. Unfortunately, it takes several hours before clinically significant decreases in branchial inflammation can be achieved — obviously insufficient to treat this patient already in respiratory failure.
Educational objective:
Maderate to severe asthma exacerbations are treated with a combination of By-agonists, inhaled anticholinergics, and intravenous steroids. Patients wha develop respiratary failure, marked by hypercapnia ar severe hypoxia, require intubation and mechanical ventilation.

question: A 25-year-old male presents with progressive shortness of breath aver the past 6 months. His past medical history is significant only far neonatal hepatitis that resolved spontaneously when he was 6 months of age. The man has never smoked. On lung auscultation today, there are decreased breath sounds over both lower lobes. Chest x-ray demonstrates emphysematous changes in the bilateral lower lobes. Routine bloodwork is normal. Which of the following analyses would be most helpful in establishing this patient's diagnosis?
options: D. High resolution CT scan of chest
explanation:
This patient's chest x-ray reveals emphysema, a diagnosis most comman in older smokers. However, patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency may develop emphysema decades earlier, even if they have never smoked. Alpha-1 antitrypsin is an enzyme that counteracts neutrophil elastase. In AAT deficiency, uninhibited elastase causes bullous changes of the lungs. The classic radiographic pattern is emphysematous changes of the lower lobes. In AAT deficiency, the involvement is panlobular, in contrast to the centrilobular pattern in smoking-induced emphysema. In addition to lung disease AAT deficiency can cause liver disease, which may manifest as neonatal hepatitis, cirrhasis ar liver failure. The diagnosis of AAT deficiency can be made by measuring the serum alpha-1 antitrypsin level (Choice B).
(Choice A & C) Lung biopsy is an invasive procedure with associated marbidity. Measurement of the serum AAT level is less invasive, and low values are highly diagnostic for alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
(Choice D) When the suspicion for lung disease is high but chest x-ray is non-diagnostic, high resalution CT (HRCT) scan of the chest is warranted. This patient's chest x-ray shows the classic pattern of panlabular emphysema seen in AAT deficiency. Therefore, HRCT will not add diagnostic value.
(Choice E) Fulmanary function testing (FFT) in emphysema reveals a | FEV1/FYC ratio, + TLC, and | DLCO. However, PFTs will not help distinguish AAT deficiency emphysema from smaoking-induced emphysema.
Educational objective:
Suspect alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency in non-smoking adults <=45 years of age with panlobular emphysema an chest x-ray. Patients with AAT deficiency are also at risk for liver disease (neonatal hepatitis, cirrhosis, and/or liver failure). Measurement of the serum alpha-1 antitrypsin level is minimally invasive but can be highly diagnastic.

question:
A 38-year-old male is brought to the emergency room with high-grade fever, shaking chills, productive cough and shortness of breath that started twa days ago. His medical history is significant far two hospital admissions for alcohal withdrawal seizures. He continues to drink alcohal every day. He has no other medical problems and does not take any medications. On admission, his temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and respirations are 20/min. His skin and mucous membranes are dry. Physical examination reveals crackles and bronchial breath sounds in the right lower lobe. Chest x-ray demanstrates right lower lobe consolidation. He is started on ceftriaxone, azithromycin and intravenous normal saline at 200 ml/hr. Six hours later the nurse calls you because he is breathing at 38/min and requiring 100% oxygen. Emergent intubation is performed. A repeat chest x-ray is shown below.
Which of the following is now most likely to be present in this patient?
options: A. Normal pulmanary capillary wedge pressure
C. Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure
explanation:
This patient was initially admitted ta the hospital with pneumonia. Despite the institution of appropriate antibiotic therapy, he developed a dangerous condition known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS most often develops in the clinical setting of sepsis, pneumonia, aspiration, toxic ingestions, trauma, and/or burns. A history of alcoholism is a further risk factor for ARDS. The pathophysiology of ARDS involves release of inflammatory mediators as a result of local or distant tissue injury. These inflammatory mediators cause alveolar damage, increased alveolar capillary permeability, and leakage of proteinaceous fluid inta the alveoli. Clinically, this leads to the acute onset of tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and dyspnea. Arterial blood gas reveals hypoxemia and chest x-ray reveals bilateral alveolar infiltrates. The differential diagnasis for hypoxemia and bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray also includes cardiogenic pulmanary edema. An important diagnostic tool for differentiating ARDS from cardiogenic pulmanary edema is measurement of the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). A PCWP <=18 mmHg suggests ARDS (Choice A), while a value >=18 mmHg suggests cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
(Choice B) Any disease process causing edema or fibrosis of the lung parenchyma causes decreased, not increased, lung compliance. Mechanical ventilation wath positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) is used in the treatment of ARDS to counteract the decreased compliance.
(Choice C) Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure may be seen in congestive heart failure caused by hypertension or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Cardiac dysfunction does not cause ARDS.
(Choice D) Pulmonary arterial pressure is variable in patients with ARDS. Pulmonary arterial hypertension accurs in 25% secondary to hypoxic vasoconstriction and destruction of lung parenchyma.
(Choice E) ARDS causes shunting, as evidenced by elevation of the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. In contrast, hypoventilation and decreased FiQ2 (fraction of inspired oxygen) cause hypoxemia with a normal alveaolar-arterial oxygen gradient.
Educational objective:
ARDS is a form of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema caused by inflammatory damage to the alveoli. Criteria for the diagnosis of ARDS include: acute onset of respiratory distress in the setting of a predisposing condition (sepsis, pneumonia, etc), Pa02/FiO2 ratio <200, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray, and a normal PCWE.

question: A 64-year-old male presents to the physician's office with increasing shortness of breath. He denies arthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or chest pain. He was hospitalized for pneumonia four years ago but has otherwise been healthy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg, pulse is 82/min and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry reveals an oxygen saturation of 88%. On chest auscultation, breath sounds are diminished throughout, and the expiratory phase is prolonged. Heart sounds are regular and there are no murmurs ar gallops. There is no peripheral edema or jugular venous distention. Laboratory studies show a hematocrit of 56% and WBC count of 8,700/mm3. Which af the following interventions will have the maximum impact an this patient's survival?
options: B. Prophylactic antibiotics to reduce exacerbations
explanation:
COPD is a progressive condition of limited airflow during expiration which is not entirely reversible. COFD encompasses chronic bronchitis and emphysema, and is one of the leading causes of death worldwide. Smoking is the most important risk factar for COFD. Signs and symptoms include progressive dyspnea, cough, decreased breath sounds, and a prolonged expiratory phase. Hypoxemia — measured via arterial blood gas, pulse oximetry, or hematocrit — is common. Long-term supplemental oxygen therapy has been proven to prolong survival and improve quality of life in hypoxemic patients with COPD (Choice D). Indications far oxygen therapy in COPD include: Pa02<=55, Sa02<=88%, hematocrit>=55%, ar evidence of cor pulmonale.
(Choice A) Temparary use af systemic steroids is appropriate in the management of acute COPD exacerbations, but maintenance systemic steroids should never be used, as side effects are significant and mortality may be increased.
(Choice B) Frophylactic antibiotics are not routinely used in COFD management. They may be appropriate in select patients during acute exacerbations but are nat proven to improve survival.
(Choice C) While vaccinating against influenza and pneumococcus is impartant, oxygen therapy is the best proven method of improving survival in COPD.
(Choice E) Beta-blackers are generally avoided in maoderate/severe asthma and COPD because of their bronchoconstrictive properties. Beta-aganists, however, are central to COPD management.
Educational objective:
Long-term supplemental oxygen therapy has been proven ta prolong survival in patients with COPD and hypoxemia. Criteria for therapy include PaO2<=55, Sa02<=88%, erythrocytosis (hematocrit>=55%), or evidence af cor pulmanale.

question: A 47-year-old male who has just returned from a cruise to the Bahamas presents to the hospital with a high-grade fever, productive cough and shortness of breath for the past two days. He also complains of frequent vomiting and diarrhea. He has no prior medical problems, does not take any medications, and denies using tobacco, alcohol or drugs. His temperature is 40°C (104°F), blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 18/min. Lung examination reveals right lower lobe crackles. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Chest x-ray demonstrates right lower lobe consalidation. Sputum Gram stain contains many neutrophils with no organisms. Which of the following antibiotics must be given to this patient?
explanation:
Legionella accounts for approximately 2-10% of all community acquired pneumonias (CAF). Travel associated Legionnaire's disease is a well-documented phenomenon that has been linked to cruise ship and hotel water supplies. Symptoms that help distinguish Legionella from other causes of CAP include high-grade fever (>=39.0°C), gastrointestinal symptoms, and neurologic symptoms. Lung exam typically reveals rales and chest radiograph mast often reveals focal lobar consolidation. Legionella pneumophila is a Gram negative rod that stains poorly because it is primarily intracellular. Therefore, sputum gram stain showing many neutrophils but no organisms is alsa characteristic. The definitive diagnosis may be made by culturing the bacteria on charcoal agar and/or urinary antigen testing. Legionnaire's disease is treated with either macrolides (azithromycin) aor newer generation fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin) (Choice E).
(Choice A) Vancomycin is used to treat patients with nosocomial pneumonia, where the probability of MRSA is high.
(Choice B) Clindamycin is primarily used to treat infections with anaerobic organisms. It is the antibiatic of choice in aspiration pneumania.
(Choice C) Fluconazole is an anti-fungal agent. It can be used to treat pulmanary cryptococcal infection.
(Choice D) Amoxicillin does not cover Legionnaire's disease or ather atypical pneumonias.
Educational objective:
Legionella pneumaphila is an intracellular Gram negative organism commonly spread by cooling towers and water supplies. Travel-associated infection is well-documented. Symptoms suggestive af Legionnaire's disease include cough, fever >39°C, Gl symptoms, and confusion. Diagnosis is confirmed by urine antigen testing or culture on charcoal agar. Treatment with azithromycin or levofloxacin is appropriate.

question:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room with shortness of breath, which she says began suddenly two hours ago while she was enjoying her favorite television show. She also reports the simultaneous onset of sharp, left-sided chest pain. Her previous medical history includes diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years and hypertension for the past 6 years. Her family history is significant far heart disease in her father, who died at age 40. Her medications include enteric-coated aspirin, captopril and glipizide. She has a 30 pack-year smoking history, but does not smoke currently. On physical examination, she is in acute distress and is sweating profusely. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.5°F), pulse is 140/min and irregular, respiratory rate is 30/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Her oxygen saturation is 84% on room air by pulse oximetry. Jugular venous pressure is within normal limits and her lungs are clear to auscultation. Serum analysis reveals the following:
Hematacrit             40%
WBC count           11,600/mm3
Platelet count         190,000/mm3
Chest x-ray is unremarkable. ECG reveals irregular RR intervals, with no definite P waves and narrow QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current symptoms?
explanation:
The signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism (FE) are nonspecific and highly variable but this patient's acute onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain are the twa mast common symptoms of FE, accurring in 73 and 86 percent of patients respectively. Hemoptysis occurs in =20% of cases, and leg symptoms (which suppart the diagnosis by suggesting concomitant deep venous thrombosis) are present in =30%. She also has multiple physical exam findings consistent with PE including tachypnea, tachycardia, and low-grade fever, which are presentin 70, 30, and 15 percent of cases, respectively. Still, this combination of signs and symptoms—though consistent with pulmonary embalism—is by no means diagnostic. Furthermare, she does nat have the classic findings of PE on ECG (S1Q3T3) ar chest x-ray (Hampton's hump, Westermark's sign), but again such findings are present in only the minarity of cases. The ECG and chest x-ray findings described here are inconsistent with the other answer chaices provided, however. In patients with PE, low oxygen saturation and atrial fibrillation—baoth present in this patient—are associated with poor prognosis.
(Choice A) This patient has many risk factors far myocardial infarction (diabetes, family history, and smoking), putting this high on the differential diagnosis. However, the absence of ST elevation, T wave inversion, and GQ waves on ECG make PE the more likely explanation.
(Choice B) Atrial fibrillation is a common consequence of mitral valve stenosis. Mitral valve stenosis presents with a mid-diastolic rumble and opening snap at the apex on cardiac auscultation. Acute onset shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, and tachypnea are not characteristic of this condition.
(Choice C) Cardiac tamponade may present with dyspnea, tachypnea and tachycardia. However, the classic triad of distant heart sounds, hypotension and distended neck veins is absent in this patient, and electrical alternans is not present an ECG.
(Choice D) Tension pneumatharax presents with acute onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. Exam reveals unilateral absence of breath sounds, tracheal deviation and hypatension, none of which are present here.
(Choice F) Bronchaconstriction, as occurs in asthma and emphysema, may present with dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, and low oxygen saturation. The absence of wheezing and the presence of pleuritic chest pain in this patient make bronchaoconstriction less likely. Hyperinflation is common on chest x-ray.
Educational objective:
The signs and symptoms of PE are nonspecific and highly variable. It is a diagnosis that should be suspected in any patient who presents with some combination of sudden-onset shartness of breath, pleurtic chest pain, low-grade fever and hemoptysis. Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxemia are common exam findings. Calf swelling and Virchow's triad (stasis, endothelial injury, and hypercoagulable state) are not always present in PE.

question: A 36-year-old female presented to the emergency room with fever and a productive cough. The physician on call suspected community acquired pneumonia and prescribed azithromycin for 5 days. After 5 days of treatment, she comes to your office with no improvement of her symptoms and complains of worsening foul smelling sputum. Further inquiry reveals that she had undergone an upper Gl endoscopy 8 days ago for a lang history of heartburn and suspected peptic ulcer disease. She also reports a history of manic-type bipolar disorder. In your office she has a blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg, her pulse is 108/min, temperature is 38.7C (101.6F) and respirations are 26/min. Chest x-ray showed a right upper lobe infiltrate. Which of the following additional therapies would be most helpful for this patient's condition?
explanation:
This patient likely has an anaerobic pneumonia as a complication of upper Gl endoscopy (aspiration pneumania). Patients with pneumonia caused by anaerobic arganisms typically present with systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise as well as a characteristic foul-smelling sputum. Patients with poor dentition, who have a greater quantity of anaerobic organisms in their mouth, are at greater risk of anaerobic aspiration pneumonia. The location of the infiltrate depends on the patient's body position when the aspiration accurs as the infectious agents tend to settle in dependent lung zones, such as the posterior segments af the upper lobes (recumbent) and the superior and basilar segments of the lower lobes (standing). Adding an antibiotic with anaerobic coverage, such as clindamycin, is the most reasonable next step.
(Choice A) Doxycycline is a good antibiotic far outpatient community acquired pneumonia where the macrolide resistance is suspected.
(Choice B) Ciprofloxacin has good gram negative coverage but is not effective for anaerobic or most gram-positive organisms.
(Choice C) TMP+SMX is the drug of choice far pneumocystis pneumonia, and it is effective against many gram-negative and gram-positive agents, but it does not provide significant anaerabic coverage.
(Choice E) The ampicillin and gentamicin combination has good synergism against gram-negative aerobes. It can be used for abdominal infections in combination with metronidazole.
Educational objective:
In patients with fever and a cough productive of foul-smelling sputum after an upper Gl endoscopy or any ather instrumentation of the upper airway or esophagus suspect an anaerobic lung infection. Clindamycin is the mast commanly used agent far this type of infection.

question:
A 32-year-old man is intubated and mechanically ventilated after an opioid drug overdose. The ventilator triggers 12 breaths per minute, each delivering 500 ml of tidal volume at a flow rate of 60 L/min. You perform an inspiratory hold for 2 seconds following delivery of the tidal volume, and the airway pressure is measured to be 30 cm H2O.
Time
The measured pressure reflects which of the fallowing?
explanation:
Several aspects of pulmanary mechanics may be measured while patients are mechanically ventilated. The peak airway pressure (the maximum pressure during the respiratory cycle) equals the sum of the resistive pressure, elastic pressure, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEER).
Peak ainway pressure = resistive pressure + elastic pressure + PEEP
The elastic pressure, or plateau pressure, is the pressure at the end af an inspiratory hold maneuver. It is the product of the lung's elastance and the volume of gas delivered. Since one's elastic recall is inversely related to lung compliance, a decrease in compliance (e.g. with pulmanary fiborosis) is accompanied by an increase in the elastic pressure.
(Choice A) It is impossible to calculate the upper airway resistance when a patient has an endotracheal tube in place because the tube bypasses the upper airway.
(Choice B) In mechanically ventilated patients, the total airway resistance takes into account the resistance af the ventilator circuit, the resistance of the endotracheal tube, and the resistance of the patient's airways. The resistive pressure is alsa referred to as the peak pressure.
(Choice D) Respiratory muscle strength is determined by measuring the patient's negative inspiratary force (MIF).
(Choice E) The alveolar end-expiratory pressure is typically equal ta the atmospheric pressure. In abstructive lung disease, however, the alveoli cannot empty completely, resulting in higher than normal end-expiratory pressures. This is called intrinsic, or auto-, PEEP. The end-expiration hold maneuver measures auto-PEEF.
Educational objective:
Several values related to pulmonary mechanics can be calculated in mechanically ventilated patients. Lung compliance is calculated by performing the end-inspiratary hald maneuver. Airway resistance is calculated by examining the peak airway pressures. Positive end-expiratory pressure (FEEF) is calculated with the end-expiratory hold maneuver.

question: A 55-year-old man presents to your office with a six-month history of non-productive cough, especially at night. He denies pastnasal drip, chest pain, difficulty breathing, or wheezing. His anly ather complaint is water brash. His past medical history is insignificant, and he is not taking any medications. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. Physical examination is insignificant. Chest x-ray and pulmonary function testing are normal. Esophagoscopy is also narmal. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is an impartant cause of chronic cough. Cough can be a presenting symptom of GERD. This should be considered in the differential diagnasis of chronic cough alang with postnasal drip, which is the number ane cause of chronic cough in nonsmokers. Usually, patients with GERD typically complain of heartburn. However, water brash is also a common presenting symptom. In this patient with persistent cough and water brash, esophagoscopy does not reveal mucosal inflammation. Even though endoscopy is the mast sensitive investigation far establishing the diagnosis of reflux esophagitis, it does not eliminate GERD as a cause af the patient's symptoms. The next best step in the management of this patient is a 24-hour pH recording that can be dane an an ambulatory basis. It can record acid reflux at the esophageal site as well as at the pharyngeal site, which makes this test very specific for supra esophageal complications of GERD. This test is usually employed in patients with chest pain ar chranic cough when esophagoscopy is negative.
Other tests far GERD, like mucosal biopsy (Choice A), barium swallow (Choice C), Bernstein test (Choice D), and esophageal manometry (Choice E) help to establish the diagnasis, but are less specific and usually are not helpful in demonstrating pharyngeal reflux.
Educational Objective:
Cough can be a presenting symptom of GERD. A 24-hour pH recording is the most specific test available far acidic gastroesophageal reflux. It is usually employed to diagnose the cause of chest pain or supra esophageal complications of GERD in patients with negative esophagoscopy.

question: A 53-year-old homosexual man comes to the ER with shortness of breath and dry cough over the past week. You note that he was hospitalized for Candida esophagitis one month ago, but left against medical advice. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, heart rate is 120/min and regular, oxygen saturation is 89% on 2L/min of oxygen by nasal cannula, and temperature is 38.3°C (101°F). options: A. Increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
explanation:

This manifests as an increase in the alvealar-arterial axygen gradient.
(Choice A) The pulmanary capillary wedge pressure is increased in the setting of left atrial hypertension. This is typically due to left ventricular failure but may also result fram mitral valve disease.
(Choice B) Obstructive lung disease and obesity hypoventilation syndrome can cause hypoxia secondary ta alveolar hypoventilation. Alveolar hypoventilation is rarely the cause of hypoxia in pneumonia.
(Choice D) Lung compliance, ar distensibility, is increased in emphysema; it is not greatly affected by PCP.

Pneumocystis jiroveci {carini) pneumania is an important cause of progressive dyspnea and hypoxia in patients with HV/AIDS Hypoxia results from an increased alvealar-arterial oxygen gradient.

question: A 65-year-old Caucasian male comes to the physician because of shortness of breath, fever, and a productive cough for the last four days. He is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. He quit smoking twa years ago. His medical problems include hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and coronary artery disease. He is taking daily-inhaled ipratropium bromide, albuterol, metformin, metoprolol, warfarin, and diltiazem. His temperature is 38.9 C (102 F), blood pressure is 140/88 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 28/min. Pulse oximetry showed 88% on room air. Examination shows decreased breath sounds and crackles over the right lower lobe of the lung. Which of the following is the mast appropriate next step in his management?
explanation:
This patient is presenting with pneumania. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COFD). The acute exacerbations in COPD patients may be bactenal, viral, ar non-infectious in origin. Patients with COPD are at high risk of respiratory infection due to underlying pathological abnormalities, like histological abnormalities in the airways and an impaired local host immune system. The most cammoan bacteria responsible for acute exacerbation of COPD are S pneumaniae, H. influenza, and M. catarrhalis. Clinically, it may be difficult to determine if the patient is having infectious exacerbation of COPD; however, the presence of a productive cough, fever, hypoxia, and auscultatory findings as found in this patient is suggestive of pneumonia. A chest x-ray is the mast useful preliminary and first investigation to be done in a case of suspected pneumonia in any patient (Choice C).
(Choice A) Bronchascopy is a useful aid in some cases of respiratory infections (FCF pneumania, fungal); however, it is never recommended as a routine and preliminary investigation in suspected pneumonia.
(Choice B) Sputum gram stain is a useful investigation for pneumonia. A specimen that contains greater than 25 PMN and less than 10 epithelial cells per low power field represents a purulent specimen: however, it is very nonspecific, and you often see the oropharyngeal flora. Many physicians do not order this test for community-acquired pneumonia, since it is often difficult to identify the microbiologic cause of the pneumania. Most often the treatment is empirical after the chest x-ray.
Obtaining routine sputum cultures (Choice E) is also controversial. One, itis difficult to interpret because of the many arganisms that cause pneumania are fastidious in the oropharyngeal cavity {including Strep pnuema and Hemophilus). The secand difficulty is these fastidious organisms overgrow the arganisms that actually cause pneumania. Another problem is that it is difficult to interpret if there is a colonizer, such as MRSA and pseudomanas.
(Choice D) Mycoplasma causes atypical pneumania, which is characterized by fever dry cough, and bilateral perihilar infiltrates on chest x-ray. Mycoplasma serology is rarely performed, since it is not cost effective and most of the empirical antibiotics (azithromycin, levafloxacin, gatifloxacin) often caver these atypical organisms.
Educational Objective:
All patients with suspected bacterial pneumania should have a chest x-ray done as the first step, and antibiotics should be administered as soon as possible without waiting for sputum gram stain ar cultures.

question: A 42-year-old white male presents to your office complaining of periodic breathing difficulty and wheezing. He visited an otolaryngologist far persistent nasal blockage recently. His past medical histary is significant for unstable angina experienced five months ago. His current treatment includes aspirin, diltiazem, and pravastatin. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or drugs. His vital signs are within limits. What is the mast probable cause of this patient's respiratory complaints?
explanation:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is aspirin sensitivity syndrome. The clues to the correct diagnosis include aspirin ingestion, persistent nasal blackage, and episodes of bronchocanstriction. The pathogenesis af aspirin sensitivity syndrome is believed to involve 'pseudo-allergic reaction,’ that is an exaggerated release af vasoactive and inflammatory mediatars in susceptible individuals. Aspirin is a cyclooxygenase (COx-1 and COX-2) inhibitor. As the result of its pharmacalogic action, arachidonate diverges from blocked COXs to a 5-lipoxygenase pathway. Accumulation of leukotrienes and changed prostaglandin/leukotriene balance triggers characteristic reactions (bronchoconstriction, palyp farmation) in susceptible individuals. Leukotriene inhibitors are gaining popularity in the treatment of this condition. Other commanly used treatment modalities include topical corticosteroids and aspirin desensitization therapy.
IgE-mediated reaction (Choice A) and immune-complex disease (Choice B) are important in the pathogenesis of some asthmatic conditions. Cytotoxic antibodies (Choice C) and cell-mediated hypersensitivity (Choice D) have limited rale in the pathogenesis of asthma.
Educational Objective:
Aspirin sensitivity syndrome is believed to be a pseudo-allergic reaction. It results from aspirin-induced prostaglandinfleukotriene misbalance in susceptible individuals. Treatment includes avoidance of NSAIDs and the use of leukoiriene receptor antagonists (drug of choice).

question: A 45-year-old male comes to the emergency room complaining of shartness of breath that began 3 hours ago. explanation:

question:

question:

question:

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes to your office with a three-month history of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and non-
productive cough. She has also been having difficulty swallowing. Her only ather medical problems are
Raynaud's phenomenon, heartburn, and high blood pressure. On examination, diffuse thickening of the skin
with telangiectasia is noted. Her current medications include amlodipine, enalapril, and ranitidine. What is the
mast probable pathologic mechanism of her pulmonary complaints?
explanation:
This patient most likely has systemic sclerosis. A wide range of pulmanary complications can occur in

comman underlying mechanism of pulmonary complications is interstitial fibrosis. It develops in about 40%
patients with diffuse disease. Pulmonary vascular lesions (Choice B) can develop concomitantly with
interstitial fibrosis, but isolated pulmonary hypertension without interstitial fibrosis occurs in less than 10% of
patients. Aspiration of gastric content with resultant pneumonia (Choice C) due to esophageal dysmotility, is
less caomman than interstitial fibrosis. The risk of bronchogenic carcinoma (Choice D) is increased in
patients with systemic sclerosis, but it is not the most common cause of pulmonary complications.
Restriction of chest mavements (Choice E) due to extensive thoracic skin fibrosis is rare.
Educational Objective:

question:
A B5-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and

prolonged and there are bilateral wheezes. You administer bronchodilators, facial mask oxygen, and

explanation:
This is a patient with carbon dioxide narcosis secondary to a severe COPD exacerbation. A viral upper
respiratary infection is often the inciting event for a COPD exacerbation, if the infection and/or underlying lung
disease is severe, frank respiratary failure may ensue. In severe exacerbations, alveolar hypoventilation
leads to hypoxia and hypercapnia. Sedatives should be avoided in these patients as they can exacerbate
alveolar hypoventilation. Elevated carbon dioxide concentrations can cause confusion, somnolence, cama,
and tanic-clanic seizures.
(Choice A) A thromboembalic stroke is more likely to cause unilateral hemiparesis, numbness, ar
paresthesias than somnalence or tonic-clanic seizures, particularly in the setting of a COPD exacerbation.
(Choice B) Diffuse cerebral vasoconstriction may result from drugs (e.g. cocaine) or intracranial

(Choice C) Subarachnoid hemorrhage cammaonly results from shear injury. Patients may experience

Educational objective:
Alvealar hypoventilation, as in a COPD exacerbation, can cause carbon dioxide retention and resultant

question:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling in the right leg. He was
recently hospitalized for a right lower extremity deep venous thrombosis and discharged on warfarin. Today
his INR is 1.12. Ultrasound reveals a right popliteal vein thrombosis extending into the deep femoral
vein. What is the best initial management step far this patient?
options: A. Increase warfarin dose for goal INR = 2.0
D. Place inferior vena cava filter
explanation:
This patient should be started on intravenous or low molecular weight heparin, and his warfarin dose should
be increased until his INR is at least 2.0. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) management is divided into acute
anticoagulation and clot stabilization, chronic anticoagulation, and treatment of DVT-related
complications. Initial clot stabilization with a heparin product is mandatory. Heparin retards further thrombus
formation by binding to antithrombin lll and enhancing its activity; heparin stabilizes but does not lyse existing
clot. Mext, long-term anticoagulation with warfarin is necessary. Warfarin inhibits activation of the vitamin k-
dependent clotting factors Il, Vil, IX, and x, but unfortunately it takes at least 4-5 days for warfarin to became
therapeutic, hence the need for concomitant "bridging" heparin. Lastly, patients with new DVTs should wear
compression stockings to decrease the risk of developing post-phlebitic syndrome, a potentially devastating
complication.
The abave patient presents with a propagating clat in the setting of sub-therapeutic warfarin. This must be
treated like a new, unstable clot; thus heparin must be used while his INR becomes therapeutic.
(Choice A) This patient certainly requires an increase in his warfarin dose to reach an INR = 2.0. However,
this unstable clot also requires heparin.
(Choice C) Thrombalytics are indicated for patients with hemodynamically significant pulmaonary
embali. They are nat routinely used for patients with DVTs.
(Choice D) Inferior vena cava filters may be used in patients with lower extremity DVTs where
anticoagulation is contraindicated. This patient has no contraindications to anticoagulation.
(Choice E) First-time DVTs are typically treated with anticoagulation for 8 months. Thus, it would be
inappropriate to discontinue warfarin in this patient.
Educational objective:
Acute deep vein thromboses should be treated with a combination of warfarin and heparin for the first &
days. After § days, the heparin may be discontinued if the patient's INR is therapeutic. Warfarin should be
continued for at least 6 months in mast patients with a first-time clot. A progressing clot in a patient with a
sub-therapeutic INR requires bridging heparin until the INR is therapeutic.

question:
A 56-year-old Caucasian male complains of chronic exertional dyspnea for the past several years that has
progressively worsened. He cannot remember the last time that he saw a doctor, and does not take any
medications regularly. Itis difficult for him to climb two flights of stairs without having to rest. His dyspnea
has gotten so bad that it has severely limited his activity level, and he now spends most of his time on the

00 AM with difficulty breathing, coughing, and wheezing that improve when he sits up. He usually coughs up

The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is chronic bronchitis. Along with emphysema, chranic

result of several hours of not coughing. The sputum in patients with chranic bronchitis is usually white ar

function tests should be performed on this patient to determine the degree of airway obstruction.
(Choice A) Patients with left ventricular failure often become dyspneic at night, but this is a result of lying flat

(Choice B) Asthma can lead to cough and dyspnea, and can present at nearly any age. Asthma symptoms

{Choice D) This patient has no apparent risks for pulmanary embalism. Patients with a pulmanary embolism

(Choice E) Patients with pulmanary fibrosis have dyspnea, but usually have a dry cough as opposed to the
productive cough seen in this patient's case.
(Choice F) Isolated right ventricular failure would nat be expected to result in respiratory symptoms.
Educational objective:
Chranic branchitis is defined as a chronic productive cough that has been present for at least three manths in

question:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath
accompanied by a non-productive cough and left-sided chest discomfort that increases on inspiration. She

age B5, has had diabetes for 20 years; mother, age 58, has coronary artery disease. She has never been

85% on 6 liters of oxygen. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2. She is alert and cooperative without cyanosis or

explanation:
The patient described is suffering from a pulmanary embolism (PE) of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Risk

uncaomman. The most definitive tests used to diagnose PE include ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning,

the most commonly used.
(Choice A) EKG and cardiac enzymes can be used to assess for chest pain related to myocardial ischemia,

{Choice B) Echocardiography can be used to assess myocardial thickness, ejection fraction and the cardiac

(Choice C) Doppler ultrasound of lower extremities to diagnose DVT may be helpful in this setting as this

{Choice E) Chest-x ray and sputum cultures are used to diagnose pulmanary tuberculosis and other
respiratory infections.
(Choice F) Coronary angiography is used in the diagnosis of coronary artery atherosclerosis and in variant

Educational objective:

question:
A 53-year-old male presents with progressively worsening dyspnea over a 4 month period. He also

alcohol or illicit drugs. He has worked as a plumber far the past 30 years. On physical examination, his

15/min. Physical exam reveals fingernail clubbing and bibasilar end-inspiratory crackles on lung
auscultation. Chest x-ray demonstrates ground glass opacities of the lower lung fields, multiple pleural

Individuals with an occupational history invalving mining, shipbuilding, insulation, ar pipe wark are at risk for
asbestosis. Symptoms tend to develop 20-30 years after the initial exposure. The mast common clinical

abnormalities of the lower lung fields consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. Fleural plagues are also seenin
approximately 50% of asbestosis chest x-rays, and help distinguish this condition from other causes of
pulmanary fibrosis. In addition to pulmonary fibrosis and pleural plagues, asbestosis patients are also at
increased risk for developing certain malignancies. Studies have shown that asbestos exposure increases
the risk of lung cancer 5-fold. This patient's weight loss is further indication that his 3x3 cm peripheral mass
is likely cancerous. The mast comman malignancy in asbestosis patients is branchogenic carcinoma
(Choice D).
(Choice A, B & C) While asbestos exposure is known to increase the frequency of many cancers, there is
no definitive data indicating that affected patients are at significantly increased risk for stomach, colon or
pancreatic cancers. Duodenal ulcers da not confer a strong risk far malignancy.
(Choice E) Asbestos exposure can cause peritoneal as well as pleural mesothelioma. However, the location
af this patient's mass is not consistent with peritoneal mesothelioma.
(Choice F) Asbestos exposure is the anly risk factor for mesathelioma. Despite the strong link between
these two entities it is impartant to know that bronchogenic carcinoma has a higher incidence than
mesothelioma in patients with asbestos exposure. Furthermore, this 3x3 cm mass is in the lung field, notin
the pleura as would be the case in mesathelioma.
Educational objective:
Asbestos exposure increases the risk of malignancy, pulmanary fibrosis and pleural plagues. In terms of

bronchogenic carcinoma being the more comman cancer in these patients.

question:

question:
A 45-year-old white man presents to your office complaining of daytime somnolence, increased fatigahility,

options: B. Advise to sleep in supine position
explanation:
This patient is most probably suffering from sleep apnea syndrome. The clinical scenario described above is

headaches, increased fatigability, and loud snoring). Mild hypertension is also frequently seen, which usually
improves with treatment of sleep apnea syndrome (Choice D). The standard diagnostic method is
polysomnography. The treatment of a mild to moderate disorder usually starts with weight reduction,
avoidance of sedatives and alcohol (Choice A), and avoidance of supine posture during sleep (Choice B).
Other treatment modalities include uvulopalatopharyngoplasty and nasal continuous pasitive ainvay pressure
(CPAP) during sleep.
Tracheostomy (Choice E) is used in patients with a severe disorder, and when all the other treatment

Educational Objective:
The typical presentation of sleep apnea syndrome includes a moderately obese middle-aged man
complaining of daytime somnalence, morning headaches, increased fatigability, and who is noted to snare
loudly. Try weight reduction, avoidance of sedatives and alcohal, and avoidance of supine posture during
sleep as a first step.

question:

(Choice A) Congestive heart failure is characterized by exertional dyspnea, arthopnea and chronic

question:
A 37-year-old female with a long history of multiple sclerosis presents to her primary care physician
complaining of dyspnea. She denies cough and fever but admits to right-sided chest pain. Her medical
history is significant for an episode of atrial fibrillation diagnosed in the emergency department two weeks
ago, which resolved spontaneously without intervention. She is wheelchair-bound due to spastic paraparesis
and has saccadic speech. Her only allergy is to penicillin. On physical examination, her blood pressure is
120/70 mmHg and her heart rate is 110/min and regular. Chest x-ray demonstrates a right-sided pleural
effusion. Therapeutic thoracocentesis is performed, and pleural fluid analysis reveals the following:
Protein           3.1 all
RBC count          230/mma3
WBC count         150/mm3
LDH                  220 10
Glucose             100 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pleural effusion?
explanation:
This patient most likely has a pulmonary embolism (PE) from a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in one of her
immobilized legs. The fact that she is wheelchair-bound puts her at increased risk for DVT. Over half of
patients with a OVT in a proximal leg vein will experience a PE, which manifests clinically with dyspnea,
tachypnea and pleuritic chest pain. Arterial blood gas analysis in this setting typically shows respiratory
alkalosis and a widened A-a oxygen gradient due to WIC mismatch. Chest x-ray may be normal or show
evidence of atelectasis and/or pleural effusion. When pleural effusions develop, the pleural fluid may be
exudative ar transudative (exudative is most common) and its composition can vary widely. While pulmanary
angiography is the gald standard for diagnosing PE, in practice, helical CT scanning is the diagnostic test of
chaice.
(Choice A) Pleural effusions in congestive heart failure are typically bilateral and symmetric. These effusions
are transudative, with few RBCs or WBCs and a glucose concentration equal to that of the serum. Increased
intravascular hydrostatic pressure is the underlying mechanism responsible.
(Choice B) Effusions in hypoalbuminemia are similar to those in CHF. The mechanism here is decreased
intravascular oncatic pressure.
{Choice D) Aspiration pneumonia will initially cause an exudate due to chemical pneumonitis. Without
treatment, the effusion may progress into a pulmonary abscess, leading ta empyema with frank pus in the
infiltrate.
(Choice E) Malignancy in the lungs ar pleural space can cause turbid ar bloody exudates, with lymphaocyte-
predominance of the WBC fraction and many RBCs. The glucose concentration can be variable depending
an the tumar burden, but it approximates the serum value in early effusions.
Educational objective:
Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in all patients at risk for DVT who present with acute-onset
tachypnea, dyspnea and chest pain. The diagnostic test of choice is helical CT scanning of the chest.

question:
A 43-year-old previously healthy male is hospitalized for acute pancreatitis. On day 3 of his admission, he
develops respiratory distress. He is transferred to the intensive care unit and intubated. His initial ventilator
settings are:
FiO,                      0.8 (80%)
Respiratory rate          10/min
Tidal valume              500 mi
PEEP                    5mm H,0
Ten minutes after being intubated, the man's blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg and his heart rate is
90/min. His arterial blood gases are:
pH                        742
pO,                       105 mmHg
pCO,                     37 mmHg
Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
options: A Decrease the positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP)
explanation:
Acute pancreatitis causes adult respiratory distress syndrame (ARDS) in approximately 15% of patients. In
patients with ARDS mechanical ventilation improves oxygenation by providing an increased fraction of
inspired oxygen (FiO2) and by providing PEEF to prevent alveolar collapse. In the hospital setting, the arterial
p02 provides an important measure of oxygenation. Itis influenced mainly by the FiQO2 and PEEF level. The
arterial pCO2, a measure af ventilation, is affected mainly by the respiratory rate and tidal volume.
The narmal FiQO2 at sea level is 0.21, or 21%. Patients are often provided a high FiO2 (= 80%, ar 0.8) initially
in mechanical ventilation, pending the results of the first blood gas analysis. The ventilator settings can
subsequently be adjusted based upon these results. (The goal is to maintain paQ2 = 60) An important early
goal in initial ventilator management should be to decrease the FiO2 to non-toxic values. There is no strict
cut-off FiOZ2 value for oxygen toxicity, but levels below 50-60% are desirable. In this case, the patient's initial
ABG values indicate appropriate ventilation and excessive oxygenation. Thus the FiQ2 should be slowly
decreased to below 60% to prevent axygen toxicity to the lungs.
(Choice A) Decreasing PEEP would lower oxygenation by decreasing the number of alveoli available for gas
exchange. While this would address the patient's increased paiJ2, it would be better to decrease the FiQ2 to
also decrease the likelihood of oxygen toxicity.
(Choices B, D & E) Tidal volume (TV) and respiratory rate (RR) are the major determinants of pulmonary
minute ventilation, which predominantly affects the paCO2. This patient's initial ventilator blood gas shows a
normal paCO2, so the minute ventilation can be considered appropriate far his current condition. The TV and
RR ventilator settings do not need to be changed at this time.
Educational objective:
Acute pancreatitis can cause adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in up to 15% of patients. The first
step in the initial ventilator management of ARDS is usually to decrease the FiQ2 to relatively non-toxic values
(i.e. = 80%). PEEF may be increased as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation after the FiO2 is lowered.

question:
A 35-year-old male from Wisconsin presents to his physician complaining of fever, night sweats, productive

explanation:

question:
A 35-year-old male was involved in a motor vehicle injury and suffered serious chest trauma. A chest tube

explanation:
Empyema is an infection in the pleural space. Empyema can occur from parapneumanic effusions. They can

fistula, penetrating trauma, a thoracotomy, and infection from a hepatic or subphrenic abscess, or from a

the chest is an excellent medium far the growth of bacteria. The individual will usually present with a low-
grade fever, and empyema is best diagnosed with a CT scan. When the empyema is localized, complex, and
has a thick rim, anly surgery is the answer. In surgery, the thick pleural peel is removed, the pus is remaved,
and the chest is drained. All old blood clots are drained and removed. (Choice A)
{Choice B) Empyema, which is recent in onset, can be removed by fibrinalytic therapy. Both streptokinase
and urokinase have been used. However, in a patient with a recent matar vehicle trauma, fibrinolytic therapy
is contraindicated. In addition, the fibrinalytics usually do not have much success when the empyema is
loculated and has a thick rim round it.
(Choice C) Antibiotics are useful for early empyema. Any subacute empyema, or those which are complex,
will nat resolve with just antibiotic therapy. Drainage is always required. Increasing the dose of antibiotics
usually does nat treat complex effusions or empyema.
(Choice D) When an empyema fails ta be drained by a single chest tube, another chest tube may be placed
Just in case the first one is blacked. However, for complex empyema, chest tube insertion can be difficult and
is best dane under ultrasound ar CT scan guidance. When a thick peel is present, a second chest tube
usually does nat wark. The removal of the thick fibrinous peel in surgery is called decortication.
(Choice E) Bronchoscopy may be required if one suspects a blockage in the airways and to help clear
secretions. However, when an empyema has occurred after trauma, bronchoscopy is a redundant
procedure. It does not aid in the diagnasis, nar does it help in clearing up the effusion.
Educational Objective:
Blood in the chest, if it is not evacuated, can get infected. The majarity of patients will present with a law-
grade fever, dyspnea, and chest pain. Surgery is required to remove the clotted blood and fibrinous peel.

question:
A 40-year-old white male develops a proximal deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity. Detailed

explanation:

(Choice A) An INR of 1.0 indicates that the patient's PT is equal ta the normal contral, with no inhibition of

A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency room with shortness of breath and cough productive of blood-

question:
A 32-year-old female complains of a ‘nagging’ dry cough aver the last 4 weeks. She says that the cough is
present during the day and also wakes her from sleep at night. There is no associated shartness of breath,

H1 histamine blockers are widely used to treat patients with allergic rhinitis. Mast are available aver-the-
counter without a prescription. Chlorpheniramine is a specific H1 antihistaminic receptor blocker that

(Choice B) Up to 1/3 of patients with allergic rhinitis have coexisting branchial asthma, which is

(Choice C) Acid reflux can cause upper respiratory tract irritation sufficient to cause cough. Suppressian of

(Choice E) About 5-20% of patients treated with angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors develop dry

Educational objective:
H1 histamine receptor antagonists decrease nasal inflammation and post-nasal drip in patients with allergic

question:
A 50-year-old male presents to his physician complaining of daytime somnolence. He reports that yesterday,

explanation:

Educational objective:
Obstructive sleep apnea is an under-diagnosed condition common in the obese population. Snoring, daytime

An incidentally discovered solitary pulmonary nodule on radiographic imaging may be benign (infectious

explanation:

and can cause sare throat, cough, and wheezing. Nighttime GERD can alsa cause the patient ta wake in the
middle of the night with symptoms similar to an asthma attack.
Initial treatment of GERD involves lifestyle modifications such as avoiding late evening meals and elevating
the head of the bed. Patients may alsa be prescribed a trial of a proton pump inhibitor (FP) for symptom
