(Choice A) Lisinopril may induce cough, but is unlikely to produce strictly nocturnal symptoms.
{Choice B) Aspirin is recommended far all diabetic patients far primary prevention of coronary and

A patient with asthma-like symptoms that occur only at night and nat during the day may actually be suffering
fram GERD. Such patients should adopt anti-GERD lifestyle modifications and receive a trial of a PPL.

A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency room with shortness of breath, cough and hemaptysis far the
past two days. He says he has never had symptoms like these before. His medical history is significant for a

past 20 years. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm

the following is the most likely explanation for his hemoptysis?
explanation:
Wegener's granulomatosis is defined clinically as the triad of systemic vasculitis, upper and lower airway
granulomatous inflammation, and glamerulonephritis. Disease anset is usually around age 40, with men and
women equally affected. The upper respiratary tract is the mast common site of invalvernent and symptom
presentation. Granulomatous inflammation in the nasopharynx causes epistaxis, purulent rhinorrhea, ofitis,
sinusitis and, over time, saddle nose deformity due to destruction of the nasal cartilage. Cutaneous
manifestations are varied and include painful subcutaneous nodules, palpable purpura, and/or pyoderma
gangrenosum-like lesions as in the patient described above. Laboratory testing typically demonstrates a
positive C-ANCA due to antibodies against proteinase-3 and an elevated CRP. Urinalysis shows RBC casts,
proteinuria and sterile pyuria if glomerulonephritis is present. Treatment is with cytotoxic agents such as
cyclophosphamide.
(Choice A) Pulmonary tuberculosis can cause hemoptysis and cutaneous findings, including scrofuloderma
averlying infected lymph nodes, a facial eruption known as lupus vulgaris and others. Masal destruction is
mare typical of leprosy than cutaneous tuberculosis.
(Choice B) Bronchogenic carcinoma may cause hemoptysis but is nat commonly associated with ulcerative
diseases of the skin.
(Choice D) Severe mitral stenosis can cause hemoptysis, but associated dyspnea, fatigue, orthopnea and
paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea would also be expected.
{Choice E) Fulmonary embolism may cause hemoptysis, but associated acute-onset dyspnea and chest
pain would also be expected.
(Choice F) Clinical manifestations of pulmonary arteriovenous malformations may range from asymptomatic
to causative of severe respiratory distress and massive hemoptysis in instances of rupture. Cutaneous and
upper airway findings would not be expected.
Educational objective:
Wegener's granulomatosis is defined clinically as the triad of systemic vasculitis, upper and lower airway
granulomatous inflammation, and glomerulonephritis. Nasal cartilage destruction and vasculitic cutaneous
lesions (tender nodules, palpable purpura, ulcerations) are common external manifestations.

explanation:
Mon-productive cough is a common side effect of ACE inhibitors. It occurs in 5-20% of patients receiving

A 46-year-old male is hospitalized with severe acute pancreatitis. Because of progressive respiratory
difficulty, he is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. His weight is 70 kg (152 Ib), blood pressure is
110/70 mmHg, and heart rate is 90/min. Chest x-ray shows patchy opacities bilaterally, consistent with
pulmonary edema. His current ventilator settings are: assist control mode, respiratory rate of 12/min, tidal
valume of 450 ml, FiO2 of 40%, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cm H2O. His blood gas
readings are:
pH          7.51
pCO?2       22 mmHg
p02       121 mmHg
Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation:
The assist control mode of mechanical ventilation delivers a predetermined tidal volume with every
breath. Inspiratory cycles can be initiated by the patient, but if the patient fails to breathe at a set minimum
rate, then the ventilator will deliver the tidal volume on its awn. In general, tidal volumes should be about 6
ml/kg of ideal body weight: thus, the tidal volume being administered to the patient above is
appropriate. However, the arterial blood gas reveals an increased pH (> 7.4) and decreased pCO2,
consistent with respiratory alkalosis secondary to hyperventilation. Thus, decreasing the respiratory rate
would be the most appropriate next step in his management.
(Choice A) Bronchaodilatar therapy is useful in patients with obstructive lung disease to help conduct inspired
air from the trachea to the alveali. This patient is not hypoxic and does not appear to be having difficulty with
ventilation.
{Choice B) The Fi0O2 setting of 40% is appropriately low to avoid oxygen toxicity in this patient.
(Choice D) Increasing the tidal volume would increase ventilation and worsen the patient's respiratory
alkalosis.
(Choice E) Incentive spirametry is utilized ta prevent atelectasis in bed-bound patients, particularly following
surgical procedures. It has no role in the treatment of intubated, mechanically ventilated patients.
{Choice F) This patient's blood pressure is within normal range. Some patients with severe acute
pancreatitis do need suppart with positive inotropic agents, but they are not indicated in this particular patient
at this time.
(Choice G) Chest physiotherapy is utilized in patients with pneumonia or atelectasis to loosen and promate
expectoration of secretions. Patients with bronchiectasis require long-term chest physiotherapy.
(Choice H) A tracheostomy may be indicated if prolonged intubation is foreseen or if the patient has difficulty
maintaining airway patency and/ar managing airway secretions following weaning from mechanical
ventilation, but this is nat a pressing issue in this patient at this time.
Educational objective:
“Ventilation is defined as the product of the respiratory rate and the tidal volume. Respiratory alkalosis results
from hyperventilation. In mechanically ventilated patients with respiratory alkalosis in the setting of an
appropriate tidal volume, the respiratory rate should be lowered. (Reductions in tidal volume can trigger an
increased ventilatory rate, potentially exacerbating the situation.)

A 69-year-old male presents to the ER with severe shartness of breath for the past 12 hours. He reports that
he has used his albuterol inhaler many times without relief. On review of systems he notes having had a mild
fever yesterday that resolved with acetaminophen. The patient quit smoking 2 years ago but has a 100 pack-
year smaking history. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 150/30 mmHg and heart rate is
110/min. The patient is using accessary muscles of respiration. Expirations are prolonged, and there are
wheezes bilaterally. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following:
pH             7.36
p02            64 mmHg
pCO2          57 mmHg
HCO23        32 mEgfL
The patient is treated with ipratropium and albuterol nebulizers and moxifloxacin. Which of the following
additional therapies is most likely to benefit this patient?
explanation:
This elderly former smoker presents with acute dyspnea accompanied by fever, bilateral wheezes, prolonged
expirations and accessory muscle use. His ABG is consistent with chronic respiratory acidosis (in chronic
respiratory acidosis, HCO5 is expected ta increase by 3.5 mEg/L for every 10 mmHg increase in
pCO,). This presentation is most consistent with an acute COPD exacerbation due concomitant infectious
bronchitis. Treatment for an acute COPD flare involves branchadilators (including a beta-adrenergic aganist
such as albuterol), antimuscarinics (ipratropium), and broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage. A two week oral
corticosteroid taper is alsa recommended because itis proven to shorten hospital stays and prolong intervals
between exacerbations. Corticosteroids are likely beneficial because they reduce inflammation and reactive
edema in the bronchial mucosa. Supplemental oxygen may also be of benefit, though care must be taken
when administering oxygen ta chronically hypoxic patients because it can suppress their hypoxia-fueled
respiratory drive.
(Choice B) In contrast to the dyspnea of CHF, dyspnea in COFD is not due to pulmonary edema and is thus
not helped by diuretics.
(Choice C) Airway obstruction in COPD is mainly due to infectious/inflammatary mucosal edema, bronchial
smooth muscle hypertrophy and bronchial submucosal gland hyperplasia. Thus, mucalytics would not be
expected to have significant therapeutic benefit.
(Choice D) Aminophylline and methylxanthines are branchadilatars used in the treatment of asthma, a
condition marked by airway obstruction due ta reversible branchoconstriction.
{Choice E) While diltiazem can have bronchodilatory actions, itis not commanly used in the treatment of
asthma ar COPD.
{Choices F & G) Cromalyn sodium and leukotriene inhibitors are useful in the prevention of acute asthma
exacerbations, though neither is typically first-line.
Educational objective:
Recommended therapy for an acute bacterial exacerbation of COPD includes supplemental oxygen, inhaled
bronchodilators (B2 agonists and anticholinergics), broad-spectrum antibiotics, a two-week carticosteroid
taper and smoking cessation.

question:
A 28-year-old male presents to the physician's office far a routine health maintenance examination. He has a
two year history of bronchial asthma for which he uses an albuteral inhaler. He states that he experiences
asthma symptoms an average of 2 times per week, for which his albuterol inhaler provides relief. He has not
had nighttime awakenings over the past month. He does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. His family
history is significant for asthma in his grandfather. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the
following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
options: A. Add long-acting beta-2 aganist inhaler
explanation:
The management of asthma varies depending on symptom severity. Asthma is classified into four
categories: intermittent, mild persistent, moderate persistent, and severe persistent. The categary is
determined by assessing the frequency of a patient's daytime symptoms, nighttime awakenings, and use of
short-term beta agonists, plus pulmonary function testing. In intermittent asthma, daytime symptoms occur =
2 days/week, nighttime awakenings = 2Zx/month, use of beta agonists = Zxweek, baseline FEV and
FEY1IFVC are normal, and there are no limitations an daily activities. The above vignette describes a patient
with intermittent asthma. The appropriate pharmacologic management far intermittent asthma is a short-
acting bronchodilator (e.g. albuteral) for as needed (FRM) use, with no need for daily controller
medication. Since the patient is already using an albuterol inhaler, he should simply continue his current
medical regimen (Choice E).
In addition to a PRN albuteral inhaler, patients with mild persistent asthma (symptoms =2 days/week but less
than daily, nighttime awakenings 3-4x/manth, minor limitation of activities, and normal PFTs) should be
prescribed a low-dose inhaled corticosteroid (Choice B) as a cantraller medication.
In addition to a PRN albuteral inhaler and low-dose inhaled corticosteroid, patients with moderate persistent
asthma (daily symptoms, weekly nighttime awakenings, and FEV1 60-80% of predicted) should be
prescribed a long-acting inhaled beta-2 agonist inhaler (Choice A).
Patients with severe persistent asthma (symptoms throughout the day, frequent nighttime awakenings,
extremely limited activity, and FEV1 =60% predicted) should receive a PRM albuteral inhaler, long-acting beta-
2 agonist inhaler, and high-dose inhaled corticosteroids. Oral prednisone (Choice D) can also be used in
cases of severe persistent asthma.
(Choice C) Theophylline is a methylxanthine phosphodiesterase inhibitor that causes
bronchaodilation. Though its use is limited samewhat by its side effect profile, it is occasionally used as the
controller medication in persistent asthma
Educational objective:
Mild intermittent asthma, the least severe form, is defined as symptoms £ Zxfweek, = 2 nighttime
awakenings/month, with a normal FEY1 and na limitations on activity. For this form of asthma, only a PRN
albuterol inhaler is required. Daily contraller corticosteroids are reserved for persistent asthma.

question:
A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden-anset severe shortness af breath
and wheezing. She has a history of asthma. On examination, she is unable ta speak in full sentences and is
using accessory muscles of respiration. She is intubated, mechanically ventilated and treated with
continuous albuterol nebulization and intravenous methylprednisalane. Within six hours, her condition is
improved. She is extubated and treated with hourly nebulizer treatments. The next morning, she complains
af muscle weakness. On physical examination, she has difficulty lifting her arms over her head and mild
hand tremors. Her vital signs are stable. What should be the immediate next step in her management?
options: A Check peak expiratary flow rate
B. Check chest x-ray, PA view
explanation:
While this patient received appropriate treatment for her asthma attack, her muscle weakness is a
medication side effect. Beta-2 agonists like albuterol reduce serum potassium levels by driving potassium
into cells. In some patients, clinically significant hypokalemia can result, causing muscle weakness,
arrhythmias, and EKG changes. Other common side effects of beta-2 agonists include tremor, headache
and palpitations. Obtaining a serum electrolyte panel would be helpful here to canfirm and assess the
severity of this patient's hypokalemia.
(Choice A) The peak expiratory flow rate is an important objective measure for evaluating the severity of an
asthma attack and monitoring far respiratory improvement. However this patient's respiratory symptoms
have subsided.
(Choice B) Chest x-ray in an acute asthma exacerbation may reveal lung hyperinflation, but generally will nat
affect management. Chest x-rays are most useful where foreign body aspiration ar underlying pneumonia
are suspected.
(Choice C) Weakness may be a presenting symptom of hyper- or hypathyroidism. Such patients are also
likely to present with cold intolerance and weight gain (hypothyroidism) or heat intolerance and weight loss
(hyperthyroidism). This patient's acute presentation and histary, however, should raise greater concern for
hypokalemia.
(Choice E) EMG measures the electrical activity of muscle fibers and is useful in the evaluation of muscle
weakness due to neuropathic or myopathic conditions. This patient's muscle weakness is most likely due to
hypokalemia, and therefore an electrolyte panel is a mare appropriate first step in her evaluation.
Educational objective:
Inhaled albuterol and systemic steroids are appropriate treatments for acute asthma attacks. Patients on
high doses of beta-2 agonists may develop hypokalemia, which may present with muscle weakness,
arrhythmias and EKG abnormalities. Other common side effects of beta-2 agonists include tremar,
palpitations and headache.

question:
A 26-year-old white female comes to the Emergency Room with severe shortness of breath. She has a long
history of asthma with periodic exacerbations. She is taking an inhaled albuterol, inhaled steroid, salmeteral
and cromalyn. Her temperature is 37.2C (99F), blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and
respirations are 24/min. On examination, she has moderate respiratory distress, prolonged expiratory phase,
and significant wheezing all aver the lung fields. Patient is admitted and is given nebulized albuteral,
intravenous methyl prednisone, and oxygen. The next day her respiratory status improved. Her vital signs did
not change much, except normalization of respiratory rate. Still scattered bilateral wheezes are heard on lung
auscultation. The next day her laboratory values are:
Hemoglobin                   14 g/dL
MCY                           95 fL
Leukocyte count              19 000/cmm
Segmented Neutrophils      80%
Bands                          5%
Lymphocytes                  13%
Eosinophils                    0%
Basophils                      0%
Monocytes                     2%
Chest x-ray obtained at the time of admission is narmal, except for hyperinflated lung fields. What is the most
probable cause of the abnormal lab findings in this patient?
explanation:
The most probable cause of leukocytosis in this patient is glucocorticoid-induced neutrophilia.
Glucocorticoids have a complex effect on the blood cells. They tend to diminish the number of circulating
eosinaphils and have distinct lymphopenic effect. They alsa increase the neutrophil count by increasing the
bone marrow release and mobilizing the marginated neutrophil pool. It is not uncommon to see neutrophilia
during treatment with glucocorticoids.
Pneumonia (Choice A) is unlikely in this case, because no other symptoms and signs are present (cough,
fever, chest x-ray findings).
Hypersensitivity reaction (Choice B) is a potential cause of leukocytosis due to hypersensitivity-induced
inflammation, but the leukocyte differential (pure neutrophilia without eosinophilia) is not typical for this type of
reaction.
A myelopraliferative disorder (Choice C) is unlikely in this case. The patient had received high doses af IV
steroids, and it almost always causes left shift.
Mo obvious metabolic disorder (Choice D), (e g., ketoacidosis or poisoning), can be responsible far the
leukocytosis that is present.
Educational Objective:
Glucocorticoids cause neutrophilia by increasing the bone marrow release and mobilizing the marginated
neutrophil pool. Eosinophils and lymphocytes are decreased.
*Extremely high yield question far USMLE!

question:
A 40-year-old black male presents with dyspnea and tachypnea of sudden onset. He says that he was
diagnosed with deep venous thrombosis (DVT) of the lower extremities three times before.
Ventilation/perfusion scan reveals mismatched perfusion defect. Venous ultrasonography is positive for DVT.
You suspect that inherited predisposition to hypercoagulation may be present. Which of the following is the
mast comman farm of such a predisposition?
explanation:
This patient presents with pulmanary thromboembolism and has a history of recurrent 'unexplained' DVT of
the lower extremities. Factor V Leiden is recently recognized as a relatively common cause of such a
condition. Factor VV Leiden is the result of a point mutation in a gene coding for the coagulation factor V. As a
result of this mutation, Factor V becomes resistant to inactivation by protein C, an important counterbalance
factor in hemastatic cascade. The prevalence of factor V Leiden may be as high as 5-6% of the population.
Other disorders causing inherited predisposition to thrombasis-like protein C deficiency (Choice A), protein 5
deficiency (Choice B), antithrombin lll deficiency (Choice D), and plasminogen disorders (Choice E) are
quite rare.
Educational Objective:
Factor VV Leiden is the most common inherited disorder causing hypercoagulability and predisposition to
thromboses, especially DVT of lower extremities.

question:
A 45-year-old male immigrant from Haiti complains of cough and tenacious mucopurulent sputum for several
manths. He denies fever ar chest pain, but notes shortness of breath and occasional blood-tinged sputum.
He has received antibiotic treatment for similar symptoms twice in the past year. He has smoked 1 pack of
cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood
pressure is 120/68 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min. On lung auscultation there are
coarse crepitations at the bilateral bases. Chest x-ray reveals prominent bronchioles in the lower lobes but is
atherwise unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: A High resolution CT scan of the chest
C. Branchography using non-iodinated contrast medium
D. Check sputum far acid fast bacillus (AFB)
explanation:
Prominent bronchioles on chest x-ray suggest bronchiectasis. Other suggestive chest x-ray findings include
peripheral opacities and linear atelectasis. In bronchiectasis, abnarmally dilated segments af the bronchial
tree cause impaired clearance of secretions and resulting airflow obstruction. Presenting symptoms include
cough (>30% of patients), mucaopurulent sputum (=75%), and hemoptysis (25%). Bronchiectasis may be
either inherited or acquired. Cystic fibrosis is the most common inherited cause. Acquired bronchiectasis
may be secondary to tuberculosis (Th) or recurrent bacterial pneumonia. Haiti has the highest rate of Th in
Latin America, making this the most likely underlying diagnosis. Smoking also increases the likelihood of
bronchiectasis. High resolution CT {(HRCT) scanning of the chest (Choice A) is the imaging modality of
choice for diagnasing bronchiectasis.
(Choice B) Bronchoscopy and alveolar lavage (BAL) is often used to establish diagnoses like pneumacystis
pneumonia and certain lung cancers. Rigid bronchoscopy may occasionally be used in bronchiectasis, but
non-invasive HRCT is preferable.
(Choice C) Bronchography is an invasive procedure that uses contrast to image the interior passages of the
respiratory tract. Risks include infection and bronchospasm. Before the advent of HRCT, bronchography
was often used to diagnose bronchiectasis, but now the procedure is rarely performed.
(Choice D) Detection of AFB in a patient's sputum can confirm suspected pulmonary tuberculosis. While
this patient's productive cough and hemoptysis are certainly suspicious, his chest x-ray is most consistent
with bronchiectasis, as Is the absence of fevers, chills, and night sweats. He likely has a history of Th
infection, but bronchiectasis is a better explanation for his current condition.
(Choice E) Echocardiography would be appropriate if this patient's cough were believed ta be of cardiac
arigin (CHF, endocarditis, etc.). However, his history and prominent bronchiales on chest x-ray make
bronchiectasis a more likely explanation.
Educational objective:
In bronchiectasis, branchial dilation causes impaired clearance of secretions and resultant airway
abstruction. Acquired bronchiectasis is often secondary to prior Th or recurrent pneumania, while inherited
bronchiectasis is most often due to cystic fibrosis. Symptoms include cough, mucopurulent sputum, and
hemoptysis. Chest x-ray may reveal prominent bronchioles, peripheral opacities and linear
atelectasis. HRCT is used for definitive diagnosis.

question:
A 32-year-old male presents to your office complaining of daytime sleepiness and frequent nighttime
awakenings. He says that his sleep gets disrupted by a choking sensation, sometimes accompanied by
cough and dyspnea. After such episodes he typically has trouble falling back to sleep. The patient notes that
his symptoms are somewhat improved when he sleeps with multiple pillows. Physical examination is
unremarkable except far a BMI of 29 Kg/m®. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The differential diagnosis of repeated nocturnal awakenings associated with dyspnea and cough includes
asthma, cangestive heart failure and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Daytime sleepiness may
result from any condition causing sleep interruption. Overnight asthma attacks (Choice B) would not be
improved by head elevation, nar would repeated avernight asthma exacerbations (a sign of advanced
disease) occur in a patient without daytime symptoms, wheezes on exam, ar a history of asthma. Heart
failure (Choice C) can cause paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, cardiac asthma and simple orthopnea, which
may all disturb sleep and improve with head elevation, but a patient with this degree of heart failure would
likely have consistent signs an physical examination (e.q. peripheral edema, bibasilar rales, decreased
exercise tolerance). The description in the vignette favars a diagnosis of GERD. Reflux of gastric contents
into the pharynx gives the classic unpleasant sour taste of "heartburn," and reflux into the larynx and
tracheobronchial tree can cause cough, bronchial constriction, laryngitis, hoarseness, laryngaspasm and
possibly aspiration pneumania. Chranic GERD may be complicated by laryngotracheal stenosis, pulmonary
fibrosis and Barrett's esophagus.
{Choice A) Restless leg syndrome is characterized by abnormal creeping or crawling sensations in the
lower extremities that are exacerbated by inactivity and relieved by motion. Difficulty falling asleep and
nocturnal awakenings may occur.
(Choice D) Obstructive sleep apnea is characterized by loud snoring with occasional apneic episodes,
typically in an obese patient. These episodes are usually witnessed by the patient's spouse and are not
typically remembered by the patient. A choking sensation and cough are nat classically present.
{Choice E) Central sleep apnea causes nocturnal awakenings with apnea due to a failure of central
respiratory drive. A choking sensation and cough are not typically present. This condition is often secondary
to stroke.
(Choice G) Primary snaring results from nocturnally increased pharyngeal airflow resistance causing noisy
inspiration. It generally does not cause sleep disturbances.
Educational objective:
Repeated nocturnal awakenings associated with dyspnea, cough and a choking sensation, especially in an
averweight or obese patient, are mast likely due to gastroesophageal reflux disease.

question:
An 82-year-old woman presents 1-hour after the sudden onset of moderate-to-severe epigastric pain. The
pain radiates to her back, both scapulae, and both arms. She has been nauseated and vomited three
times in the past hour. Her past medical history is remarkable for peptic ulcer disease 10-years ago,
cholelithiasis for the past 6-years, and stable angina pectoris for the past 3-years. She has had occasional
episodes of biliary colic and twa bouts of acute cholecystitis which were treated conservatively. Her
temperature is 36 8C (98 2F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are
14/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with
mild tenderness to palpatian in the epigastrium. Murphy's sign is negative. Which af the following studies
should be done first?
explanation:
This patient might have cholecystitis, pancreatitis, complicated peptic ulcer disease (PUD), or myocardial
infarction (MI). Aortic dissection can also be a possibility. Pain that radiates to the arms is strongly
suggestive of MI, especially in a patient with known coronary artery disease. MI can present with abdominal
(epigastric) pain, especially inferior and posterior infarctions. If you have a high index of suspicion for MI, you
should obtain EKG/serum cardiac enzymes immediately - you must rule out MI before further Gl work-up.
The other diagnoses listed in the differential are often not immediately life threatening except for aortic
dissection. Pain from acute cholecystitis may radiate to the right scapula. Pain from acute pancreatitis
usually radiates to the back, but rarely as high as the level of the scapulae. Perforated PUD usually produces
signs of peritoneal irritation.
Educational objective:
MI is one of the differential diagnoses of acute abdominal pain and should be ruled out in patients with risk
factors.

question:
A 43-year-old male (Patient A) is being evaluated for an esophageal disorder. Esophageal manometry
tracings after a single swallow of 5 ml of water are shown an the slide below.
UE      N                          Normal

ME __ ~~ Normal

LES                              Normal
A A.  Patient A
UE: upper esophagus
ME: middle esophagus
LES: lower esophageal sphincter
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation:
After the contents of the oral cavity are collected on the tongue and propelled into the pharynx, involuntary
contraction of the pharyngeal muscles pushes the material into the esophagus. The cricopharyngeus
muscle contracts behind the food bolus initiating a peristaltic wave to propel the bolus downward; this
contraction is shown aon the first diagram as an upward deflection on both the normal and patient graphs.
The second diagram shows normal peristalsis of the middle esophagus. Under normal conditions when the
food bolus reaches the lower esophagus, the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes to allow the material to
enter the stomach. The third diagram portrays the decrease in LES pressure that corresponds ta its
relaxation in the narmal patient.
Esophageal manometry of the patient A reveals normal contraction of upper esophageal sphincter,
decreased peristalsis of the midesophagus illustrated by a lower amplitude of pressure increase on the
second diagram, and no LES relaxation. These manometric findings are consistent with a diagnosis of
achalasia (Choice C). This motor dysfunction is associated with an elevated resting pressure of the LES
and inability of the LES to relax during swallowing.
(Choice A) Cricopharyngeal dysfunction results from a failure of the cricopharyngeus to relax during
swallowing and causes a choking or "food sticking” sensation and pain with swallowing. A video fluoroscopic
swallowing study is used far diagnosis.
(Choice B) Diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) is an esophageal motility disarder that presents with severe,
non-cardiac chest pain. It occurs due to uncoordinated contractions of the esophageal body. Esophageal
manometry shows multiple contractions on tracings from middle and lower esophagus.
(Choice D) Reflux of gastric contents into the distal esophagus occurs due to low tone of lower esophageal
sphincter and its failure to contract after the transfer of food to stomach. Esophageal manometry in patients
with GERD would show decreased LES pressure.
(Choice E) Tears of esophageal mucosa at the esaphagogastric junction are called Mallory-VWeiss tears.
These tears are caused by forceful retching and vomiting, and are comman in alcoholics. Mallory-Weiss tear
is not a motility disorder and is not associated with abnormalities of esophageal manometry.
Educational Objective:
Decreased esophageal body peristalsis and poor relaxation of the LES on manometry are typical for
achalasia. Achalasia presents with progressive dysphagia, chest pain, food regurgitation and aspiration.
Barium swallow shows a dilated esophagus and a "bird's beak" deformity of the LES.

question:
A 45-year-old nurse practitioner presents to the emergency department due to painful abdominal cramps and
watery diarrhea. She has about 10 to 20 bowel movements a day. She also has nocturnal bowel
mavements. She has had multiple hospitalizations in the past for similar problems without a definite
diagnosis. A lower Gl endoscopy during a previous hospitalization showed dark brown discoloration of the
colon with lymph follicles shining through as pale patches. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The above case is a classic description of factiious diarrhea, specifically laxative abuse. The diarrhea
associated with laxative abuse is typically described as watery with an increase in bath frequency
and volume of stool. The bowel movement is generally profuse, with approximately 10 to 20 bowel
mavements occurring daily. Nocturnal bowel movement and painful abdominal cramps may be
accompanying symptoms. As in this case, the patient is usually employed in the medical field, comes from a
higher socioeconomic class, and generally has a history of multiple hospital admissions in an effort to
establish the cause of the diarrhea. The diagnosis can be confirmed with the characteristic biopsy finding of
dark brown discalaration of the colon with lymph follicles shining through as pale patches (melanasis cali);
this is typically seen in those using ar abusing anthraguinone-caontaining laxatives (e.g. bisacodyl). It
generally develops within four manths of the onset of laxative ingestion, and can disappear in the same
amaunt of time if laxative use is discontinued. In addition, an alternative means of diagnosis is histological
evidence of pigment in the macrophages of the lamina propria.
(Choice B) Nocturnal bowel movement is not characteristic of functional diarrhea, such as irritable bowel
syndrome.
(Choices C, D and E) Melanosis coli is not characteristic far celiac disease, infectious diarrhea, or
non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.
Educational Objective:
Laxative abuse is characterized by very frequent, watery, nocturnal diarrhea. The diagnosis can be
confirmed with the characteristic biopsy finding of dark brown discoloration of the colon with lymph follicles
shining through as pale patches (melanasis coli).

question:
A B5-year-ald woman presents with a 2-manth history of fatigue and dyspnea an exertion. She takes no
medication. Her temperature is 36.7C (98F), blood pressure is 162/83 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, and
respirations are 21/min. Auscultation shows a 2/6 systolic murmur in the 2nd right intercostal space. Mo
peripheral edema is noted. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Test of the stool for occult blood is
negative. EKG shows sinus tachycardia and non-specific ST-T changes. Laboratory studies show:
Hemaglohin                    8.1agl
MCW                                  T3fl
Platelets                              360,000/mm3
Leukocyte count                      4 500/mm3
Meutraphils                          56%
Eosinophils                         1%
Lymphocytes                       33%
Monocytes                          10%
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
This patient is mast likely suffering from iron deficiency anemia (low MCV and hemaglobin) secondary to
chronic gastrointestinal (Gl) blood loss. A single negative fecal occult blood test is not sufficient to diagnose
accult blood loss. Additional studies should be perfarmed, such as iron studies to determine if the anemia is
due to an iran deficiency. The characteristic findings of iron deficiency anemia are low iron, low serum ferritin
and high TIBC levels.
In elderly patients, iron deficiency anemia is attributed to Gl blood loss until proven otherwise, and such
patients are therefore subjected to colonoscopy. Gl blood loss without Gl complaints is most likely caused by
cancer of the colon: therefare, colonoscopy is performed first. If the colonoscapy is negative, upper Gl
endoscopy is then performed. Another indication far perfarming an upper Gl endoscopy is a current ar

endoscopy are negative, capsule endoscopy is performed to look for small intestinal disease
(e.g., arterio-venous malformations).
(Choice A) This patient's cardiac changes are mast likely due to the anemia, and nat due to an underlying
heart disease. Her heart murmur is a flow murmur. Furthermare, her wide pulse pressure indicates the
hyperdynamic circulation in anemia. Therefore, there is no need for echocardiography at this time.
{Choice B) Bone marrow biopsy is not indicated in this patient. It can be considered if the other cell lines
(platelets and WBC) are also abnormal.
(Choice E) Radioisotope scans are typically used for patients with active bleeding. If this patient was actively
bleeding, the stool heme occult test will be positive, however, her symptoms have been present for a few
months.
Educational Objective:
The most common cause of iron deficiency anemia in an elderly patient is gastrointestinal blood lass. The
next step in evaluation would be colonoscopy.

question:

has no allergies. She has had a 10 Ib (4 5 kg) weight loss over the past four weeks. Her temperature is

Laboratory studies show:

explanation:
The patient is most likely suffering from toxic megacolon secondary to ulcerative colitis. Toxic megacolon is

(Choice A) Crohn's disease is a chronic transmural inflammatary disease of the Gl tract. The mast common

(Choice B) Pseudomembranous calitis is usually associated with antibiotic usage. The other common

is produced after a patient has been receiving an antibiotic for same time, but it can occur even after a single

(Choice D) 5 aureus gastroenteritis is due to the ingestion of preformed enterotoxin. It has a shart

(Choice G) In HIV patients, CMV calitis can cause toxic megacalon.
Educational Objective:
The most common cause of toxic megacolon is ulcerative colitis. Toxic megacolon is a medical emergency;

question:
A 45-year-old Mexican male presents with a 2-day history of traces of blood on the tissue paper after he
wipes. He does not have gross blood mixed with stool, but on one occasion there were drops of blood in the
toilet after defecation. He has no past medical history or family history of cancer or other significant disease.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Minimal bright red blood per rectum (BRBFR) is also called 'scant hematochezia' ar minimal rectal bleeding.
Although there is no standardized definition, this candition is assaciated with patient complaints of small
amounts of bright red blood an toilet paper after wiping, a few drops of blood in the toilet bowl after defecation,
and small amaunts of blood an the surface of the stool. Red blood intermixed with stool is not included in this
category.
Minimal BREFR is seen in approximately 14 - 16 percent of people. Some of the most common causes are
hemarrhaids, anal fissure, polyps, proctitis, rectal ulcers and cancer. Hemorrhoids can be present in
anywhere from 27 to 95 percent of cases of minimal BREFR. The management of BREFR depends on the
patient's presentation and risk factors. If the patient is less than S0-years-old, has na other risk factars for
colon cancer, and presents with minimal BRBFR, office-based anoscopy or practoscopy should be
performed first. If no etiology is found, colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy is then cansidered. Office-based
anoscopy/proctoscaopy are simple maneuvers, have high yield and do nat require bowel preparation.
Anoscopy has higher sensitivity for diagnosing hemorrhoids than flexible endoscopy.
{Choices A and D) Colonoscopy and sigmoidoscopy would be the appropriate next steps in this patient if he
was more than 50 years old or had other risk factors far colon cancer.
{Choice B) The patient admits to seeing bright red blood; therefore, occult blood testing will be of no further
help at this time. Occult blood testing is of value in cases of melena or undiagnosed anemia.
(Choice E) Barium enema is not an appropriate first investigation for this condition.
Educational Objective:
Office-based anoscopy/proctoscopy should be the initial procedure in patients less than 50 years old who
present with minimal bright red blood per rectum and do not have any risk factors for colon cancer. Blood
intermixed with stoal is nat included in this category.

question:
A B5-year-ald man comes to the physician's office with a 2-manth history of dysphagia. He initially had
difficulty swallowing solids, but now this includes liquids. He has occasional heartburn, which usually
responds well to antacids. He has lost 20 Ibs of weight in the past 2 months. He has a 40 pack-year history
af smoking. He has been a chronic alcoholic for 20 years. His temperature is 36.7C(98F), blood pressure is
110/80 mm Hg, pulse is 66/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
Barium studies show a minimally dilated esophagus with beak-shaped narrowing. Manometry shows
increased lower esophageal sphincter tone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
It is highly likely that the above patient is suffering fram esophageal cancer involving the lower esophageal
sphincter (LES). Malignancy involving the LES can lead to progressive dysphadgia (i.e, difficulty swallowing
solids, followed by that of liquids). Factars in this case which make malignancy the mast likely diagnosis is
the patient's age, acute onset of symptoms, weight lass, and significant smoking and drinking history.
Malignancy is more commaon in the elderly age group; therefore, any elderly patient with such symptoms
needs to be tharoughly investigated. Malignant lesions usually have a short history of presentation; the
duration of symptoms is usually less than 6 months. Another objective criteria is the amount of weight loss.
Patients with esophageal cancer have mare profound weight loss over a short duration of time. Attempts to
perform endoscopy of the esophagus often leads to difficulty in passing through the gastroesophageal
junction. CT scan can diagnose such cases more definitively. The CT finding of any marked or asymmetric
thickening of the wall can suggest malignancy, which can necessitate the need for biopsy.
(Choice A) Achalasia alsa presents as dysphagia far solids and liquids: however, sometimes esophageal
cancer can present with a similar picture, as mentioned above. Radiographic studies of both diagnoses may
be similar; therefore, it is best ta have a high level of suspicion, especially if there are other symptoms or
clinical features which cannat be explained by achalasia.
(Choice C) Patients with scleroderma have other additional features, such as cutaneous thickening and
Raynaud's phenomenan. There may be symptoms of heartburn due to acid reflux. Lower esophageal
sphincter tone will be decreased.
{Choice E) Fatients with diffuse esophageal spasm have chest pain and dysphagia. A "corkscrew" pattern
is seen on barium swallow. Manometry is usually diagnostic.
(Choice D) Patients with peptic stricture usually have a history of acid peptic disease. Patients usually do
not have systemic symptoms.
Educational Objective:
Esophageal cancer may mimic achalasia clinically, radiologically AND manometrically (pseudoachalasia)l
Features that favor malignancy over achalasia are: older age, a short history, rapid weight loss, and inahility
af the esophagoscope to pass through the lower esophageal sphincter.

question:
A 73-year-old woman is transferred to the hospital from the nursing hame because of diverticulitis. A prior CT
scan showed inflamed sigmoid colon. Transferred records indicate a 2-day history of fever and abdominal
pain. On admission, her white count is 22 000/cmm, and she is started on IV antibiotics and IV fluids. Over
the ensuing few days, her white count starts to come down and she has no nausea, vomiting ar fever;
however, she suddenly develops a cough and increasing abdominal pain. Abdominal examination shows
guarding and tenderness in the left lower quadrant. An upright x-ray film of the chest shows free air under the
left diaphragm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A CT scan of the abdomen
explanation:
Bowel perforation is one of the complications of acute diverticulitis. The characteristic features are acute
abdominal pain and chest x-ray findings of free air under the diaphragm. Immediate surgical treatment is
necessary. In acute situations where there is no time for prepping and cleaning the bowel, surgical resection
af the perfarated bowel and proximal colostomy should be performed.
(Choice A) Obtaining anather CT scan is nat needed since this will not change the management of the
patient. In this case, the initial CT revealed an inflamed colon, and the chest x-ray showed free air
underneath the diaphragm, suggesting a perforation. Twa situations that frequently present with free air
underneath the diaphragm are perforated peptic ulcer and perforated inflamed colan. The treatment
af perforated bowel requires surgery.
(Choices B and C) Colonoscopy and barium enema are contraindicated when bowel perforation is
suspected. Colonoscopy can result in worsening of the injury, especially during acute diverticulitis. Barium is

(Choice D) Observation with antibiotic therapy is hazardous if free air has been identified. The inevitable

Educational Objective:
Free air underneath the diaphragm signifies bowel perforation and requires urgent laparotomy.

A 51-year-old obese male presents to your office complaining of difficulty swallowing solids but nat
liquids. His medical history is significant for GERD. Six months ago he was diagnosed with Barrett's
esophagus. He reports that three months after the diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus, his heartburn
resolved. Barium swallow now reveals an area of symmetric, circumferential narrowing affecting the distal
esophagus. Which of the following best explains this finding?
explanation:
Chronic GERD predisposes to Barrett's esophagus (intestinal metaplasia of the lower esaphagus) but also to
benign peptic esophageal strictures. Benign strictures affect 5-15% of GERD patients. Both benign peptic
esophageal strictures and Barrett's esophagus are consequences of the body's reparative response to
chronic expasure to gastric acid, and can occur simultaneously. Peptic strictures typically cause slowly
progressive dysphagia to solid foods without anorexia or weight loss. As strictures progress, they can
actually block reflux, leading to improvement of heartburn symptoms. Peptic strictures tend to appear as
symmetric, circumferential narrowings on endoscopy. Based on this patient's clinical history and endoscopic
findings, peptic stricture (Choice D) is the most likely diagnosis. Nonetheless, in any case of stricture in the
setting of Barrett's esophagus, biopsy to rule out adenacarcinama is necessary.
(Choice A) Adenocarcinoma generally occurs in patients who have had GERD symptoms for =20 years, and
presents with weight loss and asymmetric narrowing of the esophageal lumen.
(Choice B) A hiatal hernia is a protrusion of the stomach above the diaphragm. Fatients may present with
GERD, and are therefare at risk for Barrett's esophagus, peptic strictures, and adenocarcinoma. Barium
swallow reveals gastric falds protruding above the diaphragm.
(Choice C) Achalasia is an esophageal motility disorder. Barium swallow typically shows narrowing in a "bird
s beak" pattern at the gastroesophageal junction, plus dilation of the proximal esophagus caused by retention
of food.
(Choice E) Vascular rings are a class of uncommaon congenital anomalies in which aortic arch vessels
encircle the trachea and/or esophagus. Patients may present in infancy with symptoms of airway
abstruction, though some patients do nat present until adulthood. In adult cases, dysphagia is usually the
presenting complaint. There is not a strong association with GERD or Barrett's esophagus.
Educational objective:
GERD predisposes to Barrett's esophagus, erosive esophagitis and peptic stricture formation. Peptic
strictures cause symmetric and circumferential narrowing of the involved esophagus and dysphagia to solids,
but no weight lass. Other causes of peptic strictures include radiation, scleroderma, and caustic ingestions.

question:
Ms. Lee, a 62-year-old Chinese woman, comes with yellowness in her eyes for the past 6 weeks. She is

question:

temperature is 36.7 C (98F), blood pressure is 120/76 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are
18/min. Laboratory studies show:
Hemaglohin                              11.2 gfdL

Leukocyte count                        9 500/fcmm
Segmented Neutrophils               65%
Bands                                3%
Eosinophils                           1%

Serum sodium                          145 mEg/L
Serum potassium                       4.0 mEq/L
Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. Which of the following is the most likely type of diarrhea in this

explanation:
The clinical scenario described is characteristic for inflammatory diarrhea. The typical cause is idiopathic

{Choice B) Secretory diarrhea is usually the result of same medication use or hormanal disturbances.

Chronic inflammatory diarrhea is typically associated with inflammatory changes in the blood (anemia,

question:
A 35-year-old Hispanic male comes to the office because of excruciating pain during defecation for the past
week. The pain is so severe that he avoids using the toilet. He also adds that he has noticed bright red blood
in his stool. The caliber of his stool has not changed. His past medical history is significant far chronic
constipation. Rectal examination shows a posterior mucosal tear of the anus. Which of the following is the
mast appropriate next step in management?
options: B. Local anesthetic and stool softeners
E. Gradual dilatation of the sphincter
explanation:
The clinical presentation of this patient is clearly suggestive of an anal fissure. Anal fissures are slit-like tears
af the anal canal. These are mostly located on the posterior or anterior anal verge, and are mast commanly
caused by the passage of large, hard constipated stools. Other causes are crypt abscess, explosive
diarrhea, perianal dermatitis or infection, inflammatory bowel disease, trauma, and sexual abuse. The most
comman symptoms are severe pain and bright red rectal bleeding during defecation. The initial treatment of
both acute and chranic anal fissures includes dietary modification (e.g., high-fiber diet and large amounts of
fluids), a stoal softener and a local anesthetic. The local anesthetic relieves the local spasm, and the stool
softener creates soft, bulky, atraumatic stools that disrupt the vicious cycle of constipation and fissure
development. This treatment also allows the fissure to heal in approximately 50% of patients.
(Choice A) Calonascaopy is nat needed in this patient as the bright red blood on defecation is clearly due to
the fissure. His stool caliber is also normal. However, if the fissure heals and the patient still has blood in the
stools, then colonoscopy is warranted.
(Choice C) Surgical repair of a fissure is indicated in chronic or refractory acute fissures to pravide a wider
aperture for stool to pass and to interrupt the internal sphincter spasm. Lateral sphincterotamy is the
standard treatment for chronic fissures.
{Choice D) Antibiotics have no role in the management of uncomplicated anal fissures.
(Choice E) Gradual dilatation of the sphincter can also provide a wider aperture far the passage of stoal and
interrupt the spasm; however, the extent of sphincter disruption is unpredictable, causing undesirable rates of
recurrence and of anal incontinence.
(Choice F) Mitraglycerin ointment can be used ta relieve the internal sphincter spasm; however, headaches
and recurrences are commaon.
Educational Objective:
The initial treatment of both acute and chronic anal fissures includes dietary modification (e.g., high-fiber diet
and large amounts of fluids), a stool softener, and a local anesthetic.
*Extremely high yield question for the USMLE!]

question:
A 27-year-old man complains of episodic abdominal pain. The pain is concentrated in the epigastrium and is
gnawing in quality. It wakes him up during the night and is promptly relieved by a glass of water and a piece
af bread. He denies vomiting or diarrhea, but has experienced an occasional "dark stool." He has no
significant past medical history and does not take any medications. His family history is significant for biliary
disease in his mother and stomach cancer in his father. He smokes one pack of cigarettes a day and
consumes a can of beer almast every day. His vital signs are with in normal limits. Physical examination
shows mild epigastric discomfort on deep palpation. Which of the following is most likely to provide long-term
symptom relief in this patient?
explanation:
Given his melena and characteristic nocturnal pain that is relieved by eating, this patient most likely has
duodenal ulcer disease. The pain is thought ta be worse with an empty stomach because of the unopposed
acidic fluid that empties into the duodenum. The ingestion of food causes alkali solutions to be released into
the duodenum and relieves the pain. On the other hand, the pain associated with gastric ulcers tends to
worsen with eating. There is a very high (aver 80%) prevalence of H. pylori infection in people with duodenal
ulcer disease, so it is very likely that this patient is infected with H. pylori. The mainstay of therapy for
patients with peptic ulcer disease (FUD) and H. pylori infection is acid suppression and eradication of the
arganism. Antibiotic treatment is often curative for patients with H. pylortassociated PUD. There are
numerous possible regimens, but the first-line therapy is amoxicillin plus clarithromycin and a proton pump
inhibitar.
(Choice A) Acid suppression with a proton pump inhibitor (e g., omeprazole) or a histamine receptor-2 (HZ)
blocker is the treatment of choice for patients with PUD not attributable to H. pylori. This patient has a
duodenal ulcer and is therefare very likely to be infected with H. pylori. Although acid suppression is
important far this patient, antibiotics must be used ta eradicate the causal arganism.
(Choice C) NSAIDs are associated with the development of gastritis and PUD. Giving this patient an NSAID
is likely to exacerbate his ulcer.
(Choice D) Smoking is associated with the development of PUD. Interestingly though, smoking is nat
associated with ulcer recurrence if H. pylori has been eradicated. Smoking cessation is always encouraged
but would not be as effective as antibiotics in treating his PUD.
(Choice E) Alcohal can irritate the gastric mucosa and lead to gastritis. However, there is no evidence that
alcohol causes or exacerbates chranic peptic ulcer disease.
(Choice F) Selective vagotomy decreases gastric acid production by removing vagal input to the
stomach. With antibiotic regimens for H. pylori and the advent of proton pump inhibitors, selective vagatamy
is used only in refractory cases. This patient has not yet had a trial of conservative therapy.
Educational Objective:
Duodenal ulcer disease typically presents with epigastric pain that improves with eating. Over 90% of
patients with duodenal ulcer disease are infected with H. pylori. The treatment for H. pylorrassociated ulcers
is acid suppression and arganism eradication with antibiatics.

question:
A B6-year-ald man presents with a four week history of increasing back pain and severe constipation. He has

*Extremely high yield question for the USMLE!]

question:
A 26-year-old man presents with a 1-week histary of intermittent, crampy, lower abdominal pain accompanied

Ulcerative calitis thus remains as the mare likely diagnosis, and although stool studies may be helpful in the

question:
A B4-year-ald white male with a history of severe stable angina and peripheral vascular disease
undergoes coronary artery bypass surgery. His post-operative course is complicated by hypotension, which
is treated successfully, however, a few hours later, he experiences abdominal pain followed by bloody
diarrhea. His temperature is 37.8 C (100 F), blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and
respirations are 20/min. Abdominal examination is benign. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 15,000
femm with 7% bands. The lactic acid level is elevated. A CT scan is ordered. Which of the following areas
af the calon will most likely show abnormal findings?
explanation:
In this patient, ischemic colitis most likely occured following the surgical procedure. Patients with extensive
atherosclerotic vascular disease are at particularly high risk, especially if their haspital course is complicated
by hypatension, which may be due to increased perioperative fluid loss or excessive use of diuretics.
In general, the initial presentation of patients with ischemic colitis includes the acute onset of lower abdominal
pain, followed by bloody diarrhea within 12-24 hours. Fever, nausea, vomiting, and extreme leukocytosis with
left shift are often seen. The most commanly involved segment of the colon is the splenic flexure, because it
is supplied by end arteries. The splenic flexure is a 'watershed' line between the territory of the superior and
inferior mesenteric arteries. There are two watershed zones in the colon: (1) the splenic flexure, which is
supplied by narrow terminal branches of the superior mesenteric artery, and (2) the recto-sigmaid junction,
which is supplied by narrow terminal branches of the inferior mesenteric artery. These twa watershed areas
are most vulnerable to ischemia during systemic hypotensian.
There is no specific marker for ischemic colitis. Sometimes, increased levels of lactic acid are
helpful. Radiographs are non-specific, but may show classic "thumb printing." It is impartant to distinguish
ischemic colitis from infectious colitis, inflammatory bowel disease, and at times, even colon cancer.
Educational Objective:
Suspect ischemic colitis in patients who have evidence of atherosclerotic vascular disease, present with
abdominal pain followed by bloody diarrhea, and have minimal abdominal exam findings. The most
commanly involved segment of the colon is the splenic flexure, because it is supplied by end arteries.

question:
A 49-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with profuse, foul-smelling, watery
diarrhea and abdominal pain. Five days aga, she was hospitalized for urosepsis and treated with amaxicillin
and sulbactam. She recovered well, and was discharged three days ago with a prescription for aral
amazxicillin plus clavulanic acid. Her current temperature is 38.8C (101.9F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg,
pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 15/min. Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the left lower
quadrant. CBC shows a WBC count of 25 000/microL. She is started an intravenous normal saline in the
ED. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

E. Discontinue antibiotics and start oral vancomycin
explanation:
The patient presented in this vignette has developed severe watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever while
taking antibiotics for an extended period of time. She is most likely suffering from severe
pseudomembranaus calitis caused by Clostridium difficile. Staol should be sent far Clostridium difficile taxin
assay. The antibiotics should be discontinued. Metronidazole is the drug of choice far pseudomembranous
colitis. Bath intravenous and aral farms of metronidazole can be used.
(Choice E) Oral vancomycin (not intravenous) is also very effective for the treatment of pseudomembranous
colitis, but it is usually used as an alternative to metronidazole when there is intolerance to the
latter. Metronidazole is the preferred drug over vancomycin because it is very cheap, and it reduces the
chances of vancomycin resistance ta Enterococcus (VRE).
Educational Objective:
The treatment of Clostridium difficile diarrhea includes discontinuation of the offending antibiotic {usually
clindamycin) and prompt administration of metranidazale.

question:
A 52-year-old man presents to your office after passing a black stool. He also describes occasional
abdominal discomfort and nausea but denies hematemesis. He says that food seems to help his abdominal
pain, so he eats frequently during the day and keeps some snacks an his night stand. As a consequence he
has gained 5 pounds over the last year. He admits that his diet is lacking in vegetables and fruit. He drinks
ane to twa cans of beer nightly, but does not smake or use illicit drugs. He says that his father died of colon
cancer and his mother died from a stroke. Physical examination reveals a right-sided carotid bruit. The fecal
accult blood test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
explanation:
This patient's melena and abdominal pain are mast likely due to peptic ulcer disease (duodenal ulcer). Dark,
melanotic stools are the result of blood that has been processed in the Gl tract. Upper Gl bleeding is the
mast comman cause, but lower Gl bleeding proximal to the colon's hepatic flexure can also be
responsible. Peptic ulcer disease (FUD) is the most comman cause of significant upper Gl bleeding. Often
associated with H. pylori infection or NSAID use, PUD presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting,
hematemesis, and melena. The diagnosis is made by upper endoscopy.
(Choice A) Patients with mesenteric angina report pain that is exacerbated by eating.
(Choice B) Mallory-Weiss syndrome refers to hematemesis that occurs after repeated episodes of
retching. Itis naon-painful and usually self-limited. This patient does not have any history of vomiting.
(Choice C) Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease are more likely to cause lower Gl bleeding than upper Gl
bleeding, though melena can occur in Crohn's involving the upper Gl tract or small bowel. However,

(Choice D) Erosive gastritis fram chranic irritation is common in alcohalics and patients using NSAIDs

symptoms.
{Choice F) Gastric cancer can cause melena and abdominal pain but is usually accompanied by weight loss
and anorexia.
{Choices G to I) Colonic pathology usually causes bright red bleeding ar maraan colored stools.
Educational objective:
Melena is usually a manifestation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Pain fram duodenal ulcers usually

question:
A 35-year-old Caucasian female presents to your office with several manths history of heartburn. She also
describes a periodic "sticking sensation’ in her throat during the meal. Her past medical histary is significant
for asthma that is controlled with inhaled steroids, and acoustic neuroma that was removed 2 years
ago. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She denies any recreational drug use. She is not allergic to
any medications. She warks as a secretary at a private firm, and considers her wark moderately
stressful. Her family history is significant far breast cancer in her mother and prostate cancer in her
father. Endoscopic evaluation shows mild hyperemia in the distal esophagus. Esophageal manometry
reveals absent peristaltic waves in the lower two-thirds of the esophagus and a significant decrease in lower
esophageal sphincter tone. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's complaints?
options: B. GERD with ar without hiatal hernia
explanation:
This clinical scenario is mast consistent with esophageal dysmotility associated with scleroderma. Two
impartant clinical clues in this scenario are the characteristic symptoms (i.e. "sticking sensation in the throat"
ar dysphagia accompanied by heartburn) and manometric findings (i.e, absence of peristaltic waves in the

(Choice A) Manometric findings in achalasia include a significant decrease or absence of peristaltic waves

(Choice B) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) may be associated with dysphagia due to a stricture,

(Choice D) Mon-ulcer dyspepsia is not usually accompanied by esophageal dysmotility.

Educational Objective:
The absence of peristaltic waves in the lower two-thirds of the esophagus and significant decrease in lower

question:
A 34-year-old woman complains of occasional diarrhea and crampy lower abdominal pain. She says that at
times her symptoms hamper her performance in important business meetings. The pain sometimes occurs
after meals but is nat always preceded by eating. The pain is often accompanied by diarrhea with small
amounts of stoal and mucus. Her past medical history is significant for bleeding hemarrhaids. Her mother
died of calon cancer. Which of the following findings is most likely in this patient?
explanation:
This woman most likely has irritable bowel syndrame (IBS), a chronic functional gastrointestinal disorder
characterized by a myriad of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, pain
relief with bowel movements, looser and mare frequent stoals with the onset of pain, passage of mucus, a
sense of incomplete emptying, and bloating. There are diarrhea predominant, constipation predominant, and
mixed subtypes of IBS. Extraintestinal manifestations may include depression, sexual dysfunction and
urinary changes. Symptoms may be exacerbated by stress. IBS is much mare caomman in women than in
men. The exact etiology is unclear but it may be related to a heightened awareness of normal badily
functions. There is no laboratory ar pathologic hallmark of IBS.
(Choice A) Perianal fistulas are commonly seen in Crohn's disease. This patient does not have severe
abdominal pain, weight loss, fevers, ar extraintestinal manifestations consistent with Crohn's disease.
(Choice B) Crypt abscesses are characteristic for ulcerative colitis, a disease associated with abdominal
pain, weight loss, diarrhea with ar without mucus or blood, and low grade fevers. This patient's presentation
is nat severe enough to pursue a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis.
{Choice C) Folic acid deficiency can occur secondary to poor dietary intake, alcoholism, increased usage, or
as a drug side effect. It does not usually cause diarrhea.
(Choice D) A duodenal ulcer typically presents with epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, gastrointestinal blood
loss, and anemia. It is not a comman cause of lower abdominal pain or diarrhea.
(Choice E) Intestinal villous atrophy is the hallmark of celiac sprue, an autoimmune disease that causes
intolerance to gluten. Patients present with weight loss, bloating, flatulence, and malnutrition. Symptoms are

correlate with diet.
Educational objective:
Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional disarder of the gastrointestinal tract characterized by abdominal pain
with diarrhea and/or constipation. There is no laboratory or pathologic hallmark of irritable bowel syndrome.

question:
A 55-year-old obese male presents to his physician for a routine annual physical examination. A review of
systems is insignificant, except for constipation which has been present for several years. He does nat have
major medical problems and is nat on any prescription or over-the-counter medications. He has smoked one-
and-a-half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks 4 oz of alcohol daily. Physical examination is
unremarkable. As part of the routine screening, a colonoscopy is performed, which shows multiple diverticuli
at the sigmaid calon. He is concerned about the diverticulosis. Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in the management of this patient's diverticulosis?
options: A Advise him to stop smoking
B. Advise him to stop drinking alcohol
explanation:
The incidence of diverticular disease increases with advancing age. A diverticulum, by definition, is a sac-like
protrusion of the colonic wall, which develops at points of weakness. Diverticulosis is most often
asymptomatic, but can alsa present with symptoms such as constipation and abdominal pain. Constipation
causes increased pressure in the colon, and this excess pressure can lead to weak spots, thus predisposing
to the formation of diverticuli. The characteristic colonascopic findings are multiple diverticuli. The best
method of treatment of uncomplicated diverticulasis is by increasing the intake of dietary fiber. The resultant

question:

A B4-year-ald man is brought to the ER after an episode of coffee ground emesis followed by

question:

question:

question:

question:

question:

A 35-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with two episodes of bloody vomiting

mucosal injury (as in this case). Acute mucosal injury decreases the normal protective barriers (decreased
levels of secreted mucins and bicarbonate, and decreased integrity of the epithelium), thus permitting acid
and other luminal substances (e.g. proteases and bile acids) to penetrate into the lamina propria, thereby
causing additional injury to the vasculature and subsequent hemorrhage. As in this case, patients may
manifest with hematemesis and abdominal pain.

patients with liver disease. This patient is a young, occasional drinker and has nao other findings suggestive of

bouts of retching and vamiting. Mo such histary is given in this case.

characterized by hepatic encephalapathy.

amounts of aspirin, however, platelet dysfunction by itself cannot cause erosive gastritis.
Educational Objective:
Massive doses of aspirin and NSAIDs can cause acute erosive gastritis and upper Gl bleeding. Alcahal can
aggravate their effect.

the upper limit predicts a favorable response to interferon or lamivudine. In general lamivudine has a
canvenient route of administration (oral) and has fewer side effects than interferon. Interferon treatment is
particularly nat successful in young children and immunocampromised patients.
(Choices A and D) These are the modalities emplayed in the past exposure prophylaxis in susceptible
peaple but not for delaying the progression of chronic disease.
(Choice B) This is far primary prevention of people at risk.
{Choice E) This patient is having chronic hepatitis with ALT more than two times the normal and with heavy
viral load. He has a great chance of progression of disease and should be treated with interferon aor
lamivudine.
Educational Objective:
Chronic Hepatitis B patients with persistently elevated ALT levels, detectable serum HBsAg, HBeAg, and HBY
DMA should be treated with interferon ar lamivudine.

question:
A 42-year-old male comes to you with the complaints of yellow urine and yellow discoloration of eyes. His
past medical history is insignificant and he takes no medication. On examination he has Temperature:
3TC(98.6F), RR: 12/min, PR: B0/min, and icteric sclerae. His liver function tests show total bilirubin: 11.0
mag/dl, direct bilirubin: 8.0 mg/dl, AST: 45 |UJL, ALT: 40 IU/L, alkaline phosphatase: 800 IU/L, serum albumin:
3.8 g/dl, PT: 11 seconds. He has a negative autoantibody screen. Which of the following is the next best step
in investigating this patient?
options: D. Estimation of hemoglobin with peripheral smear examination
E. No further investigation is needed as the patient has rotor's syndrome
explanation:
This patient has jaundice as he has elevated serum bilirubin (normal total bilirubin = 1mgfdl). The next step is
to determine whether he has predominantly conjugated ar unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Conjugated
hyperbilirubinemia is present when direct ar conjugated bilirubin constitutes =50% of total bilirubin.
Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is present when indirect ar unconjugated bilirubin constitutes =30% of the
total bilirubin. Marmally direct ar conjugated bilirubin constitutes =10% of total bilirubin. Thus this patient has
predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
Predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia occurs in following conditions:
A) Intrahepatic causes:
1. Intrahepatic obstruction, which can accur in, conditions like viral ar autoimmune hepatitis, alcohalic hepatitis, drug reactions, third trimester of pregnancy or postoperative states.
2. Congenital defects in biliary excretion, i.e. Dubin Johnson and Rator's syndrome.
B) Extrahepatic biliary obstruction.
The next step in the evaluation of patients with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is to study the liver enzymes.
Fatients with dominant aminotransferase elevation usually have hepatocellular disease whereas patients with
dominant elevation of alkaline phosphatase have predominant intra or extrahepatic biliary obstruction. In the
second group of patients such as the patient in this question it is very important to rule out an extra hepatic
obstruction with an ultrasonogram ar a CT scan of abdomen (Choice B) If these imaging techniques fail to
show an extra hepatic biliary dilatation then the next step wauld be ta ga for an ERCP ar PTC (Choices A
and C).
(Choice D) Estimation of hemoglobin and peripheral smear examination is impartant in evaluation of
predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, as hemalytic diseases can be the cause.
(Choice E) Congenital diseases of impaired hepatic excretion of bilirubin like Dubin Johnson and Rotar's
syndrome can cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but will nat have an elevation of alkaline phosphatase.
Educational Objective:
Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is mainly because of intrahepatic or extrahepatic obstruction or congenital
impaired hepatic excretion of bilirubin.

question:
A 52-year-old male comes with acute abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, vomiting and fever. He
had a similar attack two years ago and was treated far acute pancreatitis. He is a non-alcoholic and his
ultrasonogram of abdomen shows na gallstones. He is not taking any drugs and his lipid profile is normal. His
family history and past medical history are insignificant. He is admitted and laboratory report shows marked
elevation of amylase and lipase. He is treated for acute pancreatitis and his symptoms resolve aver 5 days
with serum amylase and lipase returning to normal. What would be the next best step in the evaluation of this
patient?
options: A. Do a CT scan of the abdomen
E. Regular follow up of the patient
explanation:
This patient has recurrent pancreatitis for which no obvious cause is identified. In this situation ERCP would
be the best investigation to search far the underlying cause (Choice B). ERCF in this case would help to
diagnose ductal abnormalities including pancreatic divisum, choledachal cysts, and comman bile duct
stones. It would alsa allow for gall bladder aspiration of bile ta loak far biliary crystals ar micralithiasis.
{Choice A) CT scan can tell about hepatobiliary pathology but it is nat as sensitive as ERCP to study the
pancreatic and biliary duct and also would miss the micralithiasis which is present in more than 70 % of such
patients.
(Choice C) HIDA scan is a very sensitive tool for diagnosis of cholecystitis or sphincter of Oddi dysfunction
but it will not be useful in the present scenario.
(Choice D) Endoscopic ultrasonography can be used to look for ductal pathology ar pancreatic lesion but
ERCP is a better tool in this scenario.
(Choice E) Patients with recurrent acute pancreatitis are at risk of further attacks if the underlying cause is
not sought and corrected, therefore simply following up the patient is not appropriate.
Educational Objective:
Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatagraphy is the investigation of choice far patients with recurrent
pancreatitis with na obvious cause.

question:
A 45-year-old male is known to have chronic hepatitis C, for six years. He comes to your office complaining of
malaise that started a week ago. On examination he has mild hepatomegaly. His vitals are normal and his
liver enzymes show ALT: 150 IU/L, AST: 120 IU/L, and total bilirubin: 2.3 mg/dl. Which af the following would
wou expect to find in this patient?
explanation:
Chronic hepatitis C is associated with number of extra hepatic complications like;
1. Cryoglobulinemia
2. B cell ymphomas
3. Plasmacytomas
4 Autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome and thyroiditis
5. Lichen planus
8. Porphyria cutanea tarda
7. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura
Some of these complications are immune complex mediated, however immune complex mediated
extrahepatic complications are more common with hepatitis B than with hepatitis C except for
cryoglobulinemia.
(Choice A) Chronic hepatitis can lead to membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (less frequently
membranous nephropathy) characterized by proteinuria. It is generally secondary to cryoglobulinemia.
(Choices B and C) Pericarditis and pancreatitis are not known complications of hepatitis C.
(Choice D) Recently same relation between HCV infection and diabetes is suspected but is nat yet been
praved.
(Choice E) B cell lymphoma is a complication of chronic Hepatitis C but not T cell lymphoma
Educational Objective:
Know the extra hepatic complications of chronic hepatitis C.

question:
A 48-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant fullness. He has been morbidly obese since his early
teenage years. He has type 2 diabetes and hypertension. His current medications include glyburide,
atenolol, and hydrochlorothiazide. He does not use tobacco, alcohol or drugs. His family histary is positive
for type 2 diabetes mellitus in his father. His blood pressure is 138/30 mmHg, pulse is 72/min, temperature is
36.7C (88F) and respirations are 16/min. His BMI is 45 kg/m2. He has acanthosis over his neck.
Examination of his abdomen reveals palpable hepatomegaly. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
Lab studies show:
Albumin                                       4.0 mg/dL
Total bilirubin                                  1.0 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin                                 0.8 mag/dL
Alkaline phosphatase                          100 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)          72 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)            75 U/L
Blood glucose                                 168 mg/dL
Hepatitis serology, antimitochondrial antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, serum ceruloplasmin, and transferrin
saturation are normal. What is the mast likely pathophysiologic mechanism responsible for this patient's
increased liver transaminases?
explanation:
The patient most likely has non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, which refers to a spectrum of liver damage
ranging fram steatosis, to steato-hepatitis, and advanced fibrosis in non-alcoholic patients. Obesity and type
2 diabetes mellitus are frequently assaciated with this condition, with a prevalence as high as 74% in obese
individuals. The pathophysiology is not clearly understood; however, majarity believe that insulin resistance is the mast likely mechanism. Insulin resistance leads to increased fat accumulation in the hepatocytes by
increasing the rate of lipolysis and elevating the circulating insulin levels. Intrahepatic fatty acid oxidation
then leads to an increase in oxidative stress, thereby causing a local increase in the proinflammatory
cytokines TNF-alpha, with consequent liver inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis.
Alcahal is not involved in the pathophysiology of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, but the clinicopathological
picture resembles that of alcoholic liver disease. Liver biopsy shows macrovesicular fat deposition with
displacement of the nucleus to the periphery. Liver biopsy is the best diagnostic toal for canfirming
non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. [tis also useful in the follow-up evaluation and management of patients.
(Choice B) Hepatic glycogen synthesis is mostly reduced in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Hepatic
glycogen synthesis does not play a role in hepatic steatosis.
(Choice D and E) Glucagon production can be increased in some patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus;
hawever, it does nat play a role in hepatic fat accumulation. Patients with Cushing's syndrome may have a
clinical picture similar to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease can be seen; however, Cushing's
syndrome is unlikely in this patient since his obesity has been present since early adulthood.
Educational Objective:
Insulin resistance plays a central role in the pathophysiology of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease by increasing
the rate of lipolysis and elevating the circulating insulin levels.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with persistent abdominal pain. He says that the
pain began more than 12 hours ago and is predominantly epigastric in location. He reports having vomited
several times since the pain started. His past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia treated with
simvastatin and hypertension treated with lisinopril. He smokes one pack of cigarettes a day and consumes
4-6 cans of beer daily and several more on weekends. He does not use IV drugs. On physical examination,
his blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and temperature is
37.8°C (100°F). Abdominal examination reveals epigastric tenderness without guarding ar rebound. Chest
x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation:
This patient presents with acute alcoholic pancreatitis. Classic symptoms of pancreatitis include nausea,
