vomiting, and intense epigastric pain that radiates to the back. Low-grade fever is also common. The
diagnosis is made based on the patient's history, physical exam findings, and elevated serum amylase and
lipase levels. Gallstones and alcohol abuse are the most common causes of acute pancreatitis in
adults. Rarer causes include hypertriglyceridemia, anatomic abnormalities, infection, and medications.
Faotential complications of acute pancreatitis include exudative left-sided pleural effusions when the amylase
concentration is high, abdominal compartment syndrome, intraabdominal hemorrhage, shack, diabetes,
pancreatic pseudocyst formation, and abdominal pseudoaneurysm.
(Choice A) Acute cholecystitis typically presents as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and
leukocytosis. Episodes are usually preceded by periods of biliary colic and the pain classically radiates to the
right shoulder. This patient's alcoholism is a strong risk factor for pancreatitis but does not strongly
predispose to cholecystitis. Finally, a left-sided pleural effusion is not easily explained by cholecystitis.
(Choice B) Pneumonia can cause low-grade fever and a unilateral pleural effusion (for example secondary to
empyema or a parapneumonic effusion). However, it would be unlikely for a patient with pneumania to
present with epigastric pain rather than cough or shortness of breath. Additionally, this patient's chest x-ray
does not show any alveolar infiltrates.
(Choice C) A myocardial infarction may present with epigastric pain and nausea, but it would be unusual for
this pain to last more than a few hours, in contrast to the patient above, who has had pain for 12 hours.
(Choice D) Mesenteric ischemia presents with severe abdominal pain out of proportion to findings an
physical exam. The pain is often periumbilical and may be accompanied by nausea and
vomiting. Hematochezia or accult blood in the stoal is common.
(Choice E) Intraabdominal abscesses often present subacutely with fever, plus ar minus accompanying
nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. The patient above has a presentation that is more acute than would
be expected from an abdominal abscess.
(Choice G) A perforated peptic ulcer will cause epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, hematemesis, and
peritoneal signs on exam.
{Choice H) Pyelanephritis classically causes flank pain, fever, leukocytosis, nausealvomiting, and
costovertebral angle tenderness.
Educational Objective:
Acute pancreatitis classically causes nausea, vomiting, and epigastric pain that radiates to the back. The
patient's clinical history, physical exam findings, serum lipase and amylase levels all help to make the
diagnosis. Alcohal abuse is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in men and gallstones are the
mast comman cause in women.

question:
A B2-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of diffuse abdominal pain and is found
to have a single liver mass (3 x § cm) on abdominal ultrasound. Review of systems is positive far an
involuntary weight loss of 7 pounds and increased fatigability aver the last three months. His medical history
is otherwise noncontributory. He smokes one pack per day but he does not consume alcohol. Which of the
following is most likely to establish the diagnosis in this patent?
explanation:
This patient has chronic diffuse abdominal pain, weight loss and fatigue in the setting of a solitary liver
mass. The most likely diagnosis is an intraabdominal malignancy that has metastasized to the
liver. Because of its rich perfusion and function as a filter of the blood, the liver is a common site for
metastatic disease. Metastatic disease of the liver is many times mare common than primary liver
malignancy. Primary tumaors of the gastrointestinal tract, lung and breast metastasize ta the liver most
commanly. Patients usually present with symptoms related to the primary malignancy, as liver metastases
are generally asymptomatic. In this case, the patient's history of abdominal pain makes colonascaopy the
mast appropriate next step in establishing the diagnosis.
(Choice A) Alpha-fetoprotein measurement is used along with imaging studies in the diagnosis of
hepatocellular carcinoma, which most commonly occurs in the setting of chranic liver disease.
(Choice B) Bone marrow biopsy is useful in establishing a diagnosis of myelopraliferative ar
lymphoproliferative disorders. It would be uncommon far these disorders to cause an isolated liver mass in
an otherwise healthy-appearing patient.
(Choice C) Thyroid nuclear scanning can be used to diagnose thyroid malignancies. Thyroid cancers
usually appear as "cold" masses on such scans because they commonly do nat express the sodium/iodide
symporter and therefore fall ta take up radiolabeled iodine. Aggressive thyroid malignancies may metastasize
ta the lymph nodes, bone and lungs.
(Choice D) Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement is used together with the digital rectal examination
ta screen for prastate cancer and prostatic hypertrophy. Prastate cancer is generally an indalent
malignancy. When it does metastasize, it tends to travel to the pelvic lymph nodes. Presenting symptoms, if
any, may be related to prostate enlargement.
Educational objective:
An isolated liver mass is much mare likely to be the result of metastatic disease than a primary malignancy of
the liver. Primary tumaors of the Gl tract, lung and breast are the most common diseases causing liver
metastases. Liver metastases are generally asymptomatic; patients tend to present instead with symptoms
related to their primary malignancy.

question:
A 52-year-old obese Caucasian female with an unremarkable medical history undergoes an elective
cholecystectomy for multiple gallstones that were causing her intermittent right upper quadrant pain.
Postoperatively, her vital signs are stable but she continues to complain of right upper quadrant pain.
Labaratory evaluation demonstrates the following:
Liver studies
Tatal bilirubin                                       0.9 mo/dL
Direct bilirubin                                      0.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase                              45 iL
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT)          34 UL
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGFT)           32 UiL
An ultrasound of the abdomen reveals no dilatation of the biliary tree. What is the most likely diagnosis in this
patient?
explanation:
This woman is experiencing postcholecystectomy pain, which is usually due to one of three reasons:
sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, a comman bile duct stone, ar functional pain. Because this woman has normal
liver function tests and there is nao evidence of dilatation of her biliary tree, both sphincter of Oddi dysfunction
and common bile duct stone can be ruled out. She is therefore most likely experiencing functional pain with
no obvious arganic basis and should be treated symptamatically with analgesics and reassurance.
(Choices B and C) If this patient had an abnormal alkaline phosphatase or dilatation of the biliary tree
observed on abdominal ultrasound, then the presence of either a comman bile duct stone or sphincter of
{Oddi dysfunction would be far more likely. ERCP would then be indicated ta confirm and treat the condition,
either through stone removal or sphincterotomy. Since testing revealed na evidence of abnarmalities,
however, functional pain is the more likely diagnosis.
(Choice D) Acute pancreatitis usually causes epigastric pain rather than right upper quadrant pain. In
addition, symptoms are typically severe enough to cause disruption of vital signs (eg, tachycardia, tachypnea).
(Choice E) Factitious pain accurs when the patient intentionally feigns illness because she enjoys the "sick
role." This is a difficult to diagnose condition that usually requires same direct evidence of falsification or the
definitive elimination of all organic causes. A psychiatric histary is typically present. In this scenario, however,
there is no evidence that the patient is experiencing factitious pain.
Educational Objective:
Fast cholecystectomy pain most cammanly occurs due to one of three reasons: comman bile duct stone,
sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, or functional causes.

question:
A 29-year-old woman in her 25th week of gestation is diagnosed with chranic hepatitis secondary to infection
with hepatitis C virus. Her pregnancy has been otherwise uncomplicated to date. She is married and is
manaogamous with her husband. Her past medical history is significant only for an appendectomy at age 12.
She is currently not on any medications, aside from a daily prenatal multivitamin. Which of the following
recommendations should be given to this woman?
options: A. Commence treatment with interferon and ribavirin
B. Avoid breast-feeding the baby after birth
C. Use condoms when engaging in sexual activity with her husband
D. Obtain vaccination against Hepatitis A and B, if nat already immune
E. Schedule an elective caesarean section
explanation:
Hepatitis C is a major cause of chronic hepatitis. Up to 80% of infected patients develop chronic hepatitis. It
is acquired mast commaonly by exposure to contaminated blood. Current recommendations state that all
patients with chronic hepatitis C should receive vaccinations to Hepatitis A and B if not already
immune. Both vaccinations are safe for use during pregnancy.
{Choice B) HCV-RMA is detectable in colostrum (early farm of breast milk); however, studies have shown
that breastfeeding does not increase the risk of transmission to the neanate. For this reason, bath the
American Callege of Obstetricians and Gynecalogists and the American Academy of Pediatrics suppart
breastfeeding by HCV-infected mothers.
(Choice E) Perinatal transmission of HCV is a much less frequent cause of infection, and the overall
incidence of vertical transmission is around 2-5 %. Factors which seem to increase the averall risk of vertical
transmission are HIV coinfection and a high HCY viral load. A caesarean section does nat seem to
significantly decrease the risk of vertical transmission. Currently pregnant wamen with HCY are not advised
to have cesarean sections, other than for the usual obstetric indications.
(Choice A) Combined interferon-alfa and ribavirin is used for the treatment of patients with chronic hepatitis
C and compensated liver disease. However these drugs are contraindicated in pregnancy. Ribavirin is
particularly highly teratogenic.
(Choice C) There is some evidence that shows that sexual transmission of HCY may occur, but the
incidence is extremely low. In monogamous, heterosexual partners, the risk is less than 0.1% annually. With
such a low risk, both the United States Public Health Service and the National Institutes of Health have not
recommended barrier precautions between stable monogamous sexual partners.
Educational Objective:
The overall incidence of vertical transmission of HCV is approximately 2-5%. All patients, including pregnant
patients, with chranic hepatitis C should receive vaccinations against Hepatitis A and B if nat already immune.
*Extremely important question for the USMLE step-2

question:
A 43-year-old nurse presents to her primary care physician complaining of occasional heartburn. Cn
physical examination she is found to have hepatomegaly. Her spleen is not palpable. She denies any history
of jaundice, rash, joint pain, vomiting, or black stool. Serum analysis reveals the following:
HBsAg                          negative
Anti-HBsAg antibodies        positive
Anti-HAY antibodies            negative
Anti-HCV antibodies           positive
AST                           70 units/L
ALT                            110 units/L
Bilirubin                        1.2 mg/dL
Creatinine                     0.9 mg/dL
PT/INR                              12.0/1.0
Which of the following is the best recommendation for this patient?
explanation:
This woman is infected with the hepatitis C virus but does not have evidence of cirrhosis on physical
examination ar by laboratory data. Her transaminases and bilirubin are mildly elevated but her INR is within
normal range. All patients with chronic liver disease should be immunized against hepatitis A and B unless
they are already immune, as they are at high risk for acute hepatic failure or cirrhosis upon infection with viral
hepatitis. This woman is positive far anti-hepatitis B surface antibodies (anti-HBsAQ), indicating immunity
against hepatitis B. She is not immune against hepatitis A, however, and should be vaccinated.
(Choice A) Prednisone is used to treat severe alcohalic hepatitis. This disease typically presents with fever,
abdominal pain, jaundice, nausea, and vamiting.
(Choice B) Lamivudine (3TC] is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor used to treat HIV and chronic hepatitis
B. This woman's hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is negative, arguing against active infection with
hepatitis B.
(Choice D) Anti-HBsAg antibodies convey immunity against the hepatitis B virus. She is anti-HBsAg antibody
positive and does not require vaccination against hepatitis B.
(Choice E) Patients with cirrhosis are intravascularly depleted and impressive salt retainers. A low-salt diet
is beneficial in decreasing ascites and peripheral edema by decreasing the total amount of sodium that can
be retained. This patient does not have cirrhosis, sa a low-salt diet is not necessary.
{Choice F) Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to help prevent hypervolemia in cirrhosis. This woman does
not have cirrhasis and will not benefit from a loop diuretic.
Educational objective:
All patients with chranic liver disease should be immunized against hepatitis A and B.

question:
A 45-year-old African American alcoholic female presents to clinic complaining of cough with hemoptysis,
night sweats, and subjective fever. A chest radiograph demonstrates right upper lobe cavity that is consistent
with a diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis. Sputum staining for acid-fast bacteria is positive. She is begun on
a regimen that includes isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. She reports having taken aral
contraceptive pills for the past five years. Two manths later when she returns for follow-up examination, her
sputum is clear of acid-fast bacilli. However, she now complains of fatigue, malaise, and nausea that began
approximately ten days ago. Physical examination reveals icteric sclerae and tender hepatomegaly. Her
labaratory evaluation returns with the following:
Liver studies
Albumin                                        3.9 gfdL
Total bilirubin                                  4.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase                          98 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)          372 UL
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT)            410 LiL
Coagulation studies
Prothrombin time                              13 sec
Partial thromboplastin time                    27 sec
Hepatitis Panel
HBsAg                                           Negative
Anti-HBsAg                                      Megative
Ig Anti-HBcAg                               Megative
HBeAg                                           Negative
Anti-HBeAg                                      [Negative
Anti-HAY [gi                                          [Negative
Anti-HAY 1gG                                          Megative
Anti-HCY                                        Negative
Liver biopsy demonstrates panlobular mononuclear infiltration and hepatic cell necrosis. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: B. Hepatitis secondary to oral contraceptive usage
C. Hepatitis secondary to isoniazid usage
explanation:
This patient's liver function tests and liver biopsy results are consistent with a diagnosis of acute hepatitis
and hepatocellular injury. The most likely cause of this woman's acute hepatitis is isoniazid, which is a
component of her anti-tuberculous therapy. Isoniazid can cause severe hepatitis and even fulminant liver
failure within the first two months of treatment. The pattern of hepatic injury can vary from patient to patient,
but the most common histological pattern resembles that seen in viral hepatitis. Mild elevations in the
aminotransferases may occur in 10-20% of patients taking isoniazid but tend to resolve without
consequences. However, if the serum ALT and AST increase to more than three times the upper limit of
normal, the medication should be discontinued immediately. This is because there is a significant risk
of Isoniazig-inducea hepatic cell injury.
Drugs and toxins typically cause hepatic injury, either through direct toxic effects or through idiosyncratic
reactions. The direct toxic effects are dose-dependent and have short latent periods. Some examples of
direct toxins include carbon tetrachloride, acetaminophen, tetracycline, and substances found in the Amanita
phalloides mushroom. [diosyncratic reactions are not dose-dependent and have variable latent periods. Some
examples of pharmacological agents that cause idiosyncratic reactions include isoniazid, chlorpromazine,
halothane, and antiretroviral therapy.
Drug-induced liver disease can also be broadly categorized according to marphology: 1) cholestasis, which
is caused by medications such as chlorpromazine, nitrofurantoin, erythromycin, and anabolic steroids; 2)
fatty liver, which is caused by medications such as tetracycline, valproate, and anti-retrovirals; 3) hepatitis,
which is caused by medications such as halothane, phenytoin, isoniazid, and alpha-methyldopa; 4) toxic ar
fulminant liver failure, which is caused by medications such as carbon tetrachloride and acetaminophen; and
5) granulomatous, which is caused by medications such as allopurinol and phenylbutazone.
(Choice A) The patient's laboratory profile is not suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis. Classically, the AST ALT
ratio is = 2 in alcoholic hepatitis. Moreover, the timeline correlation between the initiation of treatment for
tuberculosis and the onset of her hepatic dysfunction mandates close scrutiny of her pharmacatherapy
regimen.
(Choice B) Oral contraceptives are unusual in that they can cause abnormalities in liver function tests
without evidence of necrosis or fatty change. Since this patient's liver biopsy demanstrated necrosis, oral
contraceptives are not likely responsible for her hepatic dysfunction.
(Choice D) Autoimmune hepatitis should be considered once all possible causes of drug-induced ar viral
hepatitis have been ruled out. Positive antinuclear antibody (AMA) and/or positive smooth muscle antibody
suggest the diagnosis of classic (type 1) autoimmune hepatitis.
{Choice E) Tuberculous hepatitis may develop in cases of miliary tuberculosis but would be characterized by
granulomas on liver biopsy. Moreover, since this patient had a sputum conversion, it is highly unlikely that she
is now suffering from miliary tuberculosis.
Educational Objective:
Isoniazid causes idiosyncratic liver injury with histological features similar to those seen in patients with viral
hepatitis.

question: A 42-year-old, Latino-American, female comes to the physician's office with complaints of intolerance to fatty foods. On examination, her vitals are normal and she has mild right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness. An ultrasonogram of the abdomen shows multiple gallstones and an intrahepatic ill-defined cyst with a thick wall. A CT of the abdomen is performed which shows a well-defined cyst with egg shell calcifications. The past medical history of the patient is insignificant. The patient has no recent or past travel, and has had two pet dogs at home for 10 years. She is not taking any drugs and had never had any surgery. What is the most likely etiology for the intrahepatic cyst in this patient?
explanation:
This patient has a hydatid cyst in the liver. Hydatid disease is due to infection with Echinococcus granulosus. Humans contract the infection from the close and intimate contacts with dogs, which are the definitive host in the life cycle of E. granulosus. It can cause unilocular cystic lesion in any organs including liver, lung, muscle, and bones. Multiple lesions are associated with E. multilocularis infection.
In most of the patients hydatid cysts are asymptomatic and generally diagnosed on screening for some other problem. However, it may cause symptoms, usually due to compression on surrounding tissues. Imaging techniques can be used for diagnosis along with the serological test. 'Eggshell’ calcification of a hepatic cyst on CT scan is highly suggestive of hydatid cyst. Aspiration of the cyst is generally not indicated due to the risk of anaphylactic shock secondary to spilling of cyst contents. Treatment is generally surgical resection under the cover of albendazole.
(Choice A) Amebic liver abscess will not have egg shell calcifications on CT scan and also the patient's history is more suggestive of a hydatid cyst.
(Choice B) Pyogenic liver abscess is generally secondary to a surgery, a gastrointestinal infection or acute appendicitis. Patients generally present with extreme pain, fever, and leukocytosis.
(Choice D) Cysticercosis is secondary to infection with tenia solium and generally results in cysts in the brain or in muscle.
(Choice E) The causes of simple liver cysts are believed to be congenital in origin. The pathophysiology of simple hepatic cysts is related to fluid secretion by the epithelial lining. Patients with simple liver cysts that cause symptoms usually report dull right upper quadrant pain, abdominal bloating, or early satiety. However it will not show any calcification on CT scan.

question: A 42-year-old Caucasian man with a history of chronic alcoholism is admitted to the hospital for acute pancreatitis. He is treated supportively with intravenous fluids and meperidine and is given nothing by mouth. Over a period of several days, his white blood cell count and serum amylase decrease. He is discharged home. Four weeks later, he presents to the emergency department complaining of a palpable mass in the epigastrium with pain radiating to his back. His vital signs include a temperature of 37.0C (98.6F), blood pressure of 117/84 mm Hg, pulse of 86/min, and respirations of 16/min. Laboratory evaluation reveals a marked increase in serum amylase to 308 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The development of a palpable mass in the epigastrium four weeks after the onset of acute pancreatitis is highly suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst formation.
Although pseudocysts are most often associated with chronic pancreatitis, they can also complicate acute pancreatitis, pancreatic trauma, or pancreatic neoplasms. Pancreatic pseudocysts are not true cysts as they lack an epithelial lining and are actually walled by a thick fibrous capsule. The pseudocyst is comprised of inflammatory fluid (containing high levels of amylase, lipase, and enterokinase), tissue, and debris that accumulate within the pancreas or by extension along anatomic planes. When the amylase-rich fluid leaks into circulation, serum amylase becomes markedly elevated. Ultrasound is the preferred means of imaging pseudocysts.
Because the pseudocyst often resolves spontaneously, drainage should only be performed if it persists for greater than six weeks, is greater than 5 cm in diameter, or becomes secondarily infected. One particularly concerning complication occurs when the inflammatory process erodes into a blood vessel, which can result in severe hemorrhaging into the pseudocyst.
(Choice A) Hemorrhagic pancreatitis is a severe, life-threatening illness characterized by retroperitoneal hemorrhage and pancreatic necrosis. Physical examination findings may include a bluish discoloration of the flanks (Grey Turner sign) or periumbilical region (Cullen sign) resulting from blood accumulation in abdominal fascial planes. However, this patient has normal vital signs and no evidence of hemorrhage associated with his abdominal mass.
(Choice B) Infected pancreatic necrosis is the diffuse infection of necrotic pancreatic tissue, usually occurring 1-2 weeks after an episode of acute pancreatitis. Patients with this condition are gravely ill, with spiking fevers, leukocytosis, and in some cases, shock and organ failure. Surgical debridement is the treatment of choice.
(Choice C) Pancreatic ascites results from rupture of the pancreatic duct or leakage of the pseudocyst into the peritoneal cavity. Abdominal distention and shifting dullness are typically observed. Significant pain is uncommon.
(Choice D) Pancreatic abscess is a localized, ill-defined collection of pus from necrotic pancreatic tissue. It presents as a tender epigastric mass and is associated with persistent fever and leukocytosis. Mortality rate is low following drainage.

question:
A 39-year-old commercial sex worker presents to clinic complaining of chronic fatigue, nausea, and myalgia. Her past medical history is significant for tension headaches. She has been treated remotely for gonorrheal infection on several occasions and an HIV test performed six months ago was negative. She admits to drinking 2-4 beers per day and uses marijuana and heroin "most every day." Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly. Laboratory evaluation returns the following:
Liver studies
Albumin 3.3 g/dl
Total bilirubin 1.3 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 124 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 1640 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 1910 U/L
Coagulation studies
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 29 sec
Serum HBsAg is positive. Supportive treatment is initiated. Several days later her laboratory results demonstrate an increase in prothrombin time and a decrease in transaminase levels. These new laboratory findings are suggestive of which of the following conditions?
options: C. Recovery phase of hepatitis B
explanation:
Broadly speaking, laboratory tests used in the evaluation of liver disease either assess liver functionality (eg, prothrombin time bilirubin, albumin, cholesterol) or structural integrity and cellular intactness (eg, transaminases, gamma glutaryl transferase, alkaline phosphatase).
The prothrombin time (PT) is considered the single most important test to assess the function of liver because all clotting factors (except for factor VIII) are synthesized in the liver. When the liver is unable to create sufficient amounts of clotting factors, the PT is prolonged.
Elevated levels of serum transaminases are indicative of hepatocyte damage because these intracellular enzymes leak from injured hepatocytes. A marked increase in the transaminases is indicative of active and ongoing tissue destruction. A progressive decrease in transaminase levels signals either recovery from liver injury or that very few hepatocytes are functional. Thus, the interpretation of transaminase levels should be made in light of other liver function tests.
In this patient's case, a rise in PT with a decrease in transaminase levels implies that very little functional tissue remains in the liver, which can happen rapidly in cases of fulminant hepatic failure.
(Choice B) Superinfection with hepatitis D would normally lead to an increase in the transaminase levels due to additional hepatic tissue injury.
(Choice C) Recovery from hepatitis B infection is heralded by decreased transaminase levels and a normal prothrombin time.
(Choice D) Coexisting infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) can only be confirmed with serological testing for HCV. While it is possible this high-risk patient has recently become infected with HCV, it is less likely given her declining transaminase levels.
(Choice E) The diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma is established through liver biopsy or the combination of confirmatory imaging studies and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels. While hepatocellular carcinoma is more likely to arise in patients with histories of HBV or HCV infection, it is improbable that cancer is the cause of this patient's recent laboratory findings.

question: A 52-year-old Hispanic male presents to clinic complaining of fever and fatigue of insidious onset. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, degenerative disc disease, and an episode of acute pancreatitis two years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day and has consumed 72-96 ounces of beer per day for the past thirty years. He denies any history of blood transfusions, tattoos, or high-risk sexual behaviors. He works as a construction foreman and is married. Physical examination reveals tender hepatomegaly with spider angiomata present on his upper torso. Liver biopsy demonstrates steatosis, polymorphonuclear cellular (PMN) infiltrates, and necrosis. Which of the following is true about alcoholic liver disease?
options: A. Males are more susceptible than females to alcoholic liver disease
B. Alcoholic fatty liver is an irreversible condition
C. In alcoholic liver disease, AST/ALT is >= 2
D. Fifty percent of alcoholics develop alcohol-related hepatitis
E. Mallory bodies are highly specific for alcoholic hepatitis
explanation:
The spectrum of alcoholic liver disease encompasses fatty liver, alcoholic hepatitis, and cirrhosis.
Alcoholic fatty liver is rarely diagnosed clinically. Most patients are asymptomatic, with a minority experiencing mild tender hepatomegaly. This condition can develop after a single large binging episode, and does not predict progression to hepatitis, fibrosis, or cirrhosis unless alcohol intake continues to be substantial.
Although some patients may be asymptomatic, those with alcoholic hepatitis often present with modest fever, hepatomegaly, jaundice, and anorexia. Aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase, gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), and bilirubin levels are typically elevated. Liver biopsy is confirmatory if the diagnosis cannot be made based on clinical evidence alone.
Classically, alcoholic cirrhosis is characterized by an increased ratio of AST/ALT, elevated alkaline phosphatase, jaundice, and hematologic abnormalities in conjunction with the stigmata of chronic liver disease.
Broadly speaking, the various forms of alcoholic liver disease are characterized by modest elevations in hepatic transaminases and GGT. Very common in alcoholics but rarely seen with other forms of liver disease, an AST:ALT >= 2 can therefore be used as an important diagnostic marker. It is thought that this transaminase imbalance occurs in alcoholics secondary to a hepatic deficiency of pyridoxal-6-phosphate (a cofactor for ALT enzymatic activity). The absolute values of serum AST and ALT are almost always less than 500 IU/L in alcoholic liver disease. If higher transaminase values are present, concurrent hepatic injury secondary to viral hepatitis, ischemic hepatitis, or acetaminophen usage should be suspected.
(Choice A) Females are actually more susceptible than males to hepatic injury from alcohol ingestion. This is likely secondary to gender-related differences in the metabolism of alcohol. An alcohol intake of 60-80 mg/day in males and 20-40 mg/day in females is considered the threshold for developing severe alcoholic liver disease. Genetic predisposition also may play a role.
(Choice B) Steatosis (fatty liver) associated with alcohol ingestion is a potentially reversible condition and will completely resolve with abstinence from alcohol.
(Choice D) Fatty liver is present in 80-100% of binge or heavy drinkers. However, only 15-20% of alcoholics will develop alcoholic hepatitis, with 50% of those individuals going on to develop cirrhosis.
(Choice E) The histological transition between fatty liver and alcoholic hepatitis is subtle. Classically, however, the findings in alcoholic hepatitis include hepatic cell injury evidenced by the presence of ballooning degeneration, PMN cellular infiltration, fibrosis, and necrosis. Mallory bodies are often observed in severe cases, but are not specific for the diagnosis of alcoholic hepatitis.

question:
A 28-year-old woman presents to clinic with intermittent episodes of tremor, clumsy gait, and depression for the past three months. Her past medical history is insignificant, and she takes no medications. She admits to occasional alcohol use but denies smoking or illicit drug use. Physical examination is notable for rigidity and restriction of upward gaze. Laboratory studies reveal the following:
Liver studies
Total bilirubin 2.3 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 130 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 325 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 258 U/L
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 13.8 g/L
Erythrocyte count 5.2 mil/mm3
MCHC 35%
MCV 80 fl
Platelets 196,000/mm3
Leukocyte count 5,500/mm3
Hepatitis Panel
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBcAg Negative
Anti-HAV IgM Negative
Anti-HAV IgG Negative
Anti-HCV Negative
Anti-nuclear antibodies Negative
Anti-smooth muscle antibodies Negative
Anti-mitochondrial antibodies Negative
A liver biopsy reveals moderate inflammation, portal fibrosis, and hepatocyte necrosis. Macrovesicular steatosis, vacuolated hepatocellular nuclei, and Mallory bodies are also observed. Which of the following investigations would provide confirmation of the most likely diagnosis?
options: B. Serum iron and ferritin levels
E. Serum ceruloplasmin levels and slit lamp examination of eyes
explanation:
Wilson's disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disease of younger individuals that is characterized by abnormal copper deposition in tissues such as the liver, basal ganglia, and cornea. Children and adolescents tend to present with liver disease (ranging from asymptomatic aminotransferase elevations to fulminant hepatic failure), while young adults tend to demonstrate neuropsychiatric disease (ranging widely from tremor and rigidity to depression, paranoia, and catatonia).
Classically, the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is confirmed by the presence of low serum ceruloplasmin (particularly <=20 mg/dL) in conjunction with increased urinary copper excretion or Kayser-Fleischer rings. Therefore, evaluation of this patient should include measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels and slit lamp examination of the eyes to establish whether the Kayser-Fleischer rings are present.
(Choice A) The neurologic symptoms of Wilson's disease are secondary to copper deposition in the basal ganglia. Therefore, a CT scan of the brain would provide little useful information in establishing the diagnosis.
(Choice B) Serum iron and ferritin levels are of benefit in evaluating a patient for hemochromatosis. While hemochromatosis typically involves the liver, symptoms tend to develop after the age of 40 and the liver biopsy shows marked iron deposition. Moreover, the presence of such distinctive neuropsychiatric symptoms supports a diagnosis of Wilson's disease.
(Choice C) The presence of Mallory hyaline on the liver biopsy in this patient is a finding suggestive of alcohol liver injury. However Wilson's disease is also associated with Mallory hyaline. In addition, alcoholic hepatitis is rarely seen in young individuals who drink alcohol only occasionally. Moreover, the presence of such distinctive neuropsychiatric symptoms supports a diagnosis of Wilson's disease.
(Choice D) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is typically associated with emphysema and liver involvement at a young age. Liver biopsy will show hepatocytes containing granules that are PAS positive and diastase-resistant.

question: A 58-year-old Russian lady, who is known to have chronic pancreatitis, comes into your office for increasing pain, during the past month. The pain is dull, boring, located in the mid epigastrium, and radiating to the back. She is not able to work because of it. The pain is relieved by hydrocodone. She is also taking pancreatic enzymes and insulin for her diabetes mellitus. She is not taking any other drugs or alcohol, at present. On examination, she is weak and distressed. Her vitals are normal and her laboratory report shows normal glucose, amylase, lipase, WBC count, hemoglobin, and liver function tests. A CT scan shows pancreatic calcifications with a stone impacted in the main pancreatic duct with marked ductal dilatation. What would be the most appropriate next intervention in this patient?
options: A. Increase her dose of hydrocodone
C. Perform an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with removal of the stone and stent insertion
D. Increase her dose of pancreatic enzymes
explanation:
Chronic pancreatitis is a serious disease and often leads to severe disability. Surgical interventions in the case of chronic pancreatitis are indicated in case of chronic pseudocyst, debilitating pain or to treat other complications. This patient has severe debilitating pain affecting her work and daily life. She is an ideal candidate for ERCP and stone removal with stent insertion, which would relieve the pain in 80% of such patients(Choice C).
(Choice A) Patient is already on hydrocodone and you have just found a treatable cause for her pain. Increasing the dose of hydrocodone would only give symptomatic relief and would not address the stone impaction.
(Choice B) Partial or complete pancreatectomy is a last resort for severe and advanced cases and it has high rates of pancreatic insufficiency and diabetes.
(Choice D) Pancreatic enzymes have a role in relieving pain in chronic pancreatitis; they work by inhibiting the food induced feedback loops of pancreatic enzymes secretion. Their efficacy is variable and in the case under discussion we should treat the underlying cause.
(Choice E) Celiac plexus nerve block can be used to relieve pain in chronic pancreatitis patients with non-dilated ducts.

question:
A 41-year-old Asian Male presents to his primary care physician with a several day history of subjective fever, generalized pruritus, clay-colored stool, dark yellow urine, and peripheral edema. A review of his chart indicates he has lost 5 kg (11 lbs) in the past ten weeks. His medical history is significant for ulcerative colitis that was diagnosed four years ago. He reports having intermittent flare-ups with bloody diarrhea. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs but has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day since the age of 11. Physical examination reveals icteric sclerae. His liver margin is 4 centimeters below the costal margin at the right mid-clavicular line and the tip of his spleen is palpable. He has 2+ peripheral edema. Laboratory evaluation shows the following:
Liver studies:
Albumin 2.0g/dL
Total bilirubin 4.4 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 1310 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) 167 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) 155 L/L
Complete blood count:
Hemoglobin 12.5 g/L
MCV 86 fl
Platelets 260,000/mm3
Leukocyte count 8,100/mm3
Coagulation studies
Prothrombin time 13 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 29 sec
Hepatitis Panel
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBcAg Negative
Anti-HAV IgM Negative
Anti-HAV IgG Negative
Anti-HCV Negative
Anti-nuclear antibodies Negative
Anti-smooth muscle antibodies Negative
Anti-mitochondrial antibodies Negative
An ultrasound of the abdomen shows minimal ascites and focal dilatations in the biliary tree. Endoscopic retrograde pancreatography is performed, which demonstrates multiple dilatations of the biliary tree with a prominent stricture at the junction of the cystic duct and hepatic duct. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
options: B. Refer patient for liver transplantation
C. Order biopsy of the prominent stricture
explanation:
This patient's history is significant for ulcerative colitis and his laboratory workup is consistent with cholestatic liver disease. The presence of peripheral edema, minimal ascites, hypoproteinemia, and hepatosplenomegaly are characteristic of early cirrhosis of the liver. Cholestatic cirrhosis in the context of ulcerative colitis is highly suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). This patient's ultrasound and ERCP findings of multiple dilatations within the biliary tree also support a diagnosis of PSC.
Cholangiocarcinoma is a rare, often lethal malignancy that is a known complication of PSC, developing in 10-15% of all patients with the condition. Cholangiocarcinoma is especially common in smokers with concurrent ulcerative colitis (UC), as nearly 30% of all cholangiocarcinomas are diagnosed in patients suffering from both UC and PSC. One of the early manifestations of cholangiocarcinoma is severe stricturing within the biliary tree, which causes a cholangitis characterized by fever, jaundice, and leukocytosis. Because cholangiocarcinoma can occur in up to 20% of patients with a long history of PSC, any severe stricture of the biliary tree in a patient with PSC should be biopsied to rule out cholangiocarcinoma. Therefore, it would be most appropriate to biopsy the prominent stricture identified with ERCP before proceeding.
(Choice A) Prednisone and sulfasalazine are recommended treatments for ulcerative colitis flare-ups. However, this patient is not experiencing an acute flare-up of ulcerative colitis. His symptoms are instead suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis and, potentially, cholangiocarcinoma.
(Choice B) Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a chronic, progressive disease that may eventually necessitate liver transplantation. However, cholangiocarcinoma is a relative contraindication for liver transplantation because of concerns about recurrence of the malignancy. Therefore, cholangiocarcinoma must be ruled out before considering liver transplantation referral.
(Choice D) Ursodeoxycholic acid can be used in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis who have elevated hepatic enzymes. However its role in preventing the development of cirrhosis or cholangiocarcinoma or in delaying the need for liver transplant remains unclear.
(Choice E) A CT scan of the abdomen can detect intrahepatic tumors or liver atrophy, and can also evaluate the level of biliary obstruction. However, CT is limited in its ability to identify the extent or resectability of cholangiocarcinoma.

question: A 45-year-old male comes to the emergency room with the complaints of severe respiratory distress. His chest x-ray is consistent with bilateral hydrothorax. A thoracentesis is done and the pleural fluid analysis shows findings consistent with a cirrhotic hydrothorax. A therapeutic thoracentesis is performed, and he is started on spironolactone and furosemide. However, the hydrothorax recurs and patient's diuretic dose is increased to 120mg/day furosemide and 200mg/day spironolactone. A repeat therapeutic thoracocentesis is done but again it recurs after 3 days. What is the best intervention for this patient now?
options: A. Do a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS)
D. Increase the dose of his diuretics
E. Do repeated large volume thoracocentesis
explanation:
This patient has refractory hydrothorax as evident by recurrent hydrothorax even with maximal dose of diuretics. TIPS procedure is the treatment of choice for patients with refractory recurrent cirrhotic hydrothorax (Choice A). Studies have shown TIPS to be more effective than medical therapy and repeated large volume thoracocentesis (Choice E) in patients with cirrhotic hydrothorax. Some of the common indications for TIPS are:
1. Refractory cirrhotic hydrothorax
2. Refractory ascites (defined as diuretic resistant or diuretic refractory ascites)
3. Recurrent variceal bleed not controlled by other minimal invasive means
4. Patients waiting for liver transplantation and needing portocaval shunts
(Choice B) Pleurodesis is a choice for refractory pleural effusions secondary to malignancy but not for a hydrothorax secondary to cirrhosis.
(Choice C) An intercostal drainage is a choice for a hemothorax or pyothorax but not for a hydrothorax.
(Choice D) The patient is already on the maximal doses of diuretic indicated for cirrhotic ascites or hydrothorax. Also, further increasing the dose makes the toxicity from diuretics more likely.

question:
A 56-year-old Caucasian man comes to the physician's office because of jaundice. He does not report feeling unwell, apart from feeling a bit more tired than usual. He is currently sexually active with two different women, but uses condoms almost all the time. He does not report any recent foreign travel or infectious contacts. Physical examination is essentially unremarkable apart from the fact that the patient appears thin and icteric. Palpation of the abdomen reveals no tenderness or masses. Laboratory studies yield the following results:
CBC
Hb 10.0g/dL
Ht 30%
MCV 80
Platelet count 180,000/cmm
Leukocyte count 6,000/cmm
Segmented neutrophils 70%
Bands 1%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 8%
Serum
Total bilirubin 5.8 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 5.0 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 380 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 22 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 18 U/L
Abdominal CT scan reveals an irregular mass extending from the pancreas. Which of the following is a risk factor for this patient's condition?
explanation:
This patient's symptoms (e.g., fatigue, painless jaundice) and abdominal CT findings (i.e., mass extending from the head of the pancreas) are highly suggestive of pancreatic cancer. This condition is rare before the age of 45 but its incidence rises sharply thereafter. The incidence is greater in males than females, and is also higher in blacks. The main symptoms are jaundice and weight loss, but keep in mind that the presentation tends to vary with the location of the tumor. Tumors in the body or tail of the pancreas usually present with pain and weight loss as the chief symptoms. Tumors in the head of the pancreas typically present with steatorrhea, weight loss, and jaundice. The recent onset of diabetes mellitus, a history of recent but unexplained thrombophlebitis, or previous attacks of pancreatitis are occasionally noted. Risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer include: family history, chronic pancreatitis, smoking, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a diet high in fat.
(Choices B to E) Alcohol, low fat diets, gallstones, or exposure to vinyl chloride have not been proven as risk factors for pancreatic cancer.

question: A 38-year-old Hispanic woman presents to clinic complaining of a three-month history of menometrorrhagia and intermittent lower abdominal pain. Prior to this, her menses were light and predictably occurred every 28 days. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonogram of the abdomen and pelvis is ordered, which demonstrates several submucosal leiomyomas in the uterus as well as multiple gallstones. She denies any history of intolerance to fatty food or biliary colic. Her medical history is significant for psoriasis and a fracture of her right tibia incurred in a motor vehicle accident ten years ago. She takes no medications at this time and has no known drug allergies. Vital signs include temperature of 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure of 116/84 mm hg, pulse of 72/min, and respirations of 12/min. Her BMI is 26.4 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals no icterus or abdominal tenderness. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of her gallstones?
options: D. Recommend no treatment at this time
E. Recommend lithotripsy to fragment the gallstones
explanation:
This patient's menometrorrhagia is secondary to leiomyomas (uterine fibroids), and she denies any history of biliary colic or intolerance of fatty foods. Therefore, her gallstones would be classified as asymptomatic. Studies indicate that only 20% of patients with asymptomatic gallstones will eventually develop symptoms within 15 years. In contrast, 70% of those patients with symptomatic gallstones and a history of biliary colic will experience symptom recurrence within two years.
This disparity in long-term outlook dictates decisions in management. Traditionally, cholecystectomy is recommended only for those patients who have symptomatic gallstones and who are otherwise good surgical candidates. Patients with symptomatic gallstones who are not good surgical candidates should be medically managed instead. Those patients with asymptomatic gallstones should not undergo prophylactic cholecystectomy, as the benefits do not outweigh the risks. The only exceptions to this rule would be patients who are at increased risk for developing gallbladder carcinoma or gallstone complications (eg, morbidly obese individuals undergoing gastric bypass surgery, individuals who have porcelain gallbladders).
(Choice A) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure and is recommended for low-risk patients who have symptomatic gallstones or a propensity for gallstone complications (eg, acute cholecystitis, porcelain gallbladder).
(Choice B) Ursodeoxycholic acid is a medical treatment used to dissolve gallstones in individuals who are symptomatic but are poor surgical candidates.
(Choice C) Most patients prefer to avoid the open cholecystectomy, a procedure that cuts the rectus abdominis and results in longer hospital stays and convalescence. It can be used for low-risk patients who have symptomatic gallstones or a history of or likelihood for gallstone complications (eg, acute cholecystitis, porcelain gallbladder).
(Choice E) Extracorporeal shock-wave lithotripsy is an alternative to surgery for high-risk patients with symptomatic, small gallstones.

question:
A 32-year-old Jewish woman presents to clinic complaining that her "face has turned yellow over the last three days." She has no other concerns at this time. She began taking oral contraceptives two weeks ago. Her medical history is otherwise significant for acne vulgaris and dysmenorrhea. Laboratory evaluation reveals the following:
Liver studies:
Albumin 3.9 g/dL
Total bilirubin 4.5 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 61 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT) 32 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGPT) 30 U/L
Hepatitis Panel:
HBsAg Negative
Anti-HBsAg Positive
Anti-HBcAg Negative
Anti-HAV IgM Negative
Anti-HAV IgG Negative
Anti-HCV Negative
Liver biopsy is performed, which shows dark granular pigment in the hepatocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: E. Liver steatosis secondary to oral contraceptive usage
explanation:
Individuals with the rare Dubin-Johnson syndrome have predominantly conjugated chronic hyperbilirubinemia that is not associated with hemolysis. This benign condition is more common in Sephardic Jews but is found in all races and both men and women.
Clinically, icterus is evident, though the physical examination is typically otherwise normal. Most patients are asymptomatic, with some complaining of nonspecific issues (eg, fatigue, abdominal pain, weakness). The icterus may be so mild as to only became evident in the context of a trigger such as illness, pregnancy, or oral contraceptive usage. Routine laboratory testing is unremarkable, including the complete blood count and liver function profile. Serum bilirubin levels usually range from 2-5 mg/dL but can also be normal or extremely elevated (20-25 mg/dL) Offering additional insight is evaluation of urinary coproporphyrin. Individuals with Dubin-Johnson syndrome have normal amounts of total urinary coproporphyrin, but will have over 80% coproporphyrin I (versus normal individuals, who have a similar majority of coproporphyrin III).
Grossly, the liver is strikingly black. Histological features are normal, though a dense pigment composed of epinephrine metabolites within the lysosomes can be seen.
For the diagnosis of Dubin-Johnson syndrome to be made, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with a direct bilirubin fraction of at least 50% and an otherwise normal liver function profile must be present. Confirmation can be obtained by evaluating the urinary coproporphyrin for unusually high levels of coproporphyrin I.
Because Dubin-Johnson is a benign condition, no treatment is required and the prognosis is excellent.
(Choice A) Rotor syndrome is a benign condition in which there is a defect of hepatic storage of conjugated bilirubin, resulting in its leakage into the plasma. Chronic and mild hyperbilirubinemia of both the unconjugated and conjugated forms then develops, without any suggestion of hemolysis. Liver function tests are normal. Pigmented granules are not seen in the hepatocytes of individuals with Rotor syndrome.
(Choice B) Gilbert's syndrome occurs in patients with no apparent liver disease who have mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia thought to be provoked by one of the classic triggers (eg, fasting, stress, illness).
(Choice C) Crigler-Najjar syndrome is divided into types 1 and 2, with the former a severe form that often results in permanent neurologic impairment or death. Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a very rare, autosomal recessive disease characterized by significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Phototherapy or plasmapheresis are typically helpful in the short term with liver transplant the only curative option.
(Choice E) Liver steatosis can occur with oral contraceptives, but would also be associated with abnormal hepatic enzymes and a history of long-term OCP usage. This patient was only using OCPs for two weeks before symptom onset.

question: A 42-year-old male comes with extensive third-degree burns. He is hospitalized and started on intra-venous fluids and antibiotics. However, on the third day he complains of severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain, vomiting and fever. His laboratory reports show WBC: 16,000/cmm and total bilirubin: 1.8 mg/dl. An ultrasonogram of the abdomen shows a dilated gallbladder with thickening of its wall but no gallstones. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation:
Acute acalculous cholecystitis is an acute inflammation of the gallbladder in the absence of gallstones (Choice A). It is most commonly seen in hospitalized patients in the following conditions:
1. Extensive burns
2. Severe trauma
3. Prolonged TPN.
4. Prolonged fasting
5. Mechanical ventilation.
Involved pathophysiology is localized or generalized ischemia, biliary stasis, infection, or external compression of the cystic duct. It generally presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain with fever, leukocytosis, and abnormal liver function tests. It can lead to complications like gangrene, perforation, and emphysematous cholecystitis. The initial investigation of choice is an ultrasonogram, which shows signs of acute cholecystitis and no gallstones; however, CT scan and HIDA scans are more sensitive and specific for the diagnosis. It is important to have a high degree of suspicion in high-risk patients in order to correctly identify this problem.
(Choice B) Patients with chronic cholecystitis will generally show a small fibrosed gall bladder on the ultrasonogram.
(Choice C) Acute pancreatitis can occur secondary to burns but it will not cause right upper quadrant abdominal pain with this kind of ultrasonographic findings.
(Choice D) This patient has localized inflammation in the gallbladder, which is responsible for the acute symptoms.
(Choice E) Bile peritonitis is a grave condition, which will be characterized by severe abdominal pain with rigidity and the ultrasonogram will show free fluid in the abdomen.

question:
A 59-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of progressive nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain that developed five days ago. His wife accompanies him and adds that he has been sleeping poorly and behaving in a disoriented and confused manner over the past three days. He was previously diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia, gout, and tension headaches. The patient's last significant headache was one week ago, and he took ten 500 mg acetaminophen tablets at the time for relief. He does not smoke cigarettes but his wife notes that he drinks 3-4 whiskey shots each night. He has no known drug allergies. Physical examination reveals tender hepatomegaly. No stigmata of chronic liver disease are seen. There is no ascites or edema. Asterixis is present. Laboratory evaluation reveals the following:
Liver studies:
Albumin 3.2 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 6.7 mg/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT) 6245 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGPT) 7116 U/L
Coagulation studies:
Prothrombin time 28 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 43 sec
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation:
This patient's acute onset jaundice and marked aminotransferase elevation are suggestive of severe hepatocyte injury. His prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are significantly prolonged, suggesting his liver is unable to synthesize clotting factors. Lastly, the presence of asterixis and the complaints of confusion and changes in sleep pattern are suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. This patient's presentation is therefore consistent with a diagnosis of fulminant hepatic failure, which is defined as hepatic encephalopathy that develops within eight weeks of the onset of acute liver failure. Coagulopathy is always present. Subfulminant hepatic failure is characterized by similar findings that develop between eight weeks and six months after the onset of acute liver failure.
Fulminant hepatic failure from acetaminophen toxicity has the most favorable prognosis, with mortality rates below 50%. The mortality rate in fulminant hepatitis with severe encephalopathy, however, approaches 80%. Adverse prognostic factors in cases of acetaminophen toxicity include acidosis (pH < 7.3), INR >= 6.5, azotemia (serum creatinine >= 3.4 mg/dL), hyperphosphatemia (>= 1.2 mmol/L), and an increased blood lactate level (>= 3.5 mmol/L).
Treatment of acute hepatic failure focuses on correcting metabolic abnormalities such as coagulation defects, electrolyte and acid-base disturbances, renal failure, hypoglycemia, and encephalopathy. Acetylcysteine should be administered promptly in cases of acetaminophen toxicity and will improve cerebral blood flow and oxygenation. Mannitol can be used if cerebral edema is present. Emergency liver transplantation may prove necessary and is associated with a 5-year survival rate of 70%.
(Choice A) Acute alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by acute onset right upper quadrant pain with fever and AST/ALT >= 2. An increase in the PT will not be observed unless liver failure from another cause is also present. The absolute values of serum AST and ALT are almost always less than 500 IU/L. Higher concentrations should raise the suspicion of concurrent liver injury from other sources (eg, drugs, ischemia).
(Choice B) Acute hepatic failure is defined as the development of liver failure within eight weeks of hepatocellular injury onset. If hepatic encephalopathy is also seen (as in this patient), then the syndrome is described as fulminant hepatic failure.
(Choice D) While this patient is a chronic alcoholic, there is no evidence of cirrhotic stigma on physical examination. Moreover, cirrhosis is associated with a slow and insidious onset.
(Choice E) Wilson's disease can cause fulminant hepatitis, but neuropsychiatric symptoms (such as Parkinsonian-like tremor or depression) are seen instead of asterixis and grossly elevated aminotransferases. Moreover, this older patient has no findings on history or physical examination that are suggestive of Wilson's disease.

question: A 51-year-old Asian male with a history of chronic liver disease secondary to hepatitis C infection presents complaining of abdominal distention. He also admits to intermittent low-grade fevers, weakness, and weight loss of 17.6 lbs (8 kg) over the past two months. He admits exposure to several tuberculosis patients when he was in INDIA. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Physical examination reveals tender enlargement of the liver. Normal heart sounds are present and the chest is clear to auscultation and percussion. There is no evidence of jaundice or scleral icterus. A paracentesis demonstrates bloody fluid with no bacteria present on Gram stain. Laboratory evaluation includes an alkaline phosphatase of 180 IU/L and an alpha-fetoprotein of 550 ng/mL (normal is 0-15 ng/mL). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: D. Metastatic carcinoma of the liver
explanation:
This patient's presentation with chronic hepatitis C infection, hemorrhagic ascites, and an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level is strongly suggestive of hepatocellular carcinoma.
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a malignant neoplasm that arises from the parenchymal cells of the liver. Cirrhosis is present in 80% of cases. In Western countries and Japan, chronic hepatitis C infection and alcoholic cirrhosis are the major risk factors for the development of HCC. In Africa and much of Asia, however, hepatitis B infection plays a more prominent role in the development of HCC. Other known associations with HCC include hemochromatosis, aflatoxin exposure, a1-antitrypsin deficiency, and tyrosinemia.
Laboratory evaluation of the patient with HCC typically demonstrates a sudden and sustained elevation of alkaline phosphatase and a marked elevation in alpha-fetoprotein (typically above 500 ng/mL). The abrupt appearance of ascites (which may be blood-tinged) suggests that the tumor is bleeding or has caused thrombosis of the portal or hepatic veins. Helical CT scanning and MRI with contrast are the preferred means of imaging HCC, with liver biopsy being diagnostic. Surgical resection may result in cure, though liver transplantation is preferable in some circumstances. In the United States, the overall 5-year survival rate for patients with HCC is only 5%.
(Choice A) Patients with cirrhosis of the liver can develop ascites secondary to portal hypertension. The ascites is always non-bloody and has a SAAG >= 1.1.
(Choice C) Tuberculosis can cause hemorrhagic ascites, but the ascitic fluid generally also contains acid-fast bacilli. Systemic symptoms like weight loss and low-grade fever are common. Alpha-fetoprotein levels are not elevated. Serum AFP levels greater than 500 mcg/L in a high-risk patient is diagnostic of hepatocellular carcinoma.
(Choice D) Metastatic carcinoma to the liver is the most common hepatic malignancy and is generally secondary to gastrointestinal cancer. It is much less likely in the context of chronic hepatitis C infection, however.
(Choice E) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is thought to occur in 20-30% of patients with cirrhosis. The condition is characterized by fever and ascitic fluid that contains a single organism, PMN >= 250/L, and no blood.

question: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic alcoholism presents to clinic complaining of "a swollen belly and puffy feet" that began some time ago. He has not been seen by a physician for several years, but says that he was previously diagnosed with depression and peptic ulcer disease. He takes no medications. He is currently living alone and is unemployed. He admits to drinking 6-12 beers per night, depending on what he can afford. He has a remote history of cigarette smoking. Physical examination reveals bilateral gynecomastia and spider angiomas on his upper extremities. Caput medusae are noted on his abdomen. Percussion of the abdomen demonstrates shifting dullness. There is no evidence of asterixis. There is pitting edema of the lower extremities. Which of the following physical findings has the same pathogenesis as gynecomastia?
explanation:
This patient has numerous cirrhotic stigmata that are suggestive of alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver. Cirrhosis of any type leads to progressive loss of liver functionality. Liver functions can be divided into three distinct categories: synthetic (synthesis of clotting factors, cholesterol, and proteins); metabolic (metabolism of drugs and steroids, including detoxification); and excretory (bile excretion).
In the cirrhotic patient, gynecomastia arises from hyperestrogenism secondary to the damaged liver's inability to metabolize circulating estrogens. Other manifestations of hyperestrogenism in the cirrhotic patient include palmar erythema, spider angiomas, and testicular atrophy and decreased body hair in males.
(Choice A) Caput medusae arise from the dilatation of superficial veins on the anterior abdominal wall secondary to portal hypertension. Portal hypertension results from increased resistance to portal flow at the sinusoids and leads to increased pressure at the portosystemic collateral veins in the anterior abdomen, lower rectum, and the lower end of esophagus where the portal and systemic circulations meet. This phenomenon is responsible for the esophageal varices, hemorrhoids, and caput medusae commonly seen in cirrhotic patients.
(Choice B) The pathogenesis of cirrhotic ascites is complex and includes sinusoidal hypertension, the seepage of hepatic lymph into the peritoneal cavity, leakage of intestinal fluid, and renal retention of sodium and water.
(Choice C) Asterixis is a neurologic sign associated with poor hepatic function and hyperammonemia. In the healthy liver, ammonia is detoxified to urea, which is then excreted in the urine. Because the cirrhotic liver has lost this function, ammonia is allowed to accumulate in the blood. Impaired neuronal function and cerebral edema are associated with hyperammonemia.
(Choice E) The liver is the primary site of protein synthesis, and the cirrhotic liver typically produces insufficient amounts of important proteins such as albumin. Hypoalbuminemia leads to a decrease in the intravascular oncotic pressure. Fluid then moves into the extravascular space, and pitting edema in the lower extremities (eg, pedal edema) results.

question: A 42-year-old alcoholic Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset severe abdominal pain and several episodes of vomiting. His friend accompanies him and says that they were binge drinking last night while watching a football game on television. The patient rates his pain as 9/10 in severity and says that it radiates to his back. He has never experienced these symptoms before and has an otherwise unremarkable medical history. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.7 C (99.9 F), blood pressure of 112/70 mm Hg, pulse of 102/min, and respirations of 16/min. Physical examination demonstrates epigastric tenderness to palpation but no rigidity. Bowel sounds are absent. There is no evidence of hematemesis and a guaiac smear is negative. Preliminary laboratory findings include a normal hemoglobin and leukocytosis. A chest radiograph and electrocardiogram are normal. Which of the following investigations should be ordered next to confirm the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation:
This patient has an acute abdomen. Given his recent binge drinking, severe epigastric pain radiating to his back, and leukocytosis, a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis would be most likely. Other medical and surgical causes of acute abdomen are lower on the differential based on the test results thus far. For instance, peptic ulcers and gastritis are typically associated with gastrointestinal bleeding; perforation of the stomach or bowel is usually signaled by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on chest radiograph; pneumonia is rarely present in patients with normal chest radiographs; and myocardial ischemia is usually identifiable by electrocardiogram.
Evaluation of all cases of suspected pancreatitis should include measurement of the serum amylase and lipase levels. Early in the course of acute pancreatitis, there is a dysfunction in the synthesis-secretion relationship of pancreatic digestive enzymes in which synthesis continues despite a blockade in secretion. The result is a leakage of digestive enzymes from acinar cells into the interstitial space and, ultimately, the systemic circulation.
Serum amylase is the most commonly ordered test in the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. It rises within 6-12 hours of symptom onset and may remain elevated for 3-5 days, with values often three times the upper limit of normal. Serum lipase has a sensitivity of 85-100% and is more specific than serum amylase. Both tests are considered nonspecific overall, however, because hyperamylasemia and hyperlipasemia are associated with a variety of nonpancreatic diseases.
(Choice A) The classic ultrasound finding in a patient with pancreatitis is a diffusely enlarged, hypoechoic pancreas. Because bowel gas obscures the pancreas in 25-35% of patients, however, ultrasound is not considered a reliable means for identifying pancreatitis. It is primarily used in diagnosing gallbladder disease instead.
(Choice C) Serum troponin I is a preferred marker for the diagnosis of myocardial injury as it is more specific than other cardiac enzymes (eg, creatinine kinase). However, since the electrocardiogram findings and patient presentation are not consistent with myocardial infarction, the testing of cardiac enzymes is likely to be of less diagnostic value at this point.
(Choice D) Endoscopic retrograde pancreatography (ERCP) is an excellent diagnostic and therapeutic tool in the evaluation of chronic pancreatitis or common bile duct pathology.
(Choice E) Abdominal CT scan is the most valuable imaging test in the identification of the presence, severity, and complications of pancreatitis. Those patients with clinical and biochemical findings suggestive of pancreatitis who fail to improve with conservative treatment should undergo abdominal CT scan to search for areas of infection or necrosis. Since this patient has just presented and has not yet been fully worked up with serum amylase and lipase levels, however, an abdominal CT scan would be premature.

question:
A 85-year-old homeless Caucasian male with a history of hepatic cirrhosis is brought to the emergency department in a semicomatose state. A friend accompanies him and says that the patient "got dehydrated from being out in the sun all day yesterday and today." The patient has had two episodes of hematemesis in the past and is currently on propanolol. He has been an alcoholic for the past thirty years and typically drinks one bottle of wine per day. Physical examination reveals decerebrate posturing, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes, and free fluid in the abdomen. His mucous membranes are dry and his exhalations have a sweet, musty smell. Laboratory evaluation includes the following:
Prothrombin time 18 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 43 sec
Total proteins, serum 4.8 g/dL
Ammonia, plasma 104 pmol/L (normal 21-50 pmol/L)
Intravenous fluids are started to correct the patient's dehydration. What additional treatment is most appropriate?
explanation:
Hepatic encephalopathy is a reversible decline in neurologic function that is precipitated by hepatic damage. The pathogenesis of this condition is likely related to increased levels of ammonia in circulation, which causes inhibitory neurotransmission via the GABA receptors in the central nervous system. The initial management of hepatic encephalopathy should be based on two principles: correction of any precipitating factors and the lowering of blood ammonia concentration. Common precipitating factors include hypovolemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, hypoxia, sedative usage, hypoglycemia, infection, and rarely hepatic vascular occlusion. Lowering of the blood ammonia level is accomplished with continuous administration of a disaccharide such as lactulose or lactitol. Bacterial action on the lactulose results in acidification of colonic contents, which converts the absorbable ammonia into nonabsorbable ammonium ion (an ammonia trap). The majority of patients will respond to the disaccharides, but those who do not can be placed on ornithine-aspartate infusion or oral sodium benzoate. A further alternative for disaccharide non-responders is the addition of neomycin, a nonabsorbable antibiotic that destroys ammonia-producing colonic bacteria, to the regimen. However, neomycin long-term use is limited by its ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity. Protein intake can be reduced but should not be significantly limited, as a drastic reduction could lead to a negative nitrogen balance
(Choice A) Protein-free diets are not appropriate in patients with hepatic encephalopathy because of concerns about the development of a negative nitrogen balance. Protein intake can be limited to less than 70 g/day, however. Implementing a glucose-free diet is also inadvisable, as patients actually require high-glucose diets.
(Choice B) Branched-chain amino acids should be added to a low-protein diet in patients who appear severely intolerant to protein. When given alone, however, these amino acids are insufficient in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy.
(Choice C) Liver transplantation may prove eventually necessary to correct this patient's underlying hepatic disease. However, transplantation is always a time-consuming process and therefore would be entirely inappropriate for the immediate management of acute hepatic encephalopathy, a condition that has a high mortality rate when untreated.
(Choice E) Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) allows for the creation of a low-resistance channel that bridges the hepatic vein and the intrahepatic segment of the portal vein. This procedure is used to treat the consequences of portal hypertension (namely, variceal hemorrhage and ascites), not hepatic encephalopathy. Infact, one of the known complications of the TIPS procedure is a portosystemic encephalopathy that occurs in 30% of all patients.

question: A 59-year-old Caucasian male presents to his primary care physician complaining of chronic fatigue of insidious onset that is limiting his ability to function as a business executive. He considers himself to normally be "in excellent health " which he attributes to his well-balanced diet and a strict exercise regimen that he recently had to curtail. He is very disturbed by this change in stamina and asks for a thorough medical examination. His past medical history is insignificant except for a motor vehicle accident in 1982 that resulted in a laceration of his spleen. The resultant heavy bleeding required that he be given four units of blood products. The patient lives with his wife and two college-age children. He denies any history of sexual contact with partners outside of his marriage. An extensive work-up for his fatigue is undertaken and he is diagnosed with anemia secondary to diverticular disease. An appropriate treatment plan is developed to address these conditions. Which of the following screening tests should also be performed at this time?
options: B. Hepatitis B and C screening
explanation:
The human immunodeficiency virus, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus all have the potential to be transmitted by blood transfusion. Due to thorough screening of donor blood today, however, blood transfusions are no longer considered a significant risk factor for contracting HIV or hepatitis B or C. As of 2002, the estimated risk of infection per unit of blood was <= 1:540,000 for HCV, approximately 1:140,000 for HBV, and approximately 1:1,900,000 for HIV. The screening of blood for anti-HBcAg was introduced in 1986 and the more sensitive immune assays for hepatitis C were introduced in 1992. Therefore, all patients who received blood transfusions before these dates should be screened for hepatitis B and C.
(Choice A) HIV screening is less important in this patient because HIV was a very unusual disease in 1982. Even if HIV had been present in the transfused units, its infectivity would be significantly less than that of HBV or HCV. Moreover, this patient reports no symptoms over the past twenty years that might suggest HIV infection.
(Choice C) In general, individuals who should be screened for hepatitis C virus include: 1) IV drug abusers; 2) persons receiving blood transfusions or organ transplants before July 1992; 3) hemodialysis patients: 4) persons with chronically elevated ALT values; 5) children born to HCV-positive mothers; 6) health care workers who have suffered needle stick injury or mucosal exposure to HCV-positive blood: and 7) persons who received blood transfusions from an individual who later seroconverted to HCV-positive.
(Choice D) In general, individuals who should be screened for hepatitis B virus include: 1) individuals born in hyperendemic areas (Africa, Southeast Asia, Middle East, Pacific islands, Amazon River basin, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic), 2) men who have sex with men; 3) IV drug abusers; 4) dialysis patients; 5) HIV-positive individuals; 6) pregnant women; and 7) contacts (family, household, or sexual) of HBV-infected individuals.
(Choice E) Hepatitis A can be transmitted by infected blood (although the fecal-oral route is more common). However, HAV would have caused symptoms at the time of transmission, as it does not have a chronic stage.

question:
A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of diabetes mellitus and coronary artery disease (status post triple vessel coronary artery bypass surgery five years ago) undergoes a left hemicolectomy for ischemic bowel disease. On post-operative day 4, he complains of new-onset abdominal discomfort. Over the past 12 hours, he has passed 200 mL of pink urine. Laboratory findings are as follows:
Hemoglobin 12.5 mg/dL
WBC count 8,700/mm3
Platelet count 170,000/mm3
Sodium 130 mEq/L
Potassium 5.0 mEq/L
Calcium 9.6 mg/dL
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 21 mEq/L
BUN 80 mg/dL
Creatinine 4.2 mg/dL
Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation:
This patient is experiencing acute renal failure (ARF), given his acute oliguria (<=250 cc urine in 12 hours), azotemia (rise in BUN), and increased serum creatinine. ARF may be pre-renal, post-renal, or intrinsic renal in etiology. Post-operative urinary retention is common after lower abdominal and/or pelvic surgery in males over age 50, due in part to the frequency of BPH in this population, and is likely the post-renal cause of ARF here. Bladder distention from such an obstruction would explain this patient's new abdominal pain. For distal obstructions, foley catheterization (Choice B) can restore normal urine output, and is essential for the resolution/prevention of hydronephrosis, tubular atrophy, and renal injury. If catheterization does not relieve the patient's oliguria, then alternative ARF etiologies (i.e. intrinsic, pre-renal) must be considered. Pre-renal causes of ARF include volume depletion, decreased cardiac output, and systemic vasodilation; patients present with BUN/Cr ratios >=20. Intrinsic causes include damage to the renal vasculature, glomeruli, tubules, or interstitium.
(Choices A & G) Urine sediment analysis is helpful in differentiating pre-renal and intrinsic renal failure. In acute tubular necrosis (ATN), muddy brown casts are present. Urine eosinophils suggest acute interstitial nephritis. Pyelonephritis, as suggested by a positive urine culture, would be unlikely to cause renal failure unless complicated by hypotension leading to ATN.
(Choice C) Urgent hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidemia, hyperkalemia, volume overload, or uremic encephalopathy.
(Choice D) IV fluids are critical in the treatment of pre-renal ARF caused by hypovolemia. In post-renal obstruction, however, administration of IV fluids without first placing a catheter would exacerbate strain on the kidneys.
(Choice E) In an adequately hydrated patient with recent-onset oliguria due to pre-renal or certain intrinsic renal causes, an IV loop diuretic may be appropriate to avoid volume overload.
(Choice F) If a normal urine output is not restored by foley catheterization, then obstruction at or proximal to the bladder (e.g. bilateral ureteral obstruction) must be ruled out. Such conditions can be diagnosed by abdominal ultrasound.
