Peritoneal fluid can accumulate due to a number of different causes including portal hypertension, trauma, infection, pancreatitis, and malignancy. To distinguish among these, it is important to differentiate transudative from exudative fluid accumulations. This is done using the serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG). The SAAG is calculated by subtracting the ascites albumin concentration from the serum albumin concentration. A difference of 1.1 g/dl or greater is 95% accurate in diagnosing a transudative process consistent with portal hypertension. This patient's SAAG of 1.3 is diagnostic of portal hypertension, or increased hydrostatic pressure within the liver's capillary beds.
(Choice A) Decreased liver synthetic function will cause a decrease in serum albumin concentration and an increase in INR. Hypoalbuminemia may contribute to edema in end stage liver disease but is not responsible for SAAGs of 1.1 or greater.
(Choice B) Increased capillary permeability is the mechanism by which exudative ascites forms. This patient's SAAG of 1.3 is not consistent with exudative ascites.
(Choice D) Increased glomerular filtration pressure will increase the glomerular filtration rate and decrease the serum creatinine concentration. It will not cause ascites.
(Choice E) Although primary hyperaldosteronism causes sodium and water retention it typically does not cause edema due to spontaneous diuresis (aldosterone escape phenomena).
Educational objective:
The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is used to distinguish between portal hypertension and other causes of ascites. A SAAG of 1.1 g/dL or greater is consistent with portal hypertension.

Liver biopsy shows Mallory's hyaline and a neutrophilic infiltrate without evidence of fibrosis. The patient is
treated with thiamine and chlardiazepoxide, and his condition improves over the next few days. He agrees to
cut down on his smoking and give up alcohol completely. Which of the following statements is most
appropriate?
options: A. The patient's condition is completely reversible with the cessation of alcohol intake.

B. The patient's condition will nat progress, but will also not improve with the cessation of alcohol
intake.
C. The patient's condition will continue to decline even with the cessation of alcohol intake.
D. The patient's ~andition ie nat doe ta hie aleabinl intake
explanation:
This patient has signs of alcoholic liver disease. His history (i.e., heavy alcohol use), physical findings (e.g, hepatomegaly; remember that the normal liver span is 6-12 cm in the midclavicular line), and laboratory findings (i.e, elevated MCV, AST to ALT ratio of 2:1) are all consistent with the disease.
Having established the patient's diagnosis, the next step to answering this question is interpreting the pathology report from the liver biopsy. The three major pathological stages of alcoholic liver disease are: 1) Fatty liver (steatosis) 2) Alcoholic hepatitis and 3) Alcoholic fibrosis/cirrhosis. Fatty liver is the result of short term alcohol ingestion, whereas hepatitis and cirrhosis require long term, sustained alcohol use. Alcohol hepatitis is characterized by Mallory bodies, infiltration by neutrophils, liver cell necrosis, and a perivenular distribution of inflammation. Fatty liver, alcohol hepatitis, and even early fibrosis can all be potentially reversible if the patient stops alcohol ingestion.
This patient's biopsy describes the classic features of alcoholic hepatitis; therefore, the correct answer is that his condition can be completely reversible with the cessation of alcohol intake.
(Choice C) True cirrhosis is characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules. This condition is irreversible, even with the cessation of alcohol intake.
(Choice D) Even though the patient gives a clear history of alcohol use, it is important to consider other causes of hepatitis such as viral hepatitis; however, the viral serologies are all negative.
Educational Objective:
Fatty liver (steatosis), alcoholic hepatitis and early fibrosis of the liver can be reversible with the cessation of alcohol intake. True cirrhosis (with regenerative nodules) is irreversible, regardless of alcohol abstinence.

question:
A 27-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician complaining of significant malaise,
anarexia, and nausea far the past few weeks, which has limited her ability to work as a waitress. Further
inquiry reveals that she has also noticed her urine to be very dark yellow and that her boyfriend believes she
is "more moody than normal." She has no history of medical problems, takes no medications, and has no
known drug allergies. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past eight years and drinks one
to two beers daily. Physical examination reveals yellow sclera, spider nevi an her upper torso, rigidity, and
tremor at rest. Slit-lamp examination demanstrates greenish brown deposits around both corneas. Palpation
af the abdomen reveals the liver to be enlarged with an irregular edge. Labaratory wark-up returns with the
following results:
Liver studies
Total bilirubin                                          4.5 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin                                         3.2 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase                                  40 iL

Wilson's disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disease most often identified in younger individuals aged 5 to 40 years. The genetic mutations associated with Wilson's disease hinder copper metabolism by reducing the formation and secretion of ceruloplasmin and by decreasing the secretion of copper into the biliary system.
Copper is a pro-oxidant, and as it accumulates in greater quantities within the liver, it causes damage to the hepatic tissue through the generation of free radicals. Eventually copper leaks from injured hepatocytes into the blood to be deposited in various tissues, including the basal ganglia (hepatolenticular degeneration) and cornea.

Neuropsychiatric symptoms can include Parkinsonian-like tremor, rigidity, ataxia, slurred speech, drooling, personality changes, depression, paranoia, and catatonia. Wilson's disease is also associated with Fanconi syndrome, hemolytic anemia, and neuropathy. More commonly, diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of low serum ceruloplasmin (particularly <20 mg/dL) in conjunction with increased urinary copper excretion or Kayser-Fleischer rings.

First-line medications include copper chelators like d-penicillamine or trientine. Oral zinc is also recommended as it prevents copper absorption. Wilson's disease is the likely diagnosis in a patient younger than 30 years old with unexplained chronic hepatitis. The presence of low serum ceruloplasmin and increased urinary copper excretion or Kayser-Fleischer rings confirms the diagnosis.

manths. He rarely drinks alcohol and does not use illicit drugs, though he has smoked ane pack of cigarettes
per day for the past 40 years. He has previously been diagnosed with hypertension, diverticulasis, external
hemorrhoids, and osteoarthritis. His current medications are atenolol and aspirin, and he has no known drug
allergies. Vital signs include temperature of 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure of 132/88 mm Hg, pulse of
70/min, and respirations of 12/min. Physical examination reveals a soft abdomen that is mildly tender to deep
palpation in the mid-epigastric region. The sclerae are icteric and his skin is jaundiced. Laboratory evaluation
returns with the following:

Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are negative. An abdominal ultrasound demonstrates mild dilation of the
common bile duct. There are no stones present in the gallbladder and no evidence of gallbladder wall
thickening. What is the next best step in the management of this patient's condition?
explanation:
In the United States, pancreatic cancer is the fourth leading cause of cancer-related death. It typically presents late and has a poor prognosis, even in those with a potentially resectable mass. The five-year survival rate ranges from 10-30%, depending on nodal status. Incidence is higher in men and in blacks, with the disease developing most often after the age of 45. Major risk factors include chronic pancreatitis, smoking, diabetes mellitus, and hereditary predisposition.
Pancreatic carcinoma most commonly presents with a dull upper abdominal pain that radiates to the back, weight loss, or jaundice. Those tumors located in the pancreatic body or tail are most likely to present with an abdominal mass or ascites present in only 20% of patients with pancreatic cancer. Classic findings include a nontender but palpable gallbladder at the right costal margin in a jaundiced patient (Courvoisier sign) or left supraclavicular adenopathy (Virchow’s node) in a patient with metastatic disease.
Laboratory evaluation of those with pancreatic cancer typically demonstrates increased serum bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase in conjunction with a mild anemia.
Abdominal ultrasound is usually the initial imaging performed on patients with jaundice. When the ultrasound is nondiagnostic (as in this case), the next step is to obtain an abdominal CT scan. This imaging modality has a sensitivity and specificity of 85-90% and 90-95% respectively, for the imaging of pancreatic cancer. Commonly, CT scan is effective in detecting bile and pancreatic duct dilation, mass lesions within the pancreas, and indications of extrahepatic spread (eg, metastases or ascites).
(Choice B) Endoscopic retrograde pancreatography (ERCP) is an excellent tool in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, with a sensitivity and specificity of 90-95%. Because it is an invasive procedure, however, it is most commonly reserved for those patients who have already undergone a nondiagnostic ultrasound and a nondiagnostic CT scan.
(Choice C) Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC) is an invasive procedure in which a needle is inserted into a dilated bile duct and contrast material is injected for bile duct opacification. PTC is used in the evaluation of patients who have previously identified biliary tract dilation but are not candidates for ERCP. PTC also allows for certain therapeutic interventions, including the drainage of infected bile (in patients with cholangitis), extraction of stones in the biliary tract, dilation of benign biliary strictures, or stent placement across malignant strictures.
(Choice D) Serum amylase and lipase are appropriate to obtain in patients with suspected pancreatitis. They are not helpful in diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma.
(Choice E) The most commonly used tumor marker for pancreatic cancer is the cancer associated antigen (CA) 19-9, which has a sensitivity and specificity of 80-80%. CA 19-3 can be elevated in patients with jaundice but no pancreatic cancer, however, which reduces its utility as a screening tool. Postoperative monitoring of pancreatic cancer with CA 199 may be helpful in evaluating the tumor response to chemotherapy.
Educational Objective:
Abdominal CT scan is a very sensitive and specific tool used in the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma.

question:
A 52-year-old male comes to your office complaining of inability to achieve erection over the last year. He
nates a recent unintended weight loss of about fifteen pounds over the past several months as well. Physical
examination reveals right-sided gynecomastia. His testes are firm and small. Laboratory testing shows
decreased levels of TSH, T4 and T3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient has signs and symptoms of chronic liver disease including weight loss, gynecomastia, testicular atrophy and impotence. The latter three symptoms are caused by the hyperestrogenemia that occurs in chronic liver disease, as estrogens are not adequately cleared from the blood due to increased portosystemic shunting and decreased synthesis of sex hormone binding globulin. Other findings in cirrhosis that are the result of estrogen excess include telangiectasias and palmar erythema. The decreases in TSH, T4 and T3 suggest hypothyroidism due to primary failure of the pituitary to appropriately secrete TSH in response to law T4 levels. Hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction can occur in patients with cirrhosis.
(Choice A) Hashimoto disease is an autoimmune thyroiditis wherein lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid leads to hypothyroidism. Laboratory studies show an elevated TSH, decreased T4 and presence of anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies.
(Choice C) Adrenal insufficiency may be associated with weight loss, anxiety and decreased body hair among other symptoms. Autoimmune adrenal insufficiency may occur in association with autoimmune thyroiditis and testicular failure, but in this setting both the testes and the adrenal would be destroyed. Without a major source of estrogens, clinical hyperestrogenism would be unlikely.
(Choice D) Increased thyroxine consumption would most likely be accompanied by a decreased TSH and high T4.
(Choice E) Pancreatic insufficiency would lead to malabsorption due to exocrine dysfunction and diabetes if endocrine function was also impaired.
Educational objective:
Chronic liver disease causes hyperestrogenism as a result of decreased clearance of estrogen from the blood by the liver due to increased portosystemic shunting. Additionally, decreased sex hormone binding globulin synthesis by the diseased liver increases the ability of circulating estrogen to exert its biologic effects. Symptoms of hyperestrogenemia include telangiectasias, palmar erythema, testicular atrophy, gynecomastia and impotence.

explanation:
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) is a functional disorder of bile formation that develops in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. The condition is characterized by intense pruritus and increased serum bile acid concentrations. Incidence ranges from 0.2-4% and is highest among those individuals from Bolivia or Chile. The etiology is unclear, but it is thought that genetic and hormonal factors (eg, higher levels of estrogen or progesterone) influence the development of ICP.
Clinical manifestations of ICP include intense, often intolerable generalized pruritus that is especially significant on the palms and soles and worsens at night. Evidence of skin excoriations may be present.
Treatment is based upon symptom relief and preventing complications in the mother and fetus. Ursodeoxycholic acid is most promising, as it increases bile flow and can relieve pruritus. Hydroxyzine and cholestyramine are alternative therapies, though they appear to be less effective and can have concerning side effects.
The maternal prognosis of those with ICP is good, as the condition resolves shortly after delivery. There are no hepatic sequelae. ICP may recur in subsequent pregnancies, and affected women are also at increased risk of developing gallstones.
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy poses more danger to the fetus than to the mother, as fetal prematurity, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, and intrauterine demise are all known complications. Therefore, the preferred approach in managing the pregnancies of women with ICP includes an early delivery once fetal lung maturity is established.
(Choice A) Normal physiological changes of pregnancy include a mild elevation of alkaline phosphatase (due to placental secretion of the enzyme) but normal bilirubin, aminotransferases, and GGT.
(Choice C) Acute fatty liver of pregnancy is a complication of the third trimester of pregnancy. Patients are sometimes asymptomatic, but may also complain of severe nausea, malaise, headache, and abdominal pain. Over half of patients also have preeclampsia, and 60% will develop acute renal failure. This condition can also cause a prolonged prothrombin time and moderate to severe elevation of transaminase levels. Histologically, acute fatty liver of pregnancy is characterized by microvesicular fat deposition in the hepatocytes without evidence of inflammation or necrosis.
(Choice D) Primary sclerosing cholangitis is more commonly seen in patients with ulcerative colitis and presents with jaundice, pruritus, and right upper quadrant pain.
(Choice E) Primary biliary cirrhosis is characterized by markedly elevated alkaline phosphatase and cholesterol levels in conjunction with intense pruritus.
Educational Objective:
Jaundice in the third trimester of pregnancy should be evaluated specifically for those hepatic disorders associated with pregnancy. Marked pruritus and elevated of total bile acids are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Fatty liver is the result of short term alcohol ingestion, whereas hepatitis and cirrhosis require long term, sustained alcohol use. Alcohol hepatitis is characterized by Mallory bodies, infiltration by neutrophils, liver cell necrosis, and a perivenular distribution of inflammation. Educational Objective:
Fatty liver (steatosis), alcoholic hepatitis and early fibrosis of the liver can be reversible with the cessation of alcohol intake. True cirrhosis (with regenerative nodules) is irreversible, regardless of alcohol abstinence.

acute hepatitis B infection seven manths ago. Her medical history is otherwise remarkable for two episodes
aof treated gonorrheal infection. Laboratary findings include the following:
Hepatitis Panel

Which of the following would be the best means of evaluating this patient's current hepatic function?
options: D. Presence of hepatitis B care antigen in serum
explanation:
Chronic hepatitis is a syndrome defined by hepatic injury that persists for at least six months, and can result from a broad spectrum of liver disorders that vary in cause and severity. In this patient, the persistence of HBsAg in the serum for a period of seven months confirms the diagnosis of chronic hepatitis B infection. Historically, chronic hepatitis was separated into two different histologic categories: "chronic active hepatitis" (associated with active liver destruction) and "chronic persistent hepatitis” (associated with no active liver destruction). These terms have largely been replaced with new terminology that grades the severity of liver disease and stages the progression of fibrosis. While the best means of evaluating liver damage in acute hepatitis includes liver function tests and viral serology, the best means of evaluating liver damage in chronic hepatitis is via liver biopsy. Therefore, a liver biopsy would be the best means of determining this patient's current hepatic function.
(Choice A) Chronic active hepatitis can be associated with extrahepatic complications (eg, arthritis). However, this is not a consistent finding and cannot be used as a reliable means of evaluating liver functionality.
(Choice C) The relative levels of hepatic enzymes vary considerably in chronic hepatitis and are therefore of limited value. However, they provide important insight into liver functionality in patients with acute hepatitis.
(Choice D) The presence of hepatitis B core antigen in serum is not an accurate marker for disease severity in patients with chronic hepatitis.
(Choice E) Ultrasound is not particularly useful in the evaluation of chronic hepatitis.
Educational Objective:
The evaluation of liver damage in patients with acute hepatitis is based upon liver function tests and viral serology. In contrast, the evaluation of liver damage in patients with chronic hepatitis is based upon liver biopsy.

explanation:
Produced primarily in the liver, alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) is a serum protein that inhibits several different proteolytic enzymes (eg, pancreatic trypsin, chymotrypsin, neutrophil elastase). It is also an acute-phase reactant that plays a significant role in inflammatory states. Alpha-1 antitrypsin is coded for by a single, highly pleomorphic gene on chromosome 14. There is considerable variation in the expression of this gene, with phenotypic results ranging from mild to severe protein deficiency. Those individuals who are homozygous and severely deficient in A1AT are most often of northern European heritage, comprising 0.02% of the white population in the United States. Heterozygotes comprise another 2-3% of the white population in the United States. Histologically, the granules evident in the hepatocytes of afflicted individuals are thought to represent the accumulation of A1AT and other proteins.
Clinical manifestations of A1AT deficiency are related to lung or liver disease. Individuals with severe deficiencies often develop panacinar emphysema. Smokers with the condition tend to develop dyspnea at a median age of 40 years versus a median age of 53 years in nonsmokers with the condition. Other common pulmonary complications include chronic bronchitis and bronchiectasis, but emphysema remains the most common cause of death.
Liver disease also develops in 12-16% of homozygous individuals and is of the greatest concern in the first two decades of life. Those affected typically demonstrate hepatomegaly or hepatosplenomegaly, cholestasis, and elevation of the hepatocellular enzymes. However it is not uncommon for patients to be asymptomatic until they have developed end-stage liver disease. The most severe consequences of liver involvement include cirrhosis (which is the second most common cause of death in this population) and hepatocellular carcinoma.
The diagnosis of A1AT deficiency is established by measurement of the serum A1AT level, followed by confirmatory genetic testing. This testing is indicated in all patients with premature onset of chronic bronchitis, emphysema, and dyspnea, as well as in nonsmokers suffering from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Treatment options include augmentation therapy with purified human A1AT for those with severe deficiencies. Individuals suffering from severe pulmonary impairment are candidates for lung transplants, while those in hepatic failure can be treated with liver transplantation.
(Choice A) Wilson's disease is an unusual genetic disorder that results in the excessive accumulation of copper in tissue, which can cause hepatic injury. It is not a common cause of cirrhosis.
(Choice B) Hemochromatosis is a genetic disorder that results in the excessive accumulation of iron in tissue, which can cause hepatic injury. It is not a common cause of cirrhosis.
(Choice C) Bronchogenic carcinoma is unlikely in a non-smoking patient of this age. Moreover, the carcinomatous cells would not contain PAS-positive granules.
(Choice E) Hodgkin's disease can cause infiltrative disease of the liver, but a biopsy would normally reveal Reed-Sternberg cells.
(Choice F) Whipple's disease is caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whippelii and typically affects the bowel, causing malabsorption. It is not associated with cirrhosis.
Educational Objective:
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is associated with panacinar emphysema and cirrhosis.

question:
A 56-year-old white male wha is experiencing massive hematemesis is brought to the emergency
department by a friend who says that this has never happened before. The patient has a history of peptic
ulcer disease and esophageal varices secondary to alcoholic cirrhosis. His current medications include
propranolol, omeprazole, and spironolactone. Vital signs include temperature of 37 6C (99 6F), blood
pressure of 102/58 mm Hg, pulse of 112/min, and respirations of 23/min. The man is in acute distress.
Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient's condition?
options: B. Perform endoscopic band ligation of varices
D. Insert twa large bare intravenous needles
explanation:
Variceal bleeding is a life-threatening emergency, as the loss of blood can be sudden and dramatic. Therefore, prompt and aggressive fluid resuscitation should be the first step in the management of this patient. All patients with acute hemorrhage should have vascular access established immediately. Two large bore intravenous needles or a central line should be placed and fluid resuscitation undertaken until any necessary blood products can be transfused. To minimize the risk of aspiration, the airway should be protected and gastric decompression initiated with nasogastric aspiration.
The second step in the management of variceal bleeding is to control the bleeding itself. In approximately 50% of cases, the bleeding ceases on its own without further intervention. Medical control of bleeding may be accomplished by administering vasoconstrictors like terlipressin (a synthetic analogue of vasopressin), octreotide, or somatostatin. The control of bleeding is established in 80% of these patients, though rebleeding is very common (especially in the six weeks following the initial hemorrhage).
(Choice A) Octreotide is a reasonable option in the medical management of variceal bleeding. It is thought to be most effective when used in conjunction with endoscopic therapy. Obtaining intravenous access should be the first priority, however.
(Choices B and C) Endoscopic sclerotherapy has been used frequently over the past two decades for the treatment of acute variceal bleeding and has been successful in controlling the bleeding in 90% of cases. Many experts prefer sclerotherapy to band ligation when bleeding is significant and the field of vision obscured, as sclerotherapy is faster and allows for better visualization while still achieving hemostasis as effectively as band ligation. For the elective endoscopic treatment of varices, however, band ligation is often employed.
(Choice E) Balloon tamponade with the Sengstaken-Blakemore, Minnesota, or Linton-Nachlas tubes can be employed for the short-term control of bleeding when endoscopy is unavailable or when medications are not taking effect quickly enough. This method is most often used to temporarily alleviate symptoms until the patient can be transferred to a tertiary care hospital, and is not considered first-line treatment. Surgical treatment (eg, shunt operations, esophageal transaction, or devascularization of the gastroesophageal junction) or the creation of a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt (TIPS) are options for patients who have failed medical or endoscopic therapy.
Educational Objective:
The first step in the treatment of acute variceal bleeding is to establish vascular access with two large bore intravenous needles or a central line.

question:
A 52-year-old patient comes to ER with severe vomiting, fever and abdominal pain. On examination he has
epigastric tenderness and xanthomas. His laboratory repart shows WBC: 18,000/cmm, normal amylase and
elevated lipase, serum triglycerides: 4 000 mg/dl, AST: 120 IU/L, ALT: 50 IU/L, and alkaline phosphatase: 120
IU/L. The patient is not taking any medication, except far naproxen (NSAID) far arthritis for the past 3 years.
He occasionally drinks a can of beer on weekends. His past medical history is insignificant except far an
elective chalecystectomy 8 years ago for recurrent abdominal pain. He says that his father had a lipid
disorder and died of a heart attack VWhat is the most likely cause of pancreatitis in this patient?
explanation:
Acute pancreatitis is most commonly secondary to gallstones or alcohol abuse. However, it may be also secondary to drug toxicity, idiopathic etiology, hypertriglyceridemia, infection, severe trauma or burns, hypercalcemia, pancreatic abnormality, tumors, toxins or due to post operative or post ERCP etiology.
This patient is not a big time alcoholic and had his gallbladder removed long time ago so thus the two most common causes are unlikely. However, he has markedly elevated triglyceride levels, along with a positive family history of early cardiovascular disease and xanthomas making the hypertriglyceridemia the most likely cause of his pancreatitis. Triglyceride levels = 1000 mg/dl is a risk factor for acute pancreatitis and during the attack the triglyceride levels can be as high as 3000-5000 mg/dl. Though acute pancreatitis itself can cause an increase in triglycerides it is usually not so high. Hyperlipidemia types 1 and 5 are associated with acute pancreatitis (Choice C). Acute pancreatitis secondary to hypertriglyceridemia often has normal levels of amylase.
(Choice A) The patient had his gallbladder removed 8 years ago. Also, in patients with pancreatitis due to gallstone the alkaline phosphatase is more than 150 IU/L.
(Choice B) NSAIDs in general do not cause acute pancreatitis. Some important drugs causing acute pancreatitis are azathioprine, sulfonamides, sulindac, tetracycline, valproic acid, didanosine, methyldopa, estrogens, furosemide, 6-mercaptopurine, pentamidine, 5-aminosalicylic acid, corticosteroids, and octreotide.
(Choice D) This patient drinks alcohol only occasionally and it usually takes more than that to cause acute pancreatitis.
(Choice E) Idiopathic pancreatitis is seen in about 10% of cases, however the diagnosis is made only after other causes have been ruled out.
Educational Objective:
Hypertriglyceridemia = 1000mg/dl can cause acute pancreatitis.

He says he feels "perfectly healthy" and has no complaints. His medical history is significant for a remote
bout of cellulitis and a fractured clavicle from playing foatball in high school. He works as a supervisar at a
corporate call center. He is monogamous and lives with his wife and two children. Labaratory testing reveals
the following:

What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
options: B. Obtain more history about alcohal or drug intake
D. Order urine copper, serum copper, and ceruloplasmin levels
E. Cirdar cart rman and ferritin las ralo
explanation:
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) are distributed widely throughout the body, with AST present and very active in the liver, heart, kidney, and skeletal muscle. While ALT is also present in reduced quantities in the kidney, heart, and skeletal muscle, it is predominantly found in the liver and is therefore more specific for hepatocyte injury.
The patient in this scenario has a mild (<= 250 U/L), asymptomatic elevation of his serum transaminases. The first step in the evaluation of his condition should be a careful screening for all hepatitis risk factors, including drug and alcohol intake, travel outside the United States, blood transfusions, or high-risk sexual practices. This aspect of the patient's history will provide insight as to whether the transaminase elevation could be caused by alcohol, medications (eg, NSAIDs, antibiotics, HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, antiepileptic drugs, antituberculous drugs, herbal preparations), or viral agents.
After thoroughly questioning the patient about his history and having him discontinue all alcohol and drug use, the next step in the evaluation process would be to repeat the liver function tests. If the transaminases persist in being elevated over a six-month period, they are categorized as chronic. Testing for viral hepatitis B and C, hemochromatosis, and fatty liver should then be undertaken to further evaluate chronically elevated transaminases. If these tests prove unremarkable, a search for muscle disorders (eg, polymyositis, seizures, heavy exercise) and thyroid disease should be made. Still less common causes of aminotransferase elevations include occult celiac disease and adrenal insufficiency.
(Choice A) This patient has no obvious risk factors for viral hepatitis. Therefore, his drug and alcohol usage must be examined first.
(Choice C) An ultrasound of the abdomen would not be particularly enlightening in a patient with asymptomatic aminotransferase elevation unless gallbladder pathology was suspected.
(Choice D) These tests are employed to rule out Wilson's disease, which is not a likely diagnosis in an asymptomatic middle-aged man with an unremarkable history and physical exam. However, these tests could be ordered after all common causes of hepatitis were ruled out.
(Choice E) These tests are employed to rule out hemochromatosis, which is a possible diagnosis in an asymptomatic middle-aged man with a normal physical exam. However, the more common causes of hepatitis should be ruled out before testing for the more unusual causes.
Educational Objective:
In evaluating the asymptomatic evaluation of aminotransferases, the first step is to take a thorough history to rule out the more common hepatitis risk factors (eg, alcohol or drug use, travel outside of the country, blood transfusions, high-risk sexual practices).

question:

pain, fever to 33 5°C {103.1°F), chills, and jaundice. She appears very ill and is in acute distress. Vital signs
include temperature of 39.0°C (102 2°F), blood pressure of 134/32 mm Hg, pulse of 30/min, and respirations
af 20/min. Her eyes appear sunken and the mucous membranes are dry. Ultrasonography of her abdomen
reveals a dilated comman bile duct with stones in both the duct and gallbladder. Laboratory evaluation
includes the following:
Liver studies
Albumin                                              4.8 g/dL
Tatal bilirubin                                         10.2 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin                                       8 4 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase                                714 UL
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, SGOT)          35 UL
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, SGFT)             40 iL
Amylase                                             GE U/L
Lipase                                    41 iL
Complete blood count
Hemaglohin                                14.1 g/L
MCW                                                 B88 fl
Reticulocytes                                                  1.1%
Platelets                                             306,000/mm3
Leukocyte count                                     18,200/mm3
Meutraphils                                       T1%
Eosinophils                                       1%
Lymphocytes                                     21%
Monocytes                                        T%
The patient is admitted to the hospital and is started on intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Over the next several hours, the patient becomes increasingly confused and her fever persists. What is the
next best step in the management of her care?
options: B. Laparotomy with stone removal and cholecystectomy
C. Insertion of T tube for drainage
explanation:
This patient has acute ascending cholangitis, which is characterized by Charcot's triad of fever, severe jaundice, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Confusion and hypotension may also be observed in those with suppurative cholangitis, producing Reynold's pentad.
An infection of the common bile duct, cholangitis most commonly arises secondary to obstruction of the common bile duct by stone or stricture. Laboratory findings include leukocytosis and liver function test abnormalities that are suggestive of cholestasis. Ultrasound is typically the first imaging study employed to confirm the diagnosis. As cholangitis is an acute condition, the immediate provision of supportive care and broad-spectrum antibiotics is required. In 80% of patients, this course of treatment is sufficient. However, some patients continue to have persistent abdominal pain, hypotension despite adequate fluids, high fever, or mental confusion. These signs and symptoms are indications for urgent biliary decompression, preferably by endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). ERCP is minimally invasive, has a low rate of complications, and allows for diagnostic confirmation. Therapeutic intervention typically includes sphincterotomy with stone removal and/or stent insertion. Early drainage of the biliary tree in acute cholangitis can significantly decrease its morbidity and mortality.
(Choice B) Surgical decompression is associated with significant morbidity and mortality and is no longer the preferred form of treatment.
(Choice C) If nonsurgical drainage procedures fail to relieve the biliary compression, choledochotomy with placement of a large-bore T tube is appropriate.
(Choice D) Transhepatic cholangiopancreatography is an alternative treatment option when ERCP is unavailable or contraindicated.
(Choice E) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy will not accomplish drainage of the biliary tree, which is the immediate concern. Although this patient should eventually undergo a cholecystectomy, the drainage of the biliary tree is more important at this time.
Educational Objective:
The treatment of acute cholangitis includes provision of supportive care and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Patients who do not respond to this treatment regimen should undergo biliary drainage with an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography.

question:
A 45-year-old female presents to clinic complaining of a six-manth histary of recurrent right upper abdominal
pain after meals. She is obese and takes anti-hypertensive medication. Vital signs are stable. There is no
abdominal tenderness to palpation, rebound, ar guarding. Abdominal radiograph is normal, but an ultrasound
af the abdomen reveals three gallstones, with the largest measuring 8 mm in diameter. She is advised to
undergo an elective cholecystectomy but she expresses great reluctance to have the surgery. Which of the
following is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
options: A. Provide her with analgesics and send her home
B. Advise her to avoid fatty foods and send her home
C. Provide her with ursodeoxycholic acid and advise her to avoid fatty foods
D. Refer her for weight reduction
E. Inform her that there are no other options at this time
explanation:
This woman's presentation is classical for gallstone disease (cholelithiasis), which is most common in those who are "fat, fertile, female, and forty." Native American heritage, diabetes mellitus, obesity, rapid weight loss, and the usage of oral contraceptives all predispose to gallstone formation. Typically, patients will complain of bloating and dyspepsia after eating fatty foods. Occasional right upper quadrant abdominal pain is common.
The diagnosis of cholelithiasis is best confirmed with abdominal ultrasound. Once diagnosed, the treatment of choice for symptomatic cholelithiasis is laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Those patients who prefer not to undergo cholecystectomy may be given a bile salt such as ursodeoxycholic acid, which decreases the cholesterol content of the bile by reducing the hepatic secretion and intestinal reabsorption of cholesterol. This medication is expensive however, and therapy may be necessary for several months before the gallstones dissolve. In addition, gallstones recur in 50% of patients once the treatment is stopped.
(Choice A) As patients with symptomatic gallstones experience a high rate of complications, it would be inappropriate to provide this woman with analgesics but no definitive therapy for her condition.
(Choice B) It is indeed important that this woman be advised to avoid fatty foods so that her symptoms can be better managed. However, dietary measures will not reverse or dissolve her gallstones and are therefore not sufficient to prevent further complications.
(Choice D) Obesity is a risk factor for gallstone disease and should be corrected to reduce the likelihood of worsening or recurrent disease. However, weight loss will not be of benefit in the dissolution of already present gallstones, and as such is not a sufficient measure in treating symptomatic patients.
(Choice E) Failing to take action in managing a patient with symptomatic gallstones is entirely inappropriate as there are multiple therapeutic options available.
Educational Objective:
Ursodeoxycholic acid is a medication used to dissolve small radiolucent gallstones in patients with normal, functional gallbladders who are poor surgical candidates. However, this medication is very costly and associated with a high risk of relapse when therapy is halted.

question:
A 65-year-old man is hospitalized for acute diverticulitis. His past medical history is significant far occasional
constipation and recent bilateral hearing loss. He smokes one pack of cigarettes a day and consumes three
to four cans of beer on weekends. His laboratory values are:
Hematocrit                                          43%
Sodium                                               138 mEg/L
Potassium                                          45 mEq/L
Calcium                                              9.8 ma/dL
Bicarbonate                                         24 mEgiL
AST                                                   22 unitsiL
ALT                                          18 units/L
Bilirubin                                              0.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase                             810 units/L
Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase             50 units/L (M 1-94 units/L)
Which of the following is the mast likely cause of his laboratory abnormalities?
explanation:
This patient has an elevated alkaline phosphatase level in the setting of a normal GGT, suggesting that the cause is probably bone rather than liver pathology. His hearing loss raises concern for Paget's disease of the bone. Paget's disease is characterized by high bone turnover and aberrant osteoid formation and occurs in up to 2% of the elderly in the United States. Often asymptomatic, Paget's may present with bone pain, headaches, and deafness depending upon the bones involved. As bones reshape they become soft and susceptible to fracture Laboratory findings consistent with Paget's disease include an elevated alkaline phosphatase but normal calcium, phosphorus, and other liver enzymes. X-rays will reveal dense, expanded bones. Treatment for Paget's disease of the bone consists of oral or intravenous bisphosphonates.
(Choice B) Biliary tract obstruction typically causes right upper quadrant pain. Elevations in alkaline phosphatase, total bilirubin, and direct bilirubin are seen first, with transaminase elevation occurring in prolonged disease.
(Choice C) Portal hypertension is typically due to cirrhosis. Labs may be consistent with hepatocellular damage (elevated AST and ALT), but are often normal early in the disease.
(Choice D) Liver fibrosis is the pathologic finding in cirrhosis. In quiescent cirrhosis, a patient's bloodwork may be normal, but as the disease progresses, laboratory abnormalities reflective of hepatocellular injury and hyperbilirubinemia develop. This patient does not have labs or symptoms consistent with cirrhosis.
(Choice F) Poor bone mineralization is the hallmark of osteoporosis. Serum calcium, phosphorus, and liver function tests are typically normal in osteoporosis. Osteoporosis due to hyperparathyroidism is accompanied by hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and a normal or elevated alkaline phosphatase.
Educational objective:
Paget's disease of the bone is characterized by increased bone remodeling and abnormal osteoid formation. It may be asymptomatic or accompanied by pain and deafness. Alkaline phosphatase will be elevated but serum calcium, phosphorus, and other liver function tests will be normal.

question:
A 23-year-old man wha recently underwent bane marrow transplantation for acute myelogenous leukemia
complains of fever, severe diarrhea, pruritis, and jaundice. Liver biopsy shows a markedly decreased
quantity of bile ducts. Which af the following conditions is characterized by the same pattern of liver injury?
explanation:
This patient has vanishing bile duct syndrome, a rare disease involving progressive destruction of the intrahepatic bile ducts. The histological hallmark is ductopenia. The exact underlying pathophysiology is unknown. Primary biliary cirrhosis is the most common cause of ductopenia in adults. Other causes include failing liver transplantation, Hodgkin's disease, graft-versus-host disease, sarcoid, CMV infection, HIV, and medication toxicity.
(Choice A) Acetaminophen toxicity causes centrilobular or diffuse necrosis, not loss of bile ducts.
(Choice B) Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by hepatocyte swelling and necrosis, Mallory bodies, and neutrophilic infiltration. Ductopenia is not commonly found.
(Choice C) The pathologic hallmarks of primary sclerosing cholangitis are periductal portal tract fibrosis and segmental stenosis of extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts. Bile duct loss is not classically observed.
(Choice E) Patients on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for 2-3 weeks may develop cholestasis. This can progress into fibrosis if TPN is continued. Ductopenia is not a common finding.
(Choice F) Liver biopsy in chronic hepatitis B will reveal hepatocellular injury, sinusoidal cell reactive changes, and inflammation and fibrosis of the portal tracts. Loss of bile ducts is not a hallmark finding.
Educational objective:
Vanishing bile duct syndrome is a rare condition characterized by progressive ductopenia, or loss of intrahepatic bile ducts. The most common cause of ductopenia in adults is primary biliary cirrhosis.

question:
he halds his arms in frant of him with his wrists extended, you note a rhythmic beating of his hands. Serum
analysis reveals the following:
Sodium                 128 mEgiL
Potassium          3.1 mEgiL
Bicarbonate            20 mEg/L
Creatinine              0.9 mog/dL
BLN                    32 mg/dL
Hematocrit             30%
WEC count            3 500/mm3
Platelets                 130,000/mm3
This patient's current condition is best treated with which of the following?
explanation:
This man has hepatic encephalopathy related to cirrhosis. Hepatic encephalopathy is a central nervous system disorder that results from the liver's inability to detoxify the body. Ammonia is a key causative agent but is not the sole agent responsible. Symptoms of hepatic encephalopathy range from day-night reversal and mild confusion to coma. Precipitants include gastrointestinal bleeding, infection, dehydration, constipation, large protein loads, and sedating medications. On physical exam patients will have stigmata of cirrhosis and asterixis — a rhythmic flapping of the hands when extended at the wrists.
The treatments for hepatic encephalopathy are numerous. The first and most important step is to treat the underlying precipitant. Lactulose is also an essential component of the management of this condition. Lactulose is a nonabsorbable disaccharide syrup that is converted into fatty acids by colonic bacteria. It acidifies the colon, causing both catharsis and a decrease in circulating ammonia levels. Third, antibiotics may be used to decrease the number of ammonia-producing bacteria in the colon. The principal antibiotics used are neomycin and rifaximin. Finally, catharsis using any laxative may be of some benefit as well.
(Choice A) Thiamine is the treatment for Wernicke's encephalopathy, a thiamine deficiency disease. This patient does not have the Wernicke triad of altered mental status, ataxia, and nystagmus. Wernicke's does not cause asterixis. That said, all alcoholics should receive thiamine upon admission to the hospital.
(Choice B) Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to treat narcotic overdose. Narcotics do not cause asterixis, and this patient's normal sized, reactive pupils are not consistent with opioid intoxication.
(Choice C) Methadone is a long-acting narcotic that will be very difficult for this patient to metabolize. It should not be given in this situation.
(Choice D) Chlordiazepoxide is a long-acting benzodiazepine used to treat alcohol withdrawal. Confusion is common in alcohol withdrawal but this patient does not have the autonomic instability characteristic of this disease. Benzodiazepines will be very sedating for this patient and should be avoided.
(Choice E) A high-calorie diet is likely to be high in protein. A high-protein diet will increase this patient's nitrogen load and likely worsen his hepatic encephalopathy.
(Choice F) A subdural hematoma results from traumatic tearing of the bridging veins. Most patients will complain of pain, confusion, and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure. It does not cause asterixis.
(Choice H) Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to promote sodium excretion and maintain volume status in patients with cirrhosis. Furosemide will help manage this patient's ascites but will not treat his hepatic encephalopathy.
Educational objective:
Hepatic encephalopathy is an alteration in CNS function due to poor hepatic clearance of toxins. There is typically a clear precipitant and symptoms may range from mild confusion to coma. Treatment includes lactulose, neomycin or rifaximin, and laxatives.

The gallbladder is palpable. Laboratory evaluation includes the following:

Alkaline phosphatase                         83 UL
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT)          102 U/L

Chemistry panel

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)                     28 maofdL
